questions.text: Optic nerve glioma is seen in:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NF-1 (Neurofibromatosis Type 1)

 

NF-1 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas) and areas of abnormal skin coloration. Among other complications, individuals with NF-1 may develop optic nerve gliomas, which are benign brain tumors that involve the optic nerves. These tumors typically appear in childhood and can cause vision problems.

 

Also seen in NF-1 are Lisch Nodules

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B Tuberous Sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that causes noncancerous tumors to form in many different organs, primarily in the brain, eyes, heart, kidney, skin, and lungs. While it is associated with a variety of brain tumors, optic nerve gliomas are not a characteristic feature of tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C Sturge-Weber syndrome: Sturge-Weber syndrome is a rare disorder present at birth, characterized by a port-wine stain birthmark on the face and neurological abnormalities. There is the development of abnormal blood vessels on the brain's surface, but optic nerve gliomas are not typically associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Option D Von Hippel-Lindau disease: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a hereditary condition associated with tumors arising in multiple organs. Hemangioblastomas of the brain, spine, and retina, pheochromocytomas of the adrenal gland, and renal cell carcinomas are common. However, optic nerve gliomas are not commonly seen in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic nerve glioma, is a type of brain tumor that affects the optic nerve, is commonly associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1) and not typically seen in Tuberous Sclerosis, Sturge-Weber syndrome, or Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female presented with Schizophrenia. Which of the following antipsychotic drug causes least weight gain? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ziprasidone

 

Ziprasidone is known to cause less weight gain compared to many other antipsychotics, making it a more suitable option for an obese patient concerned about further weight gain. Clozapine and olanzapine, in particular, are associated with a higher risk of significant weight gain and metabolic changes. Chlorpromazine, while potentially causing weight gain, is generally not as strongly linked to this side effect as clozapine or olanzapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorpromazine: This is a typical antipsychotic. These drugs can cause weight gain, though chlorpromazine is not as strongly associated with weight gain as some atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option B. Clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic known for causing significant weight gain, along with other metabolic effects.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another atypical antipsychotic that is frequently associated with substantial weight gain and metabolic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ziprasidone is an atypical antipsychotic associated with a lower risk of weight gain. It is considered more weight-neutral compared to other atypical antipsychotics like clozapine and olanzapine.

choices.text: Metastasis to breast from another primary site

questions.text: Identify the image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroadenoma

 

On ultrasound, fibroadenomas typically appear as well-defined, homogeneous, hypoechoic (dark) masses with smooth margins. They may sometimes exhibit a 'halo' sign, which is a thin, echogenic rim surrounding the lesion. The mass in the image shows these characteristic features, making fibroadenoma a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast Cyst: Cysts are fluid-filled sacs within the breast. On ultrasound, they appear as anechoic (completely black) round or oval structures with well-defined edges and posterior acoustic enhancement (increased brightness behind the cyst due to lack of absorption of ultrasound waves by the fluid). The lesion in the image does not show these typical features of a cyst.

 

Option C. Breast Carcinoma: Breast cancers can appear in various forms on ultrasound, but they typically present as irregular, microlobulated, or spiculated masses with heterogenous echotexture and may show shadowing due to their density. The margins are often ill-defined, which is not consistent with the well-defined borders seen in the image.

 

Option D. Metastasis to Breast from Another Primary Site: Metastases to the breast are rare and usually present as multiple round masses that can mimic benign lesions. However, they are not common and typically have a background of known primary malignancy elsewhere, which isn't indicated here.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Fibroadenoma appearance on USG is as a ‘Halo’ sign.

questions.text: A pregnant female who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented to hospital with blood pressure of 160/100 mm Hg. Which of the following is the preferred drug for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Considering the patient's condition of bronchial asthma, beta-blockers like labetalol and propranolol may not be the best choices due to the risk of exacerbating asthma. Nicardipine, a calcium channel blocker, is a safer alternative in this scenario. It effectively lowers blood pressure and is safe to use in pregnancy, without the risk of bronchoconstriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Labetalol: Labetalol is a beta-blocker with alpha-blocking activity. It is commonly used for hypertension in pregnancy. However, being a beta-blocker, it can potentially exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction.

 

Option B. Intravenous Labetalol: This would be used for more immediate control of severely elevated blood pressure, like in a hypertensive crisis. The same concerns regarding bronchial asthma apply as with oral labetalol.

 

Option D. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker and is generally contraindicated in asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction. It is also not the first choice for managing hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker is effective in lowering blood pressure and is generally considered safe in pregnancy. It does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects associated with beta-blockers.

questions.text: A teacher presents with the following condition and hoarseness of the voice. Identify.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vocal nodule

 

Based on the description of the condition causing hoarseness in a teacher, a profession associated with voice strain, the most likely diagnosis is Vocal nodule.

 

Vocal nodules are bilateral, benign growths that typically occur at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords. They are often a result of vocal strain or overuse and present with a hoarse voice. The nodules are usually symmetrical and look like small bumps on either side of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal carcinoma usually presents as an irregular, often unilateral growth on the vocal cord, and it can cause hoarseness. The lesion may have an irregular surface and can vary in coloration from the surrounding tissue. It is typically associated with risk factors like smoking and alcohol use.

 

Option C. Reinke’s edema is characterized by the swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation in Reinke's space (the layer of the vocal cord). The cords appear swollen and may take on a polypoid appearance, often associated with a lower-pitched, hoarse voice. Smoking is a common risk factor.

 

Option D. Vocal polyps are usually unilateral and can vary in size. They are often the result of acute vocal trauma or misuse. Polyps can cause hoarseness and have a soft, fluid-filled appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vocal nodules are benign, symmetrical lesions typically located at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd of the vocal cords, often resulting from chronic vocal strain, and present with symptoms of hoarseness.

choices.text: Compression of the inferior vena cava
Compression of the superior vena cava

questions.text: A pregnant woman has dizziness on lying down straight and this improves when she turns to one side. A possible explanation is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compression of the inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described is characteristic of supine hypotensive syndrome, which occurs when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back, causing the gravid uterus to compress the inferior vena cava (IVC). This compression decreases venous return to the heart, leading to reduced cardiac output and subsequent hypotension and dizziness.

 

Symptoms of dizziness and hypotension improve when the woman turns to her side (Left tilt), relieving the compression on the IVC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression of the aorta: While the aorta can also be compressed, the primary issue in supine hypotensive syndrome is the reduced venous return due to IVC compression.

 

Option C. Compression of the superior vena cava: This is less likely to be affected by the position of the uterus during pregnancy.
 

Option D. Compression of the pulmonary vessels: This is not typically related to positional changes during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine hypotensive syndrome is caused by the compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back. This condition is relieved by turning to one side, which reduces the compression and improves venous return to the heart.

questions.text: Drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever is? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin

 

Aspirin is the drug of choice for acute rheumatic fever due to its efficacy in reducing inflammation and managing symptoms like arthritis and carditis, which are common in rheumatic fever. The other listed drugs are not used for this condition and are more specific to heart diseases and arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: This medication is a cardiac glycoside, typically used in heart failure and certain arrhythmias. It is not used in the treatment of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication used primarily for the treatment of various cardiac arrhythmias. It is not indicated for acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic, often used in conditions like heart failure and hypertension. It is not a treatment for acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory drug and is commonly used in the treatment of acute rheumatic fever, particularly for its anti-inflammatory effects in managing arthritis and carditis associated with rheumatic fever.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiency causes xerophthalmia and follicular hyperkeratosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is well known to cause a range of clinical manifestations, primarily affecting the eyes and skin. Key signs and symptoms include:

 

  • Xerophthalmia: This condition includes dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can progress to keratomalacia and lead to blindness if untreated.

 

 

  • Follicular hyperkeratosis: This is characterized by excessive keratin deposits in hair follicles, leading to rough, bumpy skin.

 

 

Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Its deficiency can result in:

 

  • Night blindness
  • Immunosuppression: Leading to increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration
  • Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium, increasing the risk of infections in these areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin: Deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

 

Option C. Biotin: Deficiency can cause dermatitis, alopecia, and neurological symptoms.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6: Deficiency can cause anemia, dermatitis, and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 8-year-old child had fracture of humerus 2 years back. Now he’s having difficulty in hanging his school bag. There is also a presence of the shown deformity. What can be the most likely injury? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

  • The deformity seen in the image associated with supracondylar fracture of the humerus is commonly referred to as a "Gunstock deformity" or cubitus varus.
  • This deformity occurs due to malunion of the fracture, where the distal fragment of the humerus heals in a position that causes the elbow to angle inward toward the body.
  • The name "gunstock" comes from the appearance resembling the shape of a rifle's butt.
  • The anatomical distortion results from an improper alignment of the fracture during healing, often due to inadequate reduction or stabilization at the time of initial treatment.
  • This leads to a visible and functional deformity where the extended arm appears deviated towards the midline of the body, affecting the natural alignment and motion of the elbow.
  • This can also impact the arm's functionality, such as difficulty in activities that require extending the arm fully or placing load on it, like hanging a school bag.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Lateral Condyle Humerus Fracture: Often involves the growth plate and can lead to deformity if not properly treated. The most common sequela of non-union with displacement of this fracture is the development of progressive cubitus valgus deformity. Cubitus varus is the reported complication following lateral condyle fracture malunion after surgical intervention.

 

 

Option. B. Olecranon Fracture: Typically impacts elbow extension and would not generally cause problems with shoulder or arm suspension like hanging a bag. If the fracture is displaced there may be marked deformity at the elbow with a palpable gap. The hallmark of an olecranon fracture is the inability to extend the elbow against gravity. 

 

Option. D. Posterior Dislocation of Elbow: Would cause more immediate and severe movement restrictions and is less likely to present with delayed symptoms related to hanging a bag.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gunstock deformity or cubitus varus is seen in children with history of supracondylar fracture humerus.

questions.text: Mitochondrial matrix enzyme is? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Citrate synthase

 

Citrate synthase is an enzyme located in the mitochondrial matrix, where it catalyzes the first step of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle. This step involves the condensation of oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA to form citrate. The TCA cycle is a central metabolic pathway that plays a critical role in cellular respiration, generating energy through the oxidation of acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.

 

 

Note – all the enzymes of TCA are in mitochondrial matrix except – Succinate dehydrogenase (present in inner mitochondrial membrane)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Monoamine oxidase: This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of monoamine neurotransmitters such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. It is located on the outer mitochondrial membrane, not in the mitochondrial matrix.

 

Option C. ATP synthase: This enzyme complex is embedded in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is responsible for synthesizing ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate during oxidative phosphorylation. It is part of the electron transport chain (ETC) as Complex V.

 

Option D. Catalase: Catalase is an enzyme that catalyzes the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. It is predominantly found in peroxisomes, not in the mitochondria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Citrate synthase is a key enzyme of the TCA cycle located in the mitochondrial matrix.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment protocol for plasmodium vivax infection in pregnant females in the 1st trimester with complaints of headache and fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloroquine

 

Explanation:

 

For plasmodium vivax infection in pregnant females, especially in the first trimester, the recommended treatment is chloroquine.

 

For vivax and ovale malaria, the treatment of choice is chloroquine along with primaquine. However, in pregnancy primaquine is contraindicated.

 

Since the specifically asks about the treatment protocol for a pregnant female in the first trimester with vivax malaria, the appropriate treatment would be chloroquine alone, without primaquine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ART combined therapy - This option is incorrect because artemisinin-based combination therapy (ART) is the treatment of choice for falciparum and malariae malaria, not vivax malaria in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Quinine - This option is incorrect because quinine is not the recommended treatment for vivax malaria in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Chloroquine + Primaquine - This option is incorrect because primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment Protocol

questions.text: Identify the shown congenital anomaly in which the intestinal loops are present outside the abdominal cavity covered by amniotic membrane. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a congenital anomaly known as omphalocele. This condition is characterized by the presence of intestinal loops and sometimes other abdominal organs outside the abdominal cavity. These organs are covered by a transparent sac composed of the amniotic membrane, peritoneum, and Wharton's jelly.

 

Omphalocele Characteristics: In omphalocele, the herniated organs protrude through the umbilical ring and are covered by the amniotic membrane. This condition is associated with various other congenital anomalies and syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: This is incorrect. In gastroschisis, the intestines protrude through a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilical cord, without any covering membrane. The exposed intestines are directly exposed to the amniotic fluid, which distinguishes it from omphalocele.

 

Option C. Omphalocele with enteric cyst: This is incorrect. While an omphalocele can be associated with various anomalies, the specific mention of an enteric cyst is not a standard characteristic of typical omphalocele presentations.

 

Option D. Gastroschisis with enteric cyst: This is incorrect. Gastroschisis involves exposed intestines without a covering membrane. The presence of an enteric cyst does not align with the typical presentation of gastroschisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is a congenital anomaly where the intestines and possibly other organs protrude through the umbilical ring, covered by the amniotic membrane. This differentiates it from gastroschisis, where the intestines are exposed without a covering membrane.

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with the defect seen in the image below. Identify the condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omphalocele

 

Omphalocele is characterized by the presence of a sac enclosing the protruding abdominal organs, which herniate into the base of the umbilical cord.

 

The image depicts a newborn with a congenital abdominal wall defect characterized by the protrusion of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes. This condition is known as an omphalocele.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: Gastroschisis is a congenital defect where the intestines protrude through a hole in the abdominal wall, typically to the right of the umbilicus. Unlike omphalocele, in gastroschisis, the intestines are not covered by a sac and are exposed directly to the amniotic fluid.

 

Option C. Persistent vitellointestinal duct: Persistent vitellointestinal duct refers to a remnant of the yolk stalk (vitelline duct) that can cause various intestinal anomalies but does not present as a protrusion of abdominal contents covered by a sac.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs protrude into the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a sac composed of peritoneum and amniotic membranes.

questions.text: A primigravida presented to the labor room at 38 weeks. At 1 pm she is 5 cm dilated. After 4 hours she is 6 cm dilated. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ARM + oxytocin

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is experiencing protracted labor, as indicated by a slow progression in cervical dilation (only 1 cm increase in 4 hours). In active labor, the cervix is expected to dilate at a rate of approximately 1 cm per hour. Here, the cervix dilated from 5 cm to 6 cm in 4 hours, indicating a slow or protracted dilation phase.

 

Management of Protracted Labor:

 

Assessment: Evaluate the cause of slow labor, which could be due to issues with powers (uterine contractions), the passage (pelvis), or the passenger (fetal position or presentation).

 

Augmentation of Labor:

 

  • 1st step: ARM (Artificial Rupture of Membranes): This can help enhance uterine contractions and allow assessment of the amniotic fluid for the presence of meconium, which could indicate fetal distress.
  • 2nd step: Oxytocin: If contractions remain inadequate after ARM, oxytocin can be administered to strengthen uterine contractions and accelerate labor progress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait for 4 hours and reexamine: This is not recommended as it allows prolonged labor to continue without intervention, increasing the risk of complications.

 

Option B. LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section): While a cesarean section may be necessary if augmentation fails or if there are other indications, it is not the immediate next step without attempting augmentation.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps can only be applied when the cervix is fully dilated (10 cm), not at 6 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a primigravida with protracted labor (slow cervical dilation), the next best step is to perform artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) and administer oxytocin to augment labor and promote adequate uterine contractions.

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient underwent cholecystectomy and subsequently complained of pain in the legs after walking for some distance. Which investigation would be most appropriate for further evaluation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duplex scan 

 

The patient's symptoms suggest occurrence of post operative Deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The investigations listed are used to evaluate vascular conditions:

 

This ultrasound-based diagnostic technique combines traditional ultrasound to visualize the structure of the blood vessels and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow within the vessels. It is the first-line investigation for DVT as it is non-invasive, widely available, and cost-effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is a type of MRI that visualizes blood vessels. It is a good non-invasive option to visualize blood flow and vascular anatomy but is less commonly used as a first-line test due to cost and availability.

 

Option C. CT angiography: This imaging modality uses computed tomography (CT) combined with a contrast agent to visualize vascular structures. It's useful in detailed mapping of blood vessels but exposes the patient to radiation and contrast, which may not be suitable for all patients.

 

Option D. USG: Ultrasound (USG) is useful for various diagnostic purposes but on its own may not be sufficient for a full vascular assessment in the case of DVT unless it's part of a duplex scan.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a morbidly obese patient presenting with leg pain consistent with DVT post-cholecystectomy, a duplex scan is the most appropriate initial investigation to evaluate for DVT.

questions.text: A chorionic villous sampling is done at 12 weeks in a woman whose blood group is B negative. Her husband's blood group is A positive. What is the dose of Anti D given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 50

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of Rh incompatibility, where the mother is Rh-negative (B negative) and the father is Rh-positive (A positive), there is a risk of fetal-maternal hemorrhage (FMH) during invasive procedures like chorionic villous sampling (CVS). This can lead to the mixing of fetal and maternal blood, potentially causing the mother to form antibodies against the Rh-positive fetal red blood cells. To prevent this alloimmunization, an Anti-D immunoglobulin injection is administered.

 

The standard practice is to give Anti-D immunoglobulin during any inciting event (e.g., CVS, amniocentesis, abdominal trauma, abruption, placenta previa) and at delivery. Additionally, it is given prophylactically at 28 weeks of gestation to all Rh-negative women.

 

The dosage of Anti-D depends on the gestational age:

 

 

Less than 12 weeks: 50 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

More than 12 weeks: 300 micrograms intramuscularly.

 

Since the CVS was performed at 12 weeks, the appropriate dose of Anti-D is 50 micrograms.

 

Educational objective:

 

For Rh-negative women undergoing an inciting event like chorionic villous sampling at less than 12 weeks gestation, the dose of Anti-D given is 50 micrograms.

questions.text: After a severe penetrating head trauma, what is the risk of subsequent epilepsy? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 45%

 

Explanation:

 

According to Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, the risk of developing subsequent epilepsy after severe penetrating head trauma is approximately 45%. This statistic highlights the significant risk associated with severe brain injuries, particularly those involving penetration, which can lead to long-term neurological complications such as epilepsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of developing epilepsy after severe penetrating head trauma is approximately 45%.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lim’s forceps


Lim's forceps are designed for ophthalmic procedures as well. They are used to hold and stabilize the eye during surgery, particularly during corneal suturing. They have a platform-like, non-toothed tip to hold the delicate eye tissue without causing damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McPherson forceps: McPherson forceps are typically very delicate instruments used in ophthalmic surgery, especially in procedures involving the cornea and the lens, such as cataract surgery. They have very fine tips for precise manipulation of delicate eye tissues.

 

Option C. Artery forceps: Artery forceps, also known as hemostats, are used in various types of surgeries to grasp and clamp blood vessels to prevent bleeding. They are usually not used in ophthalmic surgeries due to their size and the nature of their design, which is intended to handle larger structures than those found within the eye.

 

Option D. SR (Suture Removal) holding forceps: SR holding forceps are designed for the removal of sutures. They have a small, notched tip at one end to grab and hold the suture for easier removal. They are generally not delicate enough for holding eye tissues during ophthalmic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lim’s forceps are specialized ophthalmic instruments used primarily for corneal suturing, featuring a platform-like tip to gently hold eye tissues during delicate procedures.

questions.text: A mother comes to the hospital with her newborn baby. On examination, surfactants are not adequately found and collapse of alveoli was seen. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory distress syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a condition commonly seen in premature infants where the lungs are not fully developed, leading to a deficiency in surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, allowing them to remain open and facilitating proper gas exchange. Without adequate surfactant, the alveoli collapse, leading to impaired gas exchange and difficulty breathing, which is the hallmark of RDS. In this case, the mother's newborn shows signs of inadequate surfactant and alveolar collapse, making RDS the most probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: This condition involves chronic inflammation of the airways, typically seen in older children and adults, not newborns. It presents with symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath but is not associated with surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse.

 

Option C. Pneumonia: This is an infection of the lungs that can cause fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. While it can affect newborns, it does not involve surfactant deficiency or the collapse of alveoli.

 

Option D. Pleural effusion: This condition involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space around the lungs. It can cause breathing difficulties but is not related to surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily due to a lack of surfactant, leading to alveolar collapse and breathing difficulties.

questions.text: Angular stomatitis and glossitis are associated with which vitamin deficiency?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Riboflavin

 

Explanation: 

 

Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is most characteristically associated with angular stomatitis, also known as cheilosis, which is inflammation of the corners of the mouth. Additionally, riboflavin deficiency can lead to atrophic glossitis, also referred to as geographic tongue. These oral manifestations are the hallmark signs of riboflavin deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency results in pellagra, which is characterized by the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis (especially around the Casal's necklace), dementia, and death if left untreated. While pellagra can have significant consequences, it is not primarily associated with angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Option C. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can cause beriberi in populations consuming polished rice and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcoholics. Beriberi affects the nervous and cardiovascular systems, while Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by neurological symptoms. However, thiamine deficiency is not directly linked to angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency is common in strict vegetarians and can lead to peripheral neuropathy, megaloblastic anemia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord as a severe complication. Pernicious anemia may also occur as a result of vitamin B12 deficiency. While these conditions are serious, they are not specifically associated with angular stomatitis and glossitis.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Angular stomatitis (cheilosis) and atrophic glossitis (geographic tongue) are the most characteristic oral manifestations of riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

questions.text: Cannon ball metastases on chest X-ray are seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choriocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Cannonball metastases refer to multiple, round, well-circumscribed nodules seen on a chest X-ray, typically representing metastatic deposits. These are characteristic of hematogenous spread to the lungs.

 

 

Choriocarcinoma:

 

Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant trophoblastic tumor that often follows a molar pregnancy but can also arise after a normal pregnancy or abortion.

 

It is known for its aggressive nature and tendency to metastasize early, particularly to the lungs, where it can cause cannonball metastases.

 

Despite its aggressive nature, choriocarcinoma responds well to chemotherapy, and lung metastases are associated with a relatively good prognosis compared to other metastatic sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete mole: This refers to a hydatidiform mole, a type of gestational trophoblastic disease, which may precede choriocarcinoma but does not directly present with cannonball metastases.

 

Option C. Invasive mole: This is a type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that invades the myometrium but typically does not present with cannonball metastases in the lungs.

 

Option D. Partial mole: This is a type of molar pregnancy with less malignant potential than a complete mole and does not present with cannonball metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannonball metastases on a chest X-ray are a hallmark of choriocarcinoma, representing lung metastases that, despite indicating spread, are associated with a good prognosis due to the tumor's sensitivity to chemotherapy.

choices.text: Transfer objects from one hand to another

questions.text: Identify the milestone shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transfer objects from one hand to another

 

The milestone shown in the image, where the child appears to be manipulating an object, is indicative of the ability to transfer objects from one hand to another. This skill typically develops around 6 months of age and is an important indicator of emerging fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bidextrous approach: Refers to the ability to use both hands to pick an object, which typically develops by 4 months. This involves reaching for objects with both hands but does not necessarily involve the transfer of objects between hands.

 

Option C. Hand regard: This milestone, where an infant looks at and examines their own hand, typically occurs around 3 months of age. The image does not depict this behavior.

 

Option D. Hands come in midline: By around 4 months, infants begin to bring their hands together in the midline of their body. This is a precursor to more complex hand movements but is not what is shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

By around 6 months of age, infants typically develop the ability to transfer objects from one hand to another, demonstrating emerging fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination.

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of the family cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Formation → extension → contraction → dissolution

 

Explanation:

 

The family cycle consists of the following 6 stages in the correct sequence:

 

  1. Formation: From marriage until the birth of the first child.
  2. Extension: From the birth of the first child until the birth of the last child.
  3. Complete Extension - From the birth of the last child until the first child leaves home
  4. Contraction: from first child leaves home to the last child leaves home
  5. Complete contraction: from last child leave home to the death of first spouse
  6. Dissolution: From the death of the first spouse until the death of the surviving spouse.

 

The correct sequence is formation, extension, contraction, and finally, dissolution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction and dissolution, representing the stages from marriage to the death of the surviving spouse.

questions.text: Identify the lesion seen in a patient with chronic smoking history and weight loss. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cannon ball appearance

 

The chest X-ray image provided shows multiple, well-defined rounded opacities scattered throughout the lung fields.. Here's an explanation of the potential diagnoses:

 

This term is typically used to describe the appearance of multiple large, rounded opacities throughout the lung fields, resembling cannonballs. This pattern is commonly associated with metastatic disease, where secondary tumors spread from a primary site (often from organs like the kidney or colon) to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Septic Emboli: Septic emboli can appear on a chest X-ray as multiple, variably sized nodules that often have a poorly defined border. This condition results from the embolization of infectious material, usually from a central source of infection, through the bloodstream to the lungs. However, septic emboli are generally more irregular and less well-circumscribed compared to what is shown in the image.

 

Option C. Multiple Abscesses: Lung abscesses typically appear as cavitated lesions, which can sometimes be numerous depending on the underlying cause (e.g., aspiration pneumonia). They are generally less uniform and have air-fluid levels, which are not evident in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Pulmonary tuberculosis can manifest in various radiographic appearances, including cavitary lesions, miliary tuberculosis (tiny nodules spread like millet seeds across the lung fields), and sometimes larger nodules. However, the classic "cannonball" appearance is not typical for tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In patients with a significant history of smoking and systemic symptoms like weight loss, the appearance of multiple rounded opacities on chest X-ray should prompt consideration of metastatic disease.

questions.text: Rachitic rosary is seen with which deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Rachitic rosary is a classic finding in rickets, a condition caused by Vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D is essential for calcium absorption and bone mineralization, and its deficiency leads to impaired bone growth and mineralization, resulting in features like rachitic rosary. The prominence of the costochondral junctions, referred to as rachitic rosary, is due to impaired bone mineralization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Rachitic rosary is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency primarily leads to impaired vision (night blindness), dry skin, and immune system issues.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily manifests with symptoms such as bleeding gums, petechiae, and impaired wound healing. Rachitic rosary is not associated with Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency primarily leads to bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting, but it is not associated with rachitic rosary. Vitamin K deficiency does not affect bone mineralization in the same way as Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rachitic rosary is a classic finding in rickets, a condition caused by Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text: In a community of 100000 population, 105 children were born in a year, out of which 5 were still births and 2 died within 6 months after birth and another 2 died within next 6 months. The IMR (Infant Mortality Rate) is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 40

 

Explanation:

 

The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is calculated by dividing the total number of infant deaths (deaths within the first year of life) by the total number of live births, and multiplying the result by 1,000.

 

In this case, the given information is:

 

  • Total births in a year = 105
  • Stillbirths = 5
  • Infant deaths within the first 6 months = 2
  • Infant deaths within the next 6 months = 2

 

To calculate the IMR:

 

1. Calculate the number of live births:

Total live births = Total births - Stillbirths

Total live births = 105 - 5 = 100

 

2. Calculate the total number of infant deaths:

Total infant deaths = Infant deaths within the first 6 months + Infant deaths within the next 6 months

Total infant deaths = 2 + 2 = 4

 

3. Calculate the IMR using the formula:

IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) × 1,000

IMR = (4 / 100) × 1,000

IMR = 40

Therefore, the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for this community is 40 per 1,000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) is a crucial indicator that represents the number of infant deaths (deaths within the first year of life) per 1,000 live births in a given population or community.

questions.text: A wife is complaining that her husband is not taking medications for his diabetes regularly and not maintaining his blood glucose for a long time. Which of the following markers is best for long-duration glucose analysis? (FMGE Jan 2024
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HbA1C

 

Explanation

 

HbA1c, or glycated hemoglobin, is the best marker for assessing long-term glucose control in diabetic patients. It reflects the average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months. This is because glucose binds to hemoglobin in red blood cells, and since red blood cells have a lifespan of about 120 days, the HbA1c value provides a long-term overview of blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. RBS: Not suitable for long-term glucose control as it only measures blood sugar at a specific moment.

 

Option B. FBS: Provides fasting glucose levels but does not give a long-term picture.

 

Option C. PPBS: Useful for assessing post-meal glucose control but not for long-term analysis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

HbA1c is the best marker for long-term glucose analysis in diabetic patients as it reflects average blood glucose levels over the past two to three months.

 

The target HbA1c for most patients with diabetes to ensure adequate control is less than 7%, though this may vary based on individual patient circumstances.

questions.text: Which of the following is the method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leucodepleted blood

 

Explanation:

 

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) are caused by antibodies in the recipient's plasma reacting with the donor's white blood cells (leukocytes) present in the transfused blood. The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the leukocytes, significantly reduces the risk of FNHTRs by eliminating the trigger for the antibody reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prophylactic paracetamol may help in managing fever if an FNHTR occurs, but it does not prevent the reaction itself.

 

Option B. Intravenous steroids are not typically used for the prevention of FNHTRs. Steroids may be administered in cases of severe transfusion reactions, but they do not specifically target the underlying cause of FNHTRs.

 

Option D. Saline-washed red cell transfusion is a method used to reduce the risk of allergic reactions due to the presence of plasma proteins, but it does not directly address the issue of FNHTRs caused by leukocyte antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the donor's white blood cells, is the recommended method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions caused by antibody reactions against the transfused leukocytes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and a gradual onset of fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, revealing an elevated opening pressure and a cerebrospinal fluid analysis, showing a positive India Ink stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis are:

The patient is HIV-positive, indicating an immunocompromised state.

The presentation of persistent headache, confusion, and gradual onset of fever is consistent with meningitis.

 

The lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, which is seen in meningitis.

The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows a positive India Ink stain, which is a negative stain used to detect capsulated organisms like Cryptococcus neoformans.


Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that commonly causes chronic meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

 

Indian Ink Preparation showing Cryptococcus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: While the symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are consistent with bacterial meningitis, the positive India Ink stain indicates the presence of a fungal organism rather than bacteria.

 

Option B. Viral encephalitis: The symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are not typically seen in viral encephalitis, which primarily affects the brain parenchyma rather than the meninges. Additionally, the positive India Ink stain is not consistent with a viral etiology.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Although tuberculous meningitis is a chronic form of meningitis, it is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a bacterium, and would not result in a positive India Ink stain, which is specific for detecting Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that can cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

A positive India Ink stain on CSF analysis, along with elevated opening pressure and compatible clinical symptoms, strongly suggests Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis.

choices.text: Wide local excision with frozen border

questions.text: A 55-year-old farmer presents with an ulcer on his neck, and a biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with negative lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide local excision with radiation 

 

When managing squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the skin, especially in areas exposed to high levels of sun, such as the neck, the treatment approach may vary based on the size, depth, and location of the tumor as well as the patient's overall health. 

 

This is often the preferred treatment for SCC with a high risk of recurrence or metastasis. The tumor is excised with a margin of normal tissue, and radiation is used to kill any remaining cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy: This can be used as a primary treatment for SCC, especially if surgery is not possible, but it is more commonly used adjuvantly (following surgery) if there are high-risk features.

 

Option C. Wide local excision with frozen border: This refers to excision with immediate pathological examination (frozen section) to ensure clear margins. This is a good option for ensuring complete removal during surgery, but adjuvant radiation may still be recommended based on the tumor's features.

 

Option D. Skin grafting: This is a reconstructive procedure used after the removal of the tumor if the defect is too large to close primarily. It does not treat the cancer itself but is a part of the reconstructive process after excision.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate management strategy for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck with negative lymph nodes is wide local excision to remove the tumor completely, often followed by radiotherapy to address any potential microscopic residual disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with BMI 32, was on atypical antipsychotic drugs. She presented with a complaint of weight gain. Which of the following drugs is least commonly associated with weight gain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

 

Atypical antipsychotics are known to vary in their propensity to cause weight gain. Among the options given, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain.

 

Clozapine and olanzapine are the antipsychotics most commonly associated with significant weight gain, whereas ziprasidone and aripiprazole are associated with minimal to no weight gain.

 

Thus, in the case of a patient concerned about weight gain, ziprasidone would be the preferable choice.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Risperidone: This drug is known to cause moderate weight gain in patients.

 

Option B. Quetiapine: This drug is also associated with weight gain, although not as much as clozapine or olanzapine.

 

Option D. Chlorpromazine: This is a typical antipsychotic and is known to cause significant weight gain.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among antipsychotic medications, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain, making it a better option for patients concerned about this side effect.

questions.text: A young patient presents in a multi-specialty hospital with sudden onset chest pain since 1 hour with ECG showing ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. What is the best treatment? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Primary Angioplasty

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms and ECG findings indicative of an acute inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The presence of ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF confirms the diagnosis. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), also known as primary angioplasty, is the best treatment for STEMI if it can be performed promptly. PCI is preferred because it directly opens the blocked coronary artery, restoring blood flow more quickly and effectively than thrombolytic therapy.

 

Note - If Primary PCI not possible or delayed due to some reasons then thrombolytic therapy (dual antiplatelet therapy) is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: This is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots but is considered when PCI is not available or will be delayed.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Another thrombolytic agent, similar to alteplase, used when PCI is not an option.

 

Option D. Dual Antiplatelet therapy: This is an essential part of the initial management of STEMI, involving a combination of aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (like clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel). However, it is not the definitive treatment compared to PCI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary angioplasty (PCI) is the best treatment for patients presenting with STEMI, especially when it can be performed within the recommended time frame, as it effectively restores blood flow to the affected myocardium. ​

questions.text: Plasmodium species that commonly affects the brain:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Falciparum

 

Explanation

 

Plasmodium falciparum is known for its ability to cause severe malaria, including cerebral malaria, which affects the brain. This species can lead to complications such as seizures, coma, and other neurological symptoms due to its ability to adhere to the endothelium of blood vessels in the brain, causing blockage of blood flow and resulting in cerebral symptoms.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vivax: Generally causes milder forms of malaria and is less likely to cause cerebral involvement.

 

Option C. Malaria: Known for chronic malaria but rarely causes cerebral symptoms.

 

Option D. Ovale: Typically associated with milder forms of malaria and does not commonly cause cerebral complications.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Plasmodium falciparum is the species most commonly associated with cerebral malaria, affecting the brain.

questions.text: Philadelphia chromosome is caused by translocation of which of the following chromosomes? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 22 and 9

 

Explanation:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, a hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t (9;22) (q34;q11). This translocation results in the fusion of the BCR gene on chromosome 22 and the ABL1 gene on chromosome 9, creating the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene.

 

The BCR-ABL1 fusion gene encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, which is responsible for the uncontrolled proliferation and survival of myeloid cells in CML. The enhanced tyrosine kinase activity of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein leads to the development of this malignancy.

 

The specific involvement of the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22 in the translocation can be denoted as t(9q;22q) or t(9;22)(q34;q11), where 'q' represents the long arm, and '34' and '11' represent the specific bands on the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, respectively, where the breakpoints occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, the hallmark genetic abnormality in chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), is caused by a reciprocal translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t(9;22)(q34;q11). This translocation creates the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, which encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase responsible for the development of CML.

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Air humidity

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a sling psychrometer, which is an instrument used to measure the water content, moisture content, or air humidity.

 

A sling psychrometer consists of two thermometers, one of which has a wet bulb (covered in a wet cloth) and the other a dry bulb. By comparing the temperatures of the wet and dry bulbs, the relative humidity can be determined using a psychrometric chart or calculation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Air temperature: While the sling psychrometer does measure air temperature using the dry bulb thermometer, its primary purpose is to measure humidity by comparing the dry and wet bulb temperatures.

 

Option B. Air velocity: The sling psychrometer is not designed to measure air velocity.

 

Option D. Cooling air: In the past, the Kata thermometer was used to measure the cooling power of air, but it is now primarily used to assess low air velocity. The sling psychrometer is not designed to measure the cooling effect of air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sling psychrometer is an instrument used to measure air humidity by comparing the temperatures of a wet bulb and a dry bulb thermometer.

questions.text: A person with history of RTA admitted in hospital. He is able to understand what his friend is talking but he is unable to speak. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured in this case? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Broca's area

 

Explanation

 

In the scenario described, the patient is able to understand spoken language but is unable to speak, indicating that comprehension is intact while fluency is impaired. This condition is characteristic of Broca's aphasia, which results from damage to Broca's area in the frontal lobe of the brain.

 

Broca's area is responsible for speech production and language processing. Damage to this area leads to non-fluent aphasia, where the patient struggles to form words and sentences despite understanding spoken language. This condition is often seen in individuals who have experienced a stroke or traumatic brain injury.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Wernicke's area: Damage to Wernicke's area results in Wernicke's aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension. The patient would not understand spoken language.

 

Option C. Angular gyrus: Damage to the angular gyrus typically results in Gerstmann syndrome, characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: acalculia (difficulty with calculations), agraphia (difficulty writing), right-left confusion, and finger agnosia.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: Damage to the arcuate fasciculus causes conduction aphasia, where the patient has intact comprehension and fluency but cannot repeat words or phrases.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Broca's area damage results in Broca's aphasia, characterized by impaired speech production with intact comprehension.

questions.text: In Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), which of the following structures is not preserved? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Submandibular gland 

 

In a Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), the goal is to remove lymphatic tissue that may contain cancer while preserving as many structures as possible to reduce morbidity. 

 

Option A. Sternocleidomastoid muscle: In an MRND, this muscle is typically preserved unless it is involved with the tumor.

 

Option B. Internal jugular vein: This vein is usually preserved in an MRND to maintain venous drainage from the head, unless it is involved with the tumor.

 

Option C. Spinal accessory nerve: Preservation of the spinal accessory nerve is a key goal in MRND to prevent shoulder dysfunction that can occur if the nerve is sacrificed.

 

Option D. Submandibular gland: The submandibular gland is routinely removed in an MRND, especially if the lymph nodes closely associated with it are involved with malignant disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In Modified Radical Neck Dissection, the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve are typically preserved to reduce morbidity, while the submandibular gland is often removed due to its close association with lymphatic structures that are at risk for malignancy.

questions.text: Drug of choice for malaria (plasmodium vivax) in pregnancy? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

 

The treatment of malaria in pregnancy, especially caused by Plasmodium vivax, requires special consideration due to the potential effects on both the mother and the fetus. The key points are:

 

  • Chloroquine: Chloroquine is the drug of choice for treating Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnant women. It is effective and safe during pregnancy.
  • Alternative Drugs: If there is resistance to chloroquine, quinine can be used as a secondary option.
  • For Plasmodium falciparum malaria, artesunate is the preferred drug, followed by quinine, both of which can be safely used during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine + Primaquine: This combination is not used in pregnancy due to the contraindication of primaquine. Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause hemolytic anemia in the fetus, especially in those with G6PD deficiency. It is not used for radical cure in pregnant women and is deferred until after delivery.

 

Option C. Quinine: While quinine can be used if there is resistance to chloroquine, it is not the first-line treatment for Plasmodium vivax.

 

Option D. Artesunate: Artesunate is the drug of choice for Plasmodium falciparum malaria but not for Plasmodium vivax in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy

 

  • Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days.
  • To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery.
  • For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over.
  • Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision.
  • Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion.
  • Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia.
  • Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable.
  • Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.

questions.text: Death sentence can be given by: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A. Session court judge and B. Additional session court

 

Explanation:

 

In the Indian judicial system, both the Session Court and the Additional Session Court have the authority to pass a death sentence. However, any death sentence given by these courts must be confirmed by the High Court before it can be carried out. The Supreme Court and High Court can also issue death sentences directly.

 

It is important to note that the Assistant Sessions Court Judge and the Additional Sessions Court Judge are not the same. An Assistant Sessions Court Judge is a junior position and does not have the power to issue a death sentence.

 

Other Option:

 

Option. C. Chief judicial magistrate: The Chief Judicial Magistrate does not have the authority to pass a death sentence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, death sentences can be issued by the Session Court, Additional Session Court, High Court, and Supreme Court. However, any death sentence passed by the Session Court or Additional Session Court must be confirmed by the High Court before it can be executed.

questions.text: An adult female came with curdy white vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination showed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The key points indicate Candida albicans as the causative organism are:

 

  1. The patient presented with curdy white vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of candidiasis (yeast infection).
  2. Microscopic examination revealed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae, which are characteristic of Candida albicans.
  3. Pseudohyphae are elongated structures with constrictions at the septal junctions, distinguishing them from true hyphae found in molds.
  4. Among the options provided, Candida albicans is the only fungus that forms pseudohyphae.

 

Candida albicans is a yeast that can cause various fungal infections, including vaginal candidiasis (commonly known as a "yeast infection"). The formation of pseudohyphae, along with budding yeast cells, is a distinctive feature of Candida albicans observed under the microscope.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is caused by an overgrowth of various bacteria, not a fungus like Candida albicans.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, not a fungus.

 

Option D.  Gonorrhoea: Caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, presents with purulent discharge but does not produce yeast or pseudohyphae. Diagnosis is typically confirmed with gram stain and culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida albicans is a fungus that can cause vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection), characterized by a curdy white vaginal discharge. The presence of gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae on microscopic examination is a distinctive feature of Candida albicans infections.

questions.text: During an endoscopy, a man is found to have the squamo-columnar junction located proximally than normal. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this finding? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sliding hernia 

 

During an endoscopy, finding the squamo-columnar junction (also known as the Z-line) located proximally to its normal position near the gastroesophageal junction suggests a condition in which the stomach has moved upwards. 

 

Also known as a sliding hiatal hernia, this condition occurs when part of the stomach slides up through the hiatal opening in the diaphragm into the chest cavity, leading to the upward displacement of the squamo-columnar junction observed during endoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achalasia cardia: This is a motility disorder of the esophagus where the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax properly. It doesn't typically result in an upward displacement of the squamo-columnar junction.

 

Option C. Rolling hernia: A rolling or paraesophageal hernia occurs when part of the stomach herniates through the diaphragm next to the esophagus but the gastroesophageal junction stays in its normal position, so it would not typically result in the proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction.

 

Option D. Paraesophageal hernia: This is similar to a rolling hernia where the gastroesophageal junction remains in place, but part of the stomach rolls up through the diaphragm. It does not cause proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sliding hernia is the condition most likely responsible for the proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction observed during endoscopy, indicating the upward movement of the stomach through the hiatal opening.

questions.text: Defect of enzyme tyrosine transaminase(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 2 tyrosinemia

 

Explanation

 

Tyrosinemia is a genetic disorder characterized by the body's inability to effectively break down the amino acid tyrosine. There are three types of tyrosinemia, each associated with a specific enzyme deficiency:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I tyrosinemia: This type is associated with a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH), not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Option C. Alkaptonuria: This condition involves a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Option D. Type III tyrosinemia: This type involves a deficiency in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD), not tyrosine transaminase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme tyrosine transaminase and is also known as Richner-Hanhart syndrome or Oculocutaneous syndrome.

questions.text: A lactating mother who follows a strict vegetarian diet presents with fatigue, weakness, and numbness in her extremities. Upon examination, her blood work reveals a decreased total iron binding capacity. Which of the following deficiencies can cause this clinical picture?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12 deficiency


The clinical presentation of fatigue, weakness, and numbness in the extremities is indicative of vitamin B12 deficiency, especially in someone following a strict vegetarian diet. Vitamin B12, or cobalamin, is predominantly found in animal products, and those following a vegetarian diet are at higher risk for deficiency.

 

Key symptoms of B12 deficiency include:

 

  • Fatigue and weakness due to megaloblastic anemia.
  • Numbness and tingling in the extremities due to progressive peripheral neuropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency: Typically presents with fatigue and pallor with elevated TIBC. Numbness is not a common symptom.

 

Option B. Zinc deficiency: Can cause various symptoms including growth retardation and impaired immune function, but does not typically present with anemia and neuropathy.

 

Option D. Folate deficiency: Can also cause megaloblastic anemia but does not usually cause peripheral neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency should be considered in individuals with a strict vegetarian diet presenting with symptoms of megaloblastic anemia (fatigue, weakness) and progressive peripheral neuropathy (numbness in extremities).

questions.text: Which muscle is inserted on the lesser trochanter of the femur? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psoas major

 

  • Psoas major muscle is a paraspinal muscle located deep in the body.
  • It lays close to the spine on either side and extends distally to the brim of the lesser pelvis.
  • It acts to laterally flex the lumbar spine and assists with flexion and external rotation of the hip.
  • It is essential for correct standing or sitting lumbar posture, stability of the hip joint, and during walking and running.
  • The psoas muscle is one of the core muscles.
  • The psoas muscle contains superficial and deep parts.
  • Superficially, it originates along the lateral surface of the distal thoracic vertebrae and adjacent intervertebral discs.
  • The deeper portion originates at the first 4 lumbar vertebrae.
  • The fibres of the muscle converge from its wide origin as they descend on the posterior abdominal wall.
  • They cross the pelvic inlet to form a long tendon, which is joined within the pelvic region by fibres from the iliacus muscle, finally inserting into the lesser trochanter of the femur. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoas minor: The psoas minor muscle originates along the lateral aspect of the vertebral body of the 12th thoracic vertebrae and the 1st lumbar vertebrae, and the intervertebral disc between those two vertebrae. There are two psoas minors, one on each side of the spine. Distally, it blends with the iliopsoas fascia. It inserts into the pectineal line of the pubis (not always present).

 

 

Option C. Obturator internus: The obturator internus muscle originates from the inferior margin of the superior pubic ramus and from the pelvic surface of the obturator membrane. Its tendon exits the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen to insert onto the greater trochanter of the femur.

 

 

Option D. Piriformis: It originates from the anterior aspect of the sacrum at the level of S2-S4, sacrotuberous ligament, and periphery of the greater sciatic notch. It inserts on the superior and medial aspects of the greater trochanter.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Psoas Major muscle inserts at the lesser trochanter of the femur and is involved in flexing the hip joint.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient with a history of mitral valve replacement on anticoagulation with warfarin is about to undergo hernioplasty for inguinal hernia. What is the target INR prior to surgery? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.5

 

Explanation

 

Prior to any major surgery, including abdominal surgeries like hernioplasty, it is crucial to manage the patient's anticoagulation status to minimize the risk of excessive bleeding.

 

For patients on warfarin, the target INR should be brought to less than 1.5 before the surgery.

 

This can be achieved by stopping warfarin and administering vitamin K if necessary.

 

If the INR remains above 1.5 on the day of surgery, fresh frozen plasma (FFP) may be administered to rapidly lower the INR. This approach balances the need to prevent excessive bleeding during surgery while managing the risk of thromboembolic complications.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. 0.5-0.8: This range is too low for general surgical preparation and would indicate a significant reversal of anticoagulation, which is not typically required.

 

Option C. 1.5-2: While this range might be acceptable for some minor procedures, major surgeries generally require an INR of less than 1.5 to ensure safety.

 

Option D. 2-3: This range is appropriate for therapeutic anticoagulation but is too high for surgical procedures due to the increased risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

For patients on warfarin undergoing major surgery, the target INR should be less than 1.5 to minimize bleeding risk.

questions.text: A patient with hemolytic anemia presents with index finger pain and chest pain. The patient has Hb of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin in serum. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sickling crisis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with hemolytic anemia, evidenced by a low hemoglobin level of 5.6 gm/dl and an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, indicating hemolysis. The specific symptoms of index finger pain and chest pain are highly suggestive of a sickling crisis.

 

In sickle cell disease, patients may experience episodes of severe pain, known as sickle cell crises or vaso-occlusive crises, due to the blockage of blood flow by sickled red blood cells. The index finger pain (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome) are classic manifestations of such crises. Acute chest syndrome is a severe complication of sickle cell disease that presents with chest pain, fever, and pulmonary infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microangiopathic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells in small blood vessels but does not typically present with the specific symptoms of dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: While thalassemia also causes hemolytic anemia, it does not usually present with dactylitis or acute chest syndrome.

 

Option D. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the immune system attacking red blood cells but lacks the specific signs of sickle cell crisis, such as dactylitis and acute chest syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with hemolytic anemia presenting with severe pain in the fingers (dactylitis) and chest pain (acute chest syndrome), sickle cell crisis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient complains of difficulty breathing and  fatigue. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac tamponade

 

The condition depicted in the provided X-ray, along with the clinical findings of distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds, and symptoms of difficulty breathing and fatigue, is suggestive of cardiac tamponade. Here's an explanation of each condition considered in the differential diagnosis:

 

 This is a critical condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, exerting pressure on the heart, thereby impeding its ability to fill properly during diastole. The classical clinical triad includes distended neck veins, muffled heart sounds, and hypotension (Beck's triad). The X-ray may show an enlarged cardiac silhouette, known as a "water bottle" heart, due to the accumulation of fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchial Asthma: This is primarily a pulmonary condition characterized by episodes of breathing difficulty due to reversible airway obstruction, inflammation, and bronchospasm. Typical radiographic findings in asthma include hyperinflation of the lungs, but it would not typically cause distended neck veins or muffled heart sounds.

 

Option C. Constrictive Pericarditis: This chronic condition involves thickening or calcification of the pericardium, which leads to restricted cardiac filling. Symptoms might overlap with those of cardiac tamponade, such as fatigue and elevated neck veins, but the heart sounds are not typically muffled. Radiographic findings might show pericardial calcifications, and the heart size might not be as dramatically enlarged as in tamponade.

 

Option D. Atrial Myxoma: This is a type of primary heart tumor that usually arises in the atria. It can intermittently obstruct blood flow and may lead to varied symptoms based on its size and location. An X-ray might not be diagnostic except for showing general cardiac enlargement.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Cardiac tamponade is a life-threatening emergency which looks like ‘ water bottle heat’ on x-ray and  that requires immediate intervention, typically pericardiocentesis, to relieve the pressure on the heart. Any patient presenting with the classic triad of tamponade and signs consistent on imaging should be managed with urgent care to stabilize the condition and prevent cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs cause visual problems as an adverse effect? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug that can cause visual problems as an adverse effect. It is known for its potential to lead to optic neuritis, which can result in changes in visual acuity and color vision. Monitoring of vision is important during the use of ethambutol, and if visual disturbances occur, the drug may need to be discontinued to prevent further optic nerve damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is not typically associated with visual problems as an adverse effect.

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is not known to cause visual problems. However, it is associated with hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy as potential adverse effects.

 

Option D. Pyrazinamide: Pyrazinamide is not commonly associated with visual problems as an adverse effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is the anti-tubercular drug known for its association with visual problems. It can cause optic neuritis and changes in color vision, which may be reversible upon discontinuation of the drug.

questions.text: The following image shows which X-ray view?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Towne’s view

 

Based on the image provided, where the X-ray beam is directed from above the skull at an angle and the detector is positioned below the skull, the indicated X-ray view is consistent with the Towne’s view.

 

Towne’s view is an X-ray where the beam is angled at approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and directed downward toward the patient's head, which is positioned with the chin lifted. This view is particularly useful for assessing the occipital bone, posterior fossa, and foramen magnum, as well as the mastoid and middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view is an X-ray taken with the patient's head tilted backward so that the X-ray beam is directed perpendicularly to the orbitomeatal line. It's often used to visualize the maxillary sinuses, the orbits, and the nasal cavity.

 

Option B. Caldwell view is performed with the patient’s head positioned such that the X-ray beam is angled at 15-20 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and the central ray is directed towards the nose. This view is used to visualize the frontal sinuses, orbits, and ethmoid sinuses.

 

Option D. Schuller’s view is an X-ray that provides a lateral view of the skull, specifically to evaluate the mastoid air cells and the structure of the temporal bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Towne’s view X-ray is used to visualize the occipital bone, posterior fossa, foramen magnum, and mastoid process by positioning the patient with the head tilted upward and the X-ray beam angled approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line.

questions.text: An infertile patient came with a history of sinus inversus, sinusitis, and pulmonary infection. Which syndrome is likely to occur? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

Kartagener syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the triad of situs inversus (reversed positioning of the internal organs), chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis (irreversible dilation of the bronchi).

 

The clinical features described in the question, including sinus inversus, sinusitis, and pulmonary infection (suggestive of bronchiectasis), are characteristic of Kartagener syndrome.

 

 

Kartagener syndrome is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), a genetic condition in which the cilia (hair-like structures responsible for movement) are dysfunctional or immotile. This leads to impaired mucociliary clearance, resulting in recurrent respiratory infections, sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kallaman syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (delayed or absent puberty) and anosmia (lack of sense of smell), but it is not associated with the clinical features mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Although cystic fibrosis can lead to bronchiectasis, it is not typically associated with situs inversus or sinusitis as prominent features.

 

Option D. Samter syndrome: This is a triad of asthma, nasal polyps, and sensitivity to aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). It does not involve situs inversus or the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis is characteristic of Kartagener syndrome, which is a subtype of primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) resulting from dysfunctional cilia.

choices.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges
