questions.text: Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of wound dehiscence in a post-operative hypotensive patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

 

Wound dehiscence is the partial or total separation of layers of a surgical wound. Various signs can indicate this complication, particularly in a post-operative patient who is hypotensive:

 

This type of drainage, which is composed of both blood and serous fluid, can indicate that the wound layers are not properly adhered and may be a sign of impending or actual dehiscence. It's considered a "sure sign" because it often precedes the wound actually coming apart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased bowel sounds: While changes in bowel sounds can be associated with various abdominal conditions like intestinal obstruction, they are not a specific sign of wound dehiscence.

 

Option B. Persistent abdominal pain: Pain is a nonspecific symptom that can be associated with many post-operative complications, including wound dehiscence, but on its own is not a definitive sign.

 

Option D. Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges: While this can occur with wound dehiscence, it is more of a late sign when the wound has already dehisced significantly.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Serosanguinous drainage from the surgical wound is a "sure sign" of wound dehiscence and warrants immediate medical evaluation to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Conjunctival xerosis is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Conjunctival xerosis, which refers to the drying and thickening of the conjunctiva, is indeed associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining the health of epithelial tissues, including those of the eye. This deficiency can lead to various ocular manifestations, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, of which conjunctival xerosis is a part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with conditions related to bone health, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. Conjunctival xerosis is not a recognized consequence of Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option B. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency is primarily associated with bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting. While Vitamin K deficiency can lead to bleeding in various tissues, conjunctival xerosis is not a recognized consequence of this deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and impaired wound healing. However, conjunctival xerosis is not a typical manifestation of Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival xerosis is specifically associated with Vitamin A deficiency and is a significant indicator of this deficiency, affecting the epithelial tissues of the eye.

questions.text: A 2-month pregnant female presented with Plasmodium vivax malaria. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Quinine

 

For a pregnant woman with Plasmodium vivax malaria, Chloroquine alone is the appropriate choice. Primaquine is contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential risks to the fetus. Quinine is normally used for Plasmodium falciparum malaria but can be used in P. vivax malaria also if other options are not available. It is safe in pregnancy. ACTs are generally avoided in the first trimester, and Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy. Therefore, Chloroquine, without Primaquine, is the safest and most effective option in this case. However, as it is not in the options, so the next best option i.e. quinine will be the answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine plus Primaquine: Chloroquine is considered safe and effective for the treatment of Plasmodium vivax malaria during pregnancy. However, primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of hemolytic anemia in the fetus, especially if there is G6PD deficiency, which cannot be tested for in the fetus.

 

Option C. Artemisinin-Based Combination Therapy (ACT): While ACTs are very effective in treating Plasmodium falciparum malaria, their safety profile in the first trimester of pregnancy is not well-established. Generally, they are avoided in the first trimester unless no other options are available.

 

Option D. Doxycycline: Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of interfering with bone and teeth development in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quinine is often used as a treatment for malaria during pregnancy, especially if other options are not available or suitable. However, it is usually more associated with the treatment of Plasmodium falciparum rather than Plasmodium vivax.

choices.text: Surgical management is required in most children

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngomalacia? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Most common in newborn

 

Laryngomalacia is indeed most common in newborns and is often noticed shortly after birth. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laryngomalacia typically presents with inspiratory stridor, not expiratory. This stridor is due to the collapse of supraglottic structures during inhalation.

 

Option B. The stridor of laryngomalacia typically worsens in the supine position. This is because the supraglottic structures are more likely to collapse into the airway when a child is lying on their back.

 

Option D. Most children with laryngomalacia do not require surgical management. The condition is often self-limiting and tends to improve as the child grows and the laryngeal structures become more rigid, usually by 18 to 24 months of age. Surgery is reserved for severe cases where there are feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, severe stridor, or apnea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that typically worsens in the supine position and is most commonly diagnosed in newborns. The condition generally resolves on its own without the need for surgical intervention in most cases.

questions.text: Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are clinical manifestations associated with a deficiency in Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin). Riboflavin is essential for various cellular processes, including energy production and the metabolism of fats, drugs, and steroids. Deficiency in riboflavin leads to various symptoms, most notably affecting the mucous membranes, which include angular cheilitis (cracking at the corners of the mouth), stomatitis (inflammation of the mouth and lips), and glossitis (inflammation of the tongue).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1: Thiamine deficiency is not typically associated with angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis. Instead, it leads to conditions such as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi, which affect the nervous and cardiovascular systems.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3: Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the three D's: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While oral symptoms can occur in severe cases, they usually do not present as angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6: Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with dermatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and certain types of anemia. It is not typically linked with angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are associated with Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) deficiency.

questions.text: Which appendicular carcinoma is most commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritoneii? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucinous adenocarcinoma 

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a rare condition characterized by the presence of mucinous ascites due to the dissemination of mucus-producing cells within the peritoneal cavity.

 

This is a type of cancer that arises from cells that produce mucus, commonly from the appendix. It is the most common cause of pseudomyxoma peritonei, as these malignant cells can spread throughout the peritoneal cavity and secrete mucin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucinous cystadenoma: This is a benign ovarian tumor that can produce mucus, but it is less commonly associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei compared to its malignant counterparts.

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that can occur in the appendix. While they can spread, they are not typically associated with the production of abundant mucin that characterizes pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Option D. Serous cystadenoma: This is a benign tumor that can occur in the ovaries and produce a watery serous fluid, not the mucinous ascites seen in pseudomyxoma peritonei.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mucinous adenocarcinoma, particularly of the appendix, is the most common appendicular carcinoma associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei, characterized by the accumulation of mucinous material in the peritoneal cavity.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady develops sudden onset facial deviation with slurring of speech and inability to raise right arm. The symptoms spontaneously begin to reduce and has significant improvement over the next 48 hours. She has a mid-diastolic murmur on auscultation and irregular heart rhythm. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardio-embolic stroke

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with sudden onset neurological deficits (facial deviation, slurred speech, and right arm weakness), which improved significantly over 48 hours. The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur suggests mitral stenosis, and the irregular heart rhythm indicates atrial fibrillation. These are strong risk factors for cardio-embolic stroke. Although the improvement suggests a transient ischemic attack (TIA), the symptoms lasted more than 24 hours, which aligns with the definition of a stroke rather than a TIA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TIA: By definition, a TIA's symptoms resolve within 24 hours. Since the symptoms persisted for more than 24 hours, this is not a TIA.

 

Option B. Thrombo-embolic stroke: While possible, the presence of mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation makes cardio-embolic stroke more likely.

 

Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus from the venous system passes through a right-to-left cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale) into the arterial system. There is no mention of such a shunt or a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardio-embolic stroke should be suspected in patients with sudden onset neurological deficits and risk factors such as mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation. Symptoms persisting for more than 24 hours distinguish stroke from TIA.

choices.text: See the snake brought by the relatives

questions.text: A farmer came after snake bite on right foot. There were 2 fang marks with pain, swelling, and bleeding at the site of snake bite and the patient's vitals are stable. What will be the first step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polyvalent ASV

 

Explanation:

 

Based on the presence of two fang marks, pain, swelling, and bleeding at the site of the snake bite on the farmer's right foot, it is most likely a viper snake bite, which is poisonous. The patient's vitals are stable, but the signs of envenomation are present. In all cases of envenomation, the main life-treating measure is administering antisnake venom (ASV). Polyvalent ASV 5000 units should be given as the first step in management whenever poisonous features, such as bleeding, are present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Pressure immobilization: Immobilization is done for all snake bites, but, the Pressure immobilization is done for neurotoxic snakes but not for vasculotoxic snakes like vipers. Applying pressure in vasculotoxic snake bites can lead to local toxic effects and potentially result in limb amputation.

 

Option. C. Venom suction: Venom suction is never an option in the management of snake bites.

 

Option. D. See the snake brought by the relatives: Looking at the snake brought by relatives is rarely of practical use and is more of a theoretical consideration. It should not be the first step in managing a snake bite with signs of envenomation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In cases of snake bites with signs of envenomation, such as pain, swelling, and bleeding, administering polyvalent ASV should be the first step in management, regardless of the type of snake involved.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Montgomery T tube

 

Montgomery T tube is a type of silicone stent used in the management of tracheal and subglottic stenosis. It is T-shaped to allow it to fit snugly in the trachea with one limb exiting the stoma, allowing for breathing through the upper airway or the tube itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a device inserted between the trachea and the esophagus to facilitate speech in patients who have had a total laryngectomy

 

Option C. Blom-Singer prosthesis is a type of tracheoesophageal puncture voice prosthesis used for voice rehabilitation after a laryngectomy. When a patient has their larynx removed, typically due to cancer, they lose their natural voice. A Blom-Singer prosthesis is a one-way valve inserted between the trachea and the esophagus that allows air to be diverted into the esophagus to produce sound, enabling the patient to speak. It is placed during surgery or as an office procedure after the surgical site has healed.

 

Option D. A Grommet, also known as a tympanostomy tube or ventilation tube, is a small tube inserted into the eardrum to allow air to enter the middle ear. It is used to treat recurrent middle ear infections (acute otitis media) or to relieve chronic fluid accumulation in the middle ear (otitis media with effusion). Grommets help reduce the frequency of ear infections and improve hearing by allowing the continuous drainage of fluid and equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the external atmospheric pressure.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for brachial plexus block. After some time, the patient developed hypotension and cardiovascular collapse. What is the best treatment for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 20% Intralipid

 

In the case of hypotension and cardiovascular collapse following a bupivacaine brachial plexus block, the recommended treatment is intravenous lipid emulsion therapy (e.g., 20% Intralipid). This treatment is specifically targeted at reversing the toxic effects of bupivacaine, which is a lipophilic local anesthetic. The other options, while useful in various cardiovascular emergencies, are not the primary treatments for bupivacaine toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication used primarily for the treatment of certain types of serious arrhythmias. It's not typically used for the acute management of bupivacaine-induced cardiovascular collapse.

 

Option B. Epinephrine: This is a critical care drug used in the management of various life-threatening conditions, including anaphylaxis and cardiac arrest. It could be used in this scenario for its vasoconstrictive and positive inotropic effects, but it might not be the first choice due to the risk of exacerbating cardiac arrhythmias, which can be a complication of bupivacaine toxicity.

 

Option C. Dobutamine: This is a β1-selective vasoactive agent used primarily for the management of heart failure and cardiogenic shock. It increases cardiac output but would not be the first-line treatment for bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intralipid therapy is the recommended treatment for severe local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur with medications like bupivacaine. It acts by trapping lipophilic drugs like bupivacaine in an intravascular lipid emulsion, reducing their toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following regulates the body temperature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypothalamus

 

Explanation:


The regulation of body temperature is primarily controlled by the hypothalamus. Specifically, the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus is responsible for cooling mechanisms, akin to standing in front of an air conditioner during hot weather. Conversely, the posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus manages warming mechanisms, similar to standing near an exhaust to receive warm air during cold weather.

This dual role in temperature regulation is unique to the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are involved in the coordination of movement and motor control, but they do not play a role in temperature regulation.

 

Option C. Thalamus: The thalamus acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex, and does not regulate body temperature.

 

Option D. Limbic system: The limbic system is involved in emotions, behavior, and long-term memory, but it does not have a role in the regulation of body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypothalamus, specifically its anterior and posterior nuclei, is responsible for regulating body temperature.

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described (resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

In Parkinson's disease, the brain biopsy is likely to show Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of aggregates of alpha-synuclein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirano bodies: Seen in Alzheimer's disease and other conditions like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

 

Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion) Found in cells infected with poxvirus.

 

Option D. Negri bodies: Seen in the neurons of patients with rabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Parkinson's disease, brain biopsies typically reveal Lewy bodies, which are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of alpha-synuclein.

questions.text: Patient came with fever, rash and eschar formation. On examination, mite bite was also present. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support this diagnosis are:

 

  1. The presence of eschar, which is a common finding in scrub typhus and anthrax.
  2. The mite bite, which is the biggest clue provided, as scrub typhus is transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers).
  3. The explanation that among the rickettsial diseases mentioned in the options (scrub typhus, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and epidemic typhus), only scrub typhus is transmitted by mites.

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by the bacteria Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites, commonly known as chiggers.

 

Triad – Eschar; Regional lymphadenopathy and Maculopapular rash

 

 

 

 

*Coxiella and  Bartonella  are now excluded from this family

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anthrax: Anthrax is caused by the bacteria Bacillus anthracis and is not transmitted by mite bites. It is a zoonotic disease acquired through contact with infected animals or their products, inhalation of spores, or ingestion of contaminated food.

 

Option C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever: This is another rickettsial disease, but it is transmitted by ticks, not mites. The presence of a mite bite in the given scenario rules out this option.

 

Option D. Epidemic Typhus: Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by lice, epidemic typhus presents with a rash but does not typically include eschar formation, nor is it associated with mite bites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scrub typhus is a rickettsial disease caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by the bite of larval mites (chiggers). The presence of eschar, fever, rash, and a mite bite are key clinical features suggestive of this diagnosis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient with alcoholic liver disease was given some anti-amoebic drug. Later the patient presented with nausea, vomiting, flushing and hypotension. What is the likely diagnosis? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Disulfiram like reaction

 

The most likely diagnosis in this scenario is a disulfiram-like reaction. The timing of the symptoms in relation to the administration of an anti-amoebic drug, along with the specific symptoms mentioned, aligns well with this condition. Delirium tremens and alcohol withdrawal typically have different presentations and timing, and psychosis doesn't fit the symptom pattern described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by confusion, tremors, hallucinations, and agitation. It typically occurs several days after the last drink, not usually in direct response to medication.

 

Option B. Psychosis: While chronic alcoholism can be associated with psychosis, the symptoms described (nausea, vomiting, flushing, hypotension) are not typical for a primary psychiatric condition.

 

Option D. Alcohol Withdrawal: Symptoms of alcohol withdrawal typically include tremors, anxiety, nausea, vomiting, and seizures, but the specific combination of symptoms mentioned (particularly flushing and a direct connection to medication) is less typical for alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A disulfiram-like reaction can occur when certain medications, such as some anti-amoebic drugs like metronidazole, inhibit acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed. This causes symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, flushing, and hypotension.

questions.text: A man eats 3 cones of ice cream. After some time, he starts feeling more colder ears than the central parts of his body. Which part of the brain is responsible for thermo-regulation? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypothalamus

 

The hypothalamus is responsible for regulating body temperature, among other vital functions. It serves as the body's thermostat, receiving input from temperature receptors in the body and initiating appropriate responses to maintain homeostasis. When the body temperature deviates from the set point, the hypothalamus triggers mechanisms to adjust the temperature. For instance, if the body is too cold, the hypothalamus may initiate heat production processes such as shivering.

 

In the scenario described, the man starts feeling colder in his ears compared to the central parts of his body. This is because the hypothalamus is actively managing the body's response to the cold stimuli (the ice cream), directing blood flow to the core to maintain essential organ temperature, which can result in peripheral parts like the ears feeling colder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: The thalamus is primarily involved in relaying sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and regulating consciousness, sleep, and alertness. It does not play a direct role in thermoregulation.

 

Option C. Amygdala: The amygdala is involved in emotional processing, including fear and pleasure responses, and memory formation, but it does not regulate body temperature.

 

Option D. Caudate nuclei: The caudate nuclei are part of the basal ganglia and are involved in various functions such as motor control and learning, but they are not involved in thermoregulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypothalamus is the part of the brain responsible for regulating body temperature and maintaining homeostasis.

questions.text: In a triage setting, which of the following categories requires the highest priority intervention? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In a triage setting, particularly in emergency and disaster scenarios, different colors are used to categorize the urgency of patients' conditions. 

 

This indicates that the patient has life-threatening injuries and requires immediate intervention to save their life. Patients in this category are to be treated first.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This signifies that the patient has serious injuries that are not immediately life-threatening. Their treatment can be delayed briefly, but they still need urgent care.

 

Option C. Green: This color is used for patients with minor injuries who are stable enough to wait for a longer period without immediate intervention. These are the "walking wounded."

 

Option D. Black: This category is used for patients who are either deceased or have such extensive injuries that they are not expected to survive given the level of care available. In a mass casualty incident, these patients may be deemed beyond help and may not receive treatment due to limited resources.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In triage, patients categorized as 'Red' require the highest priority intervention due to the life-threatening nature of their injuries and the necessity of immediate treatment to save their lives.

choices.text: Formed by the internal oblique aponeurosis and transversus abdominis aponeurosis
Forms the posterior wall of inguinal canal
Protects the superficial inguinal ring to maintain integrity of inguinal canal
Runs parallel to the inguinal ligament

questions.text: All of the following statements about the conjoint tendon are true, except: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Runs parallel to the inguinal ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The conjoint tendon does not run parallel to the inguinal ligament. Instead, it runs obliquely and inserts into the pubic crest and pectineal line, thereby reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal but not parallel to the inguinal ligament.

 

The conjoint tendon, also known as the falx inguinalis, is a critical structure in the anatomy of the inguinal region. It is formed by the aponeuroses of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. This structure plays an essential role in maintaining the integrity of the inguinal canal and preventing hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formed by the internal oblique aponeurosis and transversus abdominis aponeurosis: This statement is true. The conjoint tendon is indeed formed by the fusion of the internal oblique aponeurosis and the transversus abdominis aponeurosis.

 

Option B. Forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal: This statement is also true. The conjoint tendon contributes significantly to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, providing support and reinforcing this area.

 

Option C. Protects the superficial inguinal ring to maintain integrity of inguinal canal: This statement is true. The conjoint tendon helps protect the superficial inguinal ring by forming a shutter-like mechanism that reduces the risk of inguinal hernias by maintaining the canal's integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The conjoint tendon is formed by the internal oblique and transversus abdominis aponeuroses and plays a crucial role in reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and protecting the superficial inguinal ring. It does not run parallel to the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Bowing of legs with bleeding gums is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

 

Explanation:

 

Bowing of legs can be mistakenly attributed to vitamin D deficiency, which typically causes rickets in children.

 

However, the presence of bleeding gums points specifically to vitamin C deficiency.

 

Vitamin C is crucial for collagen synthesis and other structural aspects of bone formation. This deficiency, known as scurvy, involves various skeletal changes including defective osteoid matrix formation and osteolysis, beyond just the commonly noted bleeding gums. The combined symptoms of bowing of legs and bleeding gums can indeed suggest a scenario where vitamin C deficiency plays a contributory role alongside other deficiencies like vitamin D.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A: Incorrect because Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and epithelial tissues, not typically associated with bleeding gums or significant skeletal changes like bowing of legs.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Incorrect as Vitamin E deficiency generally leads to neurological problems and muscle weakness, not directly linked with bleeding gums or bone deformities.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Incorrect because while Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, its deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of legs; it would rather lead to bleeding issues without the skeletal deformities noted here.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Vitamin C deficiency can cause bleeding gums and is associated with significant bone structure changes, leading to conditions like scurvy that may present with skeletal deformities such as bowing of legs.

questions.text: A patient presented with fatigue and pallor. Investigations show Hb = 5.8 gm/dl, low ferritin, high TIBC, low MCV, high RDW. Diagnosis is? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron Deficiency Anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin levels, low ferritin (indicating depleted iron stores), high total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), and high red cell distribution width (RDW). These laboratory findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia:

 

  • Low ferritin indicates depleted iron stores.
  • High TIBC reflects an increase in the body's attempt to capture more iron due to deficiency.
  • Low MCV signifies microcytic anemia, common in iron deficiency.
  • High RDW indicates variability in red cell size, often seen in iron deficiency as the body produces new, smaller red cells alongside older, larger ones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Megaloblastic Anemia: Typically presents with high MCV (macrocytic anemia) due to deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate, not low MCV.

 

Option C. Anemia of Chronic Disease: Often presents with normal or high ferritin (reflecting inflammation or infection) and low TIBC, not high TIBC.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic Anemia: Generally associated with increased iron stores, not low ferritin, and may show a dimorphic blood picture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is indicated by low hemoglobin, low ferritin, high TIBC, low MCV, and high RDW.

questions.text: A lactating mother is eating only vegetables. Which nutrient deficiency will be seen in her newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12

 

Explanation: In this scenario, the lactating mother is following a plant-based diet, consuming only vegetables. Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that is not found in plant sources, making it a potential deficiency for strict vegetarians. As a result, the newborn of this mother is likely to experience a deficiency in vitamin B12.

 

While vitamin D is another nutrient that lacks plant sources, it can be synthesized in the skin through exposure to sunlight. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin D is less likely in this case compared to vitamin B12.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is available in various plant-based sources, such as leafy green vegetables, legumes, and whole grains. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin B2 is less likely in this scenario.

 

Option B. Vitamin A can be obtained from plant sources in the form of provitamin A carotenoids, which are found in yellow, orange, and green leafy vegetables. As the mother is consuming vegetables, a vitamin A deficiency is less likely.

 

Option D. Iron is present in several plant-based sources, including legumes, whole grains, and leafy green vegetables. While the bioavailability of non-heme iron from plant sources is lower than heme iron from animal sources, a deficiency is less likely if the mother consumes a varied vegetable-based diet.

 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that is not found in plant sources, making it a potential deficiency concern for individuals following a strict vegetarian or vegan diet, including lactating mothers and their newborns.

choices.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid twice a week
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a week
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily
60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid once a month

questions.text: What dose of iron and folic acid should an anemic pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily

 

Explanation:

 

Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, which aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia in India by 3 percentage points every year, the "6 by 6 by 6" strategy is used. This strategy targets 6 beneficiaries, includes 6 interventions, and involves 6 institutional mechanisms.

 

 

One of the interventions is iron and folic acid supplementation.

 

Anemic pregnant women in their second trimester should be given 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days, as per the guidelines of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program.

 

For pregnant women, the recommended dose is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days during pregnancy. This is provided in the form of red-colored tablets. The same dose is also given to lactating mothers for 180 days post-delivery.

 

If the woman does not respond to this dosage or is anemic, then other forms of iron supplementation, such as ferrous carboxy maltose and IV sucrose, may be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Criteria for FRU include all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24-hour MTP facility

 

Explanation:

 

The criteria for a functional First Referral Unit (FRU) include:

 

  1. 24-hour delivery services
  2. Emergency obstetric care, including surgical intervention (implying surgical intervention is a criterion)
  3. Blood storage facility
  4. RTI/STI management
  5. Newborn care
  6. Care of sick children
  7. Full range of family planning services, including safe abortion services (but not explicitly 24-hour MTP facility)
  8. Essential laboratory services
  9. Transport facility

 

The criteria "not included" for an FRU is the availability of a 24-hour MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) facility. It states that while 24-hour delivery services are available, a 24-hour MTP facility is not explicitly listed as a criterion for an FRU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a functional First Referral Unit (FRU), the criteria include 24-hour delivery services, emergency obstetric care (including surgical intervention), blood storage facility, RTI/STI management, newborn care, care of sick children, family planning services, essential laboratory services, and transport facility. However, the availability of a 24-hour MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy) facility is not explicitly a criterion for an FRU.

questions.text: Which of the following solid organ transplants have the highest chance of GVHD (graft versus host disease)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intestine

 

Explanation

 

Graft versus host disease (GVHD) is most commonly associated with hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, particularly allogeneic transplants. However, GVHD can also occur following solid organ transplants.

 

GVHD occurs when donor immune cells attack the recipient's tissues.

 

The intestine has the highest risk of GVHD among solid organ transplants due to the presence of abundant lymphoid tissue, including Peyer's patches, which contain many donor lymphocytes capable of attacking the recipient’s body.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Kidney: While kidney transplants can result in immune complications, the risk of GVHD is significantly lower compared to intestinal transplants.

 

Option B. Liver: The liver has a moderate risk of GVHD but not as high as the intestine.

 

Option D. Heart: The heart has a lower risk of GVHD compared to the intestine.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The intestine is the solid organ transplant with the highest risk of graft versus host disease due to the presence of lymphoid tissue containing donor lymphocytes.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the chest x-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cannonball metastases

 

Explanation

 

The chest x-ray shows multiple round, well-defined nodules distributed throughout the lung fields. These nodules are characteristic of cannonball metastases, which are metastatic lesions typically arising from primary cancers such as renal cell carcinoma, choriocarcinoma, or other malignancies that spread hematogenously to the lungs.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Septic emboli: These typically present with multiple small nodules with a predilection for the lung periphery and often cavitate.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Commonly presents with apical lesions, cavitary lesions, or a miliary pattern, not with multiple well-defined round nodules.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: Appears as a localized area of consolidation with a possible air-fluid level indicating cavitation.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Cannonball metastases present as multiple round, well-defined nodules scattered throughout the lung fields on chest x-ray, indicative of metastatic spread.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department following a suspected stroke. Upon assessment, it is noted that the patient is able to speak fluently, but the words uttered lack coherent meaning and lacks understanding. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Wernicke's aphasia

 

Explanation:


Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent speech that lacks coherent meaning. Patients with this condition can speak in long sentences with normal grammar, but their speech may include unnecessary or made-up words, making it difficult for others to understand.

 

This condition results from a lesion in Wernicke's area, which is responsible for language comprehension. In this scenario, the patient's ability to speak fluently yet produce nonsensical speech indicates a disruption in language comprehension, hallmark features of Wernicke's aphasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conduction aphasia: This type of aphasia is caused by a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus, which connects Wernicke's and Broca's areas. Patients with conduction aphasia have good comprehension and fluent speech but struggle with repetition and may make phonemic errors.

 

Option C. Anomic aphasia: Anomic aphasia is characterized by difficulty in finding the correct words, particularly nouns and verbs. Patients can understand speech and have fluent and grammatically correct speech but have trouble naming objects.

 

Option D. Broca's aphasia: This type of aphasia results from a lesion in Broca's area, leading to non-fluent, halting speech with good comprehension. Patients with Broca's aphasia have difficulty forming complete sentences and may produce short, broken phrases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's aphasia is identified by fluent but nonsensical speech due to impaired language comprehension.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is having tapping movements and lack of attention. He seems to be irritated, disturbing others, and restless most of the time. What should be the drug to be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylphenidate

 

The boy's symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and restlessness are indicative of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Methylphenidate is the first-line treatment for ADHD and is FDA-approved for use in children aged six years and older. It is a stimulant medication that has been found to be more effective in managing ADHD symptoms compared to non-stimulants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atomoxetine: A non-stimulant medication also used to treat ADHD but generally considered when stimulants are not effective or cause intolerable side effects.

 

Option C. Guanfacine: Another non-stimulant medication for ADHD, typically used as an adjunctive treatment or when stimulants are not suitable.

 

Option D. Clozapine: An antipsychotic medication used primarily for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and not indicated for ADHD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Methylphenidate is the drug of choice for managing ADHD in children six years and older due to its effectiveness in reducing symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity.

choices.text: Antibiotic eye drops post surgery

questions.text: After cataract surgery, endophthalmitis developed. How will you prevent post operative endophthalmitis?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Povidone iodine before surgery 

 

The most widely accepted method for preventing postoperative endophthalmitis is  Povidone-Iodine Before Surgery. It is recognized as a crucial step in the preoperative preparation of cataract surgery to minimize the risk of infection.

 

Povidone-iodine is an effective antiseptic that is widely used to reduce the risk of postoperative endophthalmitis. Applying povidone-iodine to the ocular surface before surgery can significantly decrease the number of pathogenic organisms in the operative field, thereby reducing the risk of postoperative infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intravitreal Anti-bacterial Injections: Intravitreal antibiotics are used as a treatment for established endophthalmitis, not as a prophylactic measure. Giving these injections as a routine prevention measure is not standard due to the potential risks, such as retinal detachment or injection-related infections.

 

Option C. Mydriatics Before Surgery: Mydriatics are medications used to dilate the pupils. They are important for cataract surgery because they provide the surgeon with better visibility of the lens. However, they do not have an antimicrobial effect and therefore would not prevent endophthalmitis.

 

Option D. Antibiotic Eye Drops Post-Surgery: Antibiotic eye drops post-surgery are commonly prescribed as a prophylactic measure to reduce the risk of infection. While their efficacy in preventing endophthalmitis is debated, they are still widely used in the postoperative period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent postoperative endophthalmitis following cataract surgery, the application of povidone-iodine on the ocular surface before surgery is the standard prophylactic procedure.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulbar urethral injury 

 

  • The image provided is a radiographic image, from a retrograde urethrogram, is of bulbar urethral injury with stricture. 
  • This injury occurs in the bulbar part of the urethra, which is located between the penile urethra and the membranous urethra. This type of injury can result from trauma, typically blunt perineal trauma, and can be identified on imaging by contrast extravasation or interruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Membranous urethral injury: This type of injury occurs in the membranous portion of the urethra, which is the shortest, least dilatable, and most fixed part of the urethra. It's often associated with pelvic fractures and can be identified by an abnormal urethrogram.

 

Option C. Penile stricture: A penile stricture is a narrowing of the penile urethra. It would be visualized on a urethrogram as a narrowed segment but would not show the contrast extravasation typically seen in traumatic injuries.

 

Option D. Prostate hyperplasia: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is an enlargement of the prostate gland and can cause obstruction of the urethral passage. On imaging, BPH would not present as a urethral injury but could show an enlarged prostate and possibly a post-void residual.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A bulbar urethral injury through radiographic imaging shows contrast extravasation or interruption in the bulbar urethra, indicative of trauma to this specific area.

choices.text: Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. On examination, following was seen on the CECT. All are false except: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tumor vessel lack contractility

 

Based on the provided CT image and the clinical context of recurrent bleeding, the most accurate statement is Tumor vessels lack contractility, which contributes to the propensity for bleeding in tumorous growths.

 

"Tumor vessel lack contractility" is a true statement about tumor vessels. They are often abnormally formed, with poor structural integrity and can lack the ability to contract, which normally helps control bleeding when vessels are injured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outgrown the blood supply: Suggests that the lesion has grown faster than the blood vessels can proliferate to support it. This can lead to areas of necrosis within tumours.

 

Option C. Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels: Implies that the normal vessels adjacent to the tumor are the source of bleeding. However, the bleeding associated with tumors is usually due to the tumor vessels themselves because they are prone to rupture, not the adjacent normal vessels.

 

Option D. Lacks capsule: May or may not be true depending on the type of tumor. Some benign tumors have a well-defined capsule, while malignant tumors often lack a capsule. However, this option does not directly relate to the issue of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor vessels are known to lack contractility, which contributes to the risk of bleeding associated with tumors, as they cannot constrict effectively to stop blood flow when damaged.

questions.text: What is the likely ECG change associated with Bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) QT prolongation

 

Explanation:

 

Bedaquiline is a modern anti-tubercular drug used primarily for the treatment of multidrug-resistant (MDR) and extensively drug-resistant (XDR) tuberculosis. One of the significant side effects of bedaquiline is QT prolongation.

 

QT prolongation is a measure of delayed ventricular repolarization, which can be seen on an ECG as an extended QT interval. This side effect is critical as it can predispose patients to potentially fatal arrhythmias, such as Torsades de Pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PR prolongation: This represents delayed atrioventricular conduction and is not a known side effect of bedaquiline.

 

Option C. ST elevation: This is typically associated with myocardial infarction and is not a side effect of bedaquiline.

 

Option D. Wide QRS: This indicates delayed intraventricular conduction and is not associated with bedaquiline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline, an important drug for treating MDR and XDR tuberculosis, is known for causing QT prolongation on ECG.

 

Note - The "Q" in bedaquiline can be a mnemonic to remember this important side effect.

questions.text: Arrange the stages of wound healing in the correct sequence: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, remodeling 

 

Wound healing is a complex and dynamic process involving a sequence of interrelated phases. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The correct sequence of wound healing stages is hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling, reflecting the orderly process of wound repair from clot formation to tissue regeneration and maturation.

questions.text: A patient has muffled heart sounds with low BP and elevated JVP. What is the likely JVP finding? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Absent y descent

 

The clinical presentation of muffled heart sounds, low blood pressure, and elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) suggests cardiac tamponade. In cardiac tamponade, the JVP is elevated, and the typical waveform finding is a prominent x descent with a blunted or diminished y descent. This pattern is due to the restricted filling of the right atrium and ventricle during diastole because of the pressure exerted by the pericardial fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent a wave: This is seen in patients with atrial fibrillation, where there is no organized atrial contraction.

 

Option C. Prominent y descent: This is seen in patients with constrictive pericarditis, where there is a rapid early diastolic filling, known as Friedrich's sign.

 

Option D. Absent x descent: This is a feature of tricuspid regurgitation, where the backward flow of blood during systole reduces the x descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the JVP waveform shows a prominent x descent with an absent or blunted y descent. This is due to the restricted filling of the right heart chambers caused by the pericardial fluid, leading to characteristic clinical signs such as muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and elevated JVP

choices.text: Take 2 pills the same day and continue
Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week

questions.text: A 23y woman who is using the combined oral contraceptive pill misses 2 pills in the 3rd week of the pack. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Take 2 pills the same day and continue

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, the missed pill guidelines are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and continue the packet: Simply continuing the packet without taking the missed pills would increase the risk of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week: This option is more applicable for missing three or more pills, where additional precautions and possibly emergency contraception might be necessary.

 

Option D. Start a new packet immediately: This approach is necessary only when three or more pills are missed in the third week, to avoid a pill-free interval and ensure continued contraceptive protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If one or two combined oral contraceptive pills are missed in the third week, the woman should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, then continue the pack as scheduled, taking two pills in one day if necessary. This minimizes the risk of pregnancy.

questions.text: During delivery of a 24 y primigravida, the head comes out, but the shoulders fail to deliver. McRoberts maneuver is immediately done but the shoulders still fail to deliver. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supra-pubic pressure

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of shoulder dystocia, where the baby's shoulders fail to deliver after the head, specific maneuvers are performed in a stepwise manner. The McRoberts maneuver, which involves hyperflexion and abduction of the mother's thighs onto her abdomen, is the first step and is successful in resolving many cases by reducing the angle of the pelvis.

 

If the McRoberts maneuver is unsuccessful, the next step is to apply supra-pubic pressure. This involves an assistant applying pressure just above the pubic bone to help dislodge the anterior shoulder from behind the pubic symphysis. This maneuver is often performed simultaneously with the McRoberts maneuver but is listed next in the shoulder dystocia drill.

 

HELPER mnemonic from Baxley and Gobbo, 2004, is a guideline for managing obstetric emergencies:

 

  • H: Call for Help
  • E: Evaluate for Episiotomy
  • L: Legs (The McRoberts manoeuvre)
  • P: Suprapubic Pressure
  • E: Enter manoeuvres (internal rotation)
  • R: Remove the posterior arm
  • R: Roll the patient (Gaskin maneuver)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delivery of the posterior shoulder: This is a subsequent step if supra-pubic pressure and internal rotation maneuver fail.

 

Option B. Internal rotation: This includes maneuver like the Woods corkscrew or Rubin maneuver and is considered after supra-pubic pressure fails.

 

Option D. Zavanelli maneuver: This is a last-resort measure where the baby's head is pushed back into the birth canal for an emergency cesarean section.

 

Educational objective:

 

If the McRoberts maneuver fails to resolve shoulder dystocia, the next step is to apply supra-pubic pressure to help dislodge the anterior shoulder.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the Flexor Carpi Radialis.
  • The flexor carpi radialis muscle is a long, superficial muscle of the forearm that belongs to the anterior muscle group and lies in the first layer.
  • It is a relatively thin muscle located on the anterior part of the forearm.
  • It arises in the humerus epicondyle, close to the wrist area.
  • It is a superficial muscle that becomes very visible as the wrist comes into flexion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Flexor Carpi Ulnaris: The flexor carpi ulnaris can be palpated by locating the bony landmarks associated to the muscle including the medial epicondyle, the olecranon process and the pisiform bone. After identifying the bony landmarks, the person is asked to perform ulnar deviation and wrist flexion simultaneously, which will help locate the FCU muscle.

 

 

Option. C. Palmaris Longus: The Palmaris longus (PL) muscle is a long, slender muscle which is usually present in the superficial volar compartment of the forearm, interposed between the Flexor Carpi Ulnaris and the Flexor Carpi Radialis muscles. This muscle is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

 

Option. D. Extensor Carpi Radialis: Extensor carpi radialis is a muscle that can be found in the posterior compartment of the forearm. It is partly overlapped by brachioradialis and these muscles often blend together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The marked muscle tendon in the image is of the flexor carpi radialis muscle.

questions.text: According to MTP Act, MTP at 22 weeks of gestation due to contraceptive failure requires opinion from:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cannot be done

 

Explanation:

 

According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act in India, MTP at 22 weeks of gestation due to contraceptive failure cannot be legally performed. The MTP Act allows termination of pregnancy due to contraceptive failure only up to 20 weeks of gestation.

 

For pregnancies between 20 and 24 weeks, MTP is permitted only in certain aggravated conditions, such as:

 

  • Rape
  • Minors
  • Disabled women
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Widowhood

 

Contraceptive failure is not included in the list of aggravated conditions for which MTP is allowed between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option. A. 2 doctors: This would be the requirement for MTP between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation in the case of aggravated conditions, but not for contraceptive failure.

 

Option. B. 1 doctor: This is the requirement for MTP up to 20 weeks of gestation, but not for the given scenario of 22 weeks due to contraceptive failure.

 

Option. C. Medical board: A medical board's opinion is required for MTP beyond 24 weeks of gestation, and only in cases of congenital anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with infertility, and he has chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener's syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Kartagener's syndrome, a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia, is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus.

 

Infertility in males is also a common feature due to the dysfunction of cilia and flagella, leading to impaired sperm motility.

 

Situs inversus is a condition where the major visceral organs are mirrored from their normal positions, often seen in Kartagener's syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: While patients with cystic fibrosis may also present with sinusitis, infertility, and bronchiectasis, they do not typically have situs inversus, which is specific to Kartagener's syndrome.

 

Option C. Mucoviscidosis: This is another term for cystic fibrosis, and thus the same reasoning applies as above.

 

Option D. Klinefelter syndrome: This genetic disorder can present with infertility but does not include chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, or situs inversus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by the triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus, and is associated with infertility in males due to primary ciliary dyskinesia.

questions.text: A diabetic patient's blood sample was taken in a grey top vacutainer. Which of the following is added for the correct estimate of blood glucose? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride

 

Explanation:

 

For accurate measurement of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients, the blood sample is collected in a grey top vacutainer containing sodium fluoride. Sodium fluoride acts as a glycolysis inhibitor, preventing the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells. This ensures that the glucose levels in the sample remain stable until the analysis is performed, providing an accurate representation of the patient's blood glucose concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium citrate is used as an anticoagulant and is present in blue top vacutainers, which are typically used for coagulation studies and not for glucose estimation.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is an anticoagulant used in lavender top vacutainers, which are commonly used for complete blood count (CBC) and other hematological tests, but not for glucose estimation.

 

Option D. Heparin is an anticoagulant found in green top vacutainers, which are used for various biochemical tests, but not specifically for glucose estimation in diabetic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride, present in grey top vacutainers, inhibits glycolysis and prevents the breakdown of glucose, ensuring an accurate measurement of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Captopril

 

Explanation

 

Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, and ACE inhibitors are known to be absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy. They can cause fetal toxicity, particularly in the second and third trimesters, leading to complications such as renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, pulmonary hypoplasia, and even fetal death. Therefore, ACE inhibitors should be avoided in pregnant women.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Paracetamol: Generally considered safe for use during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Cefixime: A cephalosporin antibiotic, also considered safe during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Azithromycin: An antibiotic that is commonly used and considered safe during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

ACE inhibitors, such as captopril, are absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of fetal toxicity and complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with violaceous plane topped papules associated with pruritus over wrist and antecubital fossae for 2 months. The lesions have a characteristic shiny surface and are arranged in a linear pattern. What is the first line of treatment in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical steroids

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is topical steroids.

 

The patient presents with classic signs of lichen planus, which includes violaceous (purple) plane-topped papules that are intensely pruritic (itchy). These lesions are commonly found on the flexor surfaces such as the wrists and antecubital fossae.

 

Lichen planus is a self-limiting condition that usually resolves spontaneously within about 2 years. However, due to the extreme itching, symptomatic treatment is necessary.

 

Topical steroids are the first-line treatment for localized lichen planus, providing relief from itching and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antifungals: These are not used in the treatment of lichen planus, as it is not a fungal infection.

 

Option B. Oral steroids: While oral steroids can be used in more extensive cases of lichen planus, they are not the first-line treatment for localized lesions.

 

Option D. Phototherapy: This can be used in extensive cases but is not the first-line treatment for localized lichen planus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen planus, characterized by violaceous, pruritic, plane-topped papules with a shiny surface, is best treated initially with topical steroids when the condition is localized. ​

questions.text: When does stranger anxiety appear in a child? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6-7 months

 

Stranger anxiety typically emerges by 6-7 months. At this age, infant also can transfer objects from one hand to another.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8-10 months: Sitting without support comes by eight months

 

Option C. 12 months: A Baby can independently stand by 12 months

 

Option D. 15 months: A baby can independently walk by 15 months and run by 18 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stranger anxiety typically emerges by 6-7 months of age.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of ERCP? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatitis

 

Many complications can occur with Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), a procedure used to diagnose and treat conditions of the bile ducts and pancreatic duct. 

 

This is the inflammation of the pancreas and is the most common complication of ERCP seen in 1-3% patients. It can occur due to irritation or injury to the pancreas during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal perforation: This is a serious but less common complication of ERCP. It can occur when the endoscope or the instruments used during the procedure inadvertently create a hole in the intestinal wall.

 

Option B. Cholangitis: This is an infection of the bile duct system. It can occur if bacteria spread during the procedure, especially if there is an obstruction within the bile ducts that has not been adequately drained.

 

Option C. Hemorrhage: Bleeding can occur, particularly if a sphincterotomy (cutting of the sphincter of Oddi to access the bile duct) is performed. While bleeding is a risk, it is not the most common complication.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-ERCP pancreatitis is the most common complication following ERCP, necessitating careful risk assessment and patient monitoring post-procedure.

questions.text: Xerophthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of bitot's spot is more than: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.8%

 

Explanation:

 

One of the criteria for considering xerophthalmia as a public health problem is if the prevalence of bitot's spots (a sign of vitamin A deficiency) is more than 0.5% in the population. The specifically asks about the prevalence of bitot's spots, and the option closest to 0.5% is 0.8%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevalence criteria for determining the Xerophthalmia problem in a community: (Preschool children 6 months- 6 years).

questions.text: Which nutrient deficiency is cause of night blindness? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Night blindness, or nyctalopia, is a common symptom of vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment found in the retina that is necessary for vision in low-light conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency does not typically cause night blindness. Vitamin C is important for overall health, but it is not directly involved in the visual process.

 

Option C. Vitamin B: Vitamin B deficiencies, such as vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency, can lead to various neurological symptoms but are not known to cause night blindness.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency primarily affects bone health and calcium metabolism. It is not associated with night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: Glucose load for screening diabetes in pregnancy is:  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 75 gm

 

Explanation:

 

According to the majority of guidelines, including the WHO, IADPSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups), and DIPSI (Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Group India) guidelines, a 75 gm glucose load is used for screening diabetes in pregnancy.

 

Note - The ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists) guidelines follow a two-step process where the first step involves a 50 gm glucose load for screening, and if positive, a 100 gm glucose load for confirmation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25 gm: Not used in any standard screening protocol.

 

Option B. 50 gm: Used in the initial step of the ACOG two-step screening process, but not the most common single-step screening load.

 

Option D. 100 gm: Used in the second step of the ACOG two-step screening process, not for initial screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For screening diabetes in pregnancy, the 75 gm glucose load is widely used according to various international guidelines, including WHO and IADPSG.

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization
Do clerical work and check ECG

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with a history of beta thalassemia undergoes a blood transfusion. During the transfusion, she develops anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion

 

Explanation

 

The development of anxiety, hypotension, and fever during a blood transfusion indicates a possible acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening reaction often due to ABO incompatibility. The immediate and most critical step in managing this reaction is to stop the transfusion immediately.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Stop the blood transfusion and restart after stabilization: This may be considered in mild allergic reactions with symptoms like urticaria and itching, but not in the presence of hypotension and fever.

 

Option C. Do clerical work and check ECG: These are part of the subsequent steps, but the immediate action is to stop the transfusion.

 

Option D. Administer Hydrocortisone: This may be appropriate for mild allergic reactions but is not the first line of action in suspected severe transfusion reactions.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In any suspected severe transfusion reaction, immediately stop the transfusion to prevent further complications.

questions.text: A man comes to the OPD with complaints of sinusitis and breathing difficulty. He also gives a history of infertility for the past few years. On further examination, thoracic cavity organs were found to be on the opposite side. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome


Kartagener syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (a condition where the thoracic and abdominal organs are mirrored from their normal positions).

 

The underlying cause of Kartagener syndrome is a defect in the structure and function of cilia, which are hair-like structures that line the respiratory tract and other parts of the body. These cilia are responsible for moving mucus and other substances along the respiratory tract, as well as for ensuring proper placement of organs during embryonic development.

 

In this case, the patient's symptoms of sinusitis, breathing difficulties, and history of infertility, combined with the finding of situs inversus, strongly suggest Kartagener syndrome. The infertility is due to immotile sperm in males, which is also caused by defective cilia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: This condition typically presents with recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, and chest tightness. It is not associated with situs inversus or infertility.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It is not associated with situs inversus, sinusitis, or bronchiectasis.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Although it can cause chronic cough and sinusitis, it is not associated with situs inversus or infertility. Bronchiectasis is a condition where the bronchial tubes are permanently widened, leading to frequent lung infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is diagnosed based on the presence of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus, and infertility, all of which result from defective ciliary function.

choices.text: NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation
Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition
Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male presented to the emergency with sudden onset of abdominal pain radiating to the back, which is aggravated on lying down. Serum amylase and lipase levels are elevated. Which of the following should be avoided in managing the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infusion of 5% Dextrose

 

Explanation

 

The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of acute pancreatitis, a condition confirmed by elevated serum amylase and lipase levels.

 

Infusion of 5% Dextrose: This should be avoided in managing acute pancreatitis. Patients often experience hyperglycemia, and the administration of dextrose could worsen this condition. Preferred intravenous fluids for rehydration and initial resuscitation in acute pancreatitis are normal saline (NS) or Ringer's lactate (RL).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation: Keeping the patient NPO (nothing by mouth) is crucial to avoid stimulating the pancreas and exacerbating the condition.

 

Option C. Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition: This is correct. Early enteral nutrition is preferred over total parenteral nutrition as it helps maintain gut integrity and reduce the risk of infection.

 

Option D. Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis: This is also correct. For mild cases, early reintroduction of oral feeding is beneficial.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the infusion of 5% dextrose due to the risk of exacerbating hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A patient with suspected tuberculosis underwent CBNAAT testing and is started on HRZE. CBNAAT is helpful for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation

 

Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) is a rapid molecular test for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and resistance to rifampicin (RIF).

 

It is highly effective for diagnosing tuberculosis and determining rifampicin resistance by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance. This allows for quick initiation of appropriate therapy, especially important in cases of drug-resistant TB

 

  • MTB Detection: CBNAAT can confirm the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Rifampicin Resistance: By identifying rpoB gene mutations, CBNAAT can detect rifampicin resistance, which is a critical factor in managing and treating TB.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB): While CBNAAT detects MTB, it also provides crucial information about rifampicin resistance, making option B more accurate.

 

Option C. MTB + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not detect isoniazid resistance directly.

 

Option D. MTB + Ethambutol and Rifampicin: CBNAAT does not provide information about ethambutol resistance.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

CBNAAT is a rapid and effective test for detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with complaints of dizziness and palpitations. Her ECG was done and shown below. What is the best treatment for this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with dizziness and palpitations, and her ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia.

 

This is characteristic of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), specifically AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), the most common type of PSVT. The QRS complexes are narrow (less than 0.12 seconds), and the rhythm is regular with no clearly discernible P waves in their usual locations.

 

The drug of choice for PSVT, especially AVNRT, is adenosine. Adenosine rapidly terminates the tachycardia by transiently blocking the AV node, which disrupts the reentrant circuit responsible for the tachycardia.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is used for wide complex tachycardias and is not the first-line treatment for narrow complex tachycardias like PSVT.

 

Option C. Beta-blocker: Beta-blockers can be used if adenosine is not available, but they are not the first-line treatment.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Digoxin is used for rate control in atrial fibrillation and heart failure but is not effective for terminating PSVT.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The best treatment for a regular narrow complex tachycardia like PSVT is adenosine, which acts quickly to terminate the arrhythmia by blocking AV nodal conduction.

questions.text: According to triage, which of the following colors indicates the highest priority?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

Explanation:

 

In the triage system, the red color indicates the highest priority. The triage categories and their corresponding colors are as follows:

 

Red: Category 1, highest priority. Patients requiring immediate resuscitation or life-saving surgery within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: Category 2, high priority. Possible resuscitation or possible surgery within 6 to 24 hours.

 

Option C. Green: Category 3, low priority. Ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries.

 

Option D. Black: Least priority, includes dead and moribund patients.

 

The red category, which is assigned to patients requiring immediate life-saving intervention, is the highest priority in the triage system.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The structure marked by the arrow is derived from which embryonic arch? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure in the image is identified as the malleus.

 

The first pharyngeal arch, also known as the mandibular arch, is responsible for the formation of several structures in the head and neck region.

 

  1. Malleus and Incus Formation: The 1st pharyngeal arch is crucial in forming the malleus and incus, two of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. The cartilage component of this arch, known as Meckel's cartilage, gives rise to these ossicles.
  2. Other Structures from the 1st Pharyngeal Arch: Apart from the malleus and incus, the 1st pharyngeal arch also contributes to the formation of the maxilla, mandible, sphenomandibular ligament, and parts of the middle ear, including the anterior malleolar ligament.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The 2nd pharyngeal arch (hyoid arch) primarily forms the stapes (another auditory ossicle), styloid process, stylohyoid ligament, and parts of the hyoid bone.

 

Option C. 3rd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The 3rd pharyngeal arch contributes to the formation of the greater horn and lower part of the hyoid bone.

 

Option D. Neuroectoderm: This is incorrect in the context of the malleus. While neural crest cells, derived from neuroectoderm, play a significant role in the development of many craniofacial structures, the malleus specifically develops from the 1st pharyngeal arch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

1st arch cartilage: Meckle’s cartilage → 5 ‘M’

 

1. Malleus & Incus

2. Malleolar (Anterior) ligament

3. Spheno-Mandibular ligament

4. Mandible

5. Maxilla

 

2nd arch cartilage: Reichert cartilage → 5 ‘S’

 

1. Stapes (except footplate & Otic capsule)

2. Styloid process

3. Stylohyoid ligament

4. Smaller cornu of hyoid

5. Superior ½ of body of the hyoid

 

3rd arch cartilage:

 

1. Greater cornu of hyoid

2. Inferior ½ of hyoid

 

4th & 6th arch cartilage:

 

-  Laryngeal cartilage

questions.text: A young girl presented with delayed puberty. On examination, secondary sexual characters were absent, the nipples were widely spaced, and she was short in height. The most likely karyotype would be? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45XO

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described in the question are characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is caused by the presence of only one X chromosome (45XO karyotype). The key features of Turner syndrome include:

 

  • Delayed puberty and absence of secondary sexual characteristics: Due to ovarian dysgenesis or streak ovaries, which lead to primary ovarian insufficiency.
  • Short stature: Almost all girls with Turner syndrome are short.
  • Widely spaced nipples and shield-like chest: These are typical physical features of Turner syndrome.
  • Webbed neck (common feature).

 

Note - 46XXX: This karyotype, also known as triple X syndrome, typically presents with taller than average stature and normal sexual development, which does not match the described clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The karyotype 45XO is associated with Turner syndrome, which is characterized by delayed puberty, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, short stature, widely spaced nipples, and other distinctive physical features.

questions.text: During a physical exam, a physician palpates the carotid pulse to assess circulation. At which anatomical landmark is the common carotid artery pulse most reliably palpated?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cricoid cartilage

 

Explanation:

 

The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level. The "magic of C6" is an important anatomical landmark.

 

At the C6 level, there is the cricopharyngeal junction, the cricoid cartilage, and the pulsation of the common carotid artery can be felt.

 

The common carotid artery lies just anterior to the carotid tubercle (also known as the Chassaignac tubercle), which is the anterior tubercle of the transverse process of the C6 vertebra. An artery is palpable when it lies close to a firm bony structure, and in this case, the common carotid artery is palpable due to its proximity to the carotid tubercle at the C6 level.

 

HNF Cadaveric section

 

 

Other Options:
