Option B. Laryngeal prominence: The laryngeal prominence, also known as the Adam's apple, is located at a higher level than the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct landmark for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Option C. Suprasternal notch: The suprasternal notch is located inferior to the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct level for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Option D. Angle of mandible: The angle of the mandible is located superior and lateral to the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct landmark for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level. The carotid tubercle of the C6 vertebra serves as a bony landmark for the pulsation of the common carotid artery.

questions.text: Serology of IPV vaccine strains is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1, type 2, type 3

 

Explanation:

 

The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) contains all three strains of the poliovirus: Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3. Although India switched from the trivalent Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to the bivalent OPV (containing only Type 1 and Type 3) as part of the global switch program in April 2016.

 

The IPV introduced in the national immunization schedule still contains all three poliovirus strains. It is a trivalent vaccine, containing Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3 strains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) introduced in the national immunization schedule of India contains all three strains of the poliovirus: Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3, making it a trivalent vaccine.

questions.text: A mentally challenged female requires consent for MTP. The consent can be given to her by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Legal guardian

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a mentally challenged female requiring consent for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP), the consent must be given by her legal guardian.

 

According to Indian law, consent from a guardian is required in two situations:

 

  1. If the person seeking MTP is below 18 years of age.
  2. If the person seeking MTP is mentally challenged.

 

In other cases, the consent of a guardian is not mandatory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Husband/Partner: While it is advisable to obtain consent from the husband or partner to avoid potential divorce proceedings, it is not a legal requirement for MTP.

 

Option. C. Herself: A mentally challenged female is not considered capable of giving informed consent for MTP.

 

Option. D. Magistrate: A magistrate's consent is not required for MTP in the case of a mentally challenged female.

 

Additional information:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a mentally challenged female requiring consent for MTP, the consent must be provided by her legal guardian, as she is not considered capable of giving informed consent herself.

questions.text: Which toxin can cause acute liver failure and hematuria? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amanita phylloides

 

Explanation:

 

Amanita phylloides, also known as the "death cap" mushroom, contains toxins that can cause both acute liver failure and hematuria. The mushroom contains amatoxins, which are responsible for the severe liver damage, and can also affect the kidneys, leading to renal damage and hematuria. This combination of liver and kidney damage is a characteristic feature of Amanita phylloides poisoning.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option. A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid that can cause respiratory depression and constipation, but it is not typically associated with acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

Option. B. Ketamine: Ketamine is an anesthetic that can cause dissociative effects and hallucinations, but it is not known to cause acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

Option. C. Belladonna: Atropa Belladonna, also known as deadly nightshade, contains anticholinergic compounds that can cause symptoms such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia. However, it is not associated with acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amanita phylloides, or the "death cap" mushroom, is a toxin that can cause both acute liver failure and hematuria due to the presence of amatoxins. This combination of liver and kidney damage is a characteristic feature of Amanita phylloides poisoning

questions.text: In primary accidental hypothermia, what is the usual rate of rewarming with passive external rewarming?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5-2°C per hour

 

Explanation

 

Primary accidental hypothermia refers to an unintentional drop in core body temperature due to environmental exposure. The management of hypothermia includes rewarming strategies, which can be classified into passive and active rewarming.

 

Passive External Rewarming: This method involves insulating the patient by covering them with blankets and ensuring that the head is also covered. It relies on the patient's own heat production to gradually increase body temperature.

 

According to standard medical guidelines and Harrison's principles, passive external rewarming can increase the core body temperature by approximately 0.5 to 2°C per hour.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In cases of primary accidental hypothermia, passive external rewarming can raise the core body temperature by 0.5 to 2°C per hour.

 

Additional Information –

 

Hypothermia based on core body temperature and corresponding treatment methods:

 

  1. Mild Hypothermia:
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 35 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Passive external rewarming is the treatment of choice.
  2. Moderate Hypothermia:
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 32 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Requires both passive and active rewarming methods. Passive rewarming involves external methods, while active rewarming can be either external or internal.
  3. Severe Hypothermia
    • Core Body Temperature: Less than 28 degrees Celsius.
    • Treatment: Requires both passive and active rewarming methods. Passive rewarming involves external methods, while active rewarming can be either external or internal.

questions.text: Which HLA is associated with Reiter’s syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HLA B27

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS

 

  • Reactive arthritis (ReA) is inflammatory arthritis that manifests after several days to weeks after a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection.
  • It is also described as a classic triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. However, a majority of patients do not present with the classic triad.
  • It is known to be triggered by a bacterial infection, particularly of the genitourinary (Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhea, Mycoplasma hominis, and Ureaplasma urealyticum) or gastrointestinal (GI) tract (Salmonella enteritidis, Shigella flexneri, and S. disenteriae, Yersinia enterocolitica, Campylobacter jejuni, Clostridium difficile).
  • The incidence is about 2-4% after a urogenital infection, mainly with Chlamydia trachomatis, and varies from 0-15% after gastrointestinal infections with Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or Yersinia.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Reactive arthritis is an immune-mediated syndrome triggered by a recent infection.
    • It is hypothesized that T lymphocytes are induced by bacterial fragments such as lipopolysaccharide and nucleic acids when invasive bacteria reach the systemic circulation.
    • These activated cytotoxic-T cells attack the synovium and other self-antigens through molecular mimicry.
    • It is believed that anti-bacterial cytokine response is also impaired in reactive arthritis, resulting in decreased bacteria elimination.
    • The prevalence of HLA-B27 in reactive arthritis is estimated at 30-50% in patients with reactive arthritis.
    • HLA-B27 should not be used as a diagnostic tool for diagnosing acute ReA.
    • The presence of HLA-B27 is believed to potentiate reactive arthritis by presenting bacterial antigens to T cells, altering the self-tolerance of the host immune system, increasing tumor necrosis factor-alpha production, promoting the invasion of microbes in the gut, and delaying clearance of causative organisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. HLA DR3: This allele is more commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus, rather than with reactive arthritis.

 

Option. C. HLA DR4: This allele is most notably associated with rheumatoid arthritis, especially in individuals who have severe disease forms.

 

Option. D. HLA DQ8: This HLA subtype is also more commonly associated with type 1 diabetes and not typically linked with reactive arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HLA-B27 is strongly associated with reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) and other spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis.
  • Approximately 75-80% of patients with reactive arthritis test positive for HLA-B27.
  • But it should not be used as a diagnostic tool for acute ReA.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with dysphagia for solid foods more than liquid for the last 3 months and has severe cachexia. What will be the best investigation to establish the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy with Biopsy

 

The patient's symptoms of dysphagia for solid foods more than liquids, coupled with severe cachexia, are highly suggestive of esophageal cancer.

 

Dysphagia for solids more than liquids typically indicates a structural problem in the esophagus. Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best initial investigation to directly visualize the esophagus and obtain tissue samples for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manometry: This is used to diagnose neuromuscular disorders of the esophagus, such as achalasia, but not typically used as the first-line investigation for suspected structural problems.

 

Option C. Barium swallow: This can provide imaging of the esophagus but is not as definitive as endoscopy with biopsy for diagnosing cancer.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT): This is used for staging of cancer once the diagnosis is established but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with dysphagia predominantly for solids, especially with associated severe cachexia, upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the best investigation to establish the diagnosis, often indicating esophageal cancer.

questions.text: In measurement of rifled barrel weapon, caliber depends on: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distance between two opposite lands

 

Explanation:

 

In a rifled firearm, the barrel's interior has alternating projecting parts called lands and the adjacent parts called grooves. The caliber of a rifled barrel weapon is defined as the distance between two opposite lands, which represents the diameter of the rifled firearm.

 

 

This is different from a smooth bore firearm, where the diameter is simply called the bore, as there are no lands or grooves present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Distance between two opposite grooves: The distance between two opposite grooves is not used to determine the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon. The caliber is measured between the lands, not the grooves.

 

Option. C. Number of lead pellets: The number of lead pellets is not related to the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon. Lead pellets are typically associated with shotguns, which have smooth bore barrels.

 

Option. D. Mass and velocity: While the mass and velocity of a projectile are important factors in the performance of a firearm, they do not determine the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The caliber of a rifled barrel weapon is determined by the distance between two opposite lands, which represents the diameter of the rifled firearm's barrel. This is different from a smooth bore firearm, where the diameter is simply called the bore.

questions.text: Who will give permission for MTP for a woman who is mentally unsound? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legal guardian

 

Explanation:

 

For a woman who is mentally unsound, the permission for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) cannot be given by herself due to her compromised mental state. The legal requirement is that the consent must come from her legal guardian. A legal guardian is an individual who has been legally appointed to care for and make decisions on behalf of the mentally unsound person. This guardian may be a parent or another individual assigned by the court, but the key requirement is that the guardian must have legal authority to make such decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Self: A mentally unsound woman is not legally capable of giving consent for MTP due to her compromised mental state.

 

Option B. Partner: While a partner may be involved in the decision-making process, they do not have the legal authority to give permission for MTP unless they are also the legal guardian.

 

Option C. Parent: Although a parent might be a legal guardian, simply being a parent does not automatically grant the authority. The person must be legally recognized as the guardian.

 

Educational objective:

 

The legal guardian must give permission for MTP for a woman who is mentally unsound, ensuring that the decision is made in the best interest of the patient.

questions.text: Which biological method will you use to control mosquito larvae? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gambusia fish

 

The biological method for controlling mosquito larvae involves the use of larvivorous fishes, such as Gambusia, Poecilia, and Labister. These fish species feed on mosquito larvae, helping to control their population.

 

Note - Antilarval chemical method – Paris green (stomach poison)

 

Methods like spraying (insecticides – DDT, pyrethrum, malathion) and distributing nets are measures to control adult mosquitoes but not the larvae stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDT Spray 3 times a month - This option is incorrect because spraying is a chemical method used to control adult mosquitoes, not the larvae stage.

 

Option B. Distribute nets - This option is incorrect because mosquito nets are a physical barrier used to prevent adult mosquitoes from biting, but they do not control the larvae stage.

 

Option D. Pyrethrum spray - This option is incorrect because pyrethrum spray is a chemical method used to control adult mosquitoes, not the larvae stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The biological method for controlling mosquito larvae involves the use of larvivorous fish species, such as Gambusia, which feed on and help to control the population of mosquito larvae in their aquatic habitats.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes came to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and frequent urination. His FBS = 144 mg/dl & PPBS = 210 mg/dl. What is the target HbA1c for adequate control of diabetes? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 7.0

 

Explanation

 

The universal target HbA1c for adequate control of diabetes is generally less than 7%. This target helps in reducing the risk of diabetic complications. However, it is important to consider individual patient factors when setting targets.

 

In very old and frail patients, a less stringent target of less than 8% may be appropriate to avoid the risks of hypoglycemia and other complications. Since the options do not include 8%, the standard target of less than 7% is selected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The target HbA1c for most patients with diabetes to ensure adequate control is less than 7%, though this may vary based on individual patient circumstances.

questions.text: What is the antihypertensive of choice in a 28-week preeclamptic woman with asthma? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Explanation:

 

In managing preeclampsia, labetalol is often the first-line antihypertensive due to its efficacy and safety profile in pregnancy. However, labetalol is both an alpha and beta-blocker, and its use can exacerbate asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Therefore, it is contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Nifedipine: This is a calcium channel blocker that is safe and effective in pregnancy. It does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects of labetalol, making it the antihypertensive of choice for a preeclamptic woman with asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral labetalol and Option B. IV labetalol: Both forms are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to the risk of bronchoconstriction.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: This angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause fetal renal hypoperfusion and oligohydramnios, among other teratogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nifedipine is the antihypertensive of choice in a preeclamptic woman with asthma due to its safety profile and lack of broncho constrictive effects.

questions.text: A patient presents with foul-smell from nose and nasal obstruction. The image of the finding is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Based on the image showing a significant amount of crusting and given the symptom of foul smell, the most likely diagnosis is Option A, Atrophic rhinitis.

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by a thickening and drying out of the mucous membrane in the nose, leading to crusting, a widened nasal cavity, and a foul smell. The image showing thick, greenish crusts is consistent with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinitis sicca: Is associated with dryness of the nasal mucosa but without the severe crusting or foul smell typically seen in atrophic rhinitis. It usually does not present with the extent of crusting or debris depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Rhinosporidiosis: Is a chronic infection caused by the organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It typically presents with polyp-like masses in the nasal passage, which may be friable and bleed easily. The image does not clearly show polyp-like structures, which would be more indicative of this condition.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis: Is an allergic response causing symptoms like sneezing, itching, and a runny nose, often related to seasonal allergens. It does not cause the thick crusting or the foul smell evident in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of Atrophic Rhinitis is crucial, especially the distinctive symptoms of nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge, along with visible crusting as seen in the provided image. This helps differentiate it from other forms of rhinitis, which do not present with such severe crusting or malodour.

questions.text: In the presented spirometry image, what term corresponds to the point labelled as 'F'? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Forced vital capacity

 

Explanation:

 

The spirometry diagram illustrates various lung volumes and capacities –

 

The point labelled 'F' corresponds to the forced vital capacity (FVC), which is the maximum amount of air a person can forcibly exhale from their lungs after taking the deepest breath possible. It includes the tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV).

 

In this context:

 

  • Tidal Volume (TV): The amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breathing (A).
  • Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV): The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation (B).
  • Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV): The additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation (C).
  • Forced Vital Capacity (FVC): The total volume of air that can be exhaled forcefully after taking a deep breath (TV + IRV + ERV) (F).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Expiratory reserve volume: This is the additional volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled after normal exhalation, represented by 'C' in the diagram.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: This is the total volume of air in the lungs after a maximum inhalation, including the residual volume. It is not represented by 'F'.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: This is the total volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal exhalation, represented by 'D' in the diagram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spirometry diagram

choices.text: Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline
Continue the blood transfusion and perform an ECG
Investigate for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process
Administer corticosteroids and monitor vital signs

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a known history of thalassemia undergoes blood transfusion. Following the transfusion, she developed symptoms of anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline

 

The patient's symptoms of anxiety, hypotension, and fever after a blood transfusion suggest a possible transfusion reaction, which could be due to an ABO blood group incompatibility. In such cases, the immediate and appropriate step is to stop the blood transfusion immediately to prevent further complications. Pushing normal saline helps to dilute the mismatched blood and flush out the incompatible components from the patient's circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Continuing the blood transfusion in the presence of these symptoms would be inappropriate and potentially harmful, as it could exacerbate the transfusion reaction.

 

Option C. While investigating for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process is important, it should be done after stopping the transfusion and stabilizing the patient's condition.

 

Option D. Administering corticosteroids may be helpful in managing severe transfusion reactions, but stopping the transfusion and pushing normal saline are the immediate and crucial steps to be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of suspected transfusion reactions, characterized by symptoms like anxiety, hypotension, and fever, the immediate action should be to stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Which receptor plays a crucial role in glucose uptake by skeletal muscles?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GLUT 4

 

Explanation

 

GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter responsible for insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in skeletal muscles, as well as in cardiac muscles and adipose tissues. Upon insulin binding, GLUT 4 translocates to the cell membrane, allowing glucose to enter the cells and be utilized for energy or stored as glycogen. This process is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels postprandially (after meals).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT 1: GLUT 1 is involved in basal glucose uptake and is widely distributed in tissues such as the brain, placenta, kidneys, and red blood cells.

 

Option B. GLUT 2: GLUT 2 is found in the liver, ancreas, intestines, and kidneys, playing a role in glucose absorption, glycogen formation, insulin secretion, and reabsorption processes.

 

Option C. GLUT 3: GLUT 3, similar to GLUT 1, is involved in basal glucose uptake and is primarily located in the brain, placenta, and kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT Transporters

questions.text: A vegan lady came with features of anemia. She is likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

Explanation:

 

Vegans, who follow a diet that excludes all animal products, are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is primarily found in animal-derived foods such as meat, dairy products, and eggs. Since vegans do not consume these foods, they are prone to developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D deficiency is not specifically related to a vegan diet. While vegans may need to supplement vitamin D from non-animal sources, the question does not provide enough information to suggest that this is the likely deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin A deficiency is also not directly related to a vegan diet. Vegans can obtain sufficient vitamin A from plant-based sources such as leafy green vegetables, carrots, and sweet potatoes.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency is unlikely in a vegan diet, as many fruits and vegetables are rich sources of vitamin C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vegans are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia, as vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal-derived foods.

questions.text: Which of the following agents has blood:gas partition coefficient similar to nitrous oxide? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Desflurane

 

The blood-gas partition coefficient of an inhalational anesthetic agent measures its solubility in blood. Agents with a lower blood-gas partition coefficient, like nitrous oxide, have faster onset and recovery times. Desflurane has a similar low blood-gas partition coefficient to nitrous oxide, resulting in rapid induction and emergence.

 

Blood: Gas Partition Coefficients:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoflurane: Isoflurane has a higher blood-gas partition coefficient compared to nitrous oxide, indicating slower onset and recovery.

 

Option C. Sevoflurane: Although sevoflurane has a relatively low blood-gas partition coefficient, it is still higher than that of nitrous oxide and desflurane.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane has a significantly higher blood-gas partition coefficient, leading to a slower onset and recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desflurane has a blood-gas partition coefficient most similar to that of nitrous oxide, indicative of its relatively low solubility in blood and, consequently, its rapid onset and recovery profile among the volatile anesthetics listed.

questions.text: In seat belt injury, the most commonly involved organ is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus

 

Explanation:

 

Seat belts are known to decrease mortality and prevent head injuries in accidents. However, they can increase the risk of certain abdominal and thoracic injuries.

 

Among all the thoracic and abdominal injuries associated with seat belt use, the maximum damage occurs to three organs: mesentery, omentum, and bowel (hollow viscus). This combination of injuries is known as the "seat belt syndrome." Therefore, the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injury is the hollow viscus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Liver + Spleen: Although liver and spleen injuries can occur in seat belt injuries, they are not the most commonly involved organs compared to the hollow viscus.

 

Option. B. Lungs: While thoracic injuries can be increased due to seat belt use, the lungs are not the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injuries.

 

Option. C. Head of Pancreas: The head of the pancreas is not the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injuries compared to the hollow viscus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In seat belt injuries, the most commonly involved organ is the hollow viscus (bowel), along with the mesentery and omentum, constituting the "seat belt syndrome." Although seat belts are protective and prevent head injuries, they can increase the risk of certain abdominal and thoracic injuries, with the hollow viscus being the most frequently affected.

questions.text: A newborn presents with respiratory distress. Chest X ray reveals air bubbles in the left hemithorax. What is your best possible diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a condition where there is an opening in the diaphragm, allowing abdominal contents to move into the chest cavity. This can lead to compression of the lungs and associated respiratory distress. The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is a characteristic finding for CDH, as the abdominal organs such as the stomach and intestines herniate into the thoracic cavity, causing air-filled loops to appear in the hemithorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital sequestration of lung: Congenital pulmonary sequestration is a rare condition where a portion of lung tissue develops separately from the normal lung tissue and lacks a connection to the bronchial tree. It typically presents with a solid mass or cystic lesion rather than air bubbles. The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is not consistent with this condition.

 

Option C. Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM): CCAM is a developmental lung abnormality characterized by the formation of cysts or masses of abnormal lung tissue. While it can lead to respiratory distress in newborns, it usually presents as a cystic or solid mass rather than air bubbles in the chest X-ray.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the best possible diagnosis given the described findings of air bubbles in the left hemithorax and respiratory distress in the newborn.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of air bubbles in the left hemithorax on chest X-ray is a characteristic finding for CDH

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaint of delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, and secondary sexual development. On examination, there was webbed neck and widely spaced nipples. Which karyotype is associated with the given condition? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45 XO

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described in the question is characteristic of Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder caused by complete or partial absence of one X chromosome in females. The key features that suggest Turner syndrome in this patient are:

 

  1. Delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea: Due to the presence of streak gonads (non-functional ovaries) in Turner syndrome, patients often experience delayed puberty and primary amenorrhea (absence of menstrual periods).
  2. Lack of secondary sexual development: The absence of functional ovaries leads to a lack of estrogen production, resulting in poor development of secondary sexual characteristics, such as breast development and pubic hair growth.
  3. Webbed neck: A short, wide neck with excess skin folds (webbing) is a common physical feature in Turner syndrome.
  4. Widely spaced nipples (shield chest): This is another characteristic physical finding in Turner syndrome, resulting from the altered body proportions.

 

 

The karyotype associated with classic Turner syndrome is 45,X (also written as 45,XO), indicating the presence of only one X chromosome instead of the normal two in females. This monosomy of the X chromosome is responsible for the clinical features observed in Turner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 47, XXX (Triple X syndrome): This karyotype is associated with an extra X chromosome in females but does not typically present with the features described in the question.

 

Option B. 46, XX: This is the normal female karyotype and does not explain the clinical presentation of the patient.

 

Option D. 47, XXY (Klinefelter syndrome): This karyotype is associated with an extra X chromosome in males and presents with different clinical features, such as tall stature, gynecomastia, and hypogonadism.

 

Additional information:

 

Patients with Turner syndrome are at increased risk of various complications, such as:

 

  1. Congenital heart defects (e.g., coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve)
  2. Metabolic syndrome (obesity, insulin resistance, dyslipidemia)
  3. Autoimmune disorders (e.g., Hashimoto's thyroiditis, celiac disease)
  4. Osteoporosis due to estrogen deficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome, characterized by the 45,XO karyotype, should be suspected in a female patient presenting with delayed puberty, primary amenorrhea, lack of secondary sexual development, and characteristic physical features such as webbed neck and widely spaced nipples.

choices.text: From medial to lateral part of diaphragm

questions.text: Which part of the diaphragm is derived from the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crura

 

Explanation:

 

The diaphragm is a muscular and tendinous structure that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity. It develops from several embryonic structures, including the septum transversum, pleuroperitoneal membranes, dorsal mesentery of the esophagus, and body wall musculature.

 

  1. Developmental Components of the Diaphragm:
    • Septum Transversum: This forms the central tendon of the diaphragm.
    • Pleuroperitoneal Membranes: These contribute to the posterolateral portions of the diaphragm.
    • Body Wall: Contributes to the peripheral muscular portions of the diaphragm.
    • Dorsal Mesentery of the Esophagus: This forms the crura of the diaphragm. The crura are muscular structures that extend from the lumbar vertebrae to the central tendon of the diaphragm and provide support to the esophageal opening.
  2. Role of Crura: The crura of the diaphragm are essential for anchoring the diaphragm to the vertebral column and aiding in the function of the esophageal hiatus. They form from the right and left sides of the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus, which are critical for maintaining the anatomical integrity and function of the diaphragm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleuroperitoneal membrane: This is incorrect. The pleuroperitoneal membranes contribute to the posterolateral parts of the diaphragm but not to the crura.

 

Option C. Septum transversum: This is incorrect. The septum transversum primarily forms the central tendon of the diaphragm.

 

Option D. From medial to lateral part of diaphragm: This option is not specific and does not accurately describe any particular component formed by the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The crura of the diaphragm develop from the dorsal mesentery of the esophagus and play a vital role in anchoring the diaphragm and forming the esophageal hiatus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has ptosis and limb weakness that worsens in the evening. She was diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. What is the first-line drug used?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridostigmine

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms are characteristic of myasthenia gravis, a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles. The hallmark of this condition is fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest.

 

The primary mechanism involves antibodies that attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing communication between nerves and muscles.

 

The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. Pyridostigmine works by increasing the amount of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby enhancing communication between nerves and muscles, which helps to improve muscle strength.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation and modulate the immune system. While it can be used in myasthenia gravis, it is not the first-line treatment. It is typically considered when patients do not adequately respond to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: An immunosuppressant that can be used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in patients who are not responsive to corticosteroids or those who have significant side effects from steroids. It is not a first-line treatment due to its side effect profile

 

Option D. Plasma exchange: This is a procedure used in severe cases of myasthenia gravis or during myasthenic crisis. It rapidly reduces the level of circulating antibodies by removing them from the blood. This is not used as a first-line treatment but rather as an acute intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for myasthenia gravis is pyridostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that improves muscle strength by increasing acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: All of the following electrolyte abnormalities are seen in Refeeding Syndrome except: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia

 

Explanation:

 

Refeeding syndrome occurs when nutrients are reintroduced to a severely malnourished patient, leading to metabolic and electrolyte disturbances. The reintroduction of carbohydrates causes an insulin surge, which drives electrolytes into cells, resulting in the following abnormalities:

 

  • Hypokalemia: Potassium is driven into cells, lowering serum levels.
  • Hypophosphatemia: Phosphate is used up in the production of ATP, lowering serum levels.
  • Hypocalcemia: Increased cellular uptake of calcium can lower serum levels.

 

These hypoelectrolyte states are critical to monitor as they can lead to severe complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and respiratory failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A.  Hypokalemia: This is not seen in refeeding syndrome. Instead, refeeding syndrome typically results in hypokalemia due to the intracellular shift of potassium.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Seen due to the cellular uptake of calcium.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: A hallmark of refeeding syndrome, driven by increased cellular utilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Refeeding syndrome is characterized by multiple hypoelectrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypocalcemia, but not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A patient presents after 5 days of unprotected intercourse for emergency contraception. What is the method of choice? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IUCD

 

Explanation:

 

The intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) is the preferred method for emergency contraception if presented within 120 hours (5 days) of unprotected intercourse. The IUCD is highly effective and provides long-term contraception, which makes it suitable for women seeking ongoing birth control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: This is not used for emergency contraception; it is typically used for medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Option B. Levonorgestrel: Although effective as emergency contraception, it is most efficacious within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected intercourse.

 

Option D. Combined OCP: The Yuzpe regimen, which uses a high dose of combined oral contraceptive pills, is also most effective within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

 

Additionally, another option not mentioned in the question is ulipristal acetate, a selective progesterone receptor modulator, which can be used up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse. However, it is not available in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) is the method of choice for emergency contraception if presented within 120 hours (5 days) of unprotected intercourse, offering both immediate and long-term contraception.

questions.text: A patient with crushed limb after amputation developed crepitus. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gas gangrene

 

Explanation:

 

  1.  The patient had a crushed limb that required amputation.
  2. After the amputation, the patient developed crepitus, which refers to the presence of gas bubbles in the tissues.
  3. The development of crepitus after an injury or amputation suggests a gas-forming bacterial infection, specifically gas gangrene.
  4. Gas gangrene is caused by the bacteria Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens, which can contaminate wounds from soil or other environmental sources.
  5. Clostridium perfringens is a gas-forming bacteria that ferments sugars (such as glucose in the body) into acid and gas, leading to tissue necrosis and the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the gangrenous tissue.

 

The presence of crepitus, along with the history of a crushed limb and amputation, strongly suggests gas gangrene as the diagnosis.

 

Established agents:

 

  • C. perfringens
  • C. novyi
  • C. septicum

 

Probable agents: C. histolyticum, C. sporogenes, C. fallax, C. bifermentans, C. sordellii, C. aerofoetidum, and C. tertium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cellulitis: This is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, and warmth, but it does not typically involve the formation of gas bubbles.

 

Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: This is a severe bacterial infection of the fascia (connective tissue) that can lead to tissue necrosis, but it is not specifically associated with the formation of gas bubbles.

 

Option C. Folliculitis: This is an infection of the hair follicles, which is unlikely to occur after an amputation and does not involve gas formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gas gangrene is a potentially life-threatening infection caused by gas-forming Clostridium species, primarily Clostridium perfringens. It is characterized by the formation of gas bubbles (crepitus) in the necrotic and gangrenous tissues, typically occurring after traumatic injuries or surgical procedures that allow the contamination of wounds with soil or environmental sources.

questions.text: In screening for diabetes in pregnancy, the dose of oral glucose load given is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 75g

 

Explanation:

 

For screening and diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is commonly used. The standard protocol involves a 75-gram oral glucose load.

 

Protocol for 75-gram OGTT:

 

International Guidelines: According to the International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG):

 

  • The test is performed after an overnight fast.
  • A fasting blood sample is taken.
  • The woman is then given a 75-gram oral glucose load.
  • Blood samples are taken at 1 hour and 2 hours after the glucose load.
  • Diagnostic thresholds:
    • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL
    • 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
    • 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL

 

A diagnosis of GDM is made if any one of these values is met or exceeded.

 

DIPSI Criteria (India):

 

This method can be used irrespective of the prandial state (whether the woman is fasting or not).

 

  • A 75-gram oral glucose load is given.
  • A blood sample is taken 2 hours later.
  • A 2-hour plasma glucose value ≥ 140 mg/dL indicates GDM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50g: Used in the 50-gram glucose challenge test, which is a preliminary screening test, but not diagnostic.

 

Option C. 100g: Used in the 3-hour OGTT, which is less commonly used now compared to the 75-gram test.

 

Option D. 150g: Not used for GDM screening or diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

The current standard for screening and diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus is the 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).

questions.text: A post-operative patient who is immobilized develops sudden onset severe calf pain. What is the next investigation to be done? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duplex USG

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is duplex ultrasound (USG). The clinical picture suggests deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is a common complication in immobilized, post-operative patients.

 

Duplex ultrasound is the investigation of choice for diagnosing DVT as it combines traditional ultrasound and Doppler ultrasound to visualize blood flow and identify any thrombus in the veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT angiography: This is primarily used for pulmonary embolism, not for initial evaluation of suspected DVT.

 

Option C. X-ray: This is not useful for diagnosing DVT, as it does not provide information about the veins or blood flow.

 

Option D. MRI: While MRI can visualize DVT, it is not the first-line investigation due to higher cost, longer procedure time, and less availability compared to duplex ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For post-operative, immobilized patients with sudden onset severe calf pain, suggesting DVT, the next investigation should be a duplex ultrasound, which effectively visualizes the veins and assesses blood flow to confirm the diagnosis. ​

questions.text: A multiparous woman from a low socio-economic status whose husband is a truck driver is to be screened for cervical cancer. What is the best way? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

Cervical cancer screening is crucial for early detection and prevention. The Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) is the standard screening test for cervical cancer, particularly in resource-limited settings. It involves collecting cells from the cervix to detect precancerous or cancerous changes.

 

Why Pap Smear?

 

  • Accessibility: It is widely available and can be performed in low-resource settings.
  • Cost-effective: It is a cost-effective method for cervical cancer screening.
  • Proven efficacy: It has been proven to significantly reduce the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer through early detection and treatment of precancerous lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CA125: This is a biomarker used in the screening and monitoring of ovarian cancer, not cervical cancer.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy: This is a surgical procedure used for diagnosis and treatment but not for routine screening.

 

Option C. TVS (Transvaginal Sonography): Primarily used for evaluating the uterus and ovaries, not suitable for cervical cancer screening.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Pap smear is the best and most widely recommended screening test for cervical cancer, especially in low socio-economic and resource-limited settings.

questions.text: 60-year-old obese lady underwent cholecystectomy. After 3 days she develops respiratory distress. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation

 

The patient, an obese post-operative case following cholecystectomy, presents with respiratory distress three days after surgery. This is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism, particularly in the context of immobilization and the hypercoagulable state following surgery. Pulmonary embolism is a common and serious complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can occur due to immobilization and endothelial injury during surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Air embolism: This is less likely in this scenario as it typically occurs immediately during or after surgical procedures involving vascular access.

 

Option C. Atelectasis: While atelectasis can cause respiratory distress post-operatively, it typically does not cause sudden severe symptoms three days post-op.

 

Option D. Myocardial Infarction: Although possible, the context of recent surgery and immobilization makes pulmonary embolism a more likely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-operative patients, particularly those who are obese and immobilized, the development of sudden respiratory distress should raise suspicion for pulmonary embolism due to the increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization. Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial.

 

Note - The rule of threes (in Immobilization) whenever the patient is immobilized for more than 72 hours/ >3 days in the last 3 months that is called significant immobilization and that increases the risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of same reproductive age is called:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TFR (Total Fertility Rate)

 

Explanation:

 

The total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group is referred to as the Total Fertility Rate (TFR).

 

The following definitions are provided:

 

  • TFR: Total number of children born to a woman
  • GRR: Number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan
  • NRR: Total number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan, minus mortality (taking into account their deaths)
  • GFR: Number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because NRR takes into account the mortality of the girls born, not the total number of children born to a woman.

 

Option C. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because GFR is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group, not the total number of children born to an individual woman.

 

Option D. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because GRR specifically refers to the number of girls born to a woman, not the total number of children born.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the measure that represents the total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group.

questions.text: Which GLUT is present in the skeletal muscle, adipose tissue? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) GLUT 4

 

Explanation:


GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter primarily found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. It is an insulin-dependent glucose transporter, meaning that its activity is stimulated by insulin. This allows for the efficient uptake of glucose into cells in response to insulin, helping to regulate blood sugar levels.

 

  • GLUT 2 is insulin-independent and is found in the liver, beta cells of the pancreas, intestines, and kidneys. It helps in the regulation of insulin and plays a key role in glucose sensing.
  • GLUT 5 is primarily involved in fructose transport and is found in the small intestine, kidney, and sperm.
  • GLUT 1 is a ubiquitous glucose transporter found in most tissues, including the brain, erythrocytes, and endothelial cells of the blood-brain barrier. It is responsible for the basal glucose uptake necessary for cellular metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT 2: As stated, GLUT 2 is insulin-independent and is not primarily involved in glucose uptake in skeletal muscle or adipose tissue.

 

Option C. GLUT 5: This transporter is primarily for fructose, not glucose, and is found in the small intestine and other locations, not in skeletal muscle or adipose tissue.

 

Option D. GLUT 1: Although present in many tissues, GLUT 1 is not the primary glucose transporter for skeletal muscle and adipose tissue, which rely on insulin-dependent GLUT 4 for glucose uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT 4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter present in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue.

choices.text: Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Medial rectus > Inferior rectus
Medial rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Inferior rectus
Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus
Superior rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Medial rectus

questions.text: What is the correct order of insertion of muscles from near to far from the limbus?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

 

This order represents the correct sequence of insertion of the extraocular muscles from near to far from the limbus, which is the border between the cornea and the sclera of the eye. The medial rectus inserts closest to the limbus, around 5.5mm, followed by the inferior rectus, which inserts at 6.5mm; the lateral rectus at 6.9mm and the superior rectus inserts farthest from the limbus, which is 7.7mm. The spiral formed by joining the insertion points of the four recti muscles is referred to as the Spiral of Tillaux

 

 

  • Medial rectus: This muscle is located closest to the limbus among the options provided. It inserts on the sclera of the eye near the medial aspect.
  • Inferior rectus: Following the medial rectus, the inferior rectus muscle inserts on the sclera near the lower aspect of the eye, hence moving away from the limbus.
  • Lateral rectus: Next in the sequence is the lateral rectus muscle, which inserts on the lateral aspect of the sclera, farther away from the limbus compared to the medial and inferior rectus muscles.
  • Superior rectus: Lastly, the superior rectus muscle inserts on the sclera near the upper aspect of the eye, making it farthest from the limbus among the muscles listed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of insertion of the extraocular muscles from near to far from the limbus is: Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is not a feature of refeeding syndrome? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 


Refeeding syndrome occurs when a person who has been malnourished starts to eat again. This condition is characterized by metabolic and electrolyte imbalances caused by a sudden shift from a catabolic state (where the body breaks down tissue for energy) to an anabolic state (where the body builds tissue). When refeeding begins, there is an increase in glucose intake, which leads to increased insulin secretion.

 

Hyperkalemia is not a feature of refeeding syndrome. In fact, the opposite occurs (hypokalemia) due to the insulin-mediated intracellular shift of potassium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypophosphatemia: Insulin promotes the uptake of glucose and the subsequent metabolic processes that require phosphate. As phosphate is consumed in the generation of ATP and other metabolic pathways, its levels in the blood decrease, leading to hypophosphatemia.

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: Insulin also drives potassium into cells. As potassium moves intracellularly, the serum potassium levels drop, resulting in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypomagnesemia: Magnesium is a crucial cofactor for many enzymatic reactions, especially those involving ATP. As the metabolic rate increases, magnesium is used up, leading to hypomagnesemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Refeeding syndrome is characterized by hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia, not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of palms and soles. He was subsequently diagnosed to have lung cancer. Which of the following is responsible for hyperpigmentation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH)

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, a chronic smoker, presented with weight gain and hyperpigmentation of the palms and soles and was diagnosed with lung cancer. This clinical scenario suggests the presence of an ectopic ACTH-producing tumor, most commonly associated with small cell lung cancer.

 

In such cases, the excessive ACTH produced by the tumor can lead to Cushing's syndrome.

 

Additionally, ACTH has an intrinsic MSH (Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone) activity due to the shared precursor molecule, proopiomelanocortin (POMC). The MSH part within ACTH stimulates melanocytes, leading to increased melanin production and resulting in hyperpigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex. It does not play a role in causing hyperpigmentation in this context.

 

Option C. Neuropeptide Y: Neuropeptide Y is involved in various physiological processes, including regulation of appetite and stress responses, but not in causing hyperpigmentation.

 

Option D. Melanin: While melanin is the pigment responsible for skin color, its production is stimulated by MSH. Thus, MSH is the direct cause of increased melanin and subsequent hyperpigmentation in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ectopic ACTH production, such as with small cell lung cancer, hyperpigmentation occurs due to the MSH activity of ACTH, which stimulates melanocytes to produce melanin.

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image.  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows a characteristic palisading arrangement of hyperchromatic (darkly stained) cells, which is indicative of basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

 

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells of the epidermis. It is characterized by the presence of basaloid cells arranged in a palisading pattern, with peripheral cells exhibiting hyperchromatic nuclei and a paler center.

 

The key features that suggest this image represents basal cell carcinoma include:

 

  1. Palisading arrangement: The tumor cells are arranged in a distinct palisading pattern, with peripheral cells arranged in a radial fashion around the center.
  2. Hyperchromatic cells: The cells at the periphery of the tumor nests have darkly stained (hyperchromatic) nuclei, which is a characteristic feature of basal cell carcinoma.
  3. Lack of keratinization: Unlike squamous cell carcinoma, there is no evidence of keratinization (formation of keratin pearls) in this image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer typically shows evidence of keratinization and does not exhibit the distinctive palisading pattern observed in the image.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: This is a type of cancer that originates from glandular epithelial cells and is not typically found in the skin.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma: This is a type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes and typically exhibits a different morphological appearance, with the presence of melanin pigment and atypical melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic palisading arrangement of hyperchromatic basaloid cells is a hallmark feature of basal cell carcinoma, a type of skin cancer that arises from the basal cells of the epidermis.

questions.text: Based on the labeled MRI image, identify the anatomical structures marked as 1, 2, and 3. (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-Liver, 2-Pancrease, 3-Spleen

 

Explanation:

 

In the provided CT scan of the abdomen, three structures are marked -

 

  1. The first structure (marked as "1") is identified as the liver. This identification is based on its large size and position on the right side of the vertebral column. The liver is a prominent organ in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, adjacent to the anterior abdominal wall.
  2. The second structure (marked as "2") is the pancreas. Specifically, this is the head of the pancreas. The pancreas lies in the retroperitoneal space, with its head nestled in the curve of the duodenum and its tail extending towards the hilum of the spleen.
  3. The third structure (marked as "3") is the spleen. The spleen is located in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, near the stomach and under the left diaphragm. It is typically a crescent-shaped organ.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 1- right kidney, 2- pancreas, 3- left kidney

questions.text: Identify the structures marked. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) 1- liver 2-spleen 3-pancreas

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option D: 1- liver, 2- spleen, 3- pancreas: Correct based on organ anatomy and typical CT appearance.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Accurate identification of abdominal organs on imaging studies like CT scans is essential for diagnosing diseases, planning surgeries, and tracking treatment progress.

questions.text: Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver in the form of which of the following amino acids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glutamine

 

Explanation

 

Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver primarily in the form of glutamine.

This is because glutamine can safely carry ammonia through the bloodstream to the liver, where the urea cycle converts it into urea for excretion.

The liver's urea cycle is the primary site for detoxifying ammonia, a neurotoxic byproduct of amino acid metabolism.

Glutamine plays a crucial role in this process by acting as a carrier molecule that neutralizes ammonia, thus preventing its accumulation and potential toxicity in the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamate: While glutamate is involved in ammonia metabolism, it is not the primary transporter of ammonia from the brain to the liver. Instead, glutamate is often converted to glutamine for this purpose.

 

Option B. Alanine: Alanine transports ammonia primarily from muscle tissues to the liver. It is part of the glucose-alanine cycle, which helps in the conversion of pyruvate to glucose in the liver.

 

Option C. Glycine: Glycine does not play a significant role in ammonia transport from the brain to the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glutamine is the primary amino acid responsible for transporting ammonia from the brain to the liver.

questions.text: In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus 

 

Hollow viscus organs such as the small intestine and colon are more commonly affected in seat belt injuries due to their position and vulnerability to compression forces applied by the seat belt.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver and spleen: While the liver and spleen can be injured in seat belt injuries, they are not the most commonly affected organs.

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum, being relatively protected by its retroperitoneal location, is less commonly affected in seat belt injuries compared to other abdominal organs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: The pancreas, located deep in the abdomen, can be injured in seat belt injuries, but it is not as commonly affected as other organs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In seat belt injuries, hollow viscus organs, particularly the small intestine and colon, are most commonly affected due to their susceptibility to compression forces, emphasizing the importance of thorough evaluation for intra-abdominal injuries.

questions.text: During abdominal examination, a horizontal line joining the lowest points of the costal margins corresponds to which vertebral level? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. L3

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a diagram with a line indicating the subcostal plane, which corresponds to a specific vertebral level. The subcostal plane is an important anatomical landmark and is used to divide the abdomen into regions for clinical and surgical purposes.

 

  1. Subcostal Plane: The subcostal plane passes through the lowest point of the costal margin, which is generally at the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).
  2. Anatomical Landmarks:
    • The subcostal plane is a horizontal plane that typically lies just below the rib cage.
    • It is an important reference point for dividing the abdomen into regions.
    • The umbilicus, lies at the level of the L3-L4 junction, but the subcostal plane is typically slightly superior to this and corresponds to L3.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T12: This is incorrect. T12 is located higher up in the thoracic region.

 

Option B. L1: This is incorrect. The transpyloric plane, passes through the level of L1.

 

Option C. L2: This is incorrect. L2 is also superior to the subcostal plane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subcostal plane is an important anatomical landmark that typically corresponds to the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3), helping to divide the abdomen into regions for clinical and surgical reference.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient has fever with severe shortness of breath and red currant jelly sputum. On examination, he has altered sensorium with a respiratory rate of 35 breaths/min. Lab investigations show serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL. CXR is done and shows multi-lobar infiltrates. What is correct regarding the management? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ICU management (IV drugs)

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with severe symptoms of community-acquired pneumonia, including fever, severe shortness of breath, red currant jelly sputum, altered sensorium, a high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates on the chest X-ray.

 

The CURB-65 score and IDSA/ATS guidelines for severe community-acquired pneumonia suggest that patients with severe symptoms, especially those meeting major criteria or multiple minor criteria, require intensive care unit (ICU) management.

 

CURB-65 Criteria (score 0-5)

 

  • Confusion
  • Uremia (BUN > 19 mg/dL or Urea >40 mg/dL)
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min
  • Blood pressure (systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg)
  • Age ≥ 65 years

 

The patient scores high on these criteria due to confusion, high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates.

 

IDSA/ATS Criteria for Severe CAP

 

Minor Criteria

 

  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30 breaths/min
  • PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 250
  • Multi-lobar infiltrates
  • Confusion/disorientation
  • Uremia (BUN level ≥ 20 mg/dL)
  • Leukopenia (WBC count < 4000 cells/mm3)
  • Thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 100,000 cells/mm3)
  • Hypothermia (core temperature < 36°C)
  • Hypotension requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation

 

Major Criteria

 

  • Septic shock requiring vasopressors
  • Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation

 

The patient meets several minor criteria, indicating severe CAP requiring ICU admission and intravenous antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OPD management: Not appropriate for severe symptoms and high CURB-65 score.

 

Option B. IPD management: While necessary, ICU care is more appropriate.

 

Option C. ICU management (oral drugs): IV drugs are required for severe cases in the ICU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with severe community-acquired pneumonia, especially those with altered sensorium, high respiratory rate, and multi-lobar infiltrates, should be managed in the ICU with intravenous antibiotics.

questions.text: After how many seconds of chest compressions and bag and mask ventilation, should we start the adrenaline? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 60 seconds

 

Adrenaline is administered during neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of effective bag and mask ventilation, or if the heart rate remains below 60 despite adequate bag and mask ventilation for 30 seconds. The prompt administration of adrenaline is crucial for improving perfusion and achieving successful resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenaline should be administered when the heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of bag and mask ventilation.

questions.text: All of the following are true about neutrophil extracellular trap except:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phagocytosis is enhanced

 

Explanation:

 

Phagocytosis is enhanced: This statement is incorrect. NET formation does not directly enhance phagocytosis. Instead, it is a distinct mechanism where the neutrophil traps and kills pathogens extracellularly, without engulfing them through phagocytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are a defense mechanism employed by neutrophils to trap and kill extracellular pathogens. During NET formation, neutrophils undergo a process called NETosis, which involves chromatin decondensation and the release of DNA along with antibacterial enzymes into the extracellular space. This forms a mesh-like structure that can trap and kill bacteria.

 

Option A: Induced by sepsis: True. NETs are induced by various stimuli, including sepsis. In septicemia-like conditions, the presence of pathogens triggers the formation of NETs as a response to the infection.

 

Option C: Higher risk of SLE: True. NET formation also has some negative consequences. The exposure of nuclear antigens during NETosis can lead to an increased risk of developing autoimmune disorders, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The nuclear antigens released during NET formation can be recognized as "self" by the immune system, leading to the production of autoantibodies and the development of SLE.

 

Option D: Affected cell does not survive: True. In NET formation, the neutrophil undergoes a form of cell death called NETotic cell death. The affected neutrophil does not survive the process of NETosis, as it involves the release of its cellular contents, including DNA and enzymes. This process is sometimes referred to as "beneficial suicide" because the neutrophil sacrifices itself to create the extracellular trap that can capture and kill pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps are induced by sepsis, increase the risk of developing SLE due to exposure of nuclear antigens, and result in the death of the affected neutrophil, but they do not enhance phagocytosis.

questions.text: What type of stridor occur in croup?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biphasic stridor

 

Given the question is about croup, the correct answer is Biphasic stridor, because croup usually affects the subglottic region and can cause narrowing that affects both phases of breathing.

 

Biphasic stridor is heard during both inhalation and exhalation and indicates a narrowing at the level of the vocal cords or just below them in the subglottic region. This type of stridor is characteristic of croup, which typically affects the subglottic area of the larynx.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched sound that occurs during inhalation. It is commonly associated with conditions that cause narrowing of the upper airway above the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Expiratory stridor is a wheezing sound heard during exhalation and is less common. It suggests a problem lower in the respiratory tract, such as the bronchioles or smaller bronchi.

 

Option D. No stridor would mean that there is no abnormal airway sound, which would not be applicable in the context of a discussion about croup, which typically presents with stridor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Croup typically presents with biphasic stridor, which occurs during both inspiration and expiration, reflecting the subglottic airway narrowing characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: The maternal part of the placenta is called as? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decidua basalis

 

 

Explanation:

 

The decidua basalis is the specific part of the decidua (the endometrium of the pregnant uterus) that directly interacts with the chorion frondosum (the fetal part of the placenta) to form the maternal part of the placenta.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decidua parietalis: The remaining part of the decidua lining the uterine cavity that is not involved in the formation of the placenta.

 

Option B. Decidua capsularis: The part of the decidua that covers the embryo and the gestational sac, like a capsule.

 

Option D. Decidua spongiosum: This term is not typically used to describe parts of the decidua in the context of placentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decidua basalis: Forms the maternal part of the placenta.
  • Decidua capsularis: Encloses the rest of the gestational sac.
  • Decidua parietalis: Lines the remainder of the uterus.

questions.text: Which anti-TB drug causes red colour vision defects or optic neuropathy?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is used in the treatment of tuberculosis. One of the well-known side effects of ethambutol is optic neuropathy, which can lead to color vision defects, particularly with the perception of red and green. Patients on ethambutol are usually monitored for visual acuity and color vision changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is used to treat various bacterial infections, including tuberculosis (TB). While it has a range of side effects, red color vision defects or optic neuropathy are not typically associated with rifampicin. It is more commonly known to cause orange discoloration of body fluids.

 

Option C. INH (Isoniazid): INH, or isoniazid, is another first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects can include peripheral neuropathy, which is why it is often given with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to mitigate this risk. However, INH is not commonly associated with red color vision defects or optic neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol, an anti-TB drug, can cause optic neuropathy and red color vision defects, necessitating regular eye exams for patients on this medication.

questions.text: Treatment of this condition in a pregnant female would be? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

The condition shown in the image is condyloma acuminatum, also known as genital warts, caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).

 

In pregnant females, the treatment options are limited due to potential teratogenic effects of certain medications. Cryotherapy is considered safe and effective for treating genital warts during pregnancy. If cryotherapy is not an option, trichloroacetic acid can also be used safely.

 

If the women is not Pregnant then Podophyllin can be given

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Podophyllin: This medication is teratogenic and should be avoided in pregnant women.

 

Option B. Imiquimod: Safety studies on the use of imiquimod during pregnancy are lacking, so it is also avoided in pregnant females.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This is generally reserved for very large genital warts, such as Buschke-Löwenstein tumors, and is not the first-line treatment for typical cases of condyloma acuminatum in pregnant females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant females with condyloma acuminatum, cryotherapy is the preferred treatment due to its safety profile, while teratogenic treatments like podophyllin and those with uncertain safety like imiquimod should be avoided.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked in the image (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bulbar urethral stricture

 

Correctly identified based on the image, this stricture is located in the bulbar region of the urethra, just below the prostate and above the penile segment.

 

This is a urethrogram, a type of radiographic study used to evaluate the urethra. The narrowing seen in the image is consistent with a bulbar urethral stricture, which typically occurs in the part of the urethra that runs through the bulb of the penis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prostatomegaly: This would show an enlarged prostate, which typically does not affect the urethra directly on a urethrogram unless there is significant compression or involvement of the prostatic urethra.

 

Option B. Membranous urethral stricture: This type of stricture would occur in the membranous segment of the urethra, which is located between the prostate and the bulbous urethra. The location in this image does not correspond to that segment.

 

Option D. Normal urethra: This would show an unobstructed and uniformly calibred urethral passage, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Urethral strictures, particularly in the bulbar region, are commonly evaluated and diagnosed with a urethrogram, which provides clear visualization of any narrowing or obstruction along the urethral tract.

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes with excruciating ear pain, bloody discharge from the ear and HbA1c of 10. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Necrotizing otitis externa

 

Given the description of excruciating ear pain, bloody discharge, and the presence of uncontrolled diabetes (indicated by the high HbA1c level), the most likely diagnosis is Necrotizing otitis externa. This condition is a serious, potentially life-threatening infection that requires immediate medical attention.

 

Necrotizing otitis externa is a severe form of otitis externa that occurs primarily in diabetic patients or those who are immunocompromised. It is characterized by infection that extends into the bone and cartilage of the ear canal, causing severe pain, otorrhea (often bloody), and potentially serious complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis externa, commonly known as "swimmer's ear," is an inflammation of the ear canal that can cause ear pain and discharge. While it can be painful, it typically does not cause the severe symptoms seen in diabetic patients with poorly controlled blood sugar levels.

 

Option C. Serous otitis media involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It typically causes a feeling of fullness in the ear and decreased hearing but is not typically associated with severe pain or bloody discharge.

 

Option D. Acute otitis media is an infection of the middle ear, which can present with ear pain, fever, and hearing loss. In severe cases, it may lead to tympanic membrane rupture, which can cause bloody discharge. However, the pain is not usually described as excruciating and does not typically have the same level of severity as necrotizing otitis externa in a diabetic patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a diabetic patient presenting with excruciating ear pain and bloody otorrhea, the diagnosis of necrotizing otitis externa should be considered, especially when the patient has a significantly elevated HbA1c, indicating poor glycemic control.

questions.text: Scorbutic rosary is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

 

Scorbutic rosary is a clinical sign of scurvy, a condition caused by Vitamin C deficiency. Scorbutic rosary refers to the swelling of the costochondral junctions due to impaired collagen synthesis, which occurs in scurvy. Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, and its deficiency leads to weakened blood vessels, poor wound healing, and characteristic skeletal abnormalities such as scorbutic rosary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Scorbutic rosary is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency primarily manifests as impaired vision (night blindness), dry skin, and immune system issues.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to rickets, which can cause rachitic rosary, but not scorbutic rosary. Scorbutic rosary is specifically associated with Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy).

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency primarily leads to bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting, not scorbutic rosary. Scorbutic rosary is not associated with Vitamin K deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scorbutic rosary is a clinical sign of scurvy, a condition caused by Vitamin C deficiency.

choices.text: Prescribe an abdominal belt for the daily use
Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient, who underwent midline laparotomy for colonic cancer one month ago, presents with a palpable abdominal bulge at the surgical site. Physical examination reveals a reducible midline incisional hernia of 12cm. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair 

 

For a patient with a palpable abdominal bulge at the site of a recent surgical incision, indicative of an incisional hernia, management options vary depending on the size of the hernia, symptoms, and the patient's overall health status.
