This is a minimally invasive approach that is commonly used for large ventral hernias like in this case. The use of mesh is associated with a lower rate of recurrence compared to suture repair alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use: While an abdominal belt or binder can provide temporary relief and support for a hernia, it does not correct the underlying issue. It is more of a conservative approach and may be considered in patients who are not candidates for surgery.

 

Option C. Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months: Observation may be appropriate for small, asymptomatic hernias or in patients where surgery poses a high risk. However, given the size of the hernia (12 cm), this approach could lead to an increased risk of complications such as incarceration or strangulation.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic closure without mesh: Closing the hernia laparoscopically without mesh is less favored for larger hernias due to higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a large, reducible midline incisional hernia is to schedule a laparoscopic mesh repair, which offers a minimally invasive approach with a lower risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A 48-year-old smoker presents with yellow, copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning after getting up and on changing posture. He has had this problem for a few years. What will be the first differential diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is bronchiectasis. The key features in this case include the presence of copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning and with postural changes. These features are highly suggestive of bronchiectasis, a condition characterized by chronic dilation and infection of the bronchi. This leads to the production of large amounts of sputum, particularly after changes in posture due to the drainage of secretions from the dilated airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Typically presents with wheezing, shortness of breath, and a dry or mildly productive cough. Asthma is diagnosed with spirometry, showing reversible airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Pneumonia: Usually presents acutely with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. It is less likely to cause symptoms that have persisted for years.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: May present with chronic cough and hemoptysis but is less likely to produce copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases with postural changes over several years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchiectasis should be considered in patients with chronic, copious, foul-smelling sputum that varies with posture, especially in the context of a history of smoking or recurrent respiratory infections. Recognizing these features can prompt appropriate diagnostic imaging, such as a CT scan showing characteristic tram-track or signet ring appearances.

questions.text: Delphian lymph nodes belong to which level in neck nodes? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Level 6

 

The Delphian lymph node is a prelaryngeal lymph node located just above the thyroid isthmus. In the classification of neck lymph nodes, it is part of:

 

Also known as the central compartment, Level 6 includes the pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal (Delphian) lymph nodes. This is the correct level for the Delphian lymph node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levels 3-4: These typically refer to the middle and lower jugular lymph nodes, which are located along the mid and lower third of the internal jugular vein.

 

Option B. Levels 1-2: Level 1 includes the submental and submandibular nodes, and Level 2 includes the upper jugular lymph nodes. These are not the locations of the Delphian lymph node.

 

Option C. Level 5: This includes the posterior triangle group of lymph nodes, located along the lower half of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, extending into the supraclavicular fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Delphian lymph node is categorized as Level 6 in the classification of neck lymph nodes, situated in the central compartment above the thyroid isthmus.

questions.text: What is the airway management of choice in a patient with maxillofacial trauma after a road traffic accident? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

Explanation:

 

Tracheostomy is the preferred airway management technique in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma. This approach is chosen because severe facial injuries can make other forms of intubation difficult or impossible due to anatomical disruptions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orotracheal Intubation: Typically the first-line method in emergency airway management, it may be contraindicated or challenging in maxillofacial trauma due to the risk of causing further injury.

 

Option C. Nasotracheal Intubation: Avoided in maxillofacial injuries due to the risk of creating a false passage or worsening a basal skull fracture.

 

Option D. Oxygen Therapy: While important for providing oxygen, it does not secure the airway and is insufficient in cases of airway compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In severe maxillofacial trauma where the airway is compromised, an emergency tracheostomy is often necessary if orotracheal intubation is not feasible or safe due to the extent of the injuries.

questions.text: Treatment of the male partner is needed in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. When a female is infected with trichomoniasis, she typically presents with symptoms such as green frothy vaginal discharge.

 

Treatment of the female alone is insufficient because if her male partner is not treated, he can reinfect her. This creates a cycle where the infection is passed back and forth between partners. Therefore, treating both partners is essential to break this cycle and prevent reinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is not considered a sexually transmitted disease but is due to an imbalance in the vaginal microflora. Treatment of the male partner is not required.

 

Option B. Herpes genitalis: This is caused by the herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2), which produces grouped vesicles over the genitalia. The virus resides in the sacral ganglia and can reactivate under certain conditions, such as immunosuppression. The best advice for couples during active lesions is abstinence from sexual intercourse, but partner treatment is not typically necessary.

 

 

Option C. Candidiasis: This is also not considered a sexually transmitted disease. It results from an overgrowth of Candida species, commonly due to altered vaginal flora. Treatment of the male partner is not required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of the male partner is essential in cases of trichomoniasis to prevent reinfection and break the cycle of transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazides in DCT? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blockade of Na-Cl Symporter

 

Thiazide diuretics act by blocking the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney. This action leads to decreased reabsorption of sodium and chloride, resulting in increased excretion of these ions along with water, thereby producing a diuretic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blockade of Na-K-2Cl Symporter: This is the mechanism of action of loop diuretics like furosemide, not thiazides. Loop diuretics inhibit the sodium-potassium-2 chloride symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

 

Option C. Blockade of Aldosterone Receptors: This describes the mechanism of action of spironolactone and eplerenone, which are aldosterone antagonists. They work in the collecting ducts of the kidneys.

 

Option D. Blockade of Epithelial Sodium Channels: This is the mechanism of action of potassium-sparing diuretics like amiloride and triamterene, which act on the collecting ducts of the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazide diuretics primarily work by inhibiting the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney. This inhibition reduces sodium reabsorption, leading to increased excretion of sodium and water, thereby lowering blood pressure and reducing edema.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cephal hematoma

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum and is typically limited by the edges of the skull bones. It does not cross suture lines because the bleeding is confined by the bone edges. This differentiates it from other types of scalp swellings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caput succedaneum: Caput succedaneum refers to diffuse swelling of the scalp that crosses the suture lines and extends beyond the presenting part of the baby's head. It is caused by pressure from the birth canal during delivery.

 

Option C. Subgaleal hematoma: A subgaleal hematoma is a collection of blood between the scalp galea aponeurosis and the periosteum of the skull. It typically presents as a diffuse, boggy swelling that can cross suture lines and extend over large areas of the scalp.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as the image and description fit the characteristics of a cephal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum, confined by the bone edges, and does not cross suture lines.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred drug for treatment of post-menopausal breast cancer? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anastrozole

 

Aromatase inhibitors like anastrozole and letrozole are  considered the preferred drugs for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in post-menopausal women whereas tamoxifen is considered drug of choice in pre-menopausal women. Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor whereas tamoxifen works as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), both are effective in blocking the effects of estrogen on breast cancer cells. Methotrexate may be used in breast cancer treatment, however it is not a first line drug. On the other hand, raloxifene is a SERM used for treatment of osteoporosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a chemotherapy drug used in the treatment of various cancers, including some types of breast cancer. However, it is not typically the first-line choice for post-menopausal breast cancer.

 

Option B. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used for osteoporosis and the prevention of breast cancer, rather than its treatment.

 

Option C. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is a widely used medication for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer in both pre-menopausal and post-menopausal women. It is often the preferred choice for breast cancer in pre-menopausal female.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor and is drug of choice for treatment of breast cancer (which is estrogen receptor positive) in post-menopausal females.

questions.text: How will you collect samples for blood culture in a patient with suspected Infective Endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3 aerobic and 3 anaerobic

 

Explanation:

 

Infective endocarditis is diagnosed using Duke's criteria, which includes major and minor criteria. One of the major criteria involves positive blood cultures.

 

For accurate diagnosis, it is essential to collect multiple blood cultures to identify the causative organism reliably.

 

A blood culture set includes both aerobic and anaerobic samples.

 

According to Duke's criteria:

 

  • A minimum of two cultures should be drawn at least 12 hours apart.
  • Ideally, three or more cultures should be collected.
  • When collecting three or more cultures, each culture set includes both aerobic and anaerobic samples.

 

Therefore, for three culture sets, you would collect three aerobic and three anaerobic samples.

 

The rules for collection are:

 

  1. If two culture sets are collected, both should be drawn at least 12 hours apart and both should be positive.
  2. If three or more culture sets are collected, all three should be positive for the same organism.
  3. If more than three culture sets are collected, the majority should be positive for the same organism.
  4. The gap between the first and the last culture should be at least one hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected infective endocarditis, the recommended blood culture collection includes three aerobic and three anaerobic samples to ensure accurate diagnosis and identification of the causative organism

questions.text: A female had unprotected sexual intercourse and now more than 5 days have passed. She fears getting pregnant. What is the contraceptive of choice in this case? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IUCD

 

The only option suitable for emergency contraception in this scenario (more than 5 days after unprotected intercourse) is the IUCD, specifically the copper IUCD. It can be inserted up to five days after unprotected intercourse and is highly effective in preventing pregnancy. The other options, OCP and Levonorgestrel, are typically used within a shorter time frame after unprotected sex and would not be the best choices in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. OCP (Oral Contraceptive Pills): These are typically used as a regular method of contraception and are not suitable for emergency contraception if more than 72 hours have passed since unprotected intercourse.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: This is a form of emergency contraceptive pill. It is most effective when taken within 72 hours (3 days) after unprotected sex and its effectiveness decreases significantly after this period.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option would be chosen if none of the other options were appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IUCD (Intrauterine Contraceptive Device) is an effective form of emergency contraception. Certain types of IUCDs, particularly the copper IUCD, can be used as emergency contraception if inserted within five days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse. They are one of the most effective forms of emergency contraception available.

questions.text: In the IMNCI guidelines for the management of diarrhea, the color code for some dehydration is:(FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Yellow

 

Explanation:

 

In the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) guidelines, diarrhea dehydration is classified into three categories:

 

  • No dehydration – Green – Home management
  • Some dehydration – Yellow – PHC based (MO) – 2 out of 4 criteria

 

Four criteria:

 

  1. Restlessness
  2. Irritability
  3. Sunken eyes
  4. Skin pinch goes back slowly

 

  • Severe dehydration – Pink - Is diagnosed based on the presence of two out of four criteria:

 

  1. Lethargy
  2. Unconsciousness
  3. Sunken eyes
  4. Skin pinch goes back very slowly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the IMNCI guidelines for the management of diarrhea, the color code yellow represents "some dehydration," which is diagnosed based on the presence of two out of four criteria: restlessness, irritability, sunken eyes, and skin pinch goes back slowly.

questions.text: Which of the following factor is not derived from an ABG analysis directly? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is a critical test in clinical settings that measures the levels of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and the pH of the blood. These parameters are directly measured by the ABG machine. However, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured by the ABG machine; instead, it is calculated using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, which involves the measured pH and PCO2 values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PO2: The partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) is directly measured by the ABG machine, providing vital information about oxygenation status.

 

Option C. PCO2: The partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) is also directly measured by the ABG machine and indicates the level of CO2 in the blood, reflecting respiratory function.

 

Option D. pH: The pH level of the blood, which indicates its acidity or alkalinity, is directly measured by the ABG machine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABG analysis measures the levels of oxygen (PO2), carbon dioxide (PCO2), and the pH of the blood, not bicarbonate.

questions.text: A pregnant female in first trimester developed deep vein thrombosis. She requires anticoagulation. Which of the following will be the preferred drug in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enoxaparin

 

Enoxaparin is the preferred drug for a pregnant female with DVT, particularly in the first trimester. Its safety profile and effectiveness in treating and preventing DVT make it suitable for use in pregnancy. The other options either have safety concerns during pregnancy or are not typically used for the treatment of DVT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clopidogrel: This is an antiplatelet drug, not typically used in the treatment of DVT, and its safety in pregnancy is not well-established.

 

Option B. Warfarin: Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and is generally contraindicated in pregnancy, especially during the first trimester, due to the risk of teratogenic effects (warfarin embryopathy).

 

Option C. Betrixaban: This is an oral Factor Xa inhibitor. The safety of betrixaban in pregnancy has not been established, and it is generally not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the preferred choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy because they do not cross the placenta and thus have a lower risk of fetal harm. Enoxaparin is effective in the treatment and prevention of DVT and is considered safe for use in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the lateral boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior epigastric vessels 

 

Hesselbach's triangle, also known as the inguinal triangle, is an anatomical area of the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

These vessels form the lateral border of the triangle. They run superomedially towards the umbilicus from the external iliac vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectus abdominis muscle: This is the medial border of Hesselbach's triangle.

 

Option B. Inguinal ligament: This forms the base or inferior border of the triangle. It is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Option D. Conjoint tendon: Also known as the inguinal aponeurotic falx, this is not a border of Hesselbach's triangle but is located just medial to the triangle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The inferior epigastric vessels form the lateral boundary of Hesselbach's triangle, which is an area of the abdominal wall clinically significant in the diagnosis of direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids are necessary for purine ring formation? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine, aspartate, glutamine

 

Explanation

 

Purine ring formation requires the amino acids glycine, aspartate, and glutamine.

 

These three amino acids provide crucial nitrogen and carbon atoms that are incorporated into the purine ring structure during its biosynthesis. Specifically, glycine contributes carbon and nitrogen, aspartate contributes a nitrogen, and glutamine provides another nitrogen atom. This combination is essential for the complex two-ring structure of purines.

 

In contrast, pyrimidine rings, which have a single-ring structure, require only aspartate and glutamine for their formation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glycine, aspartate, valine: Valine is not involved in purine synthesis. Valine is a branched-chain amino acid used primarily in protein synthesis and energy production.

 

Option C. Glycine, aspartate, glutamate: Glutamate does not participate in purine ring formation. Glutamate is primarily involved in amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis.

 

Option D. D. Glycine, aspartate, alanine: Alanine is not involved in purine ring formation. It is a non-essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis and glucose metabolism, but it does not contribute to the nitrogen or carbon framework of purines.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Important one liner

  • AA for Purines - Aspartate, Glutamine, Glycine
  • AA for Pyrimidines - Aspartate, Glutamine
  • Sources of N & C of Urea - CO2, Ammonia, Aspartate
  • AA linking Kreb's and Urea cycle - Aspartate
  • Molecule linking Kreb's and Urea cycle - Fumarate

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block. In a matter of few seconds the patient suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the correct 1st line treatment of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra lipid infusion

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms of hypotension and arrhythmias after the administration of 0.5% bupivacaine suggest local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation in significant amounts. Intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) therapy is considered the first-line treatment for LAST. It works by creating a "lipid sink" that helps to sequester the lipophilic local anesthetic away from target organs, particularly the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive Ventilation: This is provided if the patient is not able to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation on their own. It is supportive care and does not directly counteract the toxicity of the local anesthetic.

 

Option C. Soda Bicarbonate (Sodium Bicarbonate): This can be used to treat metabolic acidosis, which may occur secondary to hypoxia or cardiac arrest. While it can help in the supportive management of LAST, it is not the first line for the toxicity itself.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPCR): This is initiated in the case of cardiac arrest. While it's a crucial component of resuscitation, it's not a first-line treatment for the toxicity unless the patient has progressed to cardiac arrest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is intravenous lipid emulsion therapy, which helps to reduce the systemic toxicity of lipophilic local anesthetic agents such as bupivacaine.

questions.text: What type of sanitation facilities should be provided for the refugees returning from war in a camp? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trench latrine

 

For temporary sanitation facilities in refugee camps, the recommended options are shallow trench latrines, deep trench latrines, pit latrines, and borehole latrines. Among the given choices, the "trench latrine" option is the most appropriate for providing sanitation facilities to refugees returning from war in a camp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pit method - This option is incorrect because the " Pit method " is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps

 

Option B. Dumping method - This option is incorrect because the "dumping method" is not a recommended sanitation facility for refugee camps.

 

Option D. Aqua privy - Aqua privies, which are similar to septic tanks, are useful at the family level but not recommended for temporary refugee camps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When providing temporary sanitation facilities for refugees in camps, trench latrines (either shallow or deep) are the recommended option, as they are suitable for short-term use and can be easily set up in such situations.

questions.text: Identify the hemorrhage shown in the given image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural hemorrhage

 

Subdural hemorrhages occur beneath the dura mater but outside the brain parenchyma, between the dura and the arachnoid layers. They typically appear as crescent-shaped hyperdense areas on CT scans, conforming to the brain surface and often crossing suture lines, unlike extradural hemorrhages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage (Epidural Hemorrhage): This type of hemorrhage occurs between the inner surface of the skull and the dura mater. On imaging, it usually appears as a lens-shaped (biconvex) hyperdense area that does not cross suture lines due to the attachment of the dura to the sutures.

 

Option B. Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage: This refers to bleeding within the brain tissue itself. On CT scans, intraparenchymal hemorrhages appear as irregular or rounded hyperdense areas within the brain parenchyma. They are often surrounded by a low-density area due to edema.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: This type of hemorrhage occurs in the subarachnoid space, between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater, covering the brain. It usually presents as a diffuse area of increased density in the spaces around the brain, particularly visible in the sulci and cisterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subdural hemorrhages, typically appear as crescent-shaped hyperdense areas on CT scans and in particular, require timely intervention to manage increased intracranial pressure and prevent permanent damage or death. They can present with symptoms ranging from mild headaches to severe neurological deficits, depending on the extent of the bleeding.

questions.text: A young male child presented with gum bleeding and bow legs. Which vitamin deficiency is commonly associated with the described features? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ascorbic acid

 

ASCORBIC ACID DEFICIENCY

 

  • Scurvy is a clinical syndrome resulting from vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency. 
  • Vitamin C is essential for the growth and repair of skin, cartilage, bone, and teeth.
  • Humans lack the active form of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase required for synthesizing ascorbic acid, making it essential to acquire vitamin C from dietary sources or supplements. 
  • The primary cause of vitamin C deficiency is due to inadequate nutritional intake.
  • Histopathology:
    • Microscopic examination of affected tissues reveals evidence of compromised collagen synthesis.
    • In the skin, there is evident dermal disruption and atrophy, reduced number of collagen fibers, and they appear fragmented.
    • The affected area displays signs of dilated hair follicles, fibrosis, follicular hyperkeratosis, corkscrew hairs, and perifollicular hemorrhages. 
    • In the oral cavity, the gingival tissues exhibit hemorrhagic changes, characterized by capillary dilation and fibrin thrombi, subepithelial hemorrhages, and inflammatory infiltrates. 
    • Within the skeletal system, the osteoid matrix is thin and disrupted, accompanied by subperiosteal hemorrhages and indications of osteopenia.
  • Early oral signs visible in physical examination include gingivitis with bleeding, periodontal disease, loss of dentition.
  • About 80% of children with scurvy present with musculoskeletal signs and symptoms, including arthralgias, myalgias, hemarthroses, muscle hemorrhages, and subperiosteal hematomas.
  • Children might display a limp or resist bearing weight.
  • The knee joint is the most affected part of the body. 
  • Vitamin C deficiency can affect bone growth and development, leading to bone deformities like bow legs.
  • Another notable finding is the "scorbutic rosary," i.e., tender, angular, and sharp swellings at the costochondral junctions caused by weakened connective tissue.
  • Imaging studies may reveal the following:
    • Fractures and dislocations
    • Subperiosteal elevation
    • Alveolar bone resorption, osteopenia, or osteoporosis
    • Epiphyseal separation of the distal radius

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tocopherol: Vitamin E deficiency is extremely rare in humans as it is unlikely caused by a diet consisting of low vitamin E. Patients presenting early may show hyporeflexia, decreased night vision, loss/decreased vibratory sense; however, they have normal cognition. A more moderate stage of this deficiency may show limb and truncal ataxia, profuse muscle weakness, and limited upward gaze. Late presentations may show cardiac arrhythmias and possible blindness with reduced cognition. Ataxia is the most common finding. Patients that have abetalipoproteinemia have eye problems, often including pigmented retinopathy and visual field issues.

 

Option C. Calciferol: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to osteomalacia and rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. The majority of patients with vitamin D deficiency are asymptomatic. However, even mild chronic vitamin D deficiency can lead to chronic hypocalcemia and hyperparathyroidism, which can contribute risk of osteoporosis, falls, and fractures, especially in older individuals. Patients with prolonged and severe vitamin D deficiency can experience symptoms associated with secondary hyperparathyroidism, including bone pain, arthralgias, myalgias, fatigue, muscle twitching, and weakness. Fragility fractures may result from chronic vitamin D deficiency, leading to osteoporosis. In children, irritability, lethargy, developmental delay, bone changes, or fractures can be symptoms of vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option D. Biotin deficiency: Biotin deficiency is very rare in those who take in a normal balanced diet. Nominal biotin deficiency has been noted in pregnant and lactating women, but its clinical significance is unknown. Dermal abnormalities in biotin deficiency include alopecia and periorificial dermatitis. Patients may also develop conjunctivitis and skin infections. Neurological symptoms include hypotonia, seizures, ataxia, numbness and tingling of the extremities, mental retardation, and developmental delay in children. The patient may show depression, lethargy, and a history of hallucinations. Other neurological abnormalities include optic atrophy and sensorineural hearing loss if the condition is left untreated. Intestinal symptoms may also develop such as nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Other biotin deficiency presentations include ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and organic aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gum bleeding and bow legs are seen with Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency.

questions.text: The following condition is seen in: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis

 

Based on the provided chest X-ray, which shows numerous rounded opacities throughout the lung fields.

 

This would appear on an X-ray as multiple well-circumscribed nodules scattered throughout the lung fields known as “Cannon-ball” metastasis. The pattern seen in the image provided is consistent with lung metastasis, where the primary cancer elsewhere in the body has spread to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Miliary TB: This is characterized by numerous small nodules throughout the lung parenchyma resembling millet seeds, hence the term "miliary." These nodules are usually uniform in size.

 

Option B. Aspergillosis: Depending on the stage, aspergillosis can present with various radiographic appearances, from a 'fungal ball' within a pre-existing cavity (aspergilloma) to invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, which typically presents with consolidation and/or nodules, often with a halo sign.

 

Option C. Consolidation: This refers to an area of the lung where alveolar air is replaced by fluid, cells, or other substances, which on an X-ray appears as a homogenous increase in pulmonary parenchymal density. The borders of the affected area are usually indistinct and not nodular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The chest X-ray findings of multiple well-circumscribed nodules throughout the lung fields are indicative of lung metastasis, representing the spread of cancer from another part of the body to the lungs.

questions.text: Calculate Maternal Mortality Ratio in a population of 2 lacs, with 4000 live births, Death were 4 by PPH, 2 deaths by electrocution, 2 deaths by sepsis, 2 deaths by abortion, 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy, and 5 still births. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 250 per 1 lac

 

Explanation:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

 

Maternal death is defined as the death of a mother at any time during pregnancy, labor, delivery, or within 42 days of delivery, provided it is related to maternity or its complications.

 

In the given scenario, the maternal deaths are:

 

  • 4 deaths by postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)
  • 2 deaths by sepsis
  • 2 deaths by abortion
  • 2 deaths due to ectopic pregnancy

 

These deaths should be included in the calculation as they are related to maternity or its complications.

 

The deaths due to electrocution and stillbirths are not included in the calculation of MMR.

 

Therefore, the total number of maternal deaths is 10 (4 + 2 + 2 + 2).

 

The number of live births is given as 4,000.

 

MMR = (Number of maternal deaths / Number of live births) × 100,000

 

= (10 / 4,000) × 100,000

 

= 250 per 1,00,000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated by dividing the number of maternal deaths (deaths related to maternity or its complications) by the number of live births and multiplying by 100,000.

choices.text: Place them in same plastic bag and seat it for preservation
Preserve in envelope or paper bag
Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together
Place them in different plastic bags and seal for preservation

questions.text: 2 handkerchiefs with blood stains are found at a crime scene. What is the most appropriate procedure for handling these items? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Preserve in envelope or paper bag

 

When handling blood-stained handkerchiefs or any other stained items found at a crime scene, it is crucial to follow the appropriate procedure to ensure the preservation of evidence. The most suitable method is to preserve the handkerchiefs in an envelope or paper bag, which allows for air circulation. This prevents the growth of mold and bacteria that can occur when moisture is trapped in non-porous containers like plastic bags.

 

Additionally, it is important to dry the stains, but this should be done in the shade or by air drying. Exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat can denature the DNA, compromising the evidence. Therefore, using a spirit lamp or any other heating material to dry the stains is not recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A & D. Place them in same/different plastic bag and seal it for preservation: Plastic bags should be avoided as they can trap moisture, leading to the growth of mold and bacteria, which can compromise the evidence.

 

Option. C. Fold the handkerchiefs in such a manner that the stained edges come together: Folding the handkerchiefs with the stained edges together can lead to the mixing of stains, making it difficult to distinguish between the stains from different individuals, if applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When handling blood-stained items found at a crime scene, preserve them in an envelope or paper bag to allow for air circulation, and dry the stains in the shade or by air drying to prevent DNA denaturation. Avoid using plastic bags or exposing the stains to direct sunlight or heat.

questions.text: A 23-year-old hypertensive man comes to the hospital, on examination, BP was 150/90 mmHg, and was afebrile. On further evaluation, serum renin was found to be normal. He was diagnosed with Conn’s Syndrome. All are true about the Conn’s Syndrome except: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Conn’s Syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by the excessive secretion of aldosterone. Aldosterone increases sodium reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to water retention, hypervolemia, and subsequently, hypertension. Additionally, aldosterone promotes the secretion of potassium and hydrogen ions via the renal tubules.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conn’s Syndrome is characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion leading to metabolic alkalosis, hypertension, and low renin levels.

questions.text: A 5-year-old came with complaints of swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains. On further examination, petechie are seen. What is the best possible diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

 

The symptoms described, including swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains, and petechiae, are consistent with scurvy, which is caused by Vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, and its deficiency leads to impaired wound healing, weakened blood vessels, and bleeding gums.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness and xerophthalmia but is not typically associated with swollen and bleeding gums, bone pains, or petechiae. Vitamin A deficiency is more commonly linked with ocular manifestations and immune system impairment.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can cause rickets in children, characterized by bone pain and deformities. However, swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, and petechiae are not typical symptoms of Vitamin D deficiency. Furthermore, bone pains in rickets are usually associated with skeletal deformities rather than generalized bone pain.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency can lead to impaired blood clotting, resulting in excessive bleeding. While Vitamin K deficiency can cause petechiae due to bleeding disorders, it is not typically associated with swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, or bone pains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms of swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains, and petechiae in a child are characteristic of scurvy, which is caused by Vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: The rate-limiting enzyme of HMP shunt is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

 

The rate-limiting enzyme of the Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). G6PD catalyzes the first step in this pathway, converting glucose-6-phosphate into 6-phosphoglucono-δ-lactone while reducing NADP+ to NADPH.

 

This step is crucial for the production of NADPH, which is necessary for reductive biosynthesis and for maintaining the reduced state of glutathione, thereby protecting cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis but not in the HMP shunt. It catalyzes the final step of these pathways, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose in the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase I (PFK1): PFK1 is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis, not the HMP shunt. It catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.

 

Option D. Glycogen phosphorylase: This enzyme is the rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis, where it breaks down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate. It is not involved in the HMP shunt.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rate Limiting Enzymes

questions.text: A patient having hypertension, is on thiazides and is complaining of fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drug can prevent potassium loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amiloride

 

Explanation:

 

Thiazide diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, indapamide, chlorthalidone, and metolazone, are known for causing potassium wasting, which can result in hypokalemia and associated symptoms like fatigue. To counteract this effect, potassium-sparing diuretics can be used.

 

Amiloride is an epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) inhibitor, which is a type of potassium-sparing diuretic. It helps prevent potassium loss by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal tubules of the kidneys, thereby reducing potassium excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: This is a loop diuretic, which also causes potassium wasting and is not suitable for preventing potassium loss.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: This is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor diuretic, which is not typically used for potassium conservation and can also cause electrolyte imbalances.

 

Option D. Indapamide: This is another thiazide-like diuretic, which also causes potassium wasting and does not prevent potassium loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can be used to prevent potassium loss in patients on thiazide diuretics.

questions.text: A 2-month-old pregnant female presented with vivax malaria. She also had jaundice and confusion. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quinine

 

Explanation

 

In the context of malaria treatment during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, safety of the medication is paramount.

 

For pregnant women in their first trimester with severe malaria (as indicated by symptoms like jaundice and confusion), quinine is the treatment of choice. Quinine is effective against severe malaria and is safer for use in early pregnancy compared to other options.

 

Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential hemolytic effects on the fetus, and doxycycline is also contraindicated due to risks of teratogenicity and dental staining.

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are generally avoided in the first trimester due to insufficient safety data, despite being the preferred treatment in non-pregnant adults and in later stages of pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Chloroquine + Primaquine: Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Option C. Doxycycline: Contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Artemisinin Combination Therapy: Not recommended in the first trimester due to insufficient safety data.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Quinine is the preferred treatment for severe malaria in pregnant women during the first trimester due to its safety profile compared to other antimalarial medications.

questions.text: Lactulose is ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose and fructose

 

Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide used primarily as a laxative and in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It is composed of:

 

  • Galactose: A monosaccharide commonly found in dairy products.
  • Fructose: A monosaccharide found in many plants, where it is often bonded to glucose to form the disaccharide sucrose.

 

Lactulose is different from lactose, which is a natural disaccharide found in milk and composed of galactose and glucose.

 

Comparison with Other Disaccharides:

  • Lactose: Galactose + Glucose (found in milk, with a beta bond)
  • Maltose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,4 bond)
  • Isomaltose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,6 bond)
  • Trehalose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,1 bond)
  • Sucrose: Glucose + Fructose (table sugar, with an alpha bond)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactulose is composed of galactose and fructose, differentiating it from lactose, which is made up of galactose and glucose. It is commonly used for its medicinal properties, particularly as a laxative.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Global Hunger Index? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Infant Mortality Rate

 

Explanation:

 

The Global Hunger Index is calculated based on the following indicators:

 

Till 2014 – following 3 indicators

 

 

After 2016, the Global Hunger Index calculation was done using above four indicators, which do not include the infant mortality rate directly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. U5MR: Because the under-five mortality rate is one of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Option B. Malnutrition (wasting, stunting): Because both child wasting and child stunting are part of the four indicators used in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Option C. Inadequate food supply: Because, while inadequate food supply can contribute to child undernourishment, it is not directly used as an indicator in the calculation of the Global Hunger Index.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index is calculated using four indicators: child undernourishment, under-five mortality rate, child wasting, and child stunting. The infant mortality rate is not directly included in the calculation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with thumb pain at the base after trauma. Imaging reveals involvement of the marked joint. Identify the type of joint at this location? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saddle

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the hand, with the arrow pointing to the first carpometacarpal joint, which is the joint between the carpal bone (trapezium) and the first metacarpal bone (base of the thumb). This joint is a classical example of a saddle joint.

 

In a saddle joint, one bone has a concave and convex surface that articulates with the complementary convex and concave surface of the other bone, resembling a saddle shape. The joint is surrounded by a capsule and filled with synovial fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ellipsoid: An ellipsoid joint has an oval-shaped articular surface that fits into an elliptical cavity, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Option B. Condylar: A condylar joint has an oval projection of one bone fitting into an elliptical cavity of another bone, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Option C. Plane: A plane joint has two flat or slightly curved articular surfaces that allow for gliding or sliding movements. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first carpometacarpal joint at the base of the thumb is a saddle joint, allowing a wide range of thumb movements.

Saddle Joint – Mnemonic – PICS

Concavo-convex surface in each bone

P – Patellofemoral joint

I – incudomalleolar joint

C – Carpometacarpal joint

S – Sternoclavicular joint

questions.text: Identify the image and it is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Casal necklace – vitamin B3 deficiency

 

Casal necklace is a dermatological manifestation observed in pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency. It presents as a symmetrical rash around the neck region. Pellagra is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis often appears in sun-exposed areas, resulting in the distinctive Casal necklace.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to rickets, a condition characterized by soft, weak bones and skeletal deformities such as bowed legs and widened wrists. The image described does not depict these skeletal changes.

 

Option C. Rickets: Rickets is associated with Vitamin D deficiency and presents with skeletal abnormalities like bowed legs, widened wrists, and delayed growth. The image does not show these features, ruling out rickets as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. P. alba (Pityriasis alba): P. alba, also known as pityriasis alba, is a skin condition characterized by small, raised, white or flesh-colored bumps on the skin, typically affecting children. It is not associated with a specific vitamin deficiency but rather with blocked sweat ducts. The image described in the question is not consistent with pityriasis alba.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal necklace is a classic dermatological manifestation of pellagra, which is caused by Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effect is least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gynecomastia

 

Among the options given, gynecomastia is the least likely to be associated with the use of amiodarone. Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, and pulmonary fibrosis are all recognized adverse effects of amiodarone, while gynecomastia is not typically linked to its use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Amiodarone can cause both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism due to its high iodine content and its effect on thyroid hormone synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: As mentioned above, hyperthyroidism is also a known side effect of amiodarone, along with hypothyroidism.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Fibrosis: Pulmonary fibrosis is a well-known and potentially serious side effect of amiodarone, likely due to its toxic effects on lung tissue and prolonged half-life.

 

Adverse Effects of Amiodarone can be remembered as:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gynecomastia is typically associated with drugs that affect hormonal balance. Drugs causing gynecomastia includes:

 

DI:        DIgoxin

S:         Spironolactone

C:         Cimetidine

O:        Oestrogens

questions.text: Patient after road traffic accident was brought to the emergency. His pulse rate was 50 beats per minute, blood pressure was 80/60 mm of Hg. On evaluation his ECG was normal, eFAST was negative, and chest X-ray was normal. This status of the patient could be best classified under which type of shock?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neurogenic shock

 

Explanation

 

Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive shock resulting from the loss of sympathetic tone due to spinal cord injury, often seen in trauma cases like road traffic accidents. This leads to hypotension due to vasodilation and bradycardia due to unopposed vagal tone.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hemorrhagic shock: Characterized by tachycardia and clinical signs of bleeding. The normal eFAST and chest X-ray, along with bradycardia, make this unlikely.

 

Option B. Cardiogenic shock: Expected to show ECG changes and usually presents with tachycardia.

 

Option D. Anaphylactic shock: Typically presents with tachycardia, urticaria, and respiratory symptoms due to allergen exposure.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Neurogenic shock should be suspected in trauma patients with hypotension and bradycardia, especially when there is no evidence of hemorrhage or other common shock etiologies.

questions.text: External beam radiotherapy uses: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Co60

 

External beam radiotherapy, a cornerstone in the treatment of various cancers, utilizes high-energy beams to target and destroy cancer cells.

 

Co60 is a common radioisotope used in external beam radiotherapy due to its high-energy gamma rays, which are effective at penetrating tissues to treat tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cobalt-59 (Co59): Co59 is not used in radiation therapy; it is a stable isotope of cobalt.

 

Option C. Strontium: Strontium isotopes (like Sr-89) are used in the treatment of bone metastases, not typically in external beam radiotherapy. They help alleviate pain by targeting cancerous cells in the bone.

 

Option D. Phosphorus: Phosphorus (typically P-32) is used in radiopharmaceuticals for treating specific types of blood disorders and polycythemia vera, not in external beam radiotherapy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

EBRT uses Cobalt 60 as the radioisotope.

questions.text: Blood during autopsy is preserved in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NaF (Sodium Fluoride)

 

Explanation:

 

In toxicological analysis, there are two types of preservatives:

 

  • Preservatives for viscera - NaCl & rectified spirits
  • Preservatives for body fluids - For body fluids, such as blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), the main preservative used is sodium fluoride (NaF). When preserving blood specifically, an anticoagulant like potassium oxalate is also used along with sodium fluoride. For urine, thymol is used in addition to sodium fluoride. However, the primary preservative for all body fluids remains sodium fluoride.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. NaCl (Sodium Chloride): Saturated sodium chloride solution, along with rectified spirit, is used as a preservative for viscera in toxicological analysis, not for body fluids like blood.

 

Option. C. Formalin: Formalin is used for histopathology purposes, not for toxicological analysis.

 

Option. D. Rectified spirit: Rectified spirit, along with a saturated sodium chloride solution, is used as a preservative for viscera in toxicological analysis, not for body fluids like blood.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Sodium fluoride (NaF) is the main preservative used for body fluids, including blood, during autopsies for toxicological analysis. For blood, an anticoagulant like potassium oxalate is also used in conjunction with sodium fluoride.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy from Kerala presents with fever, headache, and drowsiness. His family reports that he has consumed palm fruit recently. Which virus is considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah

 

Explanation

 

The presentation of fever, headache, and drowsiness in a boy from Kerala who has recently consumed palm fruit, a known vector for bat-related transmissions, suggests Nipah virus infection. Nipah virus is known for causing severe encephalitis and has been associated with outbreaks in Kerala, often linked to bat consumption of fruits and subsequent transmission to humans.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Dengue: Does not typically cause encephalitis, although severe dengue can lead to altered sensorium.

 

Option C. Ebola: Not endemic in India and typically presents with hemorrhagic symptoms.

 

Option D. Chikungunya: Causes fever and arthritis, not encephalitis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Nipah virus should be considered in cases of encephalitis, especially in regions like Kerala, where outbreaks linked to bat consumption of palm fruit have been reported.

questions.text: Bilirubin is measured as mg/dl in which scale? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous

 

Explanation:

 

Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which is a continuous scale. Continuous quantitative data, where multiple values can exist between any two given values, is measured on a continuous or metric scale.

 

Such as bilirubin levels of 4 mg/dl, 4.1 mg/dl, 4.25 mg/dl, 6 mg/dl, 7 mg/dl, 10 mg/dl, and 11.4 mg/dl, illustrate the continuous nature of the measurement, with numerous possible values between any two points.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ordinal: This option is incorrect because ordinal scales represent ordered categories or ranks. This is discrete data

 

Option B. Nominal: This option is incorrect because nominal scales represent categories or names without any inherent order or quantitative value. This is discrete data

 

Option C. Discrete: This option is incorrect because discrete scales involve counting or whole numbers, whereas bilirubin measurements can have fractional or decimal values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which falls under the continuous scale, as it allows for numerous possible values between any two given points, reflecting the precise quantitative nature of the measurement.

questions.text: Preferred sample for testing random blood sugar is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venous

 

Explanation:

 

The preferred sample for testing random blood sugar is a venous sample. Venous blood glucose measurements are considered accurate and reliable for diagnostic purposes. This method is used in clinical settings to ensure consistent and precise glucose level readings. Venous samples are obtained by drawing blood from a vein, typically using a standard venipuncture technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arterial: Arterial blood samples are primarily used for blood gas analysis rather than for routine glucose testing. Arterial sampling is more invasive and not typically used for random blood sugar testing.

 

Option C. Capillary: Capillary blood samples are commonly used in self-monitoring of blood glucose (SMBG) using finger-prick devices. While convenient for personal use, they are less accurate compared to venous samples and are not typically used in clinical settings for diagnostic purposes.

 

Option D. Arteriole: Arteriole samples are not used for glucose testing. This is a dummy choice, as obtaining blood from arterioles is not a standard practice for measuring blood glucose levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred sample for testing random blood sugar in a clinical setting is a venous blood sample due to its accuracy and reliability.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is asked to clench his fist, and a prominent tendon is observed on the anterior aspect of his wrist, as shown by the arrow. Which tendon is being palpated?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flexor carpi radialis

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the anterior compartment of the forearm, focusing on the tendons near the wrist. The arrow is pointing to a tendon that runs from the forearm to the wrist and to the palm. This tendon belongs to the flexor carpi radialis muscle. The flexor carpi radialis is one of the superficial flexor muscles of the forearm. It plays a crucial role in flexion and abduction of the wrist.

 

Flexor Carpi Radialis: The flexor carpi radialis tendon is located just lateral to the palmaris longus tendon. It is prominent and easily palpable in many individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexor carpi ulnaris: This is incorrect. The flexor carpi ulnaris tendon is located medial to the palmaris longus tendon and runs towards the pisiform bone.

 

Option C. Flexor digitorum superficialis: This is incorrect. The flexor digitorum superficialis tendons are deeper and run to the fingers, responsible for flexion of the middle phalanges.

 

Option D. Palmaris longus: This is incorrect. The palmaris longus tendon runs from the forearm to the palm and is more centrally located in the wrist. It is a thin tendon that is absent in about 14% of the population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor carpi radialis is a superficial flexor muscle of the forearm with a prominent tendon that runs from the forearm to the base of the second and third metacarpals, playing a key role in wrist flexion and abduction.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a previous history of GTCS presents with convulsions which are ongoing since 45 minutes. What should be the appropriate management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam.

 

In the case of a prolonged seizure such as status epilepticus, immediate seizure termination is critical. Lorazepam is a preferred initial treatment due to its rapid onset of action in stopping seizures. After the acute phase is managed, levetiracetam can be used for ongoing seizure control. This combination makes option (a) the most appropriate choice for the described scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate followed by Gabapentin: Valproate is an effective antiepileptic drug, but it's not typically the first choice for acute seizure termination in the emergency setting of status epilepticus. Gabapentin is used as a maintenance therapy for seizures but not in the acute setting.

 

Option C. Ethosuximide followed by Gabapentin: Ethosuximide is used primarily for absence seizures and is not appropriate in the acute management of status epilepticus. Gabapentin, as mentioned, is for maintenance therapy.

 

Option D. Carbamazepine followed by Gabapentin: Carbamazepine is used for the treatment of epilepsy but is not the drug of choice in the acute management of status epilepticus. Gabapentin, again, is for longer-term control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is one of the first-line treatments for the acute management of seizures, particularly in status epilepticus. Following the control of immediate seizures with lorazepam, levetiracetam can be used as maintenance antiepileptic therapy.

questions.text: The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) G2 phase

 

Each phase of the cell cycle exhibits different levels of sensitivity to radiation damage:

 

This is the second gap phase after DNA synthesis where the cell prepares for mitosis. Cells in the G2 phase are more sensitive to radiation than those in the G1 and S phases, as the cell checks for DNA damage and repairs it before proceeding to mitosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M Phase (Mitosis): This is the phase where the cell divides into two daughter cells.. The cell's machinery is entirely focused on the mitotic process, making it less able to repair DNA damage effectively.

 

Option C. S Phase: During this phase, DNA replication occurs. Cells are more resistant to radiation in the S phase because the DNA is actively being synthesized, and the repair processes are robust.

 

Option D. G1 Phase: This is the first gap phase, where cells increase in size and prepare the necessary components for DNA synthesis. Cells in the G1 phase are relatively resistant to radiation compared to other phases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is the G2-> M  (G2>M) phase. During this phase cells are particularly vulnerable to radiation because any damage caused during this phase can lead to immediate catastrophic errors in cell division, leading to cell death.

questions.text: The congenital anomaly shown in the image results from the failure of fusion between which embryological structures? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a preauricular sinus, a congenital anomaly characterized by a small opening or pit near the external ear. This condition arises due to incomplete fusion during embryonic development.

 

  1. Embryological Development: The external ear develops from six small hillocks of tissue that form around the 1st pharyngeal cleft, derived from the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches. These hillocks eventually merge to form the pinna (external ear).
  2. Non-fusion of Pharyngeal Arches: If there is incomplete or improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches, a preauricular sinus may form. This sinus can present as a small pit or dimple in front of the ear and can sometimes become infected or form cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arch: This is incorrect. The structures formed by the 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arches do not contribute to the formation of the external ear and thus are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.

 

Option C. 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. The pharyngeal pouches form internal structures such as the tonsils, thymus, and parts of the ear's auditory tube but are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.

 

Option D. 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. These pouches are involved in forming structures like the thymus and parathyroid glands and do not play a role in the formation of the external ear or preauricular sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sinuses result from the incomplete fusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryonic development, leading to the formation of a small pit or tract near the external ear.

questions.text: What is true regarding normal semen parameters? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Motility >32%

 

Explanation:

 

According to the recent guidelines on normal semen parameters, progressive motility should be more than 32%. This is an important indicator of sperm health and fertility potential. The motility of sperm refers to their ability to move efficiently, which is crucial for natural conception as the sperm must travel through the female reproductive tract to fertilize the egg.

 

Other Options:

 

The other parameters provided in the options are either outdated or incorrect according to the latest guidelines:

 

Option B. Sperm count > 20 million: The current guideline indicates that the sperm count should be more than 16 million per milliliter, not 20 million.

 

Option C. Morphology < 8%: The normal morphology (shape and structure) of sperm should be more than 4%, not less than 8%. This means that at least 4% of the sperm should have a normal shape.

 

Option D. Sperm concentration < 40 million/ml: The correct parameter is that sperm concentration should be more than 16 million per milliliter, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational objective:

 

The correct parameter for normal semen analysis regarding motility is that progressive motility should be more than 32%.

choices.text: Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus
Superior rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus
Medial rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus, superior rectus
Medial rectus, superior rectus, lateral rectus, inferior rectus

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the arrangement of rectus muscles from closest to farthest from the limbus? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, superior rectus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a cross-sectional view of the eye with the extraocular muscles labeled along with their distances of attachment from the limbus (sclerocorneal junction). The order of the recti muscles from closest to farthest attachment to the limbus is:

 

  • Medial rectus (5.5 mm)
  • Inferior rectus (6.5 mm)
  • Lateral rectus (6.9 mm)
  • Superior rectus (7.7 mm)

 

 

Remember :

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The order of the recti muscles from nearest to farthest attachment to the limbus (sclerocorneal junction) is: medial rectus, inferior rectus, lateral rectus, and superior rectus.

questions.text: A patient feels that someone is inserting some thoughts in his mind. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delusion of influence

 

The patient's experience of someone inserting thoughts into their mind is best described as thought insertion, a type of delusion where an individual believes that external forces are controlling their thoughts. This phenomenon falls under the category of delusion of influence, where a person feels that their thoughts, feelings, or actions are being controlled or influenced by an external source. This is also known as a passivity phenomenon, where the individual feels passive and controlled by others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nihilistic delusion: This involves a belief that oneself, others, or the world does not exist or is coming to an end. For example, a patient might believe their internal organs are rotten or that the world has stopped.

 

Option C. Othello syndrome: This is a delusional belief of infidelity, where the patient is convinced that their partner is unfaithful.

 

Option D. Delusion of reference: This involves the belief that common elements of the environment are directly related to the individual, such as thinking people are talking about them or that events are directed at them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A delusion of influence involves the belief that an external force is controlling one's thoughts, feelings, or actions. This phenomenon is also known as thought insertion or passivity phenomenon.

questions.text: In a given population, total births in a year are 4050. There are 50 stillbirths. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, whereas the number of deaths within 8-28 days of life is 150. What is the neonatal mortality rate in the population?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 50

 

Explanation:

 

The neonatal mortality rate is calculated by dividing the total number of neonatal deaths (deaths within 0-28 days of life) by the total number of live births and multiplying the result by 1,000.

 

Given:

 

  • Total births in a year = 4050
  • Stillbirths = 50
  • Neonatal deaths within the first 7 days (early neonatal period) = 50
  • Neonatal deaths within 8-28 days (late neonatal period) = 150

 

Step 1: Calculate the number of live births.

Number of live births = Total births - Stillbirths

Number of live births = 4050 - 50 = 4000

 

Step 2: Calculate the total number of neonatal deaths.

Total neonatal deaths = Neonatal deaths within the first 7 days + Neonatal deaths within 8-28 days

Total neonatal deaths = 50 + 150 = 200

 

Step 3: Calculate the neonatal mortality rate using the formula:

Neonatal mortality rate = (Total neonatal deaths / Total live births) × 1000

Neonatal mortality rate = (200 / 4000) × 1000

Neonatal mortality rate = 50 per 1,000 live births

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neonatal mortality rate is a crucial indicator that represents the number of neonatal deaths (deaths within 0-28 days of life) per 1,000 live births in a given population. It encompasses both early neonatal deaths (within the first 7 days) and late neonatal deaths (8-28 days).

questions.text: Which type of intracranial hemorrhage is most likely depicted in the given image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subdural hematoma 

 

The image provided shows a computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain with a collection of blood within the skull but outside the brain tissue. 

 

This type of hemorrhage occurs beneath the dura mater and above the arachnoid layer. It commonly appears as a crescent-shaped collection that can cross suture lines but is limited by dural attachments such as the falx and tentorium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural hemorrhage (also known as epidural hematoma): Typically biconvex in shape and does not cross suture lines due to the firm attachment of the dura to the skull at the sutures. It is often associated with a skull fracture and middle meningeal artery rupture.

 

Option B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Blood is located under the arachnoid membrane, in the subarachnoid space, where cerebrospinal fluid circulates. On a CT scan, it appears as areas of increased density in the sulci and cisterns, rather than a localized collection.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: This is bleeding directly into the brain tissue and appears as a localized area of increased density within the brain parenchyma itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The crescent-shaped collection of blood on a CT scan that can cross suture lines but is limited by dural reflections is indicative of a subdural hematoma, a type of intracranial hemorrhage that occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid layer.

questions.text: A female presented to the OPD within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse. Which contraception is advised? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IUCD

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a female presenting within 5 days of unprotected sexual intercourse, the most effective emergency contraceptive (interceptive) method advised is the intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD).

 

The IUCD is the recommended method of choice for emergency contraception with the highest efficacy and least failure rate when used within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Misoprostol: This option is incorrect because misoprostol is not an emergency contraceptive method.

 

Option C. LNG: Levonorgestrel (LNG) is a widely accepted method of emergency contraception and is recommended as a first-line option. However, its effectiveness is optimal only within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse, with significantly reduced efficacy beyond this timeframe. And an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) remains the most effective alternative, providing protection for up to 5 days post-intercourse.

 

Option D. OCP: This option is incorrect. While combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are an option, they are not the recommended method of choice when the female presents within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended emergency contraceptive method currently in use are –

 

  • OCPs (Yuzpe and Lancee Method) –  (pills with 30 mcg oestrogen) - 4 pills immediately followed by 4 pills 12 hours later. This method can be used till 72hrs of intercourse.
  • Mini Pills (POP): Progesterone only Pill (POP) 0.75 mg – Pill has to be ‘used within 72 hours of intercourse (LNG oral tablet (0.75 mg): 1st tablet within 72 hours of intercourse and 2nd tablet after 12 hours of first dose)
  • IUCD (most effective; highest efficacy & least failure) – can be used till 5 days
  • RU486 (mifepristone) – within 72 hours
  • High dose of estrogen – to be continuously used for 5 days

questions.text: The rate-limiting enzyme of cholesterol synthesis is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HMG CoA reductase

 

Explanation:

 

HMG CoA reductase (3-hydroxy-3-methyl-glutaryl-CoA reductase) is the rate-limiting enzyme in the cholesterol synthesis pathway. It catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a critical step in the production of cholesterol. This enzyme is a major target for statins, a class of drugs used to lower cholesterol levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 7-alpha hydroxylase: This enzyme is involved in bile acid synthesis from cholesterol, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option C. Carnitine acyltransferase I: This enzyme is involved in the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Option D. Carnitine acyltransferase II: This enzyme is also involved in fatty acid metabolism, specifically in the mitochondrial matrix, not in cholesterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis, making it a critical target for cholesterol-lowering therapies.

 

Note – Rate limiting enzyme of ketone bodies synthesis - HMG CoA Synthase

questions.text: What is the most radiosensitive phase of a cell cycle? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G2M

 

The cell cycle consists of several phases, including the quiescent phase (G0), G1 phase, S phase, G2 phase, and M phase.

 

The G2/M phase of the cell cycle is the most radiosensitive. This phase is critical for cell division, involving DNA repair mechanisms and the process of mitosis. Radiosensitivity is heightened due to the cells’ high mitotic activity and the presence of condensed chromosomes, which are more susceptible to damage by radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S phase: Cells are synthesizing DNA and are somewhat resistant to radiation because DNA repair enzymes are active. S phase is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option C. M phase: Although mitosis is a rapid process, its radiosensitivity is slightly less than G2/M phase.

 

Option D. G1 phase: This phase involves the growth and preparation of the cell for DNA synthesis; cells in G1 are less sensitive to radiation compared to G2/M.

 

Note – Phases of cell cycle –

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who is concerned about his nasal-sounding voice. She reports that her son seems to be frequently "talking through his nose," especially when he is trying to pronounce 'm' and 'n' sounds. Additionally, she mentions that he breathes through his mouth most of the time, especially at night, and has been having difficulty sleeping. On examination, the boy has no signs of acute respiratory distress but does have a hyponasal voice. Xray reveals enlarged adenoids obstructing the nasopharynx. No other abnormalities are noted. What type of voice change is most likely present in this patient due to his enlarged adenoids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinorrhea clausa

 

Given the context of adenoid enlargement affecting the voice, the most likely associated voice change would be Option A, Rhinolalia clausa, because enlarged adenoids can block the nasal passages and affect the normal resonance of speech.

 

Rhinolalia clausa is characterized by a nasal quality to the voice due to blockage in the nasal passages, which could be caused by enlarged adenoids. This blockage prevents normal resonance in the nasal cavities, leading to a muffled, nasal-sounding voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinolalia aperta refers to a voice that sounds excessively nasal due to inadequate closure of the velopharyngeal sphincter, usually not directly associated with adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. A hot potato voice is typically described as a muffled and garbled voice, as if speaking with a hot potato in the mouth. This is often found in conditions such as a peritonsillar abscess rather than adenoid enlargement.

 

Option D. Echolalia is the repetition of phrases or sounds and is a communication disorder. It is not a type of voice quality and is not related to adenoids or their enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The voice of a patient with enlarged adenoids is likely to exhibit Rhinolalia clausa, characterized by a nasal quality due to obstruction of the nasal passages.

questions.text: An old man has recurrent fainting episodes. His ECG shows P-waves at 75/min, QRS complexes are at 35 bpm. The clinical diagnosis is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stokes-Adams Syndrome

 

The patient has recurrent fainting episodes, and his ECG shows a discrepancy between the rate of P-waves (75/min) and QRS complexes (35 bpm), indicating an AV block.

 

In this case, the P-waves are getting blocked at the AV node, leading to fewer QRS complexes.

 

Stokes-Adams Syndrome refers to recurrent fainting/ syncopal episodes caused by sudden fluctuations in cardiac output, paroxysmal Bradycardia often due to AV blocks such as complete heart block or second-degree AV block (Mobitz type II).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: This is seen in cardiac tamponade and is characterized by beat-to-beat variations in QRS amplitude or axis. The patient would present with signs of tamponade such as hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Atrial tachycardia: This would present with a ventricular response rate of more than 100 bpm and would typically involve abnormal P-wave morphology. The patient in this case has bradycardia (QRS at 35 bpm), excluding atrial tachycardia.

 

Option C. First degree AV block: This is characterized by a prolonged PR interval with a 1:1 P to QRS ratio. The discrepancy between P-wave and QRS complex rates in this case excludes first degree AV block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stokes-Adams Syndrome involves recurrent fainting episodes due to sudden changes in cardiac output, typically from AV block-related bradycardia. Recognizing the discrepancy between atrial and ventricular rates is crucial for diagnosis.

choices.text: Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus
Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

questions.text: A 27y primigravida has just delivered. When removing the placenta, uterine inversion is noted. What is the next immediate step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
