questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

 

Explanation:

 

Uterine inversion is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when the uterus turns inside out after delivery. Immediate management is crucial to prevent severe hemorrhage and shock. The next immediate step in the management of uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached. This is done to quickly restore the uterus to its normal position and reduce the risk of continued bleeding and shock.

 

 

After manually repositioning the uterus, the healthcare provider should maintain the position by keeping a fist inside the uterus and administering uterotonic agents such as oxytocin to promote uterine contractions, which help to keep the uterus in place and reduce bleeding. The placenta should only be removed after the uterus has been repositioned successfully.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shift to OT immediately: While surgical intervention may be required if manual repositioning fails, the initial step is to manually reposition the uterus.

 

Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to increased bleeding and is not recommended.

 

Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver: This maneuver involves using fluid pressure to reposition the uterus and is used if manual repositioning fails. It is not the immediate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate step in managing uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached, followed by administration of uterotonic agents to maintain the uterus in its correct position.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with a history of GTCS presented with 4-5 episodes of seizures, and seizures are present for more than 45 minutes. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam

 

Explanation:

 

In the management of status epilepticus (SE), the first line of treatment involves benzodiazepines. Lorazepam is preferred due to its rapid onset and longer duration of action compared to other benzodiazepines like diazepam or midazolam.

 

  • First line treatment: Intravenous (IV) lorazepam (standard dose of 4 mg in adults; different doses for children).
  • If seizures persist after the first dose of lorazepam, it can be repeated once.
  • Second line treatment: If seizures continue after two doses of lorazepam, IV anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) are administered. Options include IV phenytoin, fosphenytoin, levetiracetam, valproate, or lacosamide.
  • If still persist, intubate the patient, continuous EEG monitoring and give IV General anaesthesia (IV midazolam or IV propofol infusion)

 

In this case, following lorazepam with levetiracetam is consistent with current guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Levetiracetam followed by valproate: Levetiracetam is a second-line treatment, not first-line.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine followed by lorazepam: Carbamazepine is not typically used in the acute management of SE.

 

Option D. Valproate followed by gabapentin: Valproate can be used as a second-line treatment, but gabapentin is not typically used for SE management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first line of management for status epilepticus is IV lorazepam, followed by IV antiepileptic drugs like levetiracetam if seizures persist.

questions.text: A pregnant female who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented to the hospital with blood pressure of 210/110 mm Hg. Which of the following is the preferred drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nifedipine

 

Explanation

 

In managing hypertension in a pregnant patient with a history of bronchial asthma, the choice of antihypertensive medication is critical due to the contraindications of certain drug classes in both pregnancy and asthma.

 

Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that is considered safe in pregnancy and does not cause bronchoconstriction, making it the preferred choice for hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with asthma.

 

Nicardipine, another calcium channel blocker, can also be used, especially in IV form, but nifedipine is often chosen due to its safety profile and efficacy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Oral Labetalol and Option C. IV Labetalol: Contraindicated in asthma due to bronchoconstriction. These drugs can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction, making them unsuitable for patients with asthma.

 

Option D. Ramipril: ACE inhibitors like Ramipril are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their association with fetal toxicity, including renal damage and oligohydramnios

 

Educational Objectives:

 

For hypertensive management in a pregnant patient with bronchial asthma, nifedipine is the preferred drug due to its safety in pregnancy and lack of bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: A lady with mitral stenosis who is bedridden, develops sudden onset shortness of breath. On examination, she has a swollen red limb with pain in the calf. What is the clinical diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

 

Explanation

 

The patient, who is bedridden with mitral stenosis, presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb with calf pain. These clinical features strongly suggest deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The sudden shortness of breath indicates that a thrombus from the DVT has likely embolized to the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism. This is a common and potentially life-threatening complication in bedridden patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: This is characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, typically secondary to heart failure, and does not present with a swollen, red limb or calf pain.

 

Option C. Cerebral embolism: This would present with neurological deficits, not shortness of breath and a swollen, red limb.

 

Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus passes from the venous to the arterial system through a cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale). While this could be considered if there were signs of arterial embolism, the presentation here is more consistent with pulmonary embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in bedridden patients presenting with sudden onset shortness of breath and clinical signs of deep vein thrombosis, such as a swollen, red, painful limb.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image, which developed after 3 days of catheterization. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fournier gangrene 

 

This is a serious bacterial infection characterized by necrotizing fasciitis affecting the perineal, genital, or perianal regions. It often presents with rapid onset, pain, swelling, and crepitus due to gas formation, and is associated with high morbidity and mortality rates. The infection can spread quickly, and early surgical intervention is critical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gas gangrene: Also known as clostridial myonecrosis, gas gangrene is caused by infection with Clostridium species and is characterized by sudden, severe pain, swelling, and production of gas, which can be palpable as crepitus

 

Option C. Wet gangrene: This form of gangrene arises when the blood flow to an area is lost, and a bacterial infection develops. It typically affects extremities and is associated with swelling, blistering, and a wet appearance due to pus.

 

Option D. Scrotal hematoma: This is a collection of blood within the scrotal sac but does not involve an infection. It may occur after trauma or surgery. While it can cause swelling and discoloration, it does not present with the same level of systemic illness seen in gangrenous conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fournier gangrene is a urological emergency that involves necrotizing fasciitis of the external genitalia and requires prompt surgical debridement along with broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in the calf muscles after walking for a certain distance. The pain is relieved by rest and reoccurs upon resuming walking. Based on Boyd’s classification, what is the most likely grade? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade III

 

The patient's symptoms are indicative of intermittent claudication, which is pain in the muscles due to inadequate blood flow that occurs with exercise and is relieved with rest. 

 

Patient gets pain on walking, but it compelled to rest leading to relief of pain. This is the scenario in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I: This usually refers to asymptomatic or mild claudication, where the patient has noticeable pain or discomfort in the muscles but can continue to walk and pain disappears.

 

Option B. Grade II: Patient gets pain on walking, but it is bearable and can continue to walk with a limp. 

 

Option D. Grade IV: This implies pain is at rest (not included in the original Boyde’s classification).

 

Given the description of the pain being relieved by rest and reoccurring upon walking, it suggests the patient's symptoms are more than just mild claudication but have not yet progressed to rest pain, which would indicate Grade III.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The patient's symptoms of calf pain upon walking that is relieved by rest is indicative of intermittent claudication, likely corresponding to Grade III of Boyde.

questions.text: A patient had a history of thorn prick while working in a rose garden and later observed linear spread proximally till his shoulder. What is the underlying cause for this clinical feature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphangitis

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is lymphangitis. The patient presents with a history of a thorn prick followed by a linear spread of lesions, which is indicative of sporotrichosis.

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," is caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. The infection typically occurs when the fungus is inoculated into the skin through a thorn prick. The characteristic clinical feature is a linear pattern of nodulo-ulcerative lesions that follow the lymphatic vessels, resulting in lymphangitis.

 

 

Asteroid bodies in sporotrichosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blaschkitis: This condition follows Blaschko's lines and is unrelated to thorn pricks or fungal infections.

 

Option C. Abscess: An abscess is a localized collection of pus within tissues, usually caused by bacterial infection, and does not typically present with a linear pattern of spread.

 

Option D. Furuncle: A furuncle, or boil, is a painful infection of a hair follicle and surrounding tissue caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It does not present with a linear pattern of lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It presents with a linear pattern of nodulo-ulcerative lesions following the lymphatic vessels, leading to lymphangitis. This is typically seen after a thorn prick or similar injury.

questions.text: While performing epidural anaesthesia which of these layers is not punctured ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachnoid mater

 

Explanation:

 

For epidural anesthesia, the needle is inserted through several layers before reaching the epidural space, which is just outside the dura mater. The arachnoid mater is a delicate membrane that encloses the cerebrospinal fluid and runs just under the dura mater. In epidural anesthesia, the arachnoid mater is not punctured, as this would mean the needle has gone too deep, entering the subarachnoid (intrathecal) space.

 

Layers pierced for Epidural anesthesia (from outside to inside):

 

  1. Skin, subcutaneous tissue
  2. Supraspinous ligament
  3. Interspinous ligament
  4. Ligamentum flavum
  5. Epidural space

 

  • Structures pierced during spinal anesthesia / lumbar puncture (outside to inside): Skin, subcutaneous fat, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, duramater, arachnoid mater.
  • Last structure to be pierced during epidural anesthesia : Ligamentum flavum
  • Last structure to be pierced during spinal anesthesia / lumbar puncture: Arachnoid mater

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligamentum Flavum: This is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is the last ligamentous layer that the needle passes through before entering the epidural space.

 

Option C. Supraspinous Ligament: This is a strong, fibrous cord that connects the tips of the spinous processes from the seventh cervical vertebra to the sacrum. This ligament is pierced as the needle progresses towards the epidural space.

 

Option D. Interspinous Ligament: This ligament lies immediately below the supraspinous ligament and connects the adjoining spinous processes to each other. The needle also traverses this ligament as it moves toward the epidural space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The arachnoid mater is not punctured during epidural anesthesia; penetration of this layer indicates a breach into the subarachnoid space, which is not the target for an epidural block.

questions.text: Bubo seen in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphogranuloma venereum

 

Explanation:

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3.

 

A bubo refers to an inflamed, swollen lymph node, often filled with pus. In LGV, this typically presents as inguinal lymphadenitis with pus formation, which is a key characteristic feature.

 

 

Another important sexually transmitted disease associated with bubo formation is chancroid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. Granuloma inguinale: Also known as donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with subcutaneous nodules in the inguinal region but does not involve lymphadenopathy. These nodules are sometimes referred to as pseudo-bubo because of their superficial similarity to buboes, but they do not have the same pathophysiology.

 

Option D. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea typically presents with urethral discharge and does not cause bubo formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bubo is a characteristic feature of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and chancroid, involving inflamed, pus-filled lymph nodes, particularly in the inguinal region. ​

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic patient had undergone surgery for cataract.  6 weeks post-operatively, the patient came with inflammation, decreased vision. On further examination, honeycomb appearance of retina is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoid macular edema

 

The postoperative period, presence of inflammation, decreased vision, and the characteristic honeycomb appearance of the retina are indicative of CME.

 

When CME develops following cataract surgery and its cause is thought to be directly related to the surgery, it is referred to as Irvine-Gass syndrome or pseudophakic CME.

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) involves fluid accumulation within the macula, the central part of the retina, leading to swelling and cyst-like spaces, which can create a honeycomb appearance on optical coherence tomography (OCT). CME is a common complication after cataract surgery, particularly in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSR (Central Serous Retinopathy): Central serous retinopathy is characterized by the accumulation of fluid under the retina, which can cause visual disturbances. It often presents with a serous detachment of the central retina. The classic appearance is not honeycomb-like, and CSR is typically not associated with inflammation.

 

Option C. Retinal Detachment: Retinal detachment is a serious condition where the retina peels away from its underlying layer of support tissue. The classic symptoms are the sudden appearance of floaters, flashes, and a shadow or curtain over part of the visual field. The honeycomb pattern is not characteristic of retinal detachment.

 

Option D. Diabetic Retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the retina. It typically presents with dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and neovascularization. While macular edema can occur in diabetic retinopathy, the description of a postoperative honeycomb appearance of the retina is more specific to cystoid macular edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a diabetic patient presenting with postoperative inflammation and decreased vision featuring a honeycomb appearance of the retina, the likely diagnosis is cystoid macular edema.

questions.text: Thiazide works on ________ in DCT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Na+ Cl- Cotransporter

 

Explanation:

 

Thiazide diuretics act specifically on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) of the nephron. They inhibit the sodium-chloride (Na+ Cl-) cotransporter, which is responsible for the reabsorption of sodium and chloride from the lumen of the DCT into the cells. This inhibition leads to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, resulting in diuresis (increased urine production).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+ K+ 2Cl- Cotransporter: This cotransporter is located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, not in the DCT. Therefore, thiazide diuretics do not act on this transporter.

 

Option B. ENaC Channels: Epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) are found in the collecting duct (CD), not the DCT. Thiazide diuretics do not affect these channels.

 

Option D. Na+ H+ Antiport: This antiport mechanism is not the target of thiazide diuretics. They do not act on this transport system in the DCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+ Cl- cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: What adverse effect is NOT seen with amiodarone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gynaecomastia

 

Explanation

 

Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication with a wide range of potential adverse effects. It is known to cause both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism due to its high iodine content.

 

Hypothyroidism occurs through the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, while hyperthyroidism occurs via the Jod-Basedow phenomenon. Additionally, amiodarone can cause pulmonary toxicity, which can manifest as pneumonitis and pulmonary fibrosis.

 

Gynaecomastia, which is the enlargement of male breast tissue, is not typically associated with amiodarone use. This condition is more commonly linked to medications that influence estrogen or androgen levels, which amiodarone does not significantly affect.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Can occur due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Can occur due to the Jod-Basedow phenomenon.

 

Option D. Pulmonary fibrosis: Known adverse effect of amiodarone, particularly with long-term use.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Amiodarone can cause both hypo- and hyperthyroidism as well as pulmonary fibrosis, but it does not cause gynaecomastia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appears cyanotic with increased work of breathing. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. Chest x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia 

 

  • The clinical picture of a cyanotic newborn with respiratory distress and auscultation revealing bowel sounds in the left hemithorax, combined with chest X-ray showing multiple air-fluid levels, is suggestive of a congenital anomaly that allows abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity. 
  • CDH is a defect in the diaphragm that allows abdominal organs to herniate into the thoracic cavity, impairing lung development and causing respiratory distress and cyanosis after birth. The presence of bowel sounds in the thorax and air-fluid levels on X-ray are indicative of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tetralogy of Fallot: This is a congenital heart defect that includes four abnormalities: ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It leads to cyanotic congenital heart disease but does not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option C. Transposition of the great vessels: This is another congenital heart defect where the major vessels (the aorta and the pulmonary artery) are switched. It results in cyanosis but would not cause bowel sounds in the chest or air-fluid levels on X-ray.

 

Option D. Tracheoesophageal fistula: This condition involves an abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus, which can lead to respiratory distress due to aspiration, but it would not cause bowel sounds in the thorax or the radiographic appearance of air-fluid levels as seen with CDH.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is most likely responsible for the clinical findings of cyanosis, respiratory distress, and bowel sounds in the chest of a newborn, along with air-fluid levels on chest X-ray.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman complains of leakage of urine on straining and coughing. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stress urinary incontinence

 

Explanation:

 

Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) occurs when there is involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining, coughing, sneezing, or exercising. This condition is often due to weakness of the pelvic floor muscles and the urethral sphincter, which fail to properly support the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urge urinary incontinence: This type of incontinence is characterized by a sudden and intense urge to urinate, followed by involuntary leakage of urine. It is commonly associated with an overactive bladder.

 

Option C. Mixed urinary incontinence: This occurs when a person experiences symptoms of both stress and urge urinary incontinence.

 

Option D. Overflow incontinence: This type occurs when the bladder fails to empty completely, leading to leakage of small amounts of urine. It is often associated with bladder outlet obstruction or neurological conditions affecting bladder function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stress urinary incontinence is diagnosed when an individual experiences leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining or coughing, due to weakened pelvic floor muscles and urethral sphincter.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT or GeneXpert? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic test used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin.

 

The key points are:

 

  1. CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection  limit  à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen)
  2. In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance
  3. CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While CBNAAT can detect the presence of MTB, it also provides information on rifampicin resistance, making this option incomplete.

 

Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not directly detect resistance to isoniazid, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance: CBNAAT does not detect resistance to ethambutol, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT or GeneXpert) is a molecular diagnostic tool that primarily identifies the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene.

 

Additional Information –

 

Laboratory Diagnosis

 

  1. Direct microscopy by acid-fast staining
  2. Kinyoun’s Cold acid-fast Staining
  3. Fluorescence Staining
  4. Culture Methods
    1. Conventional Media
    2. Automated Liquid Culture  à BACTEC MGIT
  5. Molecular Methods

  6. Polymerase Chain reaction (PCR)

  7. Automated real Time PCR  à  CBNAAT, TrueNat

 

RNTCP diagnostic algorithm -

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydro-rhodamine test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic Granulomatous Disease

 

Explanation

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary to kill certain bacteria and fungi. This condition is most commonly inherited in an X-linked recessive manner due to a defect in the CYBB gene, which encodes a component of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex.

 

Patients with CGD typically present with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly affecting the skin, lungs, and lymph nodes. The dihydro-rhodamine (DHR) test, which measures the oxidative burst of neutrophils, is used to diagnose CGD. An abnormal DHR test indicates a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme, confirming the diagnosis of CGD.

 

Investigation – NBT and DHR 123 test (flow cytometry)

 

TOC – Allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; IFN gamma

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): SCID is characterized by a severe defect in both T- and B-lymphocyte systems. It presents very early in life with severe immunodeficiency and is often due to adenosine deaminase deficiency.

 

Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect: This results in leukocyte adhesion defect type 2 (LAD-2), which involves issues with leukocyte migration due to defective carbohydrate metabolism affecting leukocyte rolling.

 

Option D. Leukocyte Adhesion Defect (LAD): LAD type 1 involves a defect in the CD18 gene affecting leukocyte adhesion and migration, leading to recurrent infections without pus formation and poor wound healing. LAD type 2 involves a defect in the Sialyl Lewis X structure.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease is diagnosed with the DHR test, which reveals defects in the oxidative burst of neutrophils due to NADPH oxidase deficiency.

questions.text: A child presents with sudden loss of vision in one eye, pain on eye movement and there was RAPD. This is due to the lesion of:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Optic nerve

 

The symptoms described are indicative of an issue at the level of the optic nerve, such as optic neuritis, which can cause sudden vision loss, pain on movement of the eye, and RAPD.

 

The optic nerve transmits visual information from the eye to the brain. A lesion in the optic nerve can cause sudden vision loss in one eye, pain with eye movement (often associated with optic neuritis), and an RAPD, where the pupil of the affected eye does not respond as well to light as the unaffected eye due to the reduced sensory input from the retina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is the part of the brain where the optic nerves partially cross. Lesions at this location typically produce visual field defects in both eyes, such as bitemporal hemianopia, where both outer (temporal) halves of the visual field are lost. It would not typically cause sudden vision loss in one eye, nor would it be associated with pain on eye movement.

 

Option B. Optic Tract: The optic tract carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the lateral geniculate nucleus and other areas. Lesions here can result in homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field cut is observed in both eyes. Like with optic chiasma lesions, optic tract issues do not typically cause sudden unilateral vision loss or pain on eye movement.

 

Option C. Visual Cortex: The visual cortex is located in the back of the brain and is responsible for processing visual information. Damage to the visual cortex can cause a variety of complex visual disturbances, including homonymous hemianopia or cortical blindness, depending on the extent and location of the damage. However, it would not cause unilateral vision loss, pain on eye movement, nor an RAPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of sudden vision loss in one eye, pain on eye movement, and RAPD suggests a lesion in the optic nerve.

choices.text: Derived from pouch of 1st and 2nd arches

questions.text: A patient presents with repeated infections from the lesion shown in the image. The correct statement in relation to the image is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Derived from 1st and 2nd arches

 

Given the location of the lesion near the ear and the recurrent infections which are characteristic of a preauricular sinus, the correct statement is Option C. Derived from 1st and 2nd arches.

 

These lesions are ectodermal in origin and are related to the developmental defects of the first and second branchial arches, which also contribute to the formation of the auricle (external ear).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. "Derived from first cleft" refers to structures that develop from the first branchial cleft in embryonic development. External ear structures, such as the external auditory canal, are derived from the first cleft, but preauricular sinuses are not typically included in this category.

 

Option B. "Derived from pouch of 1st and 2nd arches" refers to internal structures of the ear that can be affected by branchial pouch anomalies. However, preauricular sinuses are not associated with the internal structures derived from the pouches.

 

Option D. "Derived from 3rd and 4th arches" is incorrect for preauricular lesions. The third and fourth branchial arches contribute to the development of parts of the hyoid bone and the structures of the neck, not the external ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sinuses or cysts are congenital lesions derived from the first and second branchial arches and are associated with the external ear, often presenting with recurrent infections

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of wound healing?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemostasis, Inflammation, Proliferation, remodeling

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence of events in the wound healing process is hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling.

 

1. Hemostasis: This is the first step in wound healing, where bleeding is stopped by the formation of a blood clot. This involves vasoconstriction, platelet aggregation, and the activation of the coagulation cascade.

 

2. Inflammation: After hemostasis, the inflammatory phase begins, which involves the influx of inflammatory cells (neutrophils, macrophages) to the wound site. These cells remove debris, bacteria, and damaged tissue, setting the stage for the next phase.

 

3. Proliferation: In this phase, new blood vessels (angiogenesis) are formed, and fibroblasts proliferate and produce collagen, forming granulation tissue. This granulation tissue fills the wound and provides a matrix for the migration and proliferation of epithelial cells, leading to re-epithelialization.

 

4. Remodeling: This is the final phase, where the newly formed collagen fibers are reorganized and cross-linked, leading to increased tensile strength. During this phase, the wound contracts, and excess cells and blood vessels are removed through apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of events in wound healing is hemostasis (stopping bleeding), inflammation (influx of inflammatory cells), proliferation (formation of granulation tissue, angiogenesis, and re-epithelialization), and remodeling (reorganization and cross-linking of collagen fibers).

questions.text: First line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PG analogues

 

These are typically the first choice for the long-term management of glaucoma due to their efficacy and favourable patient adherence factors.

 

Prostaglandin analogues are a class of medications used as the first-line treatment for glaucoma. They work by increasing the outflow of the aqueous humor from the eye, which lowers intraocular pressure. These drugs are preferred due to their effectiveness and once-daily dosing, which improves patient compliance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atropine: is a muscarinic antagonist and is not used for the treatment of glaucoma. It dilates the pupil, which can potentially worsen glaucoma, especially angle-closure glaucoma, by blocking the drainage of the aqueous humor from the eye.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces the production of aqueous humor in the eye, thereby reducing intraocular pressure. It is not typically the first-line treatment due to the potential for systemic side effects and the presence of more effective topical treatments.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: is a cholinergic agonist that contracts the ciliary muscle and opens the trabecular meshwork, allowing for increased outflow of aqueous humor. It is not usually the first choice for the chronic treatment of glaucoma due to its frequent dosing and side effects but can be used in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for adult glaucoma is Prostaglandin Analogues, which are effective in lowering intraocular pressure with a convenient dosing schedule.

questions.text: All of the following are true about NF-1 EXCEPT: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal recessive

 

The correct answer is autosomal recessive. Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1) is an autosomal dominant disorder, not autosomal recessive. It is characterized by multiple café-au-lait macules, Lisch nodules, and an increased risk of developing various tumors, including optic gliomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic glioma: This is true. Patients with NF-1 have an increased risk of developing optic gliomas.

 

Option C. CALM (Cafe Au Lait Macules): This is true. Café-au-lait macules are a common feature of NF-1.

 

Option D. Lisch nodules: This is true. Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas commonly seen in patients with NF-1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by features such as café-au-lait macules, Lisch nodules, and optic gliomas. It is important to remember that it is not autosomal recessive.

questions.text: A patient presented in the ER with hypotension. On auscultation, dullness of heart sound and dilated neck veins was diagnosed, along with cardiac tamponade. Which of the following JVP findings is typically associated with cardiac tamponade? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absent y descent

 

Explanation:


In cardiac tamponade, there is an accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, which impairs the filling of the heart chambers, particularly during diastole. This results in the characteristic absence of the y descent in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform.

 

The y descent normally represents the rapid filling phase of the right atrium and right ventricle.

 

In cardiac tamponade, this filling is restricted, leading to a blunted or absent y descent.

 

Mnemonic "No ThankYou"  → No/ Absence of the Y descent in cardiac Tamponade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prominent x descent: This is typically seen in conditions with increased atrial relaxation and tricuspid regurgitation, but not in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Cannon a wave: This is associated with conditions involving atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block, where atrial contractions occur against a closed tricuspid valve.

 

Option D. Absent a wave: The a wave is absent in atrial fibrillation, where there is no coordinated atrial contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, the characteristic JVP finding is the absence of the y descent.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes conjunctival xerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin A

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A deficiency leads to a condition called xerophthalmia, which causes conjunctival xerosis, also known as dry eye. Xerophthalmia can be classified into two types: primary and secondary.

 

Primary xerophthalmia has five categories:

 

  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis (dry eye)
  • X1B: Bitot's spots (a specific manifestation)
  • X2: Corneal xerosis
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration
  • X3B: Keratomalacia

 

Secondary manifestations of xerophthalmia include:

 

  • XN: Night blindness
  • XF: Xerophthalmic fundus
  • XS: Xerophthalmic scarring

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with megaloblastic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the "4 D's" (diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death). It does not directly cause conjunctival xerosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects in developing fetuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency causes xerophthalmia, which leads to conjunctival xerosis (dry eye) and other ocular manifestations, including Bitot's spots, corneal xerosis, corneal ulceration, and keratomalacia.

questions.text: Which of the following is observed with Philadelphia chromosome:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reciprocal translocation

 

Explanation:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, characteristic of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), is the result of a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t(9;22) (q34;q11).

 

This translocation leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase that drives the uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells in CML.

 

The presence of the BCR-ABL fusion gene can be detected using Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization (FISH), a highly specific and sensitive technique for identifying chromosomal abnormalities. The identification of this fusion gene is crucial for the diagnosis of CML and for guiding targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as imatinib.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Inversion involves a reversal of a chromosomal segment within a single chromosome and is not the mechanism underlying the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option C. Deletion refers to the loss of a portion of a chromosome and is not the primary chromosomal abnormality in CML.

 

Option D. Insertion involves the integration of a segment of one chromosome into another chromosome and is not the characteristic finding in the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome in CML is the result of a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, leading to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which can be detected using FISH and is the target of tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy.

questions.text: Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 Weeks

 

Congenital biliary atresia is a condition where the bile ducts are blocked or absent, leading to bile accumulation in the liver. This condition often presents with jaundice that persists beyond the normal neonatal period.

 

This option is correct. If jaundice is present beyond the first 2 weeks of an infant's life, it is a significant indicator to suspect congenital biliary atresia. Early diagnosis is crucial for better outcomes, and any persistent jaundice beyond this period warrants further investigation for possible biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital biliary atresia should be suspected when jaundice is present beyond 2 weeks.

questions.text: Arrange in order the disaster management cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impact → response → rehabilitation → mitigation

 

Explanation:

 

The correct chronological order of the disaster management cycle is as follows:

 

5 stages -

 

  1. Impact: This is the initial stage when a disaster strikes an area, such as an earthquake, flood, or tsunami.
  2. Response: In this stage, search and rescue operations, first aid, and medical relief efforts are launched.
  3. Rehabilitation: This stage focuses on addressing water, sanitation, food supply, vector control, and other essential services.
  4. Mitigation: Efforts are made to prevent hazards or risks from turning into disasters, minimizing potential damage.
  5. Preparedness: This stage involves planning and preparation for an anticipated disaster, such as a tsunami or earthquake season.

 

The answer to this is choice A, which correctly arranges the stages as impact, response, rehabilitation, and mitigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of the disaster management cycle is impact, response, rehabilitation, mitigation, and preparedness, representing the chronological sequence of actions taken during and after a disaster.

questions.text: Patient has problems in doing heel to shin test and repeatedly misses, and he has tremors in his hands. What is the likely site of lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cerebellum

 

Explanation

 

The heel-to-shin test is a classic test for cerebellar function, and difficulty or inaccuracy in performing this test indicates cerebellar dysfunction.

 

Additionally, the presence of tremors, particularly intention tremors, is characteristic of cerebellar lesions.

 

Cerebellar dysfunction can also present with other signs such as dysdiadochokinesia (difficulty with rapid alternating movements), dysmetria (inability to judge distance or scale), nystagmus, and ataxia (uncoordinated movement).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caudate: Lesions in the caudate nucleus are associated with chorea, characterized by involuntary, irregular, and unpredictable movements.

 

Option C. Globus pallidus: Lesions here typically result in dystonia and rigidity, not tremors or difficulty with the heel-to-shin test.

 

Option D. Pyramidal tract: Lesions in the pyramidal tract lead to spasticity, increased muscle tone, and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, not the symptoms described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebellar lesions are indicated by difficulties with coordination tests such as the heel-to-shin test, presence of intention tremors, and other signs of ataxia. Recognizing these features helps in localizing the lesion to the cerebellum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came with a history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solid foods and now to liquids too. He has also experienced significant weight loss over the past few months. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing the underlying cause of his symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI Endoscopy 

 

The patient's symptoms of progressive dysphagia first to solids and then to liquids, along with significant weight loss, are concerning for an esophageal pathology, possibly a malignancy. 

 

This is the investigation of choice for evaluating dysphagia. It allows direct visualization of the esophageal lumen, can detect strictures, masses, or other abnormalities, and offers the possibility of biopsy, which is essential for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This can provide detailed images of the esophageal wall and adjacent structures and is useful for staging esophageal cancer. It is generally not the first test ordered when investigating dysphagia.

 

Option C. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT): While CECT can provide information about the extent of a disease and help in staging cancer, it is not the first-line investigation for dysphagia and cannot provide a definitive diagnosis without endoscopic visualization and biopsy.

 

Option D. Barium swallow: A barium swallow X-ray study can show structural changes in the esophagus, such as narrowing or obstruction, and is useful in diagnosing conditions like achalasia or strictures. However, it is less definitive than endoscopy for tissue diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Upper GI endoscopy is the first-line diagnostic tool for evaluating a patient with progressive dysphagia and significant weight loss, as it allows for direct visualization and biopsy to establish a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: At what period of gestation is the nuchal translucency measured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Nuchal translucency (NT) measurement is an ultrasound marker used for the screening of chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome (trisomy 21). The optimal time to measure NT is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation, more specifically between 11 weeks and 13 weeks and 6 days. During this period, the NT measurement is most accurate and predictive. The NT scan involves measuring the clear space in the tissue at the back of the baby's neck.

 

An absent Nasal Bone (NB) and increased NT measurement both are the marker of Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Nuchal translucency should be measured between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation to effectively screen for chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with fever and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture was done and CSF examination shows lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein and positive India ink staining. What is likely causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Cryptococcus neoformans. The patient presents with signs of meningitis (fever, neck stiffness) and has a cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) profile showing lymphocytosis, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining.

 

Cryptococcal meningitis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV patients and is diagnosed by the presence of encapsulated yeast cells seen on India ink staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumocystis jirovecii: This organism typically causes pneumonia rather than meningitis.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Tuberculous meningitis usually presents with low glucose levels in the CSF, which is not the case here.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus: Pneumococcal meningitis typically presents with a neutrophilic CSF rather than lymphocytic CSF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is a common cause of meningitis in HIV patients, characterized by lymphocytic CSF, normal glucose, increased protein, and positive India ink staining, which reveals encapsulated yeast cells. ​

questions.text: A pregnant lady comes to the OPD for a regular check-up. She has decreased iron levels and the doctor prescribed her iron medication. Which of the following decreases the iron absorption from the gut? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tea


Iron absorption in the gut is influenced by various dietary factors. Vitamin C, found in foods such as amla (Indian gooseberry), lemon juice, and sprouts, enhances iron absorption by converting ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which is more readily absorbed.

 

On the other hand, substances like tannins and polyphenols, which are abundant in tea, inhibit iron absorption.

 

When tea is consumed with meals, the tannins bind to non-heme iron (plant-based iron), forming insoluble complexes that are not easily absorbed by the gut. This reduces the overall bioavailability of dietary iron. Thus, drinking tea during or shortly after meals can significantly decrease iron absorption, which is particularly important to avoid in individuals with iron deficiency, such as pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amla: Rich in vitamin C, amla enhances iron absorption by converting Fe3+ to Fe2+.

 

Option B. Lemon juice: A citrus fruit high in vitamin C, which aids in iron absorption.

 

Option D. Sprouts: Also high in vitamin C, promoting better iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea contains tannins that decrease iron absorption from the gut by binding to non-heme iron and forming insoluble complexes.

questions.text: In arterial blood gas analysis which one of the following is derived or calculated? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

In arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, we measure specific parameters directly from the arterial blood sample. The directly measured values include:

 

  • pH: The measure of hydrogen ion concentration, indicating the acidity or alkalinity of the blood.
  • pCO2: The partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood, indicating how well CO2 is being eliminated from the body.
  • pO2: The partial pressure of oxygen in the blood, indicating how well oxygen is being absorbed from the lungs.

 

Bicarbonate (HCO3-), however, is not directly measured in ABG analysis. Instead, it is derived from the measured values using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation or calculated from the blood gas analyzer. Along with bicarbonate, base excess or base deficit values are also derived to assess the metabolic component of the acid-base balance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. pH: This is a measured value that indicates the hydrogen ion concentration in the blood.

 

Option B. pCO2: This is a measured value representing the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood.

 

Option C. pO2: This is a measured value representing the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In arterial blood gas analysis, bicarbonate is a derived or calculated value, whereas pH, pCO2, and pO2 are directly measured parameters.

questions.text:
The correct order of events of lactation in the puerperium are? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

 

  1. Lactogenesis
  2. Mammogenesis
  3. Galactopoiesis
  4. Galactokinesis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 1, 4, 3

 

Explanation:

 

The process of lactation involves several stages, each with specific physiological changes. Understanding these stages helps in comprehending the sequence of events that occur from the preparation of the breast during pregnancy to the maintenance of milk production.

 

2. Mammogenesis: This is the first stage, involving the development and growth of the mammary glands in preparation for lactation. It occurs during pregnancy when the breast tissue proliferates and differentiates under the influence of hormones such as estrogen and progesterone.

 

1. Lactogenesis: This stage refers to the initiation of milk production, which begins around the time of birth. Lactogenesis is divided into two phases:
 

  • Lactogenesis I: Occurs during pregnancy when the mammary gland is capable of producing some milk.
  • Lactogenesis II: Occurs postpartum when copious milk secretion begins, typically around 2-3 days after delivery, driven by the sudden drop in progesterone and the increase in prolactin.

 

4. Galactokinesis: This stage involves the ejection or movement of milk from the alveoli to the nipple. It is facilitated by the let-down reflex, which is triggered by the hormone oxytocin. Oxytocin causes the myoepithelial cells around the alveoli to contract, expelling the milk into the ducts and out through the nipple.

 

3. Galactopoiesis: This final stage refers to the maintenance of milk production. It is sustained by the regular removal of milk from the breast, either through breastfeeding or pumping, which maintains prolactin levels and keeps the milk supply ongoing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of events in lactation during the puerperium is: Mammogenesis (breast development), Lactogenesis (initiation of milk production), Galactokinesis (milk ejection), and Galactopoiesis (maintenance of milk production).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with features of massive splenomegaly. On examination, his TLC was more than 85,000/mm³ with immature cells and a shift to the left with the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome. The mutation associated with the Philadelphia chromosome is? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Translocation

 

Explanation

 

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from a balanced reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22. Specifically, the ABL1 gene on chromosome 9 is translocated to the BCR gene on chromosome 22, resulting in the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene encodes a protein with constitutively active tyrosine kinase activity, which leads to uncontrolled cell proliferation.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Inversion: This involves a segment of a chromosome being reversed end to end. It is not associated with the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option C. Deletion: This refers to the loss of a chromosome segment. It is not related to the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option D. Insertion: This involves the addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into a DNA sequence. It is not the mechanism behind the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome is the result of a balanced reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which is a hallmark of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).

questions.text: A G2P1L1 with a previous cesarean section now presents at term. Which of the following is most favorable for a vaginal birth? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Previous lower segment cesarean

 

Explanation:

 

The type of uterine incision from a previous cesarean section significantly impacts the safety and likelihood of a successful vaginal birth after caesarean (VBAC).

 

The lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) involves a transverse incision made in the lower, thinner part of the uterus. This type of incision is most favorable for a vaginal birth due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor, which is around 0.2%.

 

Other Options:

 

Other Incision Types and Associated Risks:

 

Option A. Previous upper segment cesarean: This is also known as a classical cesarean section, where the incision is made vertically in the thicker, upper part of the uterus. The risk of uterine rupture with this type of incision is significantly higher, ranging from 4-9%.

 

Option C. Previous J-shaped cesarean: This incision extends from the lower segment into the upper segment, increasing the risk of rupture to 4-9%.

 

Option D. Previous T-shaped cesarean: This incision combines a lower segment transverse incision with a vertical extension into the upper segment, also associated with a 4-9% risk of rupture.

 

Educational objective:

 

The most favorable incision for a vaginal birth after a previous cesarean section is the lower segment transverse incision due to its lower risk of uterine rupture during labor.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical wall repair 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital condition where the baby is born with the intestines located outside of the body through an opening in the abdominal wall. 

 

This is the most appropriate management strategy. It involves surgical correction where the exposed intestines are placed back into the abdominal cavity and the abdominal wall defect is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This is not an appropriate strategy for gastroschisis. Without prompt surgical intervention, the exposed intestines are at risk of infection, dehydration, and injury.

 

Option C. Slowly putting it inside: While the concept of gradually reducing the bowel back into the abdominal cavity (sometimes called "silo" reduction) is a valid approach, it is performed as part of the surgical management and under controlled conditions, not as a standalone treatment.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This option is not relevant to the management of gastroschisis. There is no need to excise the bowel unless there is nonviable tissue.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate management for a neonate with gastroschisis is immediate surgical repair to return the intestines to the abdominal cavity and close the defect in the abdominal wall.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a diagnostic test for CML? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FISH

 

Explanation

 

Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). This test detects the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is the result of a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, creating the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene produces a protein with abnormal tyrosine kinase activity, which drives the pathogenesis of CML.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Bone marrow Aspiration: While it can show increased cellularity and myeloid hyperplasia, i.e. help in assessing the extent of disease and marrow involvement but is not definitive for diagnosing CML.

 

Option C. LAP score: Low in CML but also low in other conditions, hence not specific.

 

Option D. Karyotyping: While it can detect chromosomal abnormalities, it is less sensitive compared to FISH for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard diagnostic test for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) because it specifically identifies the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of night blindness in pediatric age? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

Night blindness, also known as nyctalopia, is the inability to see well in low light or darkness. The most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group is vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment in the retina that is crucial for vision in low-light conditions.

 

Key Points:

  • Vitamin A deficiency: Leads to inadequate production of rhodopsin, resulting in night blindness.
  • Common causes of vitamin A deficiency: Poor dietary intake, malabsorption disorders, or increased requirements during periods of rapid growth.

 

Symptoms of Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Night blindness
  • Xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  • Bitot's spots (foamy patches on the conjunctiva)
  • Keratomalacia (softening of the cornea)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C deficiency: Causes scurvy, characterized by bleeding gums and perifollicular hemorrhages, but not night blindness.

 

Option B. Congenital glaucoma: A rare condition that can affect vision but does not specifically cause night blindness.

 

Option D. Vitamin E deficiency: Can cause neurological problems and hemolytic anemia but is not typically associated with night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of night blindness in the pediatric age group, emphasizing the importance of adequate intake of vitamin A for maintaining healthy vision, especially in low-light conditions.

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

 

Explanation:

 

The Plasmodium species that affects the brain and can cause cerebral malaria is Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Among the four major Plasmodium species that cause malaria (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale), only P. falciparum is associated with cerebral malaria.

 

While all Plasmodium species can cause malaria symptoms like fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, complications like cerebral malaria are caused specifically by P. falciparum.

 

Pernicious malaria -  (due to heavy parasitization)

 

  • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis
  • Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure
  • Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs

 

Other Options:

 

A. P. vivax, C. P. malariae, and D. P. ovale: These species can cause uncomplicated malaria but do not typically affect the brain or lead to cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Plasmodium falciparum is the only Plasmodium species that can cause cerebral malaria, a potentially life-threatening complication in which the parasites invade and clog the brain's blood vessels.

questions.text: The gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopy

 

Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis. This minimally invasive surgical procedure allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, enabling the identification of endometriotic lesions.

 

During laparoscopy, biopsies can be taken from suspected areas, which are then examined histologically to confirm the presence of endometriosis.

 

While other imaging techniques, such as transvaginal ultrasound or MRI, can suggest the presence of endometriosis, particularly in the case of endometriotic cysts (also known as chocolate cysts), they may miss smaller or less obvious lesions. Laparoscopy, therefore, provides a definitive diagnosis by allowing direct inspection and biopsy of the lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This imaging technique is useful as an initial investigation, especially for detecting endometriotic ovarian cysts, but it is not as comprehensive as laparoscopy for diagnosing all forms of endometriosis.

 

Option B. MRI: MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in some cases, particularly for deep infiltrating endometriosis, but it is not as definitive as laparoscopy.

 

Option C. CT scan: CT scans are not typically used for diagnosing endometriosis due to their lower sensitivity for detecting endometriotic lesions compared to laparoscopy and other imaging modalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopy is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis because it allows direct visualization and biopsy of endometriotic lesions, providing a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Bleeding gums are seen in which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency in Vitamin C (ascorbic acid). Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, which is crucial for maintaining the integrity of connective tissues, including gums. A deficiency in Vitamin C leads to weakened blood vessels, resulting in symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing. The classic symptom of scurvy, bleeding gums, is a direct result of impaired collagen synthesis and capillary fragility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets: Rickets is caused by Vitamin D deficiency, leading to weakened and soft bones. Symptoms include skeletal deformities such as bowed legs and thickened wrists and ankles, but bleeding gums are not a typical feature of rickets.

 

Option C. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as brittle bone disease, is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones that break easily. It primarily affects bone health and does not typically cause bleeding gums.

 

Option D. Hartnup disorder: Hartnup disorder is a rare genetic condition that impairs the body's ability to absorb certain amino acids from the diet, leading to symptoms like skin rashes and neurological issues. Bleeding gums are not a characteristic symptom of Hartnup disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bleeding gums are a classic symptom of scurvy, which is caused by a deficiency in Vitamin C.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs can increase glucose excretion in urine? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Empagliflozin

 

Explanation:

 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor.

 

Drugs in this class (such as empagliflozin, canagliflozin, and dapagliflozin) inhibit the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine (glycosuria). This helps lower blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glimepiride: A sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin release from the pancreas.

 

Option B. Liraglutide: A GLP-1 receptor agonist that increases insulin secretion, slows gastric emptying, and promotes satiety.

 

Option C. Acarbose: An alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays carbohydrate absorption in the intestines, leading to increased excretion of undigested carbohydrates in the stools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, increases glucose excretion in the urine by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in the kidneys.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of milk production in the correct sequence: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

 

  1. Galactopoiesis
  2. Lactogenesis
  3. Mammogenesis
  4. Lactation
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 1, 4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence of milk production involves several stages, starting from the development of the mammary glands to the actual ejection of milk. These stages are:

 

3. Mammogenesis : This is the development of the mammary glands, which begins at birth but continues significantly during puberty. The breast tissue matures and prepares for potential milk production.

 

2. Lactogenesis : This stage refers to the initiation of milk synthesis. It involves hormonal changes that stimulate the mammary glands to start producing milk. Lactogenesis typically begins during the late stages of pregnancy and continues after childbirth.

 

1. Galactopoiesis : This is the maintenance of milk production after lactogenesis has initiated. It involves the continued synthesis and secretion of milk, which is essential for sustaining milk supply during breastfeeding.

 

4. Lactation: This refers to the process of milk ejection and feeding the baby. It encompasses the baby's suckling, which stimulates further milk production and ejection through the let-down reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of milk production involves mammogenesis, lactogenesis, galactopoiesis, and finally lactation.

questions.text: Which of the following middle ear structure is a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot plate of stapes

 

The malleus, incus, and stapes are the three ossicles of the middle ear that transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear. 

 

The footplate of the stapes is the portion of the stapes that sits in the oval window of the cochlea. It is unique among the ossicles because its development involves contributions from neural crest cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malleus: Develops from the first branchial (pharyngeal) arch, also known as Meckel's cartilage, which is not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option B. Stapes: While it is part of the same series of ossicles as the malleus, the main structure of the stapes develops from the second branchial (pharyngeal) arch, known as Reichert's cartilage, which is also not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option D. Incus: Like the malleus, is derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It too is not a derivative of neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The footplate of the stapes in the middle ear is the structure derived from neural crest cells, distinguishing it from the other ossicles (malleus and incus), which are derived from the first and second pharyngeal arches and not from neural crest cells.

questions.text: A mother brought her 3-year-old child with cataract for second opinion. The child appears orthotropic and fine. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cataract surgery

 

The likely management if the cataract is visually significant would be Cataract Surgery. Early intervention with cataract surgery is critical in children to prevent amblyopia and ensure proper visual development. Cataract surgery is the removal of the lens of the eye that has become opaque. In children, this is typically followed by the implantation of an intraocular lens.

 

Given the child is orthotropic (has normal eye alignment) and seems fine, the management would depend on the severity of the cataract and its effect on the child's vision. If the cataract is significant and affecting the child's vision, potentially leading to amblyopia, then cataract surgery would be the appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Convergence of Eye Muscle Exercises: are used to strengthen the eye muscles to improve binocular vision and treat convergence insufficiency. However, they are not a treatment for cataracts, which is a lens-related issue and not a muscle issue.

 

Option B. Reassurance: might be given if the cataract is very mild and not significantly affecting the child's vision. However, in children, even mild cataracts can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) if not treated in a timely manner because visual development is ongoing.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: is a medication used to constrict the pupil and reduce intraocular pressure, and it can also be used to manage acute angle-closure glaucoma. It is not a treatment for cataracts and would not be used as such in a child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 3-year-old child presenting with cataract, the management typically involves cataract surgery to prevent amblyopia and ensure normal visual development, unless the cataract is not significantly affecting vision.

questions.text: A patient came with meningitis. His protein level was elevated and glucose level was normal. CSF examination showed lymphocytosis. What is the likely etiology? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

 

The key points that indicate Mycobacterium tuberculosis as the likely etiology are:

 

  1. The patient presented with meningitis, which can be classified into three types: bacterial (acute), viral (acute), and chronic (tuberculous).
  2. The CSF examination showed lymphocytosis (elevated lymphocytes), which is characteristic of chronic tuberculous meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  3. In bacterial meningitis (caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis), neutrophils are typically elevated, not lymphocytes.
  4. The normal CSF has 0-4 lymphocytes per microliter, while in tuberculous meningitis, the lymphocyte count ranges from 100 to 1000 per microliter.
  5. The protein level was elevated, which is seen in all types of meningitis, and the glucose level was normal, which can occur in tuberculous meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae, B. H. influenzae, and C. Neisseria meningitidis: These are bacterial causes of acute meningitis, which typically present with neutrophilic pleocytosis (elevated neutrophils) in the CSF, not lymphocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with meningitis, the presence of lymphocytosis (elevated lymphocytes) in the CSF, along with an elevated protein level and normal glucose level, strongly suggests tuberculous meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: A patient had wheezing and shortness of breath. His PFT revealed FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7 and FEV1 <80% predicted value. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asthma

 

Explanation:

 

The key findings in this case are wheezing, shortness of breath, and pulmonary function test (PFT) results indicating an obstructive lung pattern (FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7 and FEV1 <80% predicted value). These findings strongly suggest that the patient is suffering from asthma.

 

Asthma is a chronic inflammatory condition of the airways characterized by bronchial hyperresponsiveness, airway obstruction, and symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness. The PFT results showing a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and reduced FEV1 are consistent with the obstructive airway pattern seen in asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial lung disease: This group of disorders primarily affects the interstitium (the tissue between the air sacs) and is not typically associated with wheezing or an obstructive pattern on PFT.

 

Option C. Pneumoconiosis: This refers to lung diseases caused by the inhalation of mineral dust or fibers, such as coal worker's pneumoconiosis or asbestosis. While it can cause respiratory symptoms, it is not typically associated with wheezing or an obstructive pattern on PFT.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: This condition is characterized by irreversible dilation and destruction of the bronchi, leading to chronic cough and copious sputum production. While it can cause shortness of breath, wheezing is not a common symptom, and the PFT pattern may vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with wheezing, shortness of breath, and PFT results indicating an obstructive pattern (FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7 and FEV1 <80% predicted value), asthma should be strongly considered as the likely diagnosis.

 

Obstructive Vs Restrictive Lung disorders:

questions.text: Which of the following type of cataract is seen in ocular blunt trauma?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rosette cataract

 

A rosette cataract, also known as a traumatic cataract, is a specific type of cataract that can occur as a result of ocular blunt trauma. When the eye experiences blunt trauma, such as a direct blow or impact, it can cause disruption or damage to the lens fibers, leading to the formation of a characteristic star-shaped opacity within the lens.

 

The term "rosette" refers to the appearance of the cataract, which resembles a flower-like pattern with radiating spokes or lines extending from a central point.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxic cataract: This type of cataract is caused by exposure to toxic substances, such as certain medications, chemicals, or radiation.

 

Option B. Metabolic cataract: Metabolic cataracts develop due to systemic metabolic disorders, such as diabetes or galactosemia, which affect the metabolism of the lens proteins.

 

Option D. Nuclear cataract: Nuclear cataract affects the central portion of the lens (nucleus) and is associated with aging. It causes gradual clouding and yellowing of the lens nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rosette cataract is commonly seen in ocular blunt trauma.

questions.text: MEN 1 syndrome is associated with:(FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parathyroid tumor

 

MEN 1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1) syndrome is associated with the development of tumors in endocrine glands, particularly the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells. This syndrome is sometimes referred to as the "3 P" syndrome, referring to the involvement of the parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreas.

 

Parathyroid tumors, specifically parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia, are a characteristic feature of MEN 1 syndrome. These tumors lead to the overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), resulting in primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid tumor: Tumors of the parotid gland are not typically associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Hepatocellular cancer: MEN 1 syndrome is not directly linked to the development of hepatocellular cancer (liver cancer).

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma, a tumor of the adrenal gland medulla, is associated with MEN 2 syndrome, not MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, the classic endocrine gland tumors involved are parathyroid tumors (leading to hyperparathyroidism), pituitary adenomas, and pancreatic islet cell tumors (such as gastrinomas and insulinomas). Remembering the "3 P" association (parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreas) can help recall the key features of this syndrome.

 

Familial Syndrome associated with Pheochromocytoma and Extra-adrenal Paragangliomas:

questions.text: A 25-year-old presents with pain over the dorsum of the hand. On examination, the tendon forming the medial border is tender. Which muscle is involved? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the anatomical snuff box, a triangular depression at the base of the thumb. The anatomical snuff box has specific boundaries, and the arrow is pointing to the posterior (posteromedial) boundary. The muscle forming the posterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box is the extensor pollicis longus.

 

 

The mnemonic "aage longus peechhe longus beech mein brevis" helps remember the boundaries:

 

  • Anterior (anterolateral) boundary: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
  • Posterior (posteromedial) boundary: Extensor pollicis longus
  • Between the two boundaries: Extensor pollicis brevis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extensor pollicis brevis: This muscle forms part of the anterior boundary and the floor of the anatomical snuff box, not the posterior boundary.

 

Option B. Abductor pollicis longus: This muscle forms part of the anterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box, not the posterior boundary.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle is not related to the boundaries of the anatomical snuff box. It is a muscle of the thenar eminence, responsible for abduction of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extensor pollicis longus forms the posterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a genital lesion as shown below. What is the best treatment option for her? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cryotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a genital wart, which is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), specifically referred to as condyloma acuminata. In the context of pregnancy, the treatment options for genital warts must be chosen with caution to ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus.

 

Treatment Considerations in Pregnancy:

 

  • Cryotherapy: This method involves freezing the wart with liquid nitrogen, which is a safe and effective treatment for genital warts during pregnancy. It is widely preferred due to its safety profile and effectiveness.
  • Trichloroacetic acid is another safe option during pregnancy for treating genital warts.

 

Other Options:
