Option A. Surgical excision: Though safe, it is not the first-line treatment in most cases unless the warts are extensive.

 

Option B. Podophyllin: Not recommended during pregnancy due to safety concerns.

 

Option C. 5% imiquimod: Also avoided during pregnancy due to safety concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best treatment option for genital warts in a pregnant woman is cryotherapy, as it is safe and effective during pregnancy.

questions.text: Shield ulcer is seen in:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spring catarrh

 

A shield ulcer, is a specific type of corneal ulcer characterized by its unique shape resembling a shield or crescent. These ulcers typically occur in the peripheral cornea and are often associated with certain inflammatory or allergic conditions of the eye, such as vernal keratoconjunctivitis (spring catarrh) or atopic keratoconjunctivitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis - Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is an inflammatory condition of the conjunctiva characterized by the formation of small, raised lesions called phlyctenules. These lesions can occur on the conjunctiva or cornea and are often associated with underlying conditions such as tuberculosis or staphylococcal infection.

 

Option C. Atopic keratoconjunctivitis - Atopic keratoconjunctivitis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the conjunctiva and cornea that occurs in individuals with a history of atopic dermatitis (eczema) or other allergic conditions. It is characterized by severe itching, papillary conjunctivitis, and corneal involvement, which may include the formation of shield ulcers.

 

Option D. Cataract - Cataract is a clouding of the lens of the eye that leads to a decrease in vision. While cataracts can cause various visual disturbances, they are not typically associated with the formation of shield ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spring catarrh, also known as vernal keratoconjunctivitis, is a chronic allergic condition of the conjunctiva that typically occurs in children and young adults during the spring and summer months. It is characterized by symptoms such as itching, redness, and photophobia, and may lead to the development of shield ulcers on the cornea.

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below.(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colour Doppler

 

This technology uses standard ultrasound methods to produce an image of structures and also captures Doppler data to visualize moving blood cells. The color (usually red or blue) in the image represents the speed and direction of blood flow, relative to the ultrasound probe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. USG (Ultrasound): Standard ultrasound uses sound waves to create images of the inside of the body. It's primarily used to view organs and structures and can also detect abnormalities but does not inherently provide information about blood flow unless it includes Doppler capabilities.

 

Option C. X-ray: An X-ray uses radiation to produce images and cannot display blood flow.

 

Option D. CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans use X-rays from multiple angles to create detailed cross-sectional images of the body's internal structures.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In the image provided, the Color Doppler is displaying the blood flow within a specific blood vessel, likely a carotid artery (indicated by R Prox ICA, meaning the proximal right internal carotid artery). The Doppler waveform below the image shows the blood flow velocity during the cardiac cycle, indicating the health and patency of the vessel.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is typically associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid hyperplasia 

 

MEN1 syndrome is characterized by a predisposition to tumors of the parathyroids, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells. Parathyroid hyperplasia is the most common feature, leading to primary hyperparathyroidism in the majority of patients with MEN1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytomas are more commonly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), not MEN1. They are tumors of the adrenal medulla that can secrete excess catecholamines.

 

Option C. Pancreatic carcinoma: While patients with MEN1 can develop various tumors in the pancreas, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are more characteristic than pancreatic carcinoma, which is a malignancy of the exocrine pancreas.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary thyroid carcinoma is associated with MEN2 syndrome, particularly MEN2A and MEN2B, and not with MEN1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hyperplasia is a hallmark of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome, often leading to primary hyperparathyroidism, and distinguish it from other conditions associated with MEN2.

questions.text: During a police investigation, bones are uncovered at the crime scene. What key characteristic feature would be crucial in differentiating between human and animal bones, aiding forensic analysis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Precipitin test

 

When differentiating between human and animal bones found at a crime scene, the key characteristic feature that aids forensic analysis is the species-specific differentiation. In such cases, regardless of the type of tissue (e.g., blood, semen, tissues, or bone), the precipitin test is the test of choice. In the precipitin test, an extract of the bone, tissue, or stain is taken, and an anti-human serum is added to it. If the sample is of human origin, a precipitate will form, indicating a positive result for human tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Acid phosphatase: Acid phosphatase is a specific test used for detecting semen and is not relevant for differentiating between human and animal bones.

 

Option. C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is another test used for detecting semen and is not applicable for differentiating between human and animal bones.

 

Option. D. Phenolphthalein test : This test is a presumptive test to detect blood stain. Also known as (Kastle-Meyer) test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The precipitin test is the key characteristic feature used to differentiate between human and animal bones found at a crime scene. This test is species-specific and can be applied to various tissues, including blood, semen, and bones. The formation of a precipitate upon the addition of an anti-human serum to the sample extract indicates the presence of human tissue.

questions.text: A patient came with infective endocarditis. Examination showed gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the likely etiological agent? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus viridans

 

The key points that indicate Streptococcus viridans as the causative agent are:

 

1. The patient has infective endocarditis, which is commonly caused by Streptococcus viridans.

 

 

2. The microscopic examination showed gram-positive cocci arranged in chains, which is a characteristic morphology of Streptococcus viridans.

 

3. The image provided also confirms the presence of gram-positive cocci (violet color) arranged in long chains.

 

4. Among the options, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Enterococcus typically appear as diplococci (in pairs) and not in chains, ruling them out.

 

5. Streptococcus pyogenes is more commonly associated with rheumatic fever endocarditis rather than infective endocarditis.

 

Gram Positive cocci

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pyogenes: This beta-hemolytic streptococcus is a common cause of rheumatic fever and pharyngitis but not typically associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae: This alpha-hemolytic streptococcus appears as gram-positive diplococci (in pairs) and is a common cause of pneumonia but not a typical cause of infective endocarditis.

 

Option D. Enterococcus: These gram-positive cocci also appear in pairs (diplococci) and are not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Streptococcus viridans, an alpha-hemolytic streptococcus found in the normal oral flora, is a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying heart valve abnormalities or prosthetic heart valves. Its characteristic microscopic appearance of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: In which of the following infections do both partners need to be treated? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. In cases of trichomoniasis, it is essential to treat both the infected individual and their sexual partner(s) to prevent reinfection and to control the spread of the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis (BV): Although BV is associated with an increased risk of acquiring STIs, it is not classified as an STI itself. Therefore, routine treatment of sexual partners is not recommended.

 

Option B. Candidiasis: This is typically caused by an overgrowth of Candida species, commonly Candida albicans, and is not considered an STI. Treating the sexual partner is not usually necessary unless the partner has symptoms of candidiasis.

 

Option D. Genital TB: This is primarily spread through hematogenous (blood) or lymphatic routes rather than sexual transmission. Partners are not treated unless they are also diagnosed with genital tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For trichomoniasis, both partners need to be treated to prevent reinfection and control the spread of the disease.

questions.text: In a patient at risk of re-feeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia 

 

Unlike hypokalemia, hyperkalemia is not typically associated with re-feeding syndrome. Instead, rapid re-feeding may lead to increased insulin secretion, which drives potassium into cells, potentially causing hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Re-feeding syndrome can lead to hypokalemia due to increased cellular uptake of potassium during the anabolic phase, especially if there is concomitant insulin administration.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Re-feeding syndrome can cause hypocalcemia due to decreased parathyroid hormone secretion and subsequent impaired bone resorption, leading to low serum calcium levels.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: Re-feeding syndrome is characterized by rapid shifts of phosphate into cells during the anabolic phase, leading to hypophosphatemia, which can manifest clinically as weakness, respiratory failure, and arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients at risk of re-feeding syndrome, electrolyte imbalances such as hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia are commonly observed, while hyperkalemia is typically not associated with this condition.

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy at 22 weeks of gestation for contraceptive failure after 21 weeks requires approval from:  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 doctors

 

Explanation:

 

Now, MTP is permitted till 24 weeks of gestation. It is divided into two categories: low-risk MTP and high-risk MTP.

 

Low-risk MTP: performed up to 20 weeks of gestation, requires the approval of only one doctor.

 

High-risk MTP: includes cases where the gestational age is between 20 weeks to 24 weeks, the approval of two doctors is required.

 

The specifies that the MTP is being considered at 22 weeks of gestation, which falls under the high-risk category. Therefore, the approval of two doctors is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1 doctor: This option is incorrect because gestational ages above 20 weeks and up to 24 weeks, the approval of two doctors is required.

 

Option C. Court: This option is incorrect because court approval is not required for MTP up to 24 weeks of gestation.

 

Option D. Medical board: This option is incorrect because a medical board's approval is only required for cases involving severe fetal malformations after 24 weeks of gestation, not for the scenario described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy between 20 and 24 weeks of gestation, which is considered a high-risk category, the approval of two doctors is required.

questions.text: The most common organ that injures in air blast-shock wave is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lungs

 

Explanation:

 

In an air blast or shock wave, the most common organs injured are the tympanic membrane (eardrums), lungs, and gastrointestinal tract (GIT), in that order. Since the tympanic membrane is not included in the given answer options, the correct answer among the available choices is the lungs, which are the second most commonly affected organ in an air blast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Kidney: Although the kidneys can be injured in an air blast, they are not the most common organ affected.

 

Option. C. Bones: While fractures can occur due to the impact of an air blast, bones are not the most frequently injured structures compared to the lungs.

 

Option. D. Skeletal muscle: Skeletal muscle injuries can happen in an air blast, but they are not the most common type of injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an air blast or shock wave, the lungs are the most common organ injured among the given options, following the tympanic membrane. In contrast, the gastrointestinal tract is the most frequently affected organ in underwater blast injuries.

questions.text: Reiter's syndrome is associated with: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

Explanation

 

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 antigen. This association is part of a broader category of diseases called seronegative spondyloarthropathies. The key conditions linked with HLA-B27 include:

 

  • Ankylosing Spondylitis: This condition has the highest association with HLA-B27.
  • Psoriatic Arthritis: A form of arthritis that affects some people with psoriasis.
  • Reactive Arthritis (Reiter's Syndrome): Characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis.
  • Enteropathic Arthritis: Associated with inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. HLA B51: It is linked with Behçet's disease.

 

Option C. HLA DR4: Associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. HLA B8: Associated with diseases such as myasthenia gravis and celiac disease.

 

Educational Objectives:


Reiter's syndrome is part of the seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 antigen.

choices.text: Complete mole is triploid, partial mole is diploid
GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma and placental site trophoblastic tumor
Multi-agent chemotherapy is indicated in low-risk choriocarcinoma
Lung metastases indicate a high-risk tumor

questions.text: Which is correct regarding gestational trophoblastic disease? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, and placental site trophoblastic tumor

 

Explanation:

 

GTDs include complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, and placental site trophoblastic tumor: This is correct. Gestational trophoblastic diseases (GTDs) encompass a range of disorders originating from the trophoblastic tissue, including complete mole, partial mole, invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, and placental site trophoblastic tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete mole is triploid, partial mole is diploid: This statement is incorrect. A complete mole is diploid (46XX or 46XY), typically arising from fertilization of an egg with no genetic material by one or two sperm. A partial mole is usually triploid (69XXX, 69XXY, or 69XYY), resulting from fertilization of a normal egg by two sperm or by one sperm that duplicates its chromosomes.

 

Option C. Multi-agent chemotherapy is indicated in low-risk choriocarcinoma: This statement is incorrect. Low-risk choriocarcinoma is typically treated with single-agent chemotherapy, such as methotrexate. Multi-agent chemotherapy is reserved for high-risk cases.

 

Option D. Lung metastases indicate a high-risk tumor: This statement is incorrect. While lung metastases indicate metastasis, in the context of gestational trophoblastic disease, they often respond well to treatment and are considered low risk when the disease is confined to the lungs and shows good prognosis with methotrexate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational trophoblastic diseases include a variety of trophoblastic tumors and conditions, and the treatment and prognosis vary depending on the specific type and risk factors associated with each condition.

questions.text: Graft rejection is seen maximum with which organ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Explanation:

 

Among solid organ transplants, lungs have the highest risk of rejection, followed by the heart, kidneys, and liver. This is due to the lungs' constant exposure to the external environment and their rich supply of blood and lymphatic vessels, which increases the likelihood of the recipient's immune system encountering and reacting to foreign antigens from the transplanted lung tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart has the second-highest risk of rejection after lungs.

 

Option C. Intestine transplantation was not mentioned in the question stem or the explanation.

 

Option D. Kidney has a lower risk of rejection compared to lungs and heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of organ rejection risk from highest to lowest is:

 

  1. Lungs (maximum chances of rejection)
  2. Heart 
  3. Kidneys
  4. Liver

questions.text: Identify the structure pointed in the anatomical snuffbox. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Option C) 

 

  • The marked muscle in the anatomical snuffbox is the extensor pollicis longus. 
  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is a long muscle located at the deep layer with extensor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, and supinator muscle in the posterior compartment of the forearm. 
  • It originates from the mid-third of the ulna, and interosseous membrane then courses down to the distal phalanx of the thumb. 
  • Though it is situated at the forearm, but it is classified as part of the extrinsic muscles of the hand as its function is seen in thumb movement.

 

ANATOMICAL SNUFFBOX

 

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the dorsum of the hand. 
  • It is formed by three tendons of the muscles of the thumb i.e., abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus. 
  • It is a clinically significant area due to the structures it contains, including the radial artery and the scaphoid bone. 
  • Components of anatomical snuffbox are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus (APL) is one of the extrinsic muscles of the hand. Its major function is to abduct the thumb at the wrist. Its tendon forms the anterior border of the anatomical snuffbox.

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) belongs to the deep group of the posterior fascial compartment of the forearm. It is a part of the lateral border of the anatomical snuffbox. This muscle extends the thumb at the MCP and CMC joints. It is also a mild abductor of the thumb.

 

 

Option D. Cephalic vein: The cephalic vein arises as a convergence of superficial veins on the dorsum of the hand in the anatomical snuffbox. From there it runs along the surface just above the radial styloid process. Just beneath the clavicle, the cephalic vein drains into the axillary vein, which bends downwards towards the heart.

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

  • The marked muscle tendon the given image is of the extensor pollicis longus in the anatomical snuffbox. 
  • It forms the medial boundary of the snuffbox and functions to extend the thumb.

questions.text: Identify the edges of the lesion given in the following image: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rolled out and beaded

 

The image depicts a skin lesion with particular features at the edges, likely a basal cell carcinoma on face. 

 

This description fits basal cell carcinoma, where the edges of the lesion often have a rolled, pearly appearance due to the nature of tumor growth beneath the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Everted: Everted edges are turned outward or upward. This can be seen in Squamous cell Ca.

 

Option C. Sloping: Sloping edges gradually incline or decline from the lesion to the surrounding skin, without a distinct border. This can be seen in various skin conditions like healing ulcers but is not typically used to describe basal cell carcinoma.

 

Option D. Punched out: Punched-out edges are very steep, almost as if the tissue has been cut with a sharp object. This is more characteristic of trophic or ischemic ulcers. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When identifying skin lesions, rolled out and beaded edges are characteristic of basal cell carcinoma, a common type of skin cancer often seen in sun-exposed areas of the skin.

questions.text: What is the likely ECG changes noted with the use of new anti-tubercular drug bedaquiline: (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) QT prolongation

 

The likely ECG change noted with the use of bedaquiline is QT prolongation. This prolongation of the QT interval can increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, including a specific type known as Torsades de Pointes. Monitoring of the QT interval is important during bedaquiline therapy, and caution is advised, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiac conditions or those taking other medications that can also prolong the QT interval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in PR interval: An increase in the PR interval is not a common ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Option C. ST segment elevation: ST segment elevation is not a typical ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Option D. QRS widening: QRS widening is not a common ECG change associated with bedaquiline use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

QT prolongation is a well-documented ECG change associated with the use of bedaquiline. It is one of the notable side effects of this drug.

questions.text: A woman presents with white vaginal discharge. On preparing a vaginal smear, pseudo hyphae are seen. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candidiasis

 

The presence of pseudohyphae on a vaginal smear is indicative of a fungal infection, specifically candidiasis. Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans, are known to form pseudohyphae as part of their growth pattern. This finding, along with white vaginal discharge, supports the diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Candidiasis: Characterized by white, thick, curd-like vaginal discharge and the presence of pseudohyphae and spores on microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomonas: Identified by the presence of flagellated protozoa (Trichomonas vaginalis) on the smear.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: Diagnosed by the presence of clue cells on the smear, which are vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, giving a stippled appearance.

 

Option D. Physiological: Normal vaginal discharge, which shows normal vaginal epithelial cells without any pathogenic organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of pseudo-hyphae on a vaginal smear with white discharge is diagnostic of candidiasis.

questions.text: A patient presented with hypertension, increased heart rate, and sweating. He sees red halos after hearing the radio. Which substance's abuse can cause this? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) LSD

 

The patient's symptoms include hypertension, increased heart rate, and reflex hallucinations (seeing red halos in response to auditory stimuli).

 

Reflex hallucinations occur when a stimulus in one sensory modality triggers a hallucination in another sensory modality, such as an auditory stimulus leading to a visual hallucination.

 

LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen known to cause such reflex hallucinations. Additionally, LSD can lead to sympathetic symptoms like hypertension and increased heart rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cocaine: Although cocaine can cause sympathetic symptoms such as hypertension and increased heart rate, it is less commonly associated with reflex hallucinations.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol abuse typically does not present with reflex hallucinations and the described symptoms.

 

Option C. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid that typically causes sedation and respiratory depression, not reflex hallucinations or sympathetic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

LSD, a hallucinogen, can cause reflex hallucinations, where a stimulus in one sensory modality (e.g., auditory) produces a hallucination in another modality (e.g., visual), along with sympathetic symptoms like hypertension and increased heart rate.

questions.text: A patient presented with ptosis which gets worsened by evening. He was diagnosed to be a case of myasthenia gravis. What is the preferred treatment of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridostigmine

 

Pyridostigmine is the preferred initial treatment for myasthenia gravis. It is effective in improving muscle strength by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, thereby increasing its availability at the neuromuscular junction. Other options like plasma exchange and cyclosporine are typically reserved for more severe cases or when standard treatments fail. Physostigmine is not commonly used for myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasma Exchange: This is used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in cases of myasthenic crisis or before surgery. It's an acute treatment method rather than a long-term management strategy.

 

Option B. Cyclosporine: This is an immunosuppressant used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis, usually in cases where patients do not respond to first-line treatments or as an adjunct therapy.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Unlike pyridostigmine, physostigmine is not commonly used for myasthenia gravis because of its central adverse effects. It is a lipid soluble cholinesterase inhibitor and is mainly used in atropine poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor and is the mainstay of treatment for myasthenia gravis. It helps increase the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving muscle strength.

questions.text: What are the stages of demographic cycle with same birth rate but variable death rate?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stage 1 + stage 2

 

Explanation: 

 

The demographic transition model consists of five stages, each characterized by different levels of crude birth rates (CBR) and crude death rates (CDR). In stages 1 and 2, the birth rate remains high, while the death rate varies.

 

 

Stage 1 (High Stationary): In this stage, both the CBR (green line) and CDR (red line) are very high, resulting in a relatively stable population size.

 

Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The CBR remains high, but the CDR starts declining due to improvements in medical facilities, more hospitals, and more doctors. This leads to population growth.

 

Other Options:

 

In stage 3 (Late Expanding), the CBR starts declining for the first time due to the introduction of family planning programs, while the CDR continues to decrease. India is currently in this stage.

 

In stage 4 (Low Stationary), both the CBR and CDR are low, resulting in a stable population. This combination does not represent stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

 

In stage 5 (Declining), the CBR falls below the CDR, leading to population reduction. This combination does not represent stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In stages 1 and 2 of the demographic transition model, the crude birth rate remains high, while the crude death rate is high in stage 1 but starts declining in stage 2, making these the stages with the same birth rate but variable death rate.

questions.text: A patient presented with Ventricular Tachycardia. What is the best drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

Explanation

 

For treating ventricular tachycardia (VT), the drug of choice in acute situations according to Advanced Life Support (ALS) protocols is Amiodarone. It is a class III antiarrhythmic medication that works by prolonging the action potential duration and refractory period in the myocardial cells, thus stabilizing the cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Adenosine: Ineffective for ventricular tachycardia as it is primarily used for supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Option C. Propranolol: A beta-blocker used for various cardiac conditions, but not typically effective for acute VT.

 

Option D. Ivabradine: Used to reduce heart rate in chronic heart failure and stable angina, not suitable for VT management

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Amiodarone is the best drug for the acute management of ventricular tachycardia due to its efficacy in stabilizing cardiac rhythm by prolonging the action potential and refractory period in myocardial cells.

questions.text: Which gene is affected in Reiter's syndrome?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HLA-B27

 

Explanation:

 

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is strongly associated with the HLA-B27 gene. The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a risk factor for developing Reiter's syndrome.

 

Reiter's syndrome is a type of spondyloarthritis, a group of inflammatory diseases that primarily affect the spine and joints. It is characterized by a triad of symptoms: arthritis (joint inflammation, typically affecting the knees, ankles, and feet), conjunctivitis (inflammation of the eye), and urethritis (inflammation of the urethra).

 

The HLA-B27 gene is a component of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) system, which plays a crucial role in the immune system's recognition of foreign substances. The association between HLA-B27 and Reiter's syndrome suggests that the gene may contribute to the development of the condition, possibly by influencing the immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA-DR3: This gene is associated with autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and Graves' disease.

 

Option B. HLA-DR4: This gene is strongly linked to rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. HLA-DQ8: This gene, along with HLA-DQ2, is associated with celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HLA-B27 gene is the primary genetic factor associated with the development of Reiter's syndrome, a type of spondyloarthritis characterized by a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who is eagerly drinking water and skin pinch goes back slowly. Which category does the child belong according to IMNCI? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

The Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) is a strategy developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF to improve child health in developing countries. The child's symptoms of eagerly drinking water and a slow skin pinch return are indicative of some dehydration, which falls under the yellow category in the IMNCI guidelines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Green: The green category denotes "no dehydration." This would be for a child who shows no signs of dehydration and is otherwise healthy.

 

Option C. Pink: The pink category denotes "severe dehydration." Signs of severe dehydration include lethargy, unconsciousness, very dry mouth, and a skin pinch that goes back very slowly.

 

Option D. Black: This is an incorrect option as the IMNCI color coding does not include black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the IMNCI color coding system:

 

  • Green indicates no dehydration.
  • Yellow indicates some dehydration.
  • Pink indicates severe dehydration.

questions.text: Which of the following factors can decrease iron absorption? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tea

 

Tea, especially black tea, contains compounds called tannins. Tannins can bind to iron, making it harder for the body to absorb. Therefore, drinking tea, especially with meals, can decrease the absorption of iron.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C: Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, actually enhances iron absorption, especially non-heme iron (the form of iron found in plant-based foods). It does this by converting iron into a form that is more easily absorbed by the body.

 

Option C. Sprouts: Sprouts, like other plant-based foods, contain phytates (phytic acid), which can bind to minerals like iron and inhibit their absorption. However, the process of sprouting reduces the phytate content, which may actually improve the availability of iron.

 

Option D. Gastric Acid: Gastric acid is crucial for iron absorption as it helps convert iron into its ferrous (Fe2+) form, which is more easily absorbed. Reduced gastric acid can lead to decreased iron absorption, as seen in conditions like atrophic gastritis or with the use of certain medications (like proton pump inhibitors).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea, particularly due to its tannin content, is known to decrease iron absorption. The other options, Vitamin C and gastric acid, typically aid in iron absorption, while sprouts, although containing phytates, have reduced phytate levels due to the sprouting process and are not the primary dietary concern for iron absorption inhibition

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with right-sided serous otitis media and history of cervical lymphadenopathy. The probable diagnosis is:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasopharyngeal cancer

 

Given the age of the patient and the presence of both right-sided serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, the most likely diagnosis is Nasopharyngeal cancer.

 

Nasopharyngeal cancer can present with serous otitis media due to Eustachian tube obstruction by the tumor or swollen lymph nodes in the nasopharyngeal region. Cervical lymphadenopathy is also a common finding due to the spread of the malignancy to the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiofibroma, specifically juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, is a benign tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males. It can cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis (nosebleeds), but is less commonly associated with serous otitis media and is not typically diagnosed in a 50-year-old male.

 

Option C. Adenoid hypertrophy is more common in children and can cause eustachian tube dysfunction leading to serous otitis media; however, it is unlikely to be associated with cervical lymphadenopathy, especially in adults.

 

Option D. Otitis media with effusion, also known as serous otitis media, is the accumulation of fluid within the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It can be a result of eustachian tube dysfunction, which could be secondary to a mass effect from a nasopharyngeal tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an adult patient presents with serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, it is crucial to consider nasopharyngeal cancer as a possible diagnosis, especially in the context of risk factors such as age over 50 years and a history suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman discovers a well-defined, mobile and rubbery breast lump measuring 2.5 x 6 cm on self-examination. The lesion is painless and has been stable over several months. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the described characteristics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroadenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario describes a young female with a well-defined, mobile lump in the breast, which is characteristic of a breast mouse or fibroadenoma. Fibroadenomas are benign breast tumors that typically present as freely mobile masses in young women. They consist of an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in the breast stroma. Depending on the arrangement of the fibrous tissue, fibroadenomas can be classified as pericanalicular or intracanalicular subtypes. Notably, the use of the immunosuppressive drug cyclosporine has been associated with an increased risk of developing fibroadenomas.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma In Situ), Option C. Invasive ductal carcinoma, and Option D. Intraductal papilloma are all malignant or precancerous lesions that would typically present with additional signs such as skin dimpling, nipple retraction, or ulceration, rather than as a mobile, painless lump in a young woman.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibroadenomas are the most common cause of benign, mobile breast lumps in young women. They are characterized by an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in the breast stroma and may be associated with the use of cyclosporine.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with seizures. On further evaluation, there was also a history suggestive of manic and depressive episodes. Which of the following drugs should be prescribed?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

The patient has a history of both seizures and bipolar disorder, characterized by manic and depressive episodes. Valproate (also known as valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant medication that is effective in treating both seizure disorders and bipolar disorder. It helps in stabilizing mood and preventing both manic and depressive episodes, making it an appropriate choice for patients with comorbid bipolar disorder and seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregabalin: This drug is primarily used for neuropathic pain and certain anxiety disorders; it is not effective in the treatment of bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Phenytoin: This is an anticonvulsant used to treat seizures but does not have mood-stabilizing properties needed for bipolar disorder.

 

Option D. Levodopa: This is primarily used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and has no role in the management of seizures or bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Valproate is effective for treating both seizure disorders and bipolar disorder, making it the drug of choice for patients with comorbid conditions.

questions.text: Apoptotic bodies comprise of: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytoplasm + nuclear fragment + organelle

 

Apoptotic bodies are formed during the process of apoptosis, or programmed cell death. Apoptosis involves the activation of caspase enzymes, endonucleases, and proteases, leading to the fragmentation of the dying cell. These cellular fragments, known as apoptotic bodies, contain components of the cell, including cytoplasm, nuclear fragments, and organelles. The presence of these components within the apoptotic bodies is a key characteristic of the apoptotic process.

 

 

 

 

TUNEL Staining (Mouse liver showing an apoptotic cell stained with TUNEL)

Apoptotic body is looks like a dense, eosinophilic structure,  the presence of a stepladder pattern on gel electrophoresis and TUNEL staining, which are both associated with the detection of apoptotic cells. These techniques help identify the fragmented DNA and cellular components present in apoptotic bodies.

 

 

Lane B – showing apoptosis as a stepladder pattern on gel electrophoresis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apoptotic bodies, formed during the process of apoptosis, comprise cytoplasm, nuclear fragments, and organelles of the dying cell.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is brought to the ER following a suspected stroke. The patient is unable to speak fluently, though he understands the given instructions. Which category of aphasia is most likely present in the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Broca's aphasia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient in the question exhibits symptoms consistent with Broca's aphasia, also known as motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, the patient has difficulty with speech production and articulation but maintains relatively intact language comprehension. This is evident from the fact that the patient understands the given instructions but is unable to speak fluently.

 

Broca's area, located in the frontal lobe (Brodmann areas 44 and 45), is responsible for speech production and articulation. Damage to this area, often caused by a stroke, results in Broca's aphasia. Patients with Broca's aphasia struggle with fluent speech but can typically understand language, as the Wernicke's area remains unaffected.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's aphasia : This is a form of sensory aphasia where patients have difficulty understanding language but can produce fluent, albeit meaningless, speech. Wernicke’s area is located at the Posterior part of area no 22. This is associated with hearing loss.

 

Option C. Conduction aphasia : In this type of aphasia, the patient can understand and produce language, but there is a disconnect between the Wernicke's area and the Broca's area (Brodmann areas 39 and 40). This results in difficulty repeating words or phrases, which is not mentioned in the patient's case.

 

Option D. Global aphasia : This is a severe form of aphasia involving both Broca's and Wernicke's areas, leading to impairments in both language production and comprehension. The patient in the question does not exhibit signs of impaired comprehension, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca's aphasia, or motor aphasia, is characterized by difficulty in speech production and articulation while language comprehension remains relatively intact. It is caused by damage to Broca's area (Brodmann areas 44 and 45) in the frontal lobe, often due to a stroke.

questions.text: Coral red fluorescence on Wood's lamp seen in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythrasma

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is erythrasma.

 

Erythrasma is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum and typically presents as hyperpigmented patches in skin folds, such as the axilla and toe web spaces. When examined under a Wood's lamp, which emits ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 365 nanometers, erythrasma exhibits a characteristic coral red fluorescence due to the porphyrins produced by the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitiligo: Under a Wood's lamp, vitiligo shows a milky white fluorescence. This is due to the absence of melanin in the depigmented areas of the skin.

 

Option C. Pityriasis versicolor: Caused by the yeast Malassezia furfur, this condition shows a yellow fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

 

Option D. Acanthosis nigricans: This condition does not exhibit any fluorescence under a Wood's lamp. It presents with hyperpigmentation and a velvety texture, particularly in skin folds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythrasma, caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, presents with coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp, distinguishing it from other dermatological conditions that may exhibit different types of fluorescence or none at all.

questions.text: Which bones are cut during external DCR?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maxillary, lacrimal

 

In external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR),  the maxillary bone is involved because it forms part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity and part of the orbit. The lacrimal bone is also involved because it contains the lacrimal sac fossa. The surgery involves creating a direct opening between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity by removing part of the lacrimal bone and the adjacent part of the maxillary bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethmoid, Sphenoid: The ethmoid and sphenoid bones are part of the skull's cranial base and are not typically involved in an external DCR. The ethmoid bone does contribute to the medial wall of the orbit and contains the ethmoid air cells, while the sphenoid bone is part of the skull base and contains the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option B. Ethmoid, Lacrimal: The lacrimal bone is a small bone forming part of the eye socket, and it is indeed involved in DCR as it forms part of the lateral nasal wall and houses part of the nasolacrimal duct. The ethmoid bone, as mentioned, is part of the medial orbital wall but is not typically cut during an external DCR procedure.

 

Option D. Nasal, Lacrimal: The nasal bone forms the bridge of the nose and is not typically modified during an external DCR. The lacrimal bone is involved in the procedure as mentioned, but the nasal bones are not cut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the maxillary and lacrimal bones are cut to establish a new tear drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following rules out transudative pleural effusion except? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High fibrin

 

Explanation:

 

Transudative pleural effusions are typically characterized by low protein, low specific gravity, and low cellular content. High fibrin content, on the other hand, is suggestive of an exudative effusion rather than a transudative one.

 

Differentiating features:

 

 

 

Additional information

 

Light's criteria: These are used to differentiate exudative pleural effusions from transudative effusions based on the chemical and cellular characteristics of the pleural fluid.

 

  1. Protein Ratio: If the ratio of the protein content in the pleural effusion to the serum protein is more than 0.5 (or 50%), the effusion is likely an exudate.
  2. LDH Ratio: If the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level in the effusion is more than 60% (or 0.6) of the serum LDH, it indicates that the effusion is likely an exudate.
  3. LDH Upper Limit: If the LDH level in the effusion exceeds two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH as defined by the laboratory, the effusion is likely an exudate.

 

If, any one out of three criteria is positive, then its an exudate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low protein: This is a feature of transudative effusions.

 

Option C. Low specific gravity: This is also a characteristic of transudative effusions.

 

Option D. Low cellular content: This is another feature seen in transudative effusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High fibrin content in pleural fluid is indicative of an exudative effusion, which rules out the diagnosis of a transudative pleural effusion.

questions.text: Which structure forms the lateral boundary of the Hasselbach’s triangle? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior epigastric vessels

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle is formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

 

The Hasselbalch triangle is an important anatomical region related to the anterior abdominal wall and is relevant to the understanding of inguinal hernias.

 

The Hasselbalch triangle's boundaries are formed by the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the rectus abdominis muscle medially, and the inguinal ligament forming the base.

 

This triangle is discussed in the context of inguinal hernias, where a direct inguinal hernia occurs when the hernia protrudes through the Hasselbalch triangle, while an indirect inguinal hernia occurs outside of this triangle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vessels: The femoral vessels are not mentioned as forming the lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle.

 

Option C. Inguinal ligament: The inguinal ligament forms the base of the Hasselbalch triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option D. Rectus abdominis: The rectus abdominis muscle forms the medial boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle, an important anatomical region related to inguinal hernias, is formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came with early satiety, massive splenomegaly, petechiae, and bleeding gums. Her hemoglobin was 8 gm/dl and TLC was 85,000/mm3. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CML

 

The clinical presentation and laboratory findings are highly suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).

 

The patient, a 20-year-old female, presents with early satiety, which can be attributed to the massive splenomegaly. An enlarged spleen can compress the stomach, leading to a feeling of early satiety. Massive splenomegaly is a characteristic feature of CML, resulting from the infiltration of the spleen by leukemic cells.

 

The presence of petechiae and bleeding gums indicates thrombocytopenia, which is a common finding in CML patients. Thrombocytopenia can be caused by the decreased production of platelets due to the crowding out of normal hematopoietic cells by the leukemic cells in the bone marrow.

 

The patient's hemoglobin level of 8 gm/dl suggests anemia, another common finding in CML. Anemia in CML can be due to the ineffective erythropoiesis caused by the abnormal proliferation of myeloid cells.

 

The most striking finding is the markedly elevated total leukocyte count (TLC) of 85,000/mm3, which is highly indicative of CML. In CML, there is a characteristic uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells, leading to a significant increase in the white blood cell count.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): ALL is more common in pediatric patients and typically presents with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and bone tenderness. The extremely high TLC and massive splenomegaly are more suggestive of CML than ALL.

 

Option B. AML (Acute Myelogenous Leukemia): AML can present with gum hyperplasia, the presence of myeloblasts with granular cytoplasm, or Auer rods (rod-shaped or needle-shaped crystals). The chronic nature of the presentation and the massive splenomegaly are more consistent with CML.

 

 

Option D. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): CLL is more common in older adults and typically presents with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and a high lymphocyte count. The high TLC with myeloid predominance and the absence of significant lymphadenopathy make CML a more likely diagnosis than CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) should be strongly suspected in a patient presenting with massive splenomegaly, early satiety, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and a markedly elevated total leukocyte count with myeloid predominance.

 

The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, is the hallmark genetic abnormality in CML.

questions.text: A 12 weeks pregnant lady visited the doctor. On ultrasound, it was found she has a low-lying placenta. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat ultrasound at 32 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

At 12 weeks gestation, the presence of a low-lying placenta is often not a cause for immediate concern because the placenta typically "migrates" upward as the pregnancy progresses. This migration is due to the expansion of the uterus, which effectively moves the placenta away from the cervix. Therefore, the recommended management is to repeat an ultrasound between 28 to 32 weeks to reassess the position of the placenta. By this time, the majority of placentas that were initially low-lying will have moved to a safer position, allowing for a more accurate determination of whether there will be any complications related to placenta previa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step for a pregnant woman found to have a low-lying placenta at 12 weeks is to repeat the ultrasound at around 32 weeks to reassess the placenta's position and determine appropriate management.

questions.text: Voltage-gated calcium channel present on T-tubule is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dihydropyridine receptor

 

Explanation:

 

The T-tubules, or transverse tubules, are invaginations of the sarcolemma (muscle cell membrane) that play a crucial role in transmitting action potentials from the sarcolemma to the interior of the muscle fiber.

 

The voltage-gated calcium channels present on the T-tubules are known as dihydropyridine receptors (DHPR). These receptors are critical for the excitation-contraction coupling in muscle cells.

 

Dihydropyridine receptor: These receptors are voltage-gated calcium channels located on the T-tubules. When an action potential travels down the T-tubule, it activates the DHPR, which in turn mechanically activates the ryanodine receptor (RYR) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, leading to the release of calcium ions into the cytoplasm and triggering muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ryanodine receptor: This receptor is also involved in calcium release but is located on the sarcoplasmic reticulum, not on the T-tubules. It is mechanically coupled to the DHPR in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. SERCA: The Sarcoplasmic/Endoplasmic Reticulum Calcium ATPase (SERCA) pump is responsible for pumping calcium back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, but it is not located on the T-tubules.

 

Option D. Nicotinic receptor: These are ligand-gated cation channels located at the neuromuscular junction on the sarcolemma, not on the T-tubules. They are responsible for initiating the action potential in response to acetylcholine but are not involved in calcium transport in the T-tubules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The voltage-gated calcium channel present on the T-tubules is the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR), which plays a crucial role in the excitation-contraction coupling in muscle cells.

questions.text: Which of the following, when consumed with oral iron, reduces its absorption?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tea

 

Explanation

 

The absorption of oral iron can be affected by various dietary substances. Tea contains tannins, which are polyphenolic compounds that can bind to iron and reduce its absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. This is why tea consumption is often advised to be separated from iron supplementation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Lemon juice: Contains high amounts of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which actually enhances iron absorption by reducing ferric iron to the more absorbable ferrous form.

 

Option B. Amla juice: Like lemon juice, it is rich in vitamin C and thus enhances iron absorption.

 

Option C. Sprouts: Contain iron and proteins, which can aid in iron absorption.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Tea, due to its tannin content, can reduce the absorption of oral iron when consumed together.

questions.text: According to European hernia society classification (EHS), hernia labelled as PL2 implies? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary indirect

 

The European Hernia Society (EHS) classification for groin hernias includes a designation based on the location and whether the hernia is primary or recurrent. 

 

Refers to a primary hernia occurring laterally to the inferior epigastric vessels, which protrudes through the deep inguinal ring. According to the EHS classification, a primary indirect hernia located in the lateral region with defect size 2 finger breadths (3 cm) is labelled as PL2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary direct: Refers to a primary hernia occurring medially to the inferior epigastric vessels, typically in Hesselbach's triangle. It is labelled as “PM”. 2 refers to size of defect as 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

 

Option C. Recurrent direct: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous direct hernia repair.

 

Option D. Recurrent indirect: Would refer to a recurrence of a hernia in the same place as a previous indirect hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

According to the EHS classification, a hernia labeled as PL2 refers to a primary indirect inguinal hernia that is having a defect of size 2 finger breadths (3 cm).

questions.text: Which virus outbreak occurred in Kerala following consumption of date palm sap? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nipah virus

 

Explanation:

 

The Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala was linked to the consumption of fruits contaminated with bat secretions. Date palm sap, which is a popular drink in the region, can become contaminated with bat secretions containing the Nipah virus when bats feed on the sap. Consumption of this contaminated sap led to the Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebola virus transmission occurs through contact with contaminated body fluids from infected individuals. It is not associated with the consumption of date palm sap or fruits.

 

Option C. Litchi Virus Disease, also known as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES), has been reported in West Bengal. It is linked to the consumption of litchis on an empty stomach by children, which can lead to severe hypoglycemia and death due to the generation of methylenecyclopropylglycine (MCPG).

 

Option D. West Nile Fever, transmitted by the Culex pipiens mosquito, has been reported in Kerala.

 

Note - Although a single case of Ebola virus was reported at the Delhi International Airport, it is not related to the Kerala outbreak caused by the consumption of date palm sap.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala was linked to the consumption of date palm sap contaminated with bat secretions containing the virus.

questions.text: On the given axial CT scan of the thorax, which heart chamber is marked by the arrow? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The radiological image shows a transverse section of the heart.

 

In a CT scan taken with the patient lying supine, the right atrium and right ventricle will be seen on the front side, while the left atrium and left ventricle will be at the back. The base (posterior surface) of the heart is mainly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) and the right atrium (one-third).

 

In the image, the vertebra is at the back, and the aorta is on the left side in front of the vertebra. The esophagus is closely related to the base of the heart, particularly the left atrium. The chamber marked in the question is the one just in front of the esophagus is the left atrium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right atrium: The right atrium is towards the right side and forms the right border of the heart in this view.

 

Option C. Right ventricle: The right ventricle lies on the front side along with the right atrium. It forms the sternocostal surface of the heart. The marked chamber is at the back, so it cannot be the right ventricle.

 

Option D. Left ventricle: The left ventricle lies next to the left atrium at the back in this transverse section. However, the marked chamber is the one closest to the esophagus, which is the left atrium, not the left ventricle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a transverse CT section of the heart, the right atrium and ventricle are seen anteriorly, while the left atrium and ventricle are seen posteriorly.

questions.text: Which injury is not a part of ‘terrible triad of elbow’? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fracture of olecranon

 

TERRIBLE TRIAD OF ELBOW

 

  • A notoriously unstable injury is the elbow dislocation with associated fractures of the radial head and coronoid process of the ulna is termed the terrible triad of the elbow.
  • Elbow dislocation is often associated with posterolateral dislocation or LCL injury.
  • Mechanism of injury is fall on supinated forearm and extended arm that results in a combination of valgus, axial, and posterolateral rotatory forces.
  • This produces posterolateral dislocation.
  • Structures of elbow fail from lateral to medial:  
    • LCL
    • Anterior capsule
    • Possible MCL disruption
  • Patients complain of pain, clicking and locking with elbow in extension.
  • Physical examination shows possible varus / valgus instability patterns.
  • Radiographs help evaluate the concentricity of humeroulnar and radiocapitellar joints; specifically, lateral films can assist in diagnosing coronoid fractures.

 

 

  • CT scan is routinely obtained to identify fracture patterns, comminution, and displacement, which may not be evident on plain radiographs. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fracture of olecranon is not a part of the terrible triad injury of the elbow.
  • In the terrible triad injury, the radial head and coronoid process are fractured, along with dislocation of the elbow joint.

questions.text: Most common complication of ERCP is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatitis

 

Explanation

 

The most common complication of Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is pancreatitis. The incidence of post-ERCP pancreatitis is approximately 5-10%, although may vary slightly with ranges from 3.5% to 9.5%. Despite this relatively high incidence, the majority of these cases are mild and can be managed conservatively. Severe acute pancreatitis occurs in less than 1% of cases following ERCP.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Cholangitis: Although a potential complication, it is less common than pancreatitis following ERCP.

 

Option B. Duodenal Perforation: This is a rare but serious complication.

 

Option C. Bleeding: Another potential complication, but less common compared to pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Pancreatitis is the most common complication following Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), occurring in approximately 5-10% of cases.

questions.text: Identify the chest x-ray finding shown below. (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lung collapse

 

A collapse can occur when part of the lung becomes airless and typically appears as an area of increased density. The X-ray provided shows a significant opacity along with volume loss, evidenced by the displacement of interlobar fissures and the mediastinum ipsilaterally, which is suggestive of collapse. This is often accompanied by compensatory hyperinflation in the unaffected areas.

 

The chest X-ray shows a significant abnormality in the lung field, suggestive of a lung collapse (atelectasis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Consolidation:  On an X-ray, consolidation typically appears as a uniform increase in pulmonary parenchymal opacity, which may obscure the lung markings and can sometimes involve an entire lobe. Air bronchograms (air-filled bronchi made visible by the opaque alveoli around them) may be visible. There is no mediastinal shift which is typically associated.

 

Option B. Effusion: On an X-ray, this typically shows as a blunting of the costophrenic angles, with fluid layering dependently and possibly causing a meniscus sign along the chest wall. With contralateral mediastinal shift

 

Option D. Intrathoracic Mass Lesion: A mass would typically appear as a well-defined area of increased density, which might push against or compress adjacent structures. The image does not clearly show such characteristics, as the opacity seems too extensive and involves a loss of volume rather than a discrete mass pushing on surrounding tissues.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The opacity and associated signs of volume loss indicate that part of the lung has collapsed, likely due to an obstruction or compression of the airways.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Newborn

 

Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) is a program focused on the care of newborns or neonates, which refers to the first 7 days of life. The term "Navjat Shishu" itself means "early newborn" or "neonate."

 

NSSK is a training program designed for healthcare personnel at all levels, aiming to improve newborn care and resuscitation practices. It is a component of the Reproductive and Child Health (RCH) program under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lactating women: NSSK does not specifically target lactating women, although proper newborn care and feeding practices are likely to be included in the training program.

 

Option B. Children: The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is a separate program that focuses on the health of children aged 0 to 18 years, not specifically newborns.

 

Option D. Pregnant women: While pregnant women are an important target group for various maternal health programs, like JSY, JSSK.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK) is a training program for healthcare personnel at all levels, focusing on the care and resuscitation of newborns (neonates) in the first 7 days of life.

questions.text: Mid-year population is the denominator in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CDR

 

Explanation:

 

The mid-year population is used as the denominator to calculate the Crude Death Rate (CDR). The CDR is calculated as the total number of deaths divided by the mid-year population, multiplied by 1,000.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because. It is calculated as Annual number of live births per 1000 women of childbearing age (15–49 years) mid-year population

 

Option C. MMR (Maternal Mortality Ratio) - This option is incorrect because the MMR is calculated as maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, not using the mid-year population as the denominator.

 

Option D. NMR (Neonatal Mortality Rate) - This option is incorrect because the NMR is calculated as neonatal deaths per 1,000 live births, not using the mid-year population as the denominator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mid-year population is the denominator used in the calculation of the Crude Death Rate (CDR), which represents the total number of deaths per 1,000 population in a given year or period.

questions.text: A patient with a painless expanding annular plaque with scarring at the center present on the buttocks. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lupus vulgaris

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis. It typically presents as a painless, expanding annular plaque with scarring at the center. The lesion often advances at one edge while showing atrophy or scarring at the center or the other edge. This characteristic appearance helps in distinguishing it from other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tinea: Tinea typically presents as an annular plaque with central clearing, not central scarring.

 

Option C. Psoriasis: Psoriasis usually presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales. It does not present with the annular configuration and central scarring described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris, the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis, presents as a painless, expanding annular plaque with central scarring. This characteristic appearance is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatological conditions such as tinea and psoriasis. ​​

choices.text: It can be done with the opinion of 2 doctors
It cannot be done if there is a fetal Anomaly
It requires the opinion of a medical board

questions.text: A patient presents at 22 weeks for an MTP due to failure of contraception. Which of the following is correct? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It cannot be done

 

As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Amendment Act of 2021, the upper limit for termination due to failure of contraception is 20 weeks.

 

The Act extends the permissible gestational age for termination to 24 weeks, but only in specific cases, including:

 

Fetal anomalies

 

Pregnancies resulting from rape or sexual assault

 

Maternal health risks

 

Certain socio-economic conditions (e.g., a woman becoming a widow or getting divorced after conception)

 

In this case, the patient requests MTP at 22 weeks due to failure of contraception, which is not a legally permissible indication beyond 20 weeks.

 

MTP beyond 20 weeks is only allowed for fetal anomalies and other specific conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be done with the opinion of 2 doctors: Incorrect because MTP beyond 20 weeks for failure of contraception is not allowed, regardless of the number of doctors.

 

Option B. It cannot be done if there is a fetal anomaly: Incorrect because MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in the presence of substantial fetal anomalies, with a board’s approval.

 

Option C. It requires the opinion of a medical board: Incorrect because a medical board is only required for MTP beyond 24 weeks for fetal anomalies or rare medical conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP for failure of contraception is only allowed up to 20 weeks.

 

MTP between 20-24 weeks is permitted for specific cases such as fetal anomalies, maternal health risks, and pregnancies due to sexual assault.

 

Beyond 24 weeks, termination requires the approval of a medical board for severe fetal anomalies.

questions.text: A patient has diabetes with fasting level of 140 gm/dl and PP level of 200 gm/dl. The target HbA1c to be maintained is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) < 7.0

 

For patients with an established diagnosis of diabetes, the target HbA1c level to be maintained is less than 7.0%. HbA1c is a measure of the average blood glucose levels over the past 2-3 months, and keeping it below 7.0% is considered good glycemic control for diabetic patients.

 

The given information indicates that the patient has diabetes, with a fasting blood glucose level of 140 gm/dl and a postprandial (PP) level of 200 gm/dl. These elevated glucose levels are characteristic of diabetes, and maintaining an HbA1c level below 7.0% is the recommended target to reduce the risk of diabetic complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with an established diagnosis of diabetes, the target HbA1c level to be maintained is less than 7.0% to achieve optimal glycemic control and reduce the risk of diabetic complications.

choices.text: Bag mask ventilation with jaw thrust

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department following severe maxillofacial trauma sustained in a road traffic accident. The airway is compromised, and immediate intervention is required. What is the most appropriate immediate management? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroidotomy 

 

Cricothyroidotomy involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane to establish an emergency airway. It's the most appropriate immediate management in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway when orotracheal intubation is not feasible or contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tracheostomy: Tracheostomy involves creating an opening in the trachea through the neck to establish an airway. While it's a definitive airway management technique, it's not the most appropriate immediate management in an emergency due to the time required and the need for specialized equipment.

 

Option B. Orotracheal intubation: Orotracheal intubation involves passing an endotracheal tube through the mouth into the trachea to secure the airway. It's a commonly performed procedure in emergency settings for airway management, but it may be challenging or contraindicated in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma.

 

Option D. Bag-mask ventilation with jaw thrust: Bag-mask ventilation involves manually delivering breaths using a bag and mask to ventilate the patient's lungs. While it can provide temporary oxygenation, it may not be sufficient for maintaining a patent airway in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway, cricothyroidotomy is the most appropriate immediate management to establish an emergency airway when orotracheal intubation is not feasible or contraindicated.

choices.text: Conservative management with observation and ice chips.
Immediate cauterization of the bleeding site

questions.text: A 10 year old girl post tonsillectomy ate a packet of chips 2-3 days after the surgery and now came to the hospital with oral bleed. What shall be the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antibiotics with semisolid food

 

Antibiotics with semisolid food is one approach to manage postoperative bleeding after tonsillectomy. The rationale behind antibiotics is to prevent or treat any possible infection that might have been caused by the chips. Semisolid food is recommended to minimize the mechanical irritation to the tonsillar fossa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical exploration may be required if the bleeding is significant or if it does not stop with conservative measures. This would involve returning to the operating room to identify the source of bleeding and achieve hemostasis.

 

Option C. Conservative management with observation and ice chips can be appropriate for minor bleeding. Ice chips can help with vasoconstriction and pain relief. Observation is crucial to ensure that bleeding does not worsen.

 

Option D. Immediate cauterization of the bleeding site may be necessary if the bleeding is active and significant. This would typically be done under controlled conditions, possibly in the operating room.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-tonsillectomy bleeding is a potential complication that can be managed conservatively with antibiotics and dietary modifications, such as semisolid food, to prevent further mechanical trauma to the surgical site. However, the approach to management should be tailored to the severity of the bleeding and the clinical condition of the patient, with more aggressive interventions like surgical exploration or cauterization reserved for significant or persistent bleeding.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the superficial parotid gland on FNAC? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy

 

The preferred treatment for a benign tumor of the parotid gland, as confirmed by fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC), is:

 

This is the treatment of choice for a benign parotid tumors like pleomorphic adenoma. It involves the surgical removal of the entire superficial lobe. Enucleation or simple excision is avoided as the tumor has projections (pseudopodia) which may be left behind leading to recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide local incision: This is not typically performed for benign parotid tumors. However, now a days it is becoming an alternate to superficial parotidectomy.

 

Option C. Chemotherapy: This is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as they are typically not responsive to chemotherapy agents.

 

Option D. Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is not a standard treatment for benign parotid tumors as it is generally reserved for cancer treatment and not indicated for benign conditions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Superficial parotidectomy is the preferred treatment for a benign tumors like pleomorphic adenoma, providing targeted removal of the entire superficial lobe.

questions.text: A 24y woman presents with suspected ovarian torsion. What is the investigation of choice? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ultrasound + Color Doppler

 

Ultrasound combined with Color Doppler is the investigation of choice for suspected ovarian torsion.

 

 

This combination is highly effective in identifying the condition. When a patient presents with symptoms of severe abdominal pain, often accompanied by nausea and vomiting, which is not relieved by analgesics, ovarian torsion should be considered, particularly if an adnexal mass is present. On the ultrasound with Color Doppler, the characteristic "whirlpool sign" can be observed, indicating twisted ovarian vessels and confirming the diagnosis.

 

The use of Color Doppler helps in assessing the blood flow to the ovary. In cases of torsion, blood flow may be absent, leading to ovarian ischemia. A laparoscopy can further confirm the diagnosis, revealing a twisted ovarian pedicle and a necrotic ovary if the torsion is prolonged. Treatment involves laparoscopic detorsion, where the twisted ovary is untwisted. If blood flow returns, a cystectomy may be performed to remove any cysts. If the ovary remains necrotic, an ovariectomy may be necessary to remove the affected ovary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound + Xray: While an ultrasound is useful, an Xray does not provide additional value in diagnosing ovarian torsion. X-rays are not effective in visualizing soft tissues or blood flow.

 

Option C. Ultrasound + DSA: Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is more invasive and not typically used for diagnosing ovarian torsion. It is mainly used for detailed vascular imaging.

 

Option D. MRI: MRI can provide detailed images but is not the first-line investigation due to its higher cost and limited availability compared to ultrasound with Color Doppler.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for suspected ovarian torsion is an ultrasound combined with Color Doppler, which helps visualize the characteristic whirlpool sign and assess blood flow to the ovary.

questions.text: A farmer had a lesion on his shoulder. Histopathological image of the lesion is shown below. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous Cell Carcinoma

 

The histopathological image provided shows features consistent with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). The key characteristics that support this diagnosis are the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.

 

Keratin pearls are concentric, whorl-like structures composed of keratinized cells, which are a hallmark of well-differentiated SCC. The presence of keratin indicates that the tumor cells are undergoing a process of keratinization, which is a characteristic feature of squamous epithelium. In the image, the pink, circular structures with a laminated appearance are keratin pearls.

 

Intercellular bridges, also known as desmosomes, are specialized cell junctions that connect adjacent squamous epithelial cells. These bridges help maintain the structural integrity of the epithelium and are visible as small, spiky projections between the tumor cells in the image.

 

The occupation of the patient (farmer) is also relevant, as prolonged exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight is a major risk factor for the development of SCC, particularly on sun-exposed areas like the shoulder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is another type of skin cancer that arises from the basal layer of the epidermis. However, BCC typically lacks keratinization and the formation of keratin pearls, which are seen in this image.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus. Histologically, it is characterized by the presence of molluscum bodies, which are large, eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions within the keratinocytes.
