These features are not seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. Verrucous carcinoma: Verrucous carcinoma is a rare, low-grade variant of SCC that typically presents as a warty, exophytic growth. While it may show some keratinization, the classic keratin pearls and intercellular bridges seen in this image are more suggestive of conventional SCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges in a skin biopsy is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma, particularly in a patient with a history of prolonged sun exposure.

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly damaged after parotid surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

 

The Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII) is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid gland surgery due to its anatomical course through the gland. Damage to this nerve can result in facial paralysis or weakness, affecting expressions and other functions like eyelid closure and stapedius muscle reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Trigeminal nerve (Cranial Nerve V) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing. It is less commonly damaged during parotid surgery because of its location and the type of sensory and motor innervation it provides.

 

Option C. The Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX) is involved in taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue and swallowing. It is not typically at risk during parotid surgery as it does not traverse the parotid gland like the facial nerve.

 

Option D. The Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI) innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles and is not usually at risk during parotid surgery because it does not run through the parotid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Facial nerve is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid surgery due to its anatomical path through the parotid gland, making it vulnerable to injury during surgical procedures involving this gland

questions.text: Asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane is due to: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Gibbs Donan reaction

 

The asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane is primarily due to the Gibbs Donan effect. This effect arises from the semi-permeable nature of the cell membrane, which allows certain ions to pass while restricting others. Inside the cell, there are non-diffusible ions such as phosphates and proteins. These non-diffusible ions create an imbalance in the distribution of diffusible ions like potassium (K⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻). The presence of non-diffusible ions inside the cell results in the repulsion of chloride ions and influences the movement of potassium ions, leading to an asymmetrical distribution of ions across the cell membrane. This equilibrium state is referred to as the Gibbs Donan equilibrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-K with primary active transport: This refers to the sodium-potassium pump (Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase), which actively transports sodium and potassium ions across the cell membrane using energy from ATP. This pump is essential for maintaining the resting membrane potential (RMP) but does not directly contribute to the asymmetrical ion differentiation as it is an active process, not a passive one like the Gibbs Donan effect.

 

Option C. Na-Cl pump: There is no specific Na-Cl pump involved in the asymmetric distribution of ions. Sodium and chloride ions are transported through different mechanisms, but they do not directly relate to the asymmetrical distribution explained by the Gibbs Donan effect.

 

Option D. Nernst Equilibrium: The Nernst equation calculates the equilibrium potential for a particular ion based on its concentration gradient across the membrane. It helps determine the magnitude of the potential difference but does not explain the asymmetrical distribution of ions itself. The Nernst equilibrium describes a theoretical condition, not the mechanism behind the asymmetrical ion distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gibbs Donan reaction explains the asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane due to the presence of non-diffusible ions and the semi-permeable nature of the membrane.

questions.text: A patient had an RTA that caused crush injury. Within 3 days of the injury and post-amputation, crepitus was present and the wound was reddish brown. Identify the diagnosis: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gas gangrene 

 

Gas gangrene, caused by Clostridium bacteria, presents with rapid onset of severe pain, edema, and crepitus due to gas production in the tissues. The wound may appear reddish-brown or bronze-colored.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Necrotizing fasciitis: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressing infection of the deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, causing severe pain, skin discoloration, and systemic toxicity. However, it typically does not present with gas production.

 

Option C. Tetanus: Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani and typically presents with muscle stiffness and spasms due to the neurotoxins produced by the bacteria. It does not involve crepitus or tissue gas.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection characterized by redness, swelling, warmth, and pain in the affected area. It does not typically involve gas production or crepitus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Gas gangrene, characterized by rapid tissue destruction, gas production, and a reddish-brown appearance of the wound, should be promptly recognized and managed due to its potential for rapid progression and systemic complications.

questions.text: Most common site of genital TB is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fallopian tube

 

Explanation:

 

Genital tuberculosis (TB) primarily affects the female reproductive system, with the fallopian tubes being the most common site of infection. Tuberculous salpingitis can lead to various complications, including:

 

  • Endosalpingitis or Exosalpingitis: Inflammation inside or around the fallopian tubes.
  • Beading of the tube: Formation of small nodular masses or swellings along the tube.
  • Constriction of the tube: Narrowing of the tube, which can obstruct the passage of the ovum.
  • Hydrosalpinx: Accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, often due to obstruction caused by TB.

 

These complications can significantly impact fertility, making infertility a common issue in women with genital TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Other Sites of Genital TB:

 

Option A. Cervix: Less commonly affected.

 

Option B. Endometrium: Can be involved, but not as frequently as the fallopian tubes.
 

Option D. Ovary: Also less commonly affected compared to the fallopian tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fallopian tube is the most common site of genital tuberculosis, leading to significant complications such as salpingitis, hydrosalpinx, and infertility.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with vertigo, tinnitus and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given image? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meniere’s disease

 

Given the patient's symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss, along with the audiogram showing a sensorineural hearing loss pattern with a dip at low to mid frequencies, the most likely diagnosis is Option B, Meniere’s disease.

 

Meniere’s disease is characterized by episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear. The audiogram typically shows a sensorineural hearing loss that predominantly affects the low to mid frequencies, which is consistent with the audiogram provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo): Is a disorder arising from a problem in the inner ear. Symptoms include vertigo that is usually triggered by changes in the position of the head. It doesn't typically cause hearing loss, which we can see in the audiogram.

 

Option C. Vestibular neuronitis: Is an inflammation of the vestibular nerve, leading to vertigo and imbalance, but it does not usually affect hearing, so the audiogram would not show the hearing loss pattern we see here.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Is a middle ear disease that usually presents with conductive hearing loss, particularly in younger adults, and it does not cause vertigo or tinnitus as primary symptoms. The audiogram for otosclerosis would show an air-bone gap, which is not present in the audiogram provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss, and an audiogram showing low to mid frequency sensorineural hearing loss is Meniere’s disease.

questions.text: The condition shown in the picture below is associated with which chromosomal abnormality? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45XO

 

The image depicts a young female with features characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is associated with the chromosomal abnormality 45X0. Turner syndrome is characterized by a complete or partial absence of one of the X chromosomes. Key clinical features include short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and delayed puberty. These physical findings align with the typical presentation of Turner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 47XXY (Klinefelter syndrome): Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males and is characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome (47XXY). This condition typically presents with tall stature, gynecomastia, and infertility, which do not match the features seen in the image.

 

Option C. 46X0 (XO mosaic): This option describes a mosaic form of Turner syndrome where some cells have a single X chromosome (45X0) while others have a typical female karyotype (46XX). While this is possible, the features described are more characteristic of classical Turner syndrome (45X0).

 

Option D. 48XY (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome - AIS): AIS occurs in individuals with a male karyotype (46XY) but with insensitivity to androgens, resulting in incomplete or complete female external genitalia. However, AIS does not typically present with short stature, webbed neck, or widely spaced nipples, which are key features of Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome (45X0) presents with short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and delayed puberty. Recognizing these phenotypic patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing patients with developmental and reproductive disorders.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a mobile, rubbery mass in her left breast. A histological image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis for the given image? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma 

 

The finding of mobile breast and the histological image showing a mixture of stromal and epithelial tissue, often described as having a 'staghorn’ appearance is seen in fibroadenoma.

 

This is a common benign tumor of the breast, usually presenting as a mobile, rubbery mass. Histologically, it shows a mixture of stromal and epithelial tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC): This is the most common type of breast cancer. Histologically, IDC typically shows abnormal, invasive glandular cells that originate from the ducts and invade surrounding breast tissue.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: This is a rare breast tumor that can be benign or malignant. Histologically, it is similar to fibroadenoma but typically shows increased stromal cellularity and leaf-like projections. It is not mobile.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma in-situ (LCIS): LCIS is a non-invasive condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lobules of the breast. Histologically, it shows small, uniform cells that fill and expand the lobules.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fibroadenoma is the likely diagnosis of a mobile, rubbery breast mass in a young woman, characterized histologically by a benign proliferation of stromal and epithelial components.

questions.text: What is the substance used in PET scan? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Fluoro-deoxy-glucose

 

This is a glucose analog where fluorine-18 replaces a normal hydroxyl group. FDG is taken up by cells, but unlike glucose, it is not metabolized, making it useful for imaging active tissues like cancer cells which metabolize glucose at high rates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tc99m pertechnetate: This is a radioactive form of technetium used primarily in the imaging of the thyroid gland and in nuclear medicine scans like the Meckel’s diverticulum scans. It is not used in PET scans.

 

Option C. Iodine-123: This isotope is primarily used in gamma imaging, particularly in thyroid studies, not in PET scanning.

 

Option D. Tc99-M: This refers to Technetium-99m, used widely in SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) imaging, not in PET scans.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Fluoro-deoxy-glucose (FDG) is the primary tracer used in PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scans to image metabolic activity of tissues.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with weight gain and hyperpigmentation. High dose dexamethasone suppression test was done in a patient & ACTH remained high before and after the test. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ectopic ACTH producing tumor

 

Explanation

 

The patient is a chronic smoker, which increases the risk of cancers such as small cell lung cancer, known to produce ectopic ACTH. The presentation of weight gain and hyperpigmentation are features of Cushing's syndrome. In ectopic ACTH production, the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test typically fails to suppress ACTH levels, as observed in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pituitary adenoma: In Cushing's disease caused by a pituitary adenoma, ACTH levels usually decrease with high-dose dexamethasone suppression.

 

Option C. Exogenous source: Exogenous steroids do not cause hyperpigmentation and would suppress ACTH levels.

 

Option D. Adrenal adenoma: In adrenal adenoma, cortisol levels are high, which suppresses ACTH production, leading to low ACTH levels and no hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ectopic ACTH production, often from small cell lung cancer, should be suspected in chronic smokers presenting with features of Cushing's syndrome and non-suppressible ACTH levels following high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. ​

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain and breathlessness but was medically fit. The patient is refusing to go back home and he doesn’t want to leave the hospital. The patient gives a history of robbery under gun-point that happened 10 days ago. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute stress disorder

 

The patient experienced a traumatic event 10 days ago and is now presenting with anxiety symptoms, making acute stress disorder the most probable diagnosis.

 

Acute stress disorder is characterized by the development of severe anxiety and other symptoms within one month after exposure to an extreme traumatic stressor. These symptoms include intrusive thoughts, flashbacks, and avoidance behavior, although the given case focuses on anxiety.

 

The duration of symptoms is crucial: if symptoms persist for more than one month, the diagnosis shifts to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avoidant personality disorder: This cannot be diagnosed based on a single event; it requires a lifelong pattern of behavior characterized by social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and hypersensitivity to negative evaluation.

 

Option B. Delusional disorder: This involves persistent delusions without other major psychotic symptoms. There is no mention of delusions in the patient's history.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia: This diagnosis requires symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and other psychotic behaviors persisting for at least six months. The patient's history does not suggest these symptoms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute stress disorder occurs within one month of a traumatic event and is characterized by anxiety and other stress-related symptoms. If symptoms last longer than one month, the diagnosis changes to PTSD.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block and suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the first line of management? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20% IV Intralipid

 

Explanation

 

The patient experienced toxicity due to bupivacaine, a local anesthetic. The first-line treatment for local anesthetic toxicity, including bupivacaine toxicity, is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy). This treatment works by acting as a "lipid sink," which helps to absorb the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules and reduce their toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. IV Epinephrine: Suitable for cardiac arrest but not the first line for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Option C. IV Soda Bicarbonate: Used in cases of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity causing ventricular arrhythmias but not for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Option D. IV Dobutamine: Used to treat heart failure and certain types of shock, but not specifically for local anesthetic toxicity

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The first-line treatment for bupivacaine toxicity is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy).

questions.text: Iron absorption is decreased by the intake of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tea

 

Explanation:

 

There are several factors that can decrease iron absorption, including phytates (present in cereals and legumes), tannates (present in tea, coffee, and soft drinks), oxalates (present in milk and eggs), and certain medications like tetracycline.

 

The only facilitator of iron absorption is vitamin C or ascorbic acid.

 

Among the given options, tea contains tannates, which are known to inhibit iron absorption. Therefore, the intake of tea decreases iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amla: This option is incorrect because amla is a rich source of vitamin C, which enhances iron absorption.

 

Option B. Sprouts: This option is incorrect because sprouts are a good source of iron.

 

Option D. Lemon: This option is incorrect because lemon is a source of vitamin C, which facilitates iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tea contains tannates, which are compounds that inhibit iron absorption. Consuming tea can decrease the absorption of iron from dietary sources.

questions.text: In context of biliary atresia, what is the typical duration of jaundice observed in infants? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 weeks 

 

Biliary atresia typically presents with jaundice that is not evident at birth but becomes apparent within the first two weeks of life. Jaundice lasting longer than two weeks in a newborn can be indicative of biliary atresia, especially if it is conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2 Months: While jaundice in biliary atresia often becomes noticeable after the first two weeks of life, it would likely persist and not resolve on its own, prompting further investigation well before two months of age if it is due to biliary atresia.

 

Option C. 2 years: Jaundice due to biliary atresia would be identified and treated well before a child reaches two years of age. If left untreated, biliary atresia can lead to liver failure within the first two years of life.

 

Option D. 48 hours: Physiological jaundice of the newborn typically appears within the first 24 to 72 hours after birth and resolves without treatment. Jaundice persisting beyond this period, especially if it's conjugated jaundice, requires further evaluation for pathological causes, including biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Persistent jaundice extending beyond two weeks of age in an infant can be indicative of biliary atresia and warrants prompt investigation and potential surgical intervention.

questions.text: A dwarf female patient brought to the hospital with a history of primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely placed nipples. What is the most common karyotype associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 45X0

 

Explanation

 

The presentation of a dwarf female patient with primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples is characteristic of Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, most commonly represented by the karyotype 45X0. This syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Turner syndrome, characterized by the karyotype 45X0, is the most common chromosomal disorder associated with features such as primary amenorrhea, webbed neck, and widely spaced nipples in females.

questions.text: What significant error did the intern make while creating a banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases, as assigned by a group of doctors?  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shift from PUFA to trans-fat

 

The significant error made by the intern while creating the banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases was the recommendation to "Shift from PUFA to trans-fat."

 

The other options, such as banning smoking in public areas, restricting alcohol selling/consumption, and decreasing additive salt on food, are appropriate measures to prevent non-communicable diseases.

 

However, the shifting from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trans-fats is incorrect, as trans-fats are one of the important risk factors for the development of non-communicable diseases. The recommendation should be to reduce trans-fat intake and promote the consumption of healthier fats like PUFA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ban smoking in public areas - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as smoking is a major risk factor for non-communicable diseases.

 

Option B. Restrictions on alcohol selling/consumption - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as alcohol consumption is a risk factor for conditions like coronary heart disease and hypertension.

 

Option D. Decrease additive salt on food - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as even prudent diet (a diet for dietary goal achievement) says the salt intake should be <5gm/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The significant error made by the intern was recommending a shift from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trans-fats, as trans-fats are known to increase the risk of non-communicable diseases, contrary to the goal of preventing their spread.

questions.text: Which of these is a contraindication to the use of BiPAP ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unconscious patient

 

Explanation:

 

BiPAP, or Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure, is a non-invasive ventilation method that provides two levels of pressure: higher inspiratory positive airway pressure (IPAP) and lower expiratory positive airway pressure (EPAP). It is commonly used in various respiratory conditions but has contraindications. An unconscious patient may not be able to protect their airway, which increases the risk of aspiration. Such patients are typically not candidates for non-invasive ventilation like BiPAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OSA (Obstructive Sleep Apnea): BiPAP can be used as a treatment for OSA to prevent airway collapse during sleep.

 

Option C. High CO2 (Hypercapnia): BiPAP is often used for hypercapnic respiratory failure because it can help blow off excess CO2.

 

Option D. Low Oxygen (Hypoxemia): While BiPAP can help improve oxygenation by increasing the alveolar ventilation, it may not be sufficient in cases of severe hypoxemia where invasive ventilation might be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BiPAP is contraindicated in unconscious patients due to the increased risk of aspiration and inability to protect their airway.

questions.text: A patient was started on haloperidol for the treatment of schizophrenia. He develops torticollis, muscle spasm, and trismus. What is the next best step in the management? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give benzhexol

 

The patient is experiencing acute dystonia, a common and early side effect of antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol.

 

Acute dystonia is characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, which can manifest as torticollis (neck muscle spasms), muscle spasms, and trismus (jaw muscle spasms).

 

The drug of choice for treating acute dystonia is an anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine or promethazine. These medications help relieve the muscle spasms quickly and are often administered intramuscularly in acute situations.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease the dose of haloperidol: While this might be considered after the acute episode is managed, it does not address the immediate need to relieve the dystonic symptoms.

 

Option B. Shift from haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is generally reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) and is not the immediate treatment for acute dystonia.

 

Option C. Shift from haloperidol to fluphenazine: Fluphenazine, another typical antipsychotic, can also cause acute dystonia, making this option less effective for immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an early side effect of antipsychotic treatment, is managed by administering an intramuscular anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine to quickly relieve muscle spasms.

questions.text: In which container will you dispose of the needle with the syringe after vaccination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) White

 

Explanation:

 

The needle of the syringe, being a metallic and sharp component, should be disposed of in the white container after vaccination. The needle, being a sharp waste, goes into the white container, which is specifically designated for disposing of sharp and metallic waste.

 

After proper treatment methods like autoclaving, dry heat destruction, shredding, or mutilation, the contents of the white container are sent to iron foundries, sharp pits, or landfills for final disposal.

 

Plastic component of syringe – in Red container

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Rukmani is attending a Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme. How frequently is it conducted? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Every month

 

The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee organizes a Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day once every month.

 

Rukmani is attending a "Village Nutrition and Sanitation Programme," which is likely referring to the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Day organized by the committee.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Programme, which Rukmani is attending, is conducted once every month by the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is found to have shock and hypotension. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. X-ray is normal, and ECG shows no abnormalities. The SpO2 is 93%, and the blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg with a pulse rate of 80/min. What type shock is most likely present? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neurogenic shock

 

Neurogenic shock results from disruption of sympathetic tone, often due to spinal cord injury or severe head injury. It is characterized by distributive shock with bradycardia and hypotension despite adequate intravascular volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylactic shock: Anaphylactic shock typically presents with symptoms such as urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, and hypotension following exposure to an allergen. It is characterized by distributive shock due to widespread vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.

 

Option B. Hemorrhagic shock: Hemorrhagic shock results from acute blood loss, leading to decreased circulating volume and impaired tissue perfusion. It is characterized by hypovolemic shock, often with tachycardia, cool clammy skin, and decreased urine output.

 

Option C. Cardiogenic shock: Cardiogenic shock occurs due to cardiac pump failure, leading to inadequate tissue perfusion. It is characterized by signs of low cardiac output, such as hypotension, tachycardia, pulmonary congestion, and altered mental status.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a trauma patient with hypotension, negative eFAST, and no evidence of hemorrhage or cardiac dysfunction, neurogenic shock should be considered, especially in the context of spinal cord injury or severe head injury.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child’s father brought him for checkup. On examination, there was white pupillary reflex. USG findings shows intraocular mass with calcification in the eye. There is a family history of enucleation. What is the diagnosis?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that typically presents in young children. It often presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may be associated with an intraocular mass with calcification. There is also a familial predisposition to retinoblastoma, which is indicated by the family history of enucleation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative retinal detachment is a condition where fluid accumulates under the retina, leading to detachment. It is not typically associated with a white pupillary reflex or intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Option B. Pediatric tuberculosis: Pediatric tuberculosis can affect various organs, including the eyes, but it usually presents with other signs and symptoms such as fever, cough, and weight loss. It is unlikely to present with a white pupillary reflex and intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Option C. Retinopathy of prematurity: Retinopathy of prematurity is a condition affecting premature infants and is characterized by abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina. It does not typically present with a white pupillary reflex or intraocular mass with calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma should be considered in a young child with a white pupillary reflex and intraocular mass with calcification, especially in the presence of a family history of enucleation.

questions.text: A child presents to the clinic with fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums. Physical examination reveals fatigue on her skin. Which of the following can be given to treat her condition?  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Explanation

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums, and specific skin manifestations such as perifollicular hemorrhages is characteristic of vitamin C deficiency, known as scurvy.

Scurvy occurs due to inadequate intake of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which is essential for collagen synthesis. Collagen is a critical component of connective tissues, and its deficiency leads to weakened blood vessels, poor wound healing, and the symptoms observed in scurvy.

 

Key clinical features of scurvy include:

 

  • Fatigue: Generalized weakness and tiredness due to impaired energy metabolism.
  • Joint pain: Due to bleeding within joints and weakened connective tissues.
  • Swollen gums: Gingival swelling, bleeding gums, and dental issues.
  • Skin manifestations: Perifollicular hemorrhages and petechiae due to fragile blood vessels.

 

The treatment for scurvy is supplementation with vitamin C, which will help restore collagen synthesis and resolve the symptoms.

 

 

Other Options

 

  • Option A. Vitamin D: Deficiency in vitamin D typically presents with symptoms related to bone health, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, rather than the symptoms described here.
  • Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision (night blindness), immune function, and skin health. It does not typically cause the symptoms described.
  • Option D. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency is rare and usually presents with neurological symptoms and hemolytic anemia, not with the symptoms described in this case.
 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) presents with fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums, and specific skin manifestations. Treatment is supplementation with vitamin C.

questions.text: MEN 1 syndrome is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Explanation

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, also known as Wermer's syndrome, is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene. It is characterized by tumors in three primary endocrine glands, known as the "three Ps":

 

  1. Parathyroid adenoma: Leading to primary hyperparathyroidism.
  2. Pituitary adenoma: Most commonly prolactinomas.
  3. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors: Which can include gastrinomas, insulinomas, and non-functioning pancreatic tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parotid tumor and Option C. Renal cell carcinoma: Not associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option D. Pheochromocytoma: Associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes, but not MEN 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 1 syndrome, also known as Wermer's syndrome, is associated with tumors in the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells, with parathyroid adenoma being a common manifestation.

questions.text: Anenecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in which week of gestation? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4th week

 

The neural tube closes by the end of the fourth week of gestation. Anencephaly occurs when the neural tube fails to close properly during this critical period.

 

Anencephaly is a serious birth defect in which a baby is born without parts of the brain and skull. It occurs when the upper part of the neural tube fails to close. The neural tube is the structure in a developing embryo that eventually becomes the baby's brain, spinal cord, and surrounding tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ananecephaly occurs due to inability of the neural tube to fuse in 4th week of gestation.

choices.text: Nil per oral to avoid pancreatic stimulation
Parentral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the nil per oral (NPO) approach

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in management of the given condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administration of 5% dextrose 

 

The patient's presentation is suggestive of acute pancreatitis, characterized by severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. The management of acute pancreatitis involves supportive care, including pain management, fluid resuscitation, and nutritional support. 

 

Administering solutions with high glucose content can increase triglyceride levels and potentially exacerbate pancreatitis, especially in a patient who is not eating. This could lead to hyperglycemia, which is why it should be avoided. The fluids preferred are RL or Normal saline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nil per oral (NPO) to avoid pancreatic stimulation: In acute pancreatitis, resting the pancreas by avoiding oral intake is a possible initial management step to prevent further pancreatic enzyme stimulation and reduce pancreatic workload.

 

Option C. Parenteral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the NPO approach: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is generally reserved for patients who cannot meet their nutritional requirements orally or enterally (via the gastrointestinal tract) after several days. The current trend is towards earlier enteral feeding when possible, rather than starting with parenteral nutrition. However, it is not a contra-indication.

 

Option D. Early initiation of oral feedings: If the patient is stable and pain is controlled, early initiation of oral feeding is recommended. This approach has been associated with a shorter hospital stay and lower complication rates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the administration of high glucose content solutions such as 5% dextrose, as they can exacerbate the condition, and instead focus on pain management, fluid resuscitation, and appropriate nutritional support.

questions.text: A 2 month pregnant female presents with swelling in legs and diagnosed with Deep vein thrombosis, she requires anticoagulation. Which of the following is Preferred?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enoxaparin

 

Explanation

 

In pregnant women diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) such as enoxaparin is the preferred anticoagulant.

 

LMWH is effective and has a better safety profile for both the mother and the fetus compared to other anticoagulants.

 

Warfarin is teratogenic and contraindicated in pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) like apixaban are not recommended during pregnancy due to insufficient safety data. Aspirin alone is not effective for treating DVT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: This is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects.

 

Option B. Apixaban: DOACs are not approved for use in pregnant or lactating women due to a lack of sufficient safety data.

 

Option D. Aspirin: While it may be used for certain cardiovascular conditions, it is not effective as a sole agent for the treatment of DVT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enoxaparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for pregnant women with DVT due to its safety and effectiveness, whereas warfarin, DOACs, and aspirin are not appropriate choices in this context.

questions.text: An audiogram of a 30-year-old female patient is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Otosclerosis

 

Based on the audiogram provided, which shows a conductive hearing loss pattern with a gap between the air conduction and bone conduction thresholds and considering the age of the patient, the most likely diagnosis is Otosclerosis. Carhart’s notch can also be noticed in the audiogram.

 

Otosclerosis is a condition affecting the bones in the middle ear, particularly the stapes, which becomes fixated, leading to conductive hearing loss. On an audiogram, this is typically indicated by a gap between the air conduction and bone conduction thresholds, particularly at lower frequencies. It is more commonly diagnosed in young adults, especially women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere’s disease: Is an inner ear disorder that can affect both hearing and balance. It is characterized by episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss. The audiogram might show a low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, especially in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Noise-induced hearing loss: Is usually the result of chronic exposure to loud noises, which damages the hair cells in the cochlea. This type of hearing loss typically manifests as a 'notch' at the high frequencies on an audiogram, mostly at 4000 Hz.

 

Option D. Presbycusis: Is age-related hearing loss and is the cumulative effect of aging on hearing. It is characterized by a gradual and symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss, especially at higher frequencies on an audiogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The audiometric profile of Otosclerosis: this typically presents as a conductive hearing loss with an air-bone gap on an audiogram, most often diagnosed in young adults, particularly females.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, 10 years after mastectomy, notices gradual swelling and heaviness in her right upper limb without pain. On examination, no skin changes or infection are noted. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphangiosarcoma 

 

Lymphangiosarcoma, also known as Stewart-Treves syndrome, is a rare form of angiosarcoma that can develop in long-standing lymphedema, and it typically occurs many years after the initial surgical procedure that caused the lymphedema, such as mastectomy. 

 

Given the timeline of 10 years post-mastectomy and the absence of skin changes or infections, lymphangiosarcoma is likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thoracic outlet syndrome: Typically presents with pain, weakness, or numbness in the limb, not just isolated swelling and heaviness.

 

Option C. Chronic venous insufficiency: More commonly affects the lower extremities and would likely show skin changes like stasis dermatitis.

 

Option D. Recurrent breast cancer: Could cause arm swelling if it involves lymphatic obstruction, but there would likely be other signs of cancer recurrence.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The cause of unilateral limb swelling in a patient with a history of mastectomy, is most commonly due to lymphedema.

choices.text: 70 percent of the drug undergoes first pass metabolism in liver.
The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical composition.
The drug is 30 percent potent in producing therapeutic effect.
30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

questions.text: What does it mean when a drug has a bioavailability of 30 percent? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans D. 30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

 

This statement accurately defines bioavailability. Bioavailability is the percentage of an administered drug dose that reaches the systemic circulation without being metabolized or changed. In this case, a bioavailability of 30 percent means that only 30 percent of the drug dose reaches the systemic circulation, while the rest may be eliminated or metabolized before reaching the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70 percent of the drug undergoes first-pass metabolism in the liver: This statement is not a direct explanation of bioavailability but is related to the fate of the drug after absorption. If 30 percent is bioavailability, then 70 percent of drug is either not absorbed or undergo first pass metabolism. First-pass metabolism in the liver can reduce the amount of drug available for systemic circulation, but it doesn't define bioavailability.

 

Option B. The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical composition: This statement is incorrect. Bioavailability is not related to the purity of a drug but rather to its absorption and availability in the bloodstream.

 

Option C. The drug is 30 percent potent in producing a therapeutic effect: This statement is not an accurate description of bioavailability. Potency refers to the strength or concentration of a drug required to produce a specific effect, while bioavailability is about how much of the administered dose reaches the systemic circulation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis in a young child, strongly suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder. The abnormal dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test result further supports the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD).

 

CGD is a rare inherited disorder characterized by defective oxygen-dependent killing of microorganisms by phagocytic cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages. This defect is caused by mutations in the genes encoding components of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex, which is responsible for generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary for microbial killing. The inability to produce sufficient ROS leads to recurrent infections, especially with catalase-positive organisms.

 

The DHR test is a flow cytometry-based assay that measures the production of ROS by neutrophils after stimulation. An abnormal DHR test result, as seen in this patient, is consistent with the diagnosis of CGD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) is a group of disorders characterized by defects in both cellular and humoral immunity.

 

X-linked SCID is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by chronic diarrhea, periodic respiratory infection, and acquired maternal T cell-mediated GVHD. Mutations in interleukin-2 receptor gamma (IL2RG) can result in X-SCID. While patients with SCID are also susceptible to recurrent infections, the presentation typically involves opportunistic infections and failure to thrive, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect, also known as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2 (LAD-2), is a rare disorder characterized by defective leukocyte rolling and adhesion due to a deficiency in the sialyl Lewis X ligand. While patients with LAD-2 may present with recurrent infections, the DHR test would not be abnormal in this condition.

 

Option D. Integrin defects, such as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD-1), are characterized by defective leukocyte adhesion and migration due to mutations in the genes encoding integrins. Although patients with LAD-1 may present with recurrent infections, the DHR test would not be abnormal in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic granulomatous disease should be suspected in a child presenting with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis, and an abnormal DHR test result.

questions.text: A 68-year-old lady presents to the OPD with resting tremors, bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity and postural instability. After some time she died due to respiratory failure following pneumonia. Which of the following is expected to be seen in his brain biopsy? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation described is the characteristic of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder affecting the central nervous system. The cardinal features of Parkinson's disease mentioned in the question are:

 

  1. Resting tremors: Tremors that occur when the affected body part is at rest and disappear with voluntary movement. These are often described as "pill-rolling" tremors.
  2. Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement and difficulty initiating movements.
  3. Cogwheel rigidity: A type of rigidity characterized by jerky, ratchet-like resistance to passive movement of a joint, resembling the clicking of a cogwheel.
  4. Postural instability: Impaired balance and coordination, leading to an increased risk of falls.

 

Parkinson's disease is caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta of the midbrain, leading to a deficiency of dopamine in the nigrostriatal pathway. The hallmark histopathological finding in Parkinson's disease is the presence of Lewy bodies in the affected neurons.

 

Lewy bodies are eosinophilic, round to elongated intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of aggregated proteins, primarily alpha-synuclein. They are considered the pathological hallmark of Parkinson's disease and other related disorders, collectively known as synucleinopathies.

 

 

The patient's death due to respiratory failure following pneumonia is a common complication in advanced stages of Parkinson's disease, as the disease progression can lead to impaired swallowing and increased risk of aspiration pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Negri bodies: These are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the neurons of animals and humans infected with rabies virus. They are not associated with Parkinson's disease.

 

 

Option C. Hirano bodies: These are eosinophilic, rod-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions found in the neurons of patients with neurodegenerative disorders, particularly Alzheimer's disease. They are not specific to Parkinson's disease.

 

 

Option D. Heinz bodies: These are intracellular inclusions found in red blood cells of individuals with various hemolytic anemias, such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. They are not related to Parkinson's disease or other neurodegenerative disorders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy bodies are the characteristic histopathological finding in the brain of patients with Parkinson's disease. Their presence, along with the clinical triad of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and rigidity, confirms the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following can result in acute liver failure? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amanita phalloides toxicity

 

Among the given options, Amanita phalloides is the most direct and significant cause of liver damage. The toxins in this mushroom specifically target the liver and can lead to acute liver failure.

 

Amanita phalloides is a type of mushroom, commonly known as the death cap. It contains amatoxins, which are extremely toxic and can cause severe liver damage and failure. Amanita phalloides poisoning is a well-known cause of acute liver failure and is often cited in toxicology as a classic cause of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphate: These are chemicals commonly found in pesticides. They are known more for their neurotoxic effects due to inhibition of acetylcholinesterase. They can cause symptoms like pinpoint pupil, increase in secretions, diarrhea, urination and muscle weakness etc. Liver damage is not the primary concern with organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option B. Morphine: This is an opioid analgesic. Its main effects and side effects are on the central nervous system and gastrointestinal system. It can cause respiratory depression, constipation, and dependence, but it is not primarily known for causing liver damage.

 

Option C. Belladonna: Also known as deadly nightshade, contains atropine and scopolamine. These substances can cause anticholinergic syndrome, but they are not typically associated with liver damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amanita phalloides (death cap mushroom) is a well-known cause of acute liver failure due to its potent hepatotoxic amatoxins, making it a critical toxicological emergency.

questions.text: The following are the phases of:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Demographic process

 

Explanation:

 

Demography is the scientific study of human populations, and demographic processes are the key factors that influence population dynamics. The five main demographic processes mentioned in the image are:

 

  1. Fertility: Related to childbirth and reproduction
  2. Mortality: Related to deaths and life expectancy
  3. Marriage: Formation and dissolution of marital unions
  4. Migration: Physical or geographical movement of people from one place to another
  5. Social mobility: Movement of individuals across social classes or socio-economic status

 

These processes collectively determine the size, structure, and distribution of populations over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Demographic dividend: This refers to the economic growth potential resulting from a population's changing age structure, typically when the working-age population is larger than the non-working-age population. It is not directly related to the five processes listed.

 

Option C. Demographic cycle: Also known as the demographic transition model, this describes the stages a population goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. While related to demographic processes, the stages of the demographic cycle are not the same as the processes listed.

 

Option D. Human Development Index (HDI): This is a composite statistic developed by the United Nations to measure and rank countries' levels of social and economic development. It takes into account life expectancy, education, and per capita income. HDI is not directly related to the five demographic processes mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertility, mortality, marriage, migration, and social mobility are the five main demographic processes that influence population dynamics and are studied in the field of demography.

questions.text: Amsel criteria is used for? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis

 

Explanation:

 

Amsel's criteria are used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV). The diagnosis requires at least three out of the following four criteria to be present:

 

  1. Homogeneous, thin, white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.
  2. Clue cells on microscopy: Vaginal epithelial cells that appear stippled with bacteria.
  3. Positive whiff test: A fishy odor is released when a solution of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to a sample of the vaginal discharge.
  4. Vaginal pH > 4.5: An elevated pH is indicative of BV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candidiasis: Diagnosed primarily by clinical presentation and microscopic identification of yeast cells or pseudo hyphae.

 

Option C. Cervicitis: Diagnosed based on clinical findings and specific laboratory tests for pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Option D. Trichomoniasis: Diagnosed by identifying the flagellated protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis on a wet mount microscopy or by specific antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amsel criteria are specifically used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis, requiring the presence of at least three out of four specific clinical and laboratory findings.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male presented with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following anti-diabetic drug acts by causing glucosuria? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin, as an SGLT2 inhibitor, is the drug among the options provided that acts specifically by causing glucosuria. This mechanism is unique to SGLT2 inhibitors and is a direct way of lowering blood glucose levels in type 2 diabetes mellitus. The other drugs listed work through different mechanisms that do not involve the induction of glucosuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarbose: This drug is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It works by slowing down the digestion of carbohydrates in the intestine, thereby reducing the rise in blood glucose after meals. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Option B. Glipizide: Glipizide is a sulfonylurea. It works by stimulating insulin release from the pancreatic beta cells. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor. It works by increasing the levels of incretin hormones, which increase insulin release and decrease glucagon release in a glucose-dependent manner. It does not cause glucosuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin is an SGLT2 (Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter-2) inhibitor, works by blocking glucose reabsorption in the kidney, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine, i.e., glucosuria.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child came with a lesion in the right eye and the histopathological image showed Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinoblastoma

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of a lesion in the eye of a young child, along with the histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (small round blue tumor cells), strongly suggests the diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that primarily affects young children. It arises from immature retinal cells called retinoblasts. The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a characteristic histopathological feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes, consisting of a ring of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen, resembling the primitive neuroepithelium.

 

It is important to distinguish Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes from Homer Wright rosettes, which are pseudo-rosettes. Homer Wright rosettes are characterized by tumor cells arranged around a central neuropil (tangled cell processes) and are seen in various tumors of neuroectodermal origin, such as neuroblastoma and medulloblastoma.

 

 

While retinoblastoma can show both true rosettes (Flexner-Wintersteiner) and pseudo-rosettes (Homer Wright), the presence of true rosettes is more specific for retinoblastoma in the context of an ocular tumor in a young child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ocular melanoma: Ocular melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes in the eye. It is more common in adults and does not typically show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle origin. While it can occur in the orbit, it does not show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve glioma is a benign tumor arising from glial cells of the optic nerve. It is more common in children with neurofibromatosis type 1 but does not typically show Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (true rosettes) on histopathology of an ocular lesion in a young child is highly suggestive of retinoblastoma. It is important to distinguish these true rosettes from Homer Wright pseudo-rosettes, which can be seen in various other neuroectodermal tumors.

questions.text: A patient reports to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and pallor. Investigations indicated hemoglobin of 5.9 g/dL, increased RDW, increased total iron binding capacity, and low ferritin. The peripheral smear shows microcytosis. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with symptoms of fatigue and pallor, which are common findings in anemia. The investigations reveal a low hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL, indicating the presence of anemia. The increased red cell distribution width (RDW) suggests anisocytosis, or variation in the size of red blood cells.

 

The increased total iron binding capacity (TIBC) and low ferritin levels indicate a deficiency in iron stores. Additionally, the peripheral smear shows microcytosis, which means the presence of small, hypochromic red blood cells. These findings are characteristic of iron deficiency anemia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemolytic anemia is incorrect because these patients typically have an increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) due to the premature destruction of red blood cells and the release of larger, immature cells into the circulation.

 

Option C. Megaloblastic anemia is incorrect because it is characterized by the presence of large, macrocytic red blood cells, rather than the small, microcytic cells seen in this case.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia is incorrect because it is typically associated with elevated ferritin levels due to increased iron storage, whereas this patient has low ferritin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by low hemoglobin, increased RDW, increased TIBC, low ferritin, and the presence of microcytic red blood cells on peripheral smear.

questions.text: If the RNA sequence is CAAGGU, what is the sequence of the template strand? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACCTTG

 

Explanation:

 

The given RNA sequence is CAAGGU. To determine the template strand sequence -

  1. Direction of RNA Sequence: The RNA sequence is provided without directions, but typically the sequence is read from 5' to 3'. Thus, the sequence is 5'-CAAGGU-3'.
  2. Non-Template Strand (Coding Strand) of DNA: The non-template strand of DNA has the same sequence as the RNA transcript except for the replacement of uracil (U) with thymine (T). Therefore, the non-template strand would be 5'-CAAGGT-3'.
  3. Template Strand of DNA: The template strand of DNA is complementary to the non-template strand. Complementarity means adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) pairs with guanine (G). Therefore, the template strand, read in the 3' to 5' direction, would be:
    • C pairs with G
    • A pairs with T
    • A pairs with T
    • G pairs with C
    • G pairs with C
    • U (in RNA) pairs with A (in DNA, U replaced by T in RNA, so G pairs with C)

 

Therefore, the template strand is 3'-GTTAAC-5'. When we reverse the direction to match the 5' to 3' orientation given in the options, the sequence is ACCTTG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CAAGGT: This option is the sequence of the non-template (coding) strand of DNA, not the template strand.

 

Option B. GTTCCA: This option is not complementary to the RNA sequence.

 

Option D. TGGAAC: This option is incorrect as it does not match the complementary base pairing rules for the given RNA sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The template strand of DNA is complementary to the RNA sequence and the non-template strand, with the RNA sequence transcribed from the 5' to 3' direction of the non-template strand.

questions.text: A patient came following an RTA in the hospital. He is able to understand his friend’s talks. He is trying to speak (non-fluent aphasia) something to his friend. Which part of the brain is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Broca’s area

 

Explanation:

 

Broca’s area is responsible for speech production and language processing. It is located in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left hemisphere) of the brain. Injury to Broca’s area leads to Broca’s aphasia, also known as non-fluent aphasia. Individuals with this condition can understand spoken language but have difficulty in speaking, writing, or forming words properly.

 

Broca’s area: Broca’s aphasia is characterized by difficulty in speech production. The patient may understand speech but will struggle to speak fluently, often speaking in short, broken sentences with considerable effort. This condition is also known as expressive aphasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke’s area: This area is involved in the comprehension of spoken language. Damage to Wernicke’s area results in Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent aphasia), where the patient can speak fluently but the speech is often nonsensical and lacks meaning.

 

Option B. Angular gyrus: This region is involved in various functions related to language, number processing, and spatial cognition but is not directly responsible for speech production or comprehension.

 

Option D. Arcuate fasciculus: This is a bundle of nerve fibers that connects Broca’s area and Wernicke’s area. Damage to this pathway can result in conduction aphasia, characterized by the ability to understand and produce speech but difficulty in repeating words or sentences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Broca’s area is involved in speech production. Damage to this area results in non-fluent (expressive) aphasia, where the patient can understand speech but has difficulty speaking fluently.

questions.text: Which nutritional deficiency is commonly associated with a chronic alcoholic presenting with a pruritic eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of hands? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

Explanation:

 

Chronic alcoholism often leads to poor dietary intake, resulting in various nutritional deficiencies.

 

One of the most significant deficiencies in chronic alcoholics is niacin (vitamin B3). Niacin deficiency leads to a condition called pellagra, which is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.

 

The dermatitis in pellagra is specifically photodermatitis, meaning it occurs in areas exposed to sunlight, such as the neck and dorsum of the hands. The rash is pruritic and eczematous, commonly presenting as Casal's necklace around the neck and gauntlet sign on the hands.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Deficiency in riboflavin (vitamin B2) typically leads to symptoms such as cheilosis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis but does not cause the characteristic dermatitis seen in niacin deficiency.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Folic acid deficiency often presents with megaloblastic anemia and glossitis, not with the dermatological symptoms described in the question.

 

Option D. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, primarily affecting the cardiovascular and nervous systems, rather than causing the dermatological symptoms seen with niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics, leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. The dermatitis is photodermatitis, presenting with a pruritic eczematous rash on sun-exposed areas like the neck and dorsum of the hands. ​

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of fatigue, lethargy, pallor, and right index finger pain. Biochemical analysis showed raised indirect bilirubin. What can be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sickle cell anemia

 

Explanation:

 

The combination of symptoms, including fatigue, lethargy, pallor (suggesting anemia), right index finger pain, and elevated indirect bilirubin levels (indicating jaundice), strongly points toward sickle cell anemia as the underlying diagnosis.

Sickle cell anemia is a hemolytic anemia characterized by the production of abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells, which can lead to vaso-occlusive crises and ischemic damage.

 

The presence of right index finger pain is a crucial clue, as it may be a manifestation of dactylitis or hand-foot syndrome, which is commonly seen in sickle cell anemia patients. This condition arises due to the involvement of small blood vessels in the hands and feet, leading to inflammation and severe pain.

 

Additionally, the hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) associated with sickle cell anemia results in anemia and elevated indirect bilirubin levels, causing jaundice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thalassemia: While thalassemia is also a type of hemolytic anemia, it does not typically present with the characteristic hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis seen in sickle cell anemia.

 

Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia: This condition involves the destruction of red blood cells by the body's own immune system. It does not typically cause the specific symptom of index finger pain.

 

Option D. PNH (Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria): PNH is a rare acquired disorder characterized by the destruction of red blood cells, but it does not typically present with the combination of symptoms seen in this case, particularly the right index finger pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with anemia, jaundice, and specific finger pain (dactylitis or hand-foot syndrome), sickle cell anemia should be strongly considered as the underlying diagnosis.

questions.text: In a solid organ transplantation, which organ is associated with a higher incidence of rejection? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lungs

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens and their role in gas exchange, which increases the risk of immune-mediated injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intestine: Intestinal transplantation also carries a high risk of rejection, but it is less common than lung rejection and is often associated with complications such as graft-versus-host disease.

 

Option C. Kidney: Kidney transplantation has a relatively lower incidence of rejection compared to lung and intestinal transplants due to the kidney's immunologically privileged status and the availability of effective immunosuppressive medications.

 

Option D. Heart: While heart transplantation can also lead to rejection, it generally has a lower incidence compared to lung transplantation, possibly due to differences in the immune response and the heart's unique anatomical and physiological characteristics.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lung transplantation is associated with a higher incidence of rejection compared to other solid organ transplants due to the lungs' constant exposure to environmental antigens, emphasizing the need for vigilant monitoring and immunosuppressive therapy in lung transplant recipients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with early satiety, bleeding and on examination, patient has spleen palpable till umbilicus. WBC count is 85,000/mm³ with immature WBCs seen in the peripheral blood smear. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Myeloid Leukemia

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). The patient presents with massive splenomegaly, early satiety, bleeding, and a significantly elevated white blood cell (WBC) count of 85,000/mm³ with immature WBCs in the peripheral smear. These features are characteristic of CML, a type of leukemia where the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells. The presence of immature WBCs (a left shift) and massive splenomegaly are classic signs of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): While AML also involves immature WBCs, it usually presents more acutely and with less pronounced splenomegaly.

 

Diagnosed if – Myeloid blast count >20%;  APL (t15:17); CBF (t8:21; t16:16 inversion 16)

 

Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL): CLL typically presents with a high number of mature lymphocytes rather than immature WBCs.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: This condition is unlikely in a 60-year-old due to autosplenectomy typically occurring by age 3-4, making splenomegaly in this age group highly unlikely. Moreover, the WBC count in sickle cell anemia is not usually elevated to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CML should be suspected in patients presenting with massive splenomegaly, significantly elevated WBC count, and immature WBCs on peripheral smear. Recognizing these signs can prompt further diagnostic evaluation, including the detection of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene).

 

CML ideally Diagnosed as – Blast count <20% + Philadelphia +ve + Left shift in PS (lots of immature WBC)

choices.text: Lateral condyle fracture of humerus

questions.text: An 18-year-old child presents with history of fall leading to injury to the right elbow. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radial head dislocation

 

RADIAL HEAD DISLOCATION

 

  • Isolated radial head dislocation is uncommon. 
  • It most commonly presents as a partial dislocation or subluxation, also known as nursemaid’s elbow, seen in children.
  • Complete radial head dislocation, although rare, is most commonly associated with high-force injuries of the arm in children as well as in adults and, therefore, is often associated with a forearm fracture or dislocation.
  • The peak incidence is between 4-10 years of age. 
  • Causes:
    • The annular ligament stabilizes the radial head.
    • In the case of subluxation, an axial force on an extended, pronated forearm causes the annular ligament to slip over the radial head.
    • A complete radial head dislocation is most commonly from a high-force injury causing a tear in the annular ligament.
    • Less often, the annular ligament remains intact, connected to the lateral collateral ligament and the ulna, causing the radial head to slip under the annular ligament.
  • On physical examination, the child with a partial displacement protectively holds their arm in an extended and pronated fashion.
  • There is discomfort and pain over the radial head, and the child refuses to use arm by holding it close to body.
  • The patient also resists forearm range of motion testing.
  • A lateral view x-ray of the elbow shows the “ulnar bow sign” seen in isolated radial head dislocation.
  • There is a slight curvature in the ulna on the lateral view.
  • "Isolated" dislocation of the radial head is almost always in fact associated with a bowing fracture of the ulna.

 

Ulnar bow sign

 

  • The lateral humeral line (LHL) is often used to diagnose lateral radial head dislocation on the anterior-posterior x-ray.
  • The LHL is a line drawn along the lateral edge of the lateral condyle parallel to the axis of the distal shaft of the humerus.
  • It typically intersects the lateral cortex of the radial neck.

 

Lateral humeral line

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow dislocation: The most common dislocation is posterior or posterolateral and is usually the result of a fall with forearm supinated and the elbow either extended or partially flexed. Simple dislocations result in injuries of the medial and lateral collateral ligament complexes without bony injury. Complex dislocations are associated with fractures about the elbow. Associated soft tissue injuries may involve the brachial artery, ulnar nerve (most commonly), median and radial nerve. Most common joint to dislocate in children (male children in 10-15 years of age group). Most prominent part is olecranon in dislocated elbow. Symptoms include painful and swollen elbow with elbow motion painful and restricted. On physical examination, the elbow is held in flexion, and forearm appears to be shortened from the anterior and posterior view. On palpation, distal humerus creates a fullness within the antecubital fossa. Radiograph shows loss of radiocapitellar and ulnohumeral relationship but maintained radial and ulnar relationship.

 

 

Option C. Supracondylar fracture of humerus: Supracondylar humeral fractures in children are most common elbow injuries, especially in children aged 5–8 years. It occurs after a fall on an outstretched hand.

 

The child complains of pain and refusal to move the elbow. On physical examination, there is a gross deformity, swelling, ecchymosis in antecubital fossa, limited active elbow motion.

 

 

Option D. Lateral condyle fracture of humerus: This is a transphyseal intraarticular injury usually involving immature skeleton of children and adolescent. The lateral condylar (or capitellar) epiphysis begins to ossify during the first year of life and fuses with shaft at 12–16 years. Between these ages, it may be sheared off or avulsed by forceful traction. The maximum chances of injury is between 5–15 years. They are the most common distal humeral epiphyseal fractures. Mechanism of fracture is fall on outstretched arm with varus stress that “Pulls off” (avulses) lateral condyle or Valgus force (rarely) in which radial head directly pushes off the lateral condyle. The child comes with lateral elbow pain and swelling. On physical examination, there is no obvious deformity seen. The swelling and tenderness are usually limited to the lateral side. Lateral ecchymosis implies a tear in the aponeurosis of the brachioradialis and signals an unstable fracture. There may be increased pain with resisted wrist extension/flexion. Crepitus may be felt at the fracture site.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the radial head dislocation.
  • Since it is common at the age between 4-10 years, it is the correct diagnosis of the given condition.

questions.text: Edges of a Basal Cell Carcinoma are? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rolled out beaded

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is rolled out beaded.

 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, typically occurring in areas with high sun exposure. It often presents initially as a pearly white, translucent nodule with surface telangiectasias. As BCC is locally invasive, it can grow and lead to the formation of an ulcer. The characteristic edges of this ulcer are described as rolled out and beaded.

 

 

Pearly white, translucent nodule with surface telangiectasias

 

 

Ulcer with rolled out and beaded edges

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sloping: Sloping edges are typically seen in healing ulcers.

 

Option C. Punched out: Punched out edges are characteristic of trophic ulcers.

 

Option D. Undermined: Undermined edges are seen in tubercular ulcers and chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The edges of a basal cell carcinoma ulcer are characteristically described as rolled out and beaded, distinguishing it from other types of ulcers which have sloping, punched out, or undermined edges. ​

questions.text: During placental development, which decidual component forms the maternal portion? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decidua basalis

 

Explanation

 

The decidua is the modified endometrium of the uterus that forms in preparation for and during pregnancy. It plays a crucial role in the implantation and support of the developing fetus.

 

Decidua Basalis: This is the part of the decidua that lies directly beneath the implanted embryo and forms the maternal part of the placenta. It is the region where the trophoblasts invade to establish the placental attachment to the maternal endometrium. It supports the exchange of nutrients and waste products between the mother and the fetus.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Decidua Parietalis: This is the part of the decidua that lines the remainder of the uterine cavity that is not involved in the implantation site. It is essentially the peripheral part of the endometrium.

 

Option C. Decidua Capsularis: This part of the decidua surrounds the embryo and eventually fuses with the decidua parietalis as the embryo grows, obliterating the uterine cavity.

 

Option D. Chorionic Plate: This is the fetal side of the placenta, consisting of the chorionic villi and other fetal tissues. It is not part of the maternal endometrium.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The decidua basalis is the part of the decidua that attaches to the maternal side of the placenta, facilitating the exchange of nutrients and waste between the mother and the fetus.
  • The decidua has three distinct regions based on their location and function in relation to the implanted embryo.

questions.text: A patient came to emergency with severe breathlessness. CXR is taken and shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pleural effusion

 

Explanation:

 

The chest X-ray (CXR) of the patient shows a whiteout on one side with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side. These findings are indicative of a massive pleural effusion.
