Pleural effusion: This condition results in the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, leading to lung compression and a shift of the mediastinum, including the trachea, away from the affected side. The presence of a large whiteout on the X-ray, along with the tracheal deviation to the opposite side, strongly suggests pleural effusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: This condition would typically present with a hyperlucent (dark) area on the X-ray without lung markings, rather than a whiteout. It also generally causes a tracheal shift towards the opposite side, but the appearance on the X-ray would be different.

 

Option B. Consolidation: This condition involves filling of the alveoli with fluid or other material, leading to a whiteout appearance on the X-ray. However, it does not usually cause a significant tracheal shift.

 

Option C. Collapse: This condition, also known as atelectasis, would cause a shift of the trachea towards the affected side. It can present with a whiteout on the X-ray, but the tracheal deviation would be opposite to that seen in pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A massive pleural effusion is characterized by a whiteout on the chest X-ray with a significant tracheal shift to the opposite side.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in MMR?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Death due to RTA

 

Explanation:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is calculated as the number of maternal deaths divided by the number of live births, multiplied by a factor of 100,000. Maternal death is defined as the death of a mother at any time during pregnancy, labour, delivery, or within 42 days after delivery, provided it is related to maternity or its complications.

 

Deaths due to preeclampsia, ectopic pregnancy, and within 14 days post-partum are included in the calculation of MMR, as they are related to maternity or its complications.

 

However, Deaths due to road traffic accidents (RTA) are not included in the MMR calculation, as they are not directly related to maternity or its complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death due to preeclampsia - This option is correct because deaths due to preeclampsia, a pregnancy-related complication, are included in the MMR calculation.

 

Option C. Death due to ectopic pregnancy - This option is correct because deaths due to ectopic pregnancy, a pregnancy-related condition, are included in the MMR calculation.

 

Option D. Death on 14th day post-partum - This option is correct because deaths within 42 days after delivery are included in the MMR calculation, which includes the 14th day post-partum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) includes deaths related to maternity or its complications during pregnancy, labour, delivery, or within 42 days after delivery. Deaths due to causes unrelated to maternity, such as road traffic accidents, are not included in the MMR calculation.

questions.text: All are features of Conn's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by an excess production of aldosterone, usually due to an adrenal adenoma.

 

The typical features of Conn's syndrome include:

 

  • Hypertension: Due to increased sodium and water retention.
  • Hypokalemia: Caused by increased potassium excretion.
  • Metabolic alkalosis: Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion and bicarbonate retention.

 

Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of Conn's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with conditions where there is a deficiency of aldosterone, such as adrenal insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to aldosterone's effect on renal tubular excretion of hydrogen ions.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Muscle cramps: Can be associated with hypokalemia seen in Conn's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of this condition.

questions.text: A 48 year old male smoker presented with cough and foul smelling sputum which increased on change in posture. He had similar episodes multiple times in last few years. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchiectasis 

 

Explanation:

 

The key features presented in this case are a 48-year-old male smoker with chronic cough, foul-smelling sputum, and an increase in sputum production upon changing posture. Additionally, the patient has experienced similar episodes multiple times over the past few years. These clinical manifestations strongly suggest a diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

 

Bronchiectasis is a chronic condition characterized by permanent dilation and destruction of the bronchi (airways) due to recurrent inflammation or infection. It leads to impaired clearance of secretions, resulting in the accumulation of thick, foul-smelling sputum within the dilated airways. The sputum production often increases upon postural changes, as described in this case, due to the pooling of secretions within the dilated bronchial segments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: While asthma can present with cough and wheezing, it is not typically associated with foul-smelling sputum or a significant change in sputum production upon postural changes.

 

Option B. Carcinoma of the lung: Lung cancer can cause cough and sputum production, but the sputum is usually not described as foul-smelling. Additionally, the recurrent nature of the episodes over several years is less consistent with lung cancer.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: A lung abscess can also present with cough and foul-smelling sputum, but it is typically an acute condition and is less likely to have recurrent episodes over several years without appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of chronic cough, foul-smelling sputum production that increases with postural changes, and recurrent episodes over several years, bronchiectasis should be strongly considered as the likely diagnosis, especially in the presence of risk factors such as smoking.

questions.text: Identify the muscle inserting at the site marked by the arrow on this radiograph. (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iliopsoas

 

Explanation:

 

The radiograph shows a lateral view of the pelvis and proximal femur. The marked bony structure is the lesser trochanter of the femur. The iliopsoas muscle, consisting of the iliacus and psoas major muscles, attaches to the lesser trochanter.

 

The iliopsoas crosses the hip joint anteriorly, causing flexion. The iliacus originates from the iliac fossa, while the psoas major originates from the lumbar vertebrae. These two muscles fuse together and insert near the lesser trochanter of the femur, forming the floor of the femoral triangle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gluteus maximus : The gluteus maximus muscle inserts on the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, not the lesser trochanter.

 

Option C. Gluteus medius : The gluteus medius muscle inserts on the greater trochanter of the femur, not the lesser trochanter.

 

Option D. Sartorius : The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle but does not attach directly to the lesser trochanter. It inserts on the medial surface of the proximal tibia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iliopsoas muscle, consisting of the iliacus and psoas major, inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. It is an important hip flexor muscle.

 

Femoral Triangle:

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented after a motor vehicle accident to the emergency. On examination, the right lower limb was longer than the left, abducted and externally rotated. What can be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior hip dislocation

 

ANTERIOR HIP DISLOCATION

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.
  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • Hip dislocations are most common in young adult males and are most often the result of motor vehicle accidents. 
  • The patients present with hip and leg in extension, abduction, and external rotation.

 

 

  • Radiological findings include loss of congruence of femoral head with acetabulum, disruption of shenton's line, femoral head appears larger than contralateral femoral head, and femoral head lies medial or inferior to acetabulum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve injury: Femoral nerve damage can occur from an injury or prolonged compression. Typically, damage and dysfunction of the femoral nerve are associated with the leg weakness and sensation changes. Injury of the femoral is uncommon but may be injured by a stab, gunshot wounds, or a pelvic fracture. It can also be damaged during hip replacement, abdominal, and pelvic surgeries. The patient presents with poor flexion of the hip because of paralysis of the iliacus, psoas and sartorius muscles. There is an inability to extend the knee because of paralysis of the quadriceps femoris. There is sensory decline over the anterior and medial aspects of the thigh, medial side of the leg and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It does not directly affect the position of the hip or the length appearance of the limb.

 

Option B. Femoral neck fracture: Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. It is commonly seen in the elderly due to low energy falls, and in young patients who perform athletics or due to high-energy trauma. The patient complains of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. The leg appears shortened due to the upward movement of the distal fragment. The key feature is the inability to bear weight and immediate pain.

 

 

Option C. Posterior hip dislocation: It is the Most common hip dislocation (90%). Patients with a posterior dislocation of the hip generally present with a shortened, internally rotated, adducted limb in slight flexion. If the hip is adducted at the time of injury, a pure dislocation occurs, whereas a neutral position or abduction leads to fracture dislocation. It is associated with a fracture of the femoral head or acetabulum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The limb appears lengthened and in FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) deformity in anterior dislocation of the hip following a motor vehicle accident.
  • Thus, in the given scenario, the patient has anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: A patient who has a pet dog, came with a complaint of hypochondrial pain. The radiological imaging showed cyst within the liver. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

The key points that indicate Echinococcus granulosus as the causative organism are:

 

  1. The patient has a pet dog, which is the definitive host for Echinococcus granulosus (also known as the dog tapeworm).
  2. The patient presented with hypochondrial pain, which could be caused by the formation of cyst in the liver.
  3. Radiological imaging revealed a cyst within the liver, which is characteristic of Echinococcus granulosus infection.

 

Echinococcus granulosus is a cestode (tapeworm) parasite that causes hydatid cyst disease, primarily affecting the liver and lungs. The life cycle involves dogs (or other canids like wolves and foxes) as the definitive hosts, where the adult tapeworm resides in the intestine. The eggs are passed in the feces of these definitive hosts and can contaminate food or water sources.

 

Humans become accidental intermediate hosts by ingesting these eggs. Once ingested, the eggs hatch in the human intestine, and the larvae migrate to various organs, most commonly the liver (70-80% of cases), where they develop into unilocular hydatid cyst.

 

 

 

Life cycle

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This is a protozoan parasite that causes amebic liver abscesses, not multilocular cysts. It is not transmitted by dogs and does not form characteristic multilocular cysts.

 

Option C. Taenia solium: Also known as the pork tapeworm, this organism can cause cysticercosis, where cysts form in muscle, brain, and other tissues, but it's not primarily known for liver cysts.

 

Option D. Diphyllobothrium latum: This is a fish tapeworm that primarily leads to vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia, not liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Echinococcus granulosus, also known as the dog tapeworm, can cause hydatid cyst disease in humans, with multilocular cysts commonly found in the liver. Owning a pet dog and ingesting food or water contaminated with dog feces containing the parasite's eggs are risk factors for acquiring this infection.

questions.text: Which value is derived in ABG?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate

 

Explanation:

 

In arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis, pH, pO2 (partial pressure of oxygen), and pCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) are measured directly by the ABG machine.

 

Bicarbonate (HCO3-) is not directly measured but is derived using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation. The equation relates the pH, pCO2, and bicarbonate concentration, enabling the calculation of bicarbonate from the directly measured values of pH and pCO2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. pH: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an electrode sensitive to hydrogen ions.

 

Option B. pO2: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using an oxygen-sensitive electrode.

 

Option C. pCO2: This is directly measured in ABG analysis using a carbon dioxide-sensitive electrode.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In arterial blood gas analysis, bicarbonate (HCO3-) is the value that is derived, not directly measured, using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

questions.text: What is the reservoir of leishmaniasis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Man

 

Explanation:

 

The reservoir of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kalazar or Indian kala-azar, is humans.

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar) is caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani.
  • The vector responsible for transmitting the disease is the sandfly (Phlebotomus species).

 

 

  • The reservoir host of the disease is humans (man).

 

Other 3 options are incorrect

 

Educational Objective:

 

For visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar or Indian kala-azar), the reservoir host is humans.

questions.text: CT scan given in the image is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural hematoma

 

Explanation

 

The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped hemorrhage, which is characteristic of a subdural hematoma (SDH). Subdural hematomas typically occur due to tearing of the bridging veins and are crescent-shaped because they can cross suture lines but are limited by the dural reflections.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Extradural (epidural) hematoma: Usually appears as a biconvex, lenticular shape and does not cross suture lines due to the tight attachment of the dura to the skull at the sutures.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Blood is found within the subarachnoid space, typically around the basal cisterns or within the sulci, and is not crescent-shaped.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal hemorrhage: Appears as a hyperdense area within the brain parenchyma and does not have the crescent shape seen here.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

A crescent-shaped hemorrhage on a CT scan, especially if it crosses suture lines, is indicative of a subdural hematoma.

questions.text: What is the "ANMOL" Program for auxiliary nurse midwives?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet-based software

 

Explanation:

 

"ANMOL" is an abbreviation that stands for "ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife) ONline." It is a tablet-based software or online monitoring tool (for RCH portal) that is specifically designed for use by auxiliary nurse midwives (ANMs).

 

The ANMOL program allows ANMs to register and track high-risk pregnancies, monitor children with low birth weight, and manage data related to their work at the sub-center level. It serves as a comprehensive monitoring and data management tool for ANMs, enabling them to efficiently carry out their responsibilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "ANMOL" program is a tablet-based software or online monitoring tool specifically designed for auxiliary nurse midwives (ANMs) to register and track high-risk pregnancies, monitor children with low birth weight, and manage data at the sub-center level.

questions.text: In POP Q staging, the reference point taken is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system is a standardized method for assessing and quantifying the severity of pelvic organ prolapse. The reference point in POP-Q staging is the hymen. All measurements in the POP-Q system are taken relative to the hymen, which serves as a fixed anatomical landmark.

 

 

The POP-Q system involves six specific points and three measurements:

 

 

Points:

 

Aa: A point on the anterior vaginal wall, 3 cm proximal to the hymen.

 

Ba: The most distal position of any part of the anterior vaginal wall.

 

C: The cervix or the vaginal cuff after hysterectomy.

 

Ap: A point on the posterior vaginal wall, 3 cm proximal to the hymen.

 

Bp: The most distal position of any part of the posterior vaginal wall.

 

D: The posterior fornix or the deepest part of the vaginal vault.

 

Measurements:

 

GH (Genital Hiatus): Distance from the external urethral meatus to the posterior hymen.

 

PB (Perineal Body): Distance from the posterior hymen to the mid-anal opening.

 

TVL (Total Vaginal Length): Distance from the hymen to the posterior fornix or vaginal apex.

 

Other 3 Options: Not used as a reference point in POP-Q staging.

 

Educational objective:

 

In the POP-Q system, the hymen is used as the reference point for all measurements and staging of pelvic organ prolapse.

questions.text: The patient is having the following hand movements. Which of the following conditions is responsible?  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercarbia

 

Explanation

 

The hand movements shown in the image are characteristic of asterixis or flapping tremors, which is a form of negative myoclonus.

 

Asterixis is most commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy but can also be seen in other conditions such as hypercarbia (CO2 narcosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyrotoxicosis: This condition typically presents with fine tremors rather than the flapping tremors seen in asterixis.

 

Option C. Hemiballismus: This condition involves violent, involuntary movements of one side of the body, not the flapping tremors associated with asterixis.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: While hypoxia can cause various neurological symptoms, it is not specifically associated with asterixis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asterixis, or flapping tremors, is a form of negative myoclonus often associated with hepatic encephalopathy and hypercarbia (CO2 narcosis). Recognizing these characteristic hand movements can help identify underlying conditions such as hypercarbia. ​

questions.text: A patient had a drop in Systolic Blood Pressure of 15 mm Hg during inspiration. Which of the following is NOT associated with it? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy

 

Explanation

 

A drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration is termed pulsus paradoxus. This phenomenon is seen in several conditions, including cardiac tamponade, status asthmaticus, and tension pneumothorax.

 

Cardiac tamponade is a classic cause of pulsus paradoxus due to the restriction of ventricular filling during inspiration. Status asthmaticus and tension pneumothorax also cause significant intrathoracic pressure changes, leading to a similar hemodynamic effect.

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, on the other hand, is not associated with pulsus paradoxus. Instead, HCM can be associated with pulsus bisferiens, a double-peaked pulse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac Tamponade: This is a well-known cause of pulsus paradoxus.

 

Option B. Status Asthmaticus: This can cause pulsus paradoxus due to severe obstruction and changes in intrathoracic pressure.

 

Option D. Tension Pneumothorax: This condition can also lead to pulsus paradoxus due to significant intrathoracic pressure changes.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulsus paradoxus, a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration, is seen in conditions like cardiac tamponade, status asthmaticus, and tension pneumothorax. It is not associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which can present with pulsus bisferiens instead.

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive male patient was taking hydrochlorothiazide. He developed fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drug can be added to prevent loss of potassium in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amiloride

 

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic, making it a suitable choice to add to the patient's regimen to prevent further potassium loss. This is particularly important in the context of the patient's fatigue and hypokalemia, likely side effects of hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic known to cause potassium loss. The other options listed would not be appropriate for addressing hypokalemia in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that actually increases the excretion of potassium, which would exacerbate hypokalemia rather than prevent it.

 

Option B. Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor diuretic. It is not typically used for preventing potassium loss and can also lead to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Adenosine is primarily used as an antiarrhythmic agent for certain types of supraventricular tachycardias and is not used for managing electrolyte imbalances like hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic, works in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct of the nephron by inhibiting sodium channels. This action reduces potassium excretion, helping to prevent hypokalemia.

choices.text: Failure of closure of neural tube at week 3 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of neural tube at week 4 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of cranial neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of caudal neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life

questions.text: The congenital anomaly observed in the image results from which of the following embryological defects? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure of closure of cranial neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a condition known as anencephaly, a severe neural tube defect characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp. This condition arises due to the failure of the cranial (anterior) neuropore to close during embryonic development.

 

  1. Neural Tube Development: The neural tube forms from the neural plate, which folds to create the neural groove and eventually closes to form the neural tube. This process begins around the third week of intrauterine life and continues into the fourth week.
  2. Closure of Neuropores: The neural tube has two openings, the cranial (anterior) and caudal (posterior) neuropores. The cranial neuropore normally closes by the 25th day of gestation (around the 4th week), while the caudal neuropore closes by the 28th day (also around the 4th week).
  3. Anencephaly: When the cranial neuropore fails to close, the result is anencephaly. This defect prevents the proper formation of the forebrain, resulting in the absence of major portions of the brain and skull.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Failure of closure of neural tube at week 3 intra-uterine life: This is incorrect because the neural tube begins to close around the third week, but the critical closure of the cranial neuropore occurs in the fourth week.

 

Option B. Failure of closure of neural tube at week 4 intra-uterine life: This is partially correct but not specific. The specific failure involved in anencephaly is the closure of the cranial neuropore, not just any part of the neural tube.

 

Option D. Failure of closure of caudal neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life: This is incorrect as it refers to the closure of the caudal neuropore, which would lead to defects like spina bifida, not anencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly results from the failure of the cranial (anterior) neuropore to close by the 25th day of gestation, which occurs around the 4th week of intrauterine life.

questions.text: A patient presents with a combination of Casal's necklace, cheilosis, and stomatitis. Upon further examination, it is discovered that the individual has a diet deficient in a specific nutrient. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin deficiency

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms—Casal's necklace, cheilosis, and stomatitis—are characteristic of niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. Niacin deficiency leads to a condition known as pellagra, which is classically described by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace, a photosensitive dermatitis appearing as a necklace-like distribution around the neck, is a hallmark of pellagra.

 

  • Casal's Necklace: A distinctive hyperpigmented rash in a necklace-like distribution due to sun exposure.

 

 

  • Cheilosis: Cracking and inflammation at the corners of the mouth, common in various B vitamin deficiencies.

 

 

  • Stomatitis: Inflammation of the mucous membrane of the mouth, also associated with B vitamin deficiencies.

 

Niacin can be synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan, making it an atypical vitamin. A deficiency in dietary tryptophan can also lead to niacin deficiency.

 

  

           Images  - photosensitive dermatitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically presents with megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, not the specific skin findings described here.

 

Option B. Riboflavin deficiency: Can cause cheilosis and stomatitis, but not Casal's necklace.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Presents with symptoms of scurvy, such as bleeding gums and perifollicular hemorrhages, not the symptoms described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin deficiency (pellagra) presents with characteristic symptoms including Casal's necklace, cheilosis, and stomatitis. Treatment involves supplementation with niacin (vitamin B3).

 

Note – Glossitis and cheilosis – occurs in B2, B3 and B6 deficiencies 60 mg of Tryptophan is used to synthesize 1 mg of Niacin

questions.text: Central venules have which type of cells in the center? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) RBCs


The central venules are part of the vascular system where blood flow dynamics play a crucial role in cell distribution. The concept of parabolic flow describes how blood components are distributed within the vessel. In this flow pattern, the velocity of the blood is highest at the center of the vessel and decreases towards the periphery.

 

  • RBCs (Red Blood Cells): Due to their biconcave shape and flexibility, RBCs tend to move towards the center of the vessel where the flow velocity is highest. This central position allows them to travel efficiently through the bloodstream without being impeded by the endothelial cells lining the vessel walls.
  • WBCs (White Blood Cells): These cells, which include lymphocytes, neutrophils, and macrophages, are larger and less flexible compared to RBCs. As a result, they are often found closer to the vessel walls where the flow velocity is lower. This positioning is also influenced by the process of margination, where WBCs move towards and interact with the endothelial cells, particularly during inflammation.
  • Platelets: Although smaller than RBCs, platelets have an irregular shape and tend to get trapped in the spaces between endothelial cells, preventing them from flowing freely in the center of the vessel.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocytes and B. Neutrophils:  Types of WBC, tend to be located near the vessel walls due to their larger size and the process of margination.

 

Option C. Macrophages: These are larger WBCs involved in immune responses and are usually found in the periphery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In central venules, RBCs are found in the center due to their shape, flexibility, and the dynamics of parabolic flow.

questions.text: A portion of animal’s intestine is fixed in the Dales chamber. After infusing a drug, changes are seen in intestinal contractility as depicted in the graph. Which of the following agent resembles the effect? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenaline

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows a decrease in the amplitude of intestinal contractions following the infusion of a drug. This decrease in contractility is indicative of the sympathetic nervous system's effect on the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Adrenaline, a sympathetic agent, reduces GI motility and contractility, prioritizing the body's resources for a "fight or flight" response rather than digestion.

 

  • Adrenaline (epinephrine) activates the sympathetic nervous system. During stress, adrenaline reduces GI motility by decreasing the contractility of intestinal muscles, which is evident from the decreased amplitude in the graph.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine: Acetylcholine is associated with the parasympathetic nervous system, which enhances GI motility and contractility. Therefore, acetylcholine would increase, not decrease, the amplitude of intestinal contractions.

 

Option C. BaCl₂ (Barium Chloride): Barium chloride increases the contractility of smooth muscles, often used in medical imaging to enhance the visibility of the GI tract. The increased contractility would result in an increased amplitude of contractions.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Serotonin increases GI motility and contractility. It plays a significant role in peristalsis by contracting the proximal part of the intestine. Thus, it would also increase the amplitude of contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenaline reduces the contractility of intestinal muscles by activating the sympathetic nervous system, resulting in decreased GI motility.

questions.text: Heme is derived from which of the following amino acids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine

 

Explanation:

 

Heme is derived from glycine, which is one of the simplest amino acids. Despite its simplicity, glycine is a precursor to several important biological compounds. In the heme biosynthesis pathway, glycine combines with succinyl-CoA to form δ-aminolevulinic acid, which is the first step in the synthesis of heme. Heme is a critical component of hemoglobin, myoglobin, and various cytochromes, playing a vital role in oxygen transport and cellular respiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved in various metabolic processes, including the synthesis of nucleotides and amino sugars, but it does not contribute directly to heme biosynthesis.

 

Option C. Glutamate: Glutamate is a key neurotransmitter and is involved in the synthesis of glutathione and other amino acids but not directly in heme formation.

 

Option D. Valine: Valine is a branched-chain amino acid important in protein synthesis and energy metabolism but not in the biosynthesis of heme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Products of amino acids -

  • Tryptophan – Niacin, serotonin, melatonin
  • Tyrosine - Melanin, catecholamine, thyroxin
  • Histidine – Histamine, Carnosine, Anserine
  • Glycine- Creatine, Glutathione, Haem, Porphyrin, Glyoxylate, Choline, Betaine, serine, Sarcosine

Glutathione – tripeptide →  Glutamate, Cysteine & Glycine

Creatine- made from 3 AA → Arginine, Methionine & Glycine

  • Serine → Glycine, Selenocysteine, Phosphatidyl serine, Sphingosine (Serine + Palmitoyl CoA)
  • Arginine - NO, Creatine, Urea & Ornithine

questions.text: A woman presented with unilateral pulsatile headache, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea, which is exaggerated on skipping her meals. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Migraine

 

Explanation

 

The patient presents with a unilateral, pulsatile headache accompanied by photophobia (sensitivity to light), phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), and nausea. These are classic features of a migraine.

 

Additionally, the headache is exacerbated by skipping meals, a known trigger for migraines. Other common triggers include stress, certain foods, and hormonal changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tension headache: This type of headache is usually bilateral, non-pulsatile, and described as a band-like tightness around the head. It does not typically present with photophobia, phonophobia, or nausea.

 

Option C. Cluster headache: Cluster headaches are characterized by severe, unilateral pain around the eye, often accompanied by autonomic symptoms such as tearing, nasal congestion, and redness of the eye. They do not typically involve photophobia, phonophobia, or nausea.

 

Option D. Malingering: This refers to the intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms, motivated by external incentives such as avoiding work or obtaining drugs. There is no indication in the question to suggest malingering.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Migraine is characterized by unilateral, pulsatile headaches accompanied by photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea, and can be triggered by factors such as skipping meals, stress, and certain foods. Recognizing these features is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

choices.text: No dose adjustment is required
Add tenofovir 150 mg in the morning
Add lamivudine 300 mg in the morning
Add dolutegravir 50 mg in the morning

questions.text: A patient with history of HIV was started on anti-retroviral therapy consisting of lamivudine 300 mg, tenofovir 150 mg and dolutegravir 50 mg once daily at night. Few weeks later, he developed tuberculosis and was started on anti-tubercular drugs. Which of the following dose adjustment may be required in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add dolutegravir 50 mg in the morning

 

Adjustment of ARV regimen with concomitant ATT:

 

  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + 1NNRTI (EFV)–based regimen has to be given 2HRZE + 4HRE–based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued without any modification.
  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + DTG–based regimen has to be given Rifampicin-based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued. However, since co-administered rifampicin reduces bioavailability of DTG, which can be overcome by an additional tablet of DTG 50 mg (at an interval of 12 hours with the regular dose of DTG) till the completion of ATT. Once the ATT is completed, additional tablet of DTG 50 mg should be stopped 2 weeks after stoppage of Rifampicin-containing treatment regimen.
  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + PI–based regimen develops TB, ART regimen has to be modified if 2HREZ + 4HRE–based ATT is co-administered.
    • If the patient has not taken DTG earlier, patient is shifted to 2 NRTIs + DLG-based regimen with twice daily DTG as discussed in last section
    • If DLG cannot be given due to any reason and boosted PIs need to continued, then rifampicin should be replaced by rifabutin

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients on a dolutegravir-based regimen who start rifampicin-based anti-tubercular therapy, an additional dose of dolutegravir 50 mg should be taken in the morning (12 hours apart from the regular dose) to maintain effective drug levels and manage HIV effectively.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a chronic productive cough and progressive difficulty in breathing. On examination, his FEV1% is significantly reduced. Based on this finding, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) COPD

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by chronic airflow limitation that is not fully reversible. It is commonly associated with a history of smoking and is diagnosed based on symptoms such as chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and a significant reduction in FEV1%. The airflow obstruction in COPD is due to a combination of airway disease (chronic bronchitis) and parenchymal destruction (emphysema), leading to difficulty in exhaling air from the lungs.

 

In this case, the patient presents with a chronic productive cough and progressive difficulty in breathing, which are hallmark symptoms of COPD. The significant reduction in FEV1% further supports the diagnosis of an obstructive lung disease, where the primary issue is the narrowing of the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pulmonary Fibrosis - Pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease characterized by the stiffening and scarring of lung tissue, which makes it difficult for the lungs to expand. FEV1% is typically preserved or increased in restrictive lung diseases, not significantly reduced as seen in obstructive lung diseases like COPD.

 

Option C. Asthma - While asthma is also an obstructive lung disease, it is usually characterized by reversible airway obstruction and presents with intermittent episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and dry cough. Chronic productive cough is less common in asthma compared to COPD.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis - Sarcoidosis is a multi-system inflammatory disease that primarily affects the lungs but presents with a variety of other systemic symptoms. It is more commonly associated with a restrictive pattern on lung function tests and does not typically present with a chronic productive cough or a significantly reduced FEV1% as seen in COPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a chronic productive cough, progressive difficulty in breathing, and a significant reduction in FEV1%. It is a common cause of chronic obstructive pulmonary symptoms in older adults, particularly those with a history of smoking.

questions.text: Radioactive tracer used in PET scans:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) F18-Deoxyglucose

 

Explanation

 

The most commonly used radioactive tracer in PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scans is F18-deoxyglucose (FDG). FDG is a glucose analog that gets taken up by metabolically active cells, including cancer cells, making it very useful for identifying areas of high metabolic activity such as tumors and sites of inflammation.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Tc99m (Technetium-99m): Used in certain SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography) scans, not PET scans. It is used for a variety of diagnostic imaging purposes, including cardiac and skeletal imaging.

 

Option C. I131 (Iodine-131): Used primarily for radioactive iodine ablation therapy in thyroid cancer and hyperthyroidism, not for PET scans.

 

Option D. Co60 (Cobalt-60): Used in external beam radiotherapy for cancer treatment, not for PET scans.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

F18-deoxyglucose (FDG) is the primary radioactive tracer used in PET scans for detecting areas of high metabolic activity, such as tumors and inflammatory sites.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with swelling in the right femur for 6 months. He complaints of severe pain in the thigh which dramatically improves with intake of aspirin. The biopsy image from the lesion is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • This benign bone tumor is smaller in size, usually < 2 cm, and is commonly located in the cortex of long bones.
  • Femoral diaphysis is the most common location.
  • It is characterized histologically by a nidus surrounded by sclerotic bone.
  • A unique feature is that the pain worsens at night and gets a dramatic relief with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Osteosarcoma: A malignant tumor characterized by the direct formation of bone or osteoid tissue by tumor cells. It often appears in the metaphysis of long bones such as the femur, tibia, and humerus, primarily affecting children and young adults. Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis. May respond to NSAIDs like aspirin, but the response is often transient. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.

 

 

Option. C. Osteochondroma: A common benign bone growth that consists of a cartilage-capped bony projection or outgrowth on the surface of bones (exostosis). It typically arises from the metaphysis near the growth plate of long bones, particularly around the knee and shoulder. Usually asymptomatic, but may cause pain if the tumor becomes large or if it irritates nearby structures. Pathology and histology of an osteochondroma reveal a cap of benign hyaline cartilage resembling a disorganized growth plate, covered peripherally by perichondrium.

 

 

Option. D. Ewing's Sarcoma: A highly aggressive, malignant bone tumor that affects mostly children and adolescents. It can occur in any bone but is most often found in long bones and the pelvic region. Histologically, it features small, round, blue cells. Typically presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass. May respond to NSAIDs, but the response is often transient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The distinctive clinical presentation of relief with aspirin strongly points to an osteoid osteoma, especially when correlated with the biopsy findings suggestive of this benign condition.

questions.text: Patient develops severe migratory joint pain after an attack of acute rheumatic fever. How will you manage this patient? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Aspirin. Acute rheumatic fever commonly presents with migratory polyarthritis, which is characterized by severe joint pain that moves from one joint to another.

 

The treatment of choice for this arthritis is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), with aspirin being the most effective and commonly used. Aspirin helps to reduce inflammation and pain associated with the arthritis of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: This is a diuretic and is not used for the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever. It may be used in cases of heart failure associated with rheumatic carditis.

 

Option B. Digoxin: This is a cardiac glycoside used in heart failure and atrial fibrillation. It is not used for managing arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication and has no role in the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for severe migratory joint pain (arthritis) in acute rheumatic fever is the use of NSAIDs, with aspirin being the drug of choice due to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation and pain.

questions.text: While administering epidural anesthesia, which structure is not punctured before injecting the drug?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arachnoid mater

 

Explanation:

 

During epidural anesthesia, the anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which lies outside the dura mater. The needle passes through several layers of tissue but does not puncture the dura mater, arachnoid mater, or enter the subarachnoid space.

The layers that are punctured during epidural anesthesia, in order, are:

 

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia
  3. Supraspinous ligament
  4. Interspinous ligament
  5. Ligamentum flavum

 

After passing through the ligamentum flavum, the needle enters the epidural space, where the anesthetic agent is deposited.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraspinous ligament : This ligament is punctured during epidural anesthesia.

 

Option B. Interspinous ligament : This ligament is also punctured during the procedure.

 

Option C. Ligamentum flavum : The needle passes through the ligamentum flavum to reach the epidural space.

 

Note: that this procedure differs from a lumbar puncture, where the needle passes through the dura mater, arachnoid mater, and enters the subarachnoid space (represented by the mnemonic "DAS": Dura mater, Arachnoid mater, Subarachnoid space).

 

Educational Objective:

 

During epidural anesthesia, the arachnoid mater is not punctured. The anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which lies outside the dura mater, after passing through the skin, superficial fascia, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with pruritic eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of hands. What is the likely nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3

 

Explanation

 

Chronic alcoholics are prone to multiple nutrient deficiencies due to malnourishment and malnutrition. The given history is compatible with a disease called Pellagra, which is due to Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is characterized by the "3 D's": Diarrhea, Dermatitis, and Dementia, and it can also lead to death, sometimes referred to as the "4 D's."

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Vitamin B1: Causes Wernicke's encephalopathy, peripheral neuropathy, and heart failure but does not match the described skin condition.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Associated with rickets and osteomalacia, not pruritic eczematous rash.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Causes scurvy with gum bleeding and other symptoms, not the described dermatitis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Pellagra, characterized by the "3 D's" (Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia), is caused by Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency and is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics.

questions.text: During the forensic examination of dry semen from undergarment of a rape victim. What specific test is employed to ascertain the presence of sperm? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

When examining dry semen stains found on the undergarment of a rape victim, the Barberio test is the specific test employed to ascertain the presence of sperm. Although the Barberio test is not considered the most reliable test for semen, it can still yield positive results in dry stains, making it the most suitable choice among the given options for this particular scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Acid phosphatase test: The acid phosphatase test is indeed a good test for detecting semen, but it is not the best choice for dry stains. The activity of acid phosphatase decreases rapidly with time, making it less effective in detecting the presence of sperm in older, dry semen stains.

 

Option. C. Papanicolaou smear: The Papanicolaou (Pap) smear is not a test used for detecting semen. It is a cytological test used primarily for screening cervical cancer and other abnormalities in the female reproductive system.

 

Option. D. Florence test: The Florence test is another test used for detecting semen, but it is not mentioned as the most appropriate test for dry semen stains in the given scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining dry semen stains, such as those found on the undergarment of a rape victim, the Barberio test is the specific test employed to ascertain the presence of sperm, as it can yield positive results even in dry stains.

questions.text: Which among the following is not true according to case-control study? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cause to effect design

 

Explanation:

 

A case-control study is a retrospective study that looks backward in time, starting with the outcome (disease) and then investigating potential exposures or risk factors that may have contributed to the disease. It is an effect-to-cause study design. Case-control studies are particularly useful for studying rare diseases, as they allow researchers to identify a sufficient number of cases without requiring a large cohort.

 

Due to the retrospective nature of the study, incidence rates cannot be calculated directly. Instead, the strength of the association between exposure and outcome is measured using the odds ratio, which is calculated using the formula –

 

2 × 2 table

 

 

Odds Ratio (Cross Product Ratio) = ad/bc

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. "Effect to cause design" is a true statement about case-control studies, as they start with the disease (effect) and work backwards to identify potential causes (exposures).

 

Option B. "Used to study Rare Disease" is also a true statement. Case-control studies are well-suited for investigating rare diseases because they allow researchers to identify a sufficient number of cases without requiring a large cohort, which would be impractical and costly.

 

Option C. "Odds ratio can be calculated" is correct. In case-control studies, the incidence rate cannot be directly calculated, so the strength of the association between exposure and outcome is measured using the odds ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case-control studies are retrospective, effect-to-cause study designs that are particularly useful for investigating rare diseases and calculating odds ratios to measure the strength of association between exposures and outcomes.

choices.text: Identify the source of bleeding
Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding in the external auditory canal following trauma. The next step in management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keep the ear dry and give oral medications

 

Given the situation of trauma and the presence of blood in the external auditory canal, the most appropriate next step is to keep the ear dry to avoid any additional complications and to provide oral medications for pain, possible infection, and to reduce inflammation.

 

Keeping the ear dry and giving oral medications is a standard approach for managing a bloody discharge from the ear following trauma. This usually includes avoiding water in the ear to prevent infection and prescribing oral antibiotics if there is a suspicion of bacterial infection. Pain relief medication may also be provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirating the clot is generally not the first step in management unless there's a need for immediate assessment of the underlying structures, and if there's concern for ongoing bleeding that may be occluding the canal and impeding examination.

 

Option B. Identifying the source of bleeding is important, especially if the bleeding is significant or ongoing. However, this would typically follow initial conservative management unless the bleeding is profuse.

 

Option D. Syringing (ear irrigation) is contraindicated in the presence of a bloody discharge following trauma, as it can exacerbate the bleeding and increase the risk of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After trauma to the external auditory canal with bloody discharge, it is important to keep the ear dry and initiate treatment with oral medications, such as analgesics and possibly antibiotics, to manage pain, prevent infection, and reduce inflammation.

questions.text: Casal's necklace is seen with which vitamin deficiency?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

Explanation:

 

 

Casal's necklace is a characteristic dermatitis seen in niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to a condition called pellagra. Niacin can be synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan, with 60 mg of tryptophan converting to 1 mg of niacin daily. Tryptophan deficiency is common in maize-based diets, but the actual reason for pellagra in maize eaters is not tryptophan deficiency itself, but rather an excess of leucine, which prevents the conversion of tryptophan to niacin. Leucine is therefore known as the pellagrogenic amino acid of India.

 

Pellagra is characterized by the "4 D's": diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and death. The dermatitis associated with pellagra often occurs around the neck or on the extremities of the body, particularly on areas of skin that are directly exposed to sunlight. When this dermatitis occurs around the neck, it may lead to the formation of Casal's necklace.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency is not associated with Casal's necklace. Instead, it can lead to beriberi in polished rice eaters and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcoholics.

 

Option C. Vitamin C deficiency is not related to Casal's necklace. It can cause scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency is not linked to Casal's necklace. It can cause peripheral neuropathy, megaloblastic anemia, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, and pernicious anemia, especially in strict vegetarians.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal's necklace is a characteristic dermatitis seen around the neck in niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to a condition called pellagra.

questions.text: A patient came with a history of mastectomy, 10 years ago. She had edema and bluish discolouration of the skin over the right upper limb. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lymphangiosarcoma

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario describes a patient with a history of mastectomy 10 years ago who presents with edema and bluish discoloration of the skin over the right upper limb. This clinical presentation is suggestive of lymphangiosarcoma, a rare malignant transformation of lymphatic vessels that can occur as a complication of mastectomy. The impaired lymphatic drainage following mastectomy leads to chronic lymphedema, which predisposes the affected limb to develop lymphangiosarcoma, also known as Stewart-Treves syndrome.

 

 

Unfortunately, lymphangiosarcoma carries a poor prognosis, with many patients surviving only 18 to 24 months after diagnosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Angioedema is a type of edema caused by increased vascular permeability, usually due to an allergic reaction or hereditary factors. It is not typically associated with a history of mastectomy.

 

Option B. Venous thrombosis can cause edema and skin discoloration but is not specifically linked to a history of mastectomy and would not explain the long interval (10 years) between the surgery and the onset of symptoms.

 

Option C. Angiosarcoma is a malignant tumor arising from blood vessels.

 

Educational objective:

 

Lymphangiosarcoma (Stewart-Treves syndrome) is a rare but serious complication of mastectomy, characterized by edema and skin discoloration of the affected limb due to malignant transformation of lymphatic vessels in the setting of chronic lymphedema. It carries a poor prognosis.

questions.text: Identify the image: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Omphalocele

 

The image provided likely shows a neonate with a congenital defect characterized by the intestines and other abdominal organs extending outside of the abdominal cavity but contained within a sac composed of peritoneum and amnion. 

 

This is a congenital defect in the abdominal wall where the intestines, liver, and occasionally other organs remain outside of the abdomen in a sac because of a failure in the normal return of intestines and other contents back to the abdominal cavity during development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urachal cyst: This is a remnant of the embryonic connection between the bladder and the umbilical cord, which usually closes before birth. A cyst can form if this connection does not close properly. It typically does not involve protrusion of abdominal contents.

 

Option C. Omphalocele with cyst: This option isn't a standard term in medical diagnosis. An omphalocele does not typically have a cyst, but rather a sac that is formed from the peritoneum and amnion, containing the herniated organs.

 

Option D. Umbilical adenoma: This is not a recognized condition related to abdominal wall defects in neonates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Omphalocele is a birth defect characterized by an abdominal wall defect with herniation of abdominal contents into an overlying sac due to a failure of normal return of contents during embryonic development.

questions.text: Kinesin, dynein and myosin proteins are an example of? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Transport protein


Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are all examples of molecular motor proteins that play critical roles in cellular transport mechanisms.

 

  • Kinesin: This motor protein moves along microtubules in cells, transporting various cellular cargoes, such as organelles, vesicles, and proteins, from the center of the cell (soma) towards the periphery (axon terminal) in an anterograde direction.
  • Dynein: This motor protein also moves along microtubules but in the opposite direction, transporting cargo from the periphery back to the center of the cell in a retrograde direction.
  • Myosin: This motor protein interacts with actin filaments and is involved in a variety of cellular movements, including muscle contraction and intracellular cargo transport.

 

These proteins are not involved in cell membrane structure, adhesion of cell organelles, or forming intercellular junctions. Their primary function is to facilitate intracellular transport, making them key components of cellular logistics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell membrane protein: These are proteins that are part of or interact with the cell membrane, such as receptors and ion channels.

 

Option C. Cell organelle adherent protein: These proteins help maintain the structure and position of organelles within the cell. Ex: catenin and cadherin

 

Option D. Intercellular junctional protein: These are proteins that form connections between cells, such as connexins in gap junctions or occludins in tight junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kinesin, dynein, and myosin are transport proteins essential for intracellular cargo movement along cytoskeletal filaments.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient after receiving haloperidol developed torticollis and dystonia. What will be the best drug in this situation? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give benzhexol (anticholinergic)

 

Explanation

 

The patient has developed extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), which are side effects commonly associated with antipsychotic medications like haloperidol. EPS can include dystonia (muscle contractions causing twisting and repetitive movements or abnormal postures) and torticollis (a type of dystonia involving the neck muscles).

 

Benzhexol, also known as trihexyphenidyl, is an anticholinergic drug that is effective in treating EPS, including acute dystonic reactions. Anticholinergics help to balance the neurotransmitters in the brain, thereby reducing the symptoms of EPS.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Increase haloperidol dose: This would likely worsen the EPS.

 

Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine: While clozapine has a lower risk of EPS, this is not an immediate treatment for the acute dystonia.

 

Option D. Change haloperidol to fluphenazine: Fluphenazine, like haloperidol, is a potent dopamine receptor blocker and would likely exacerbate the EPS.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

The immediate treatment for drug-induced dystonia is the administration of anticholinergic drugs like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl).

questions.text: A high dose of folic acid should be given pre-conceptionally in women with? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Poorly controlled diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

A high dose of folic acid is recommended pre-conceptionally for women who are at a higher risk of neural tube defects. This includes women with poorly controlled diabetes, which is associated with an increased risk of congenital abnormalities, including neural tube defects. A high dose of folic acid (4 to 5 mg daily) should be started at least three months before conception to reduce this risk and to be given till 16 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Previous h/o preeclampsia: The preventive strategy for women with a history of preeclampsia includes the use of low-dose aspirin (Ecosprin), not high-dose folic acid.

 

Option B. Previous preterm delivery: Management includes progesterone supplementation or considering a cervical cerclage in cases of cervical insufficiency, rather than high-dose folic acid.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: While folic acid is important in hemoglobinopathies, the primary concern in sickle cell anemia is maintaining adequate folic acid levels due to increased hemolysis, but it is not specifically indicated at high doses for pre-conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Women with poorly controlled diabetes, epileptics, should receive a high dose of folic acid pre-conceptionally to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

questions.text: Most common cause of blindness in children is:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A deficiency

 

The correct answer is Vitamin A Deficiency. It remains the leading cause of preventable blindness in children due to its severe impact on the cornea and overall eye health when left untreated.

 

Vitamin A deficiency is a major cause of preventable blindness in children, particularly in developing countries. It can lead to xerophthalmia, a condition that can progress to night blindness and more severe damage to the cornea, potentially resulting in complete blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glaucoma: Childhood glaucoma is rare compared to other causes of visual impairment in children. When it does occur, it can lead to blindness if not treated. However, it is not the most common cause of blindness in children globally.

 

Option C. Cataract: Cataracts in children can be congenital or develop in childhood, leading to blindness if not treated. Pediatric cataract is a significant cause of visual impairment in children, but it is not as common as vitamin A deficiency in causing blindness.

 

Option D. Refractive Error: Refractive errors, such as myopia (nearsightedness), hyperopia (farsightedness), and astigmatism, are common in children. If left uncorrected, they can significantly impair vision but are not typically considered a direct cause of blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is the most common cause of preventable blindness in children in developing countries.

questions.text: A patient of Schizophrenia was started on antipsychotic drug haloperidol. Few hours later, he presented with torticollis and muscular dystonia. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Give benztropine

 

When a patient on haloperidol develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) like torticollis and muscular dystonia, the next best step is typically to administer an anticholinergic medication like benzhexol or benztropine to alleviate these side effects. Increasing the dose of haloperidol would likely worsen the EPS, while changing to clozapine is an option for patients with severe EPS or a history of non-response to other treatments. Fluphenazine is unlikely to be significantly different from haloperidol in causing EPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose of haloperidol: Increasing the dose of haloperidol is not the appropriate response when a patient develops extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) such as torticollis and muscular dystonia. It can exacerbate these side effects.

 

Option B. Change haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is less likely to cause EPS compared to typical antipsychotics like haloperidol. Switching to clozapine can be a reasonable option to manage EPS.

 

Option C. Give fluphenzine instead of haloperidol: Fluphenazine is another typical antipsychotic and is not expected to be significantly different from haloperidol in terms of causing EPS. Switching to fluphenazine may not effectively address the EPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to manage extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) caused by antipsychotic medications. It can be an appropriate choice to alleviate the torticollis and muscular dystonia.
